LEAD: A Government hearing officer has upheld charges that five title insurance companies violated Federal antitrust laws by fixing prices for title searches and examinations in two states.


POLL GAUGES WHITE PROTESTANTS' VIEWS OF JEWS
LEAD: White Protestants who hold conservative religious views do not consciously use their convictions to justify anti-Semitic views of Jews, according to the results of a poll commissioned by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith that was released yesterday.


Shift at General Instrument
LEAD: The General Instrument Corporation has named George E. Safiol senior executive vice president and chief operating officer and a board member.


BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JANUARY 8, 1987
LEAD: Markets


U.S. SAYS N.S.C. WILL FACE CHANGES
LEAD: The National Security Council will undergo major changes under Frank C. Carlucci, the new national security adviser, including a virtual prohibition against covert operations, a senior White House official said today.


Talking Deals; Boeing's Coup In Britain
LEAD: THE Boeing Company is one of corporate America's few world-beating exporters.
And last month the aerospace giant demonstrated its prowess in foreign markets again by winning a fiercely contested contract to supply the British Government with early-warning aircraft.


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
Gemcraft Inc., Houston, a home-building concern, announced that John C. Poss had joined the company in the new position of senior vice president of corporate development.
It also appointed as directors Judy Neal Stubbs, active in civic affairs in Dallas, and Clarence C. Comer, president of Southdown Inc.


THREATS FORCE SAN JUAN EVACUATIONS
LEAD: A series of bomb threats today caused the evacuation of more than 200 people in and around San Juan, including at least nine who had survived the burning of the Dupont Plaza Hotel a week ago.


ST. JOHN'S LOSES 2D STRAIGHT
LEAD: Three days after being thrashed by Villanova, St.
John's was taken apart by Georgetown in the second half tonight, and lost, 60-46, at the Capital Centre.


Representation Sought By Air Traffic Workers
LEAD: A fledgling union is seeking recognition as bargaining agent for workers who have been without a union since President Reagan dismissed 11,400 air traffic controllers who went on strike in 1981.


CALIFORNIA NEWSPAPER IS VICTORIOUS OVER SECT
LEAD: After eight years of legal battles, the owners of a weekly newspaper in California, The Point Reyes Light, appear to have won out against Synanon, the religious and drug rehabilitation organization.


FIGHTING EXPANDS IN NORTH NICARAGUA
LEAD: Just as Lorenzo Herrera Blandon had expected, the war in northern Nicaragua has begun to intensify.


BONN AND PARIS STEP IN TO AID FRANC
LEAD: West Germany and France acted today to support the battered franc.


U.S. AIDES CONFER ON A LATIN PEACE
LEAD: Two senior United States officials met in Miami today with Costa Rica's Foreign Minister to discuss a new diplomatic initiative in Central America.


'Olympus' to Close
LEAD: ''Olympus on My Mind,'' a musical comedy with book and lyrics by Barry Harman and music by Grant Sturiale, will close after the evening performance on Saturday at the Lamb's Theater.
The play, directed by Mr.
Harman, will have run for 207 performances.


Atheism and Alcohol
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Motorists who use the major crossings of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority should prepare to pay more for the privilege.
There will be a public hearing on Monday, but what would be the fifth toll increase since 1980 on the Triborough, Bronx-Whitestone, Throgs Neck and Verrazano-Narrows Bridges and the Queens-Midtown and Brooklyn-Battery


Shultz Confirms Funds From Brunei Vanished
LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz confirmed today that a large sum of money, reported to be $10 million, from the Sultan of Brunei had disappeared.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: Because of incorrect information from the store, the Notes on Fashion column on the Style page Tuesday incorrectly described a sale at the Napoleon boutique in Trump Tower.

NO UNITY IN UNIFICATION SERIES
LEAD: Since it was formally announced nearly a year ago, Home Box Office's heavyweight unification series has had one after another of the sort of seriocomic vicissitudes that make boxing a delight to fans of chaos.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a brief article yesterday on the weekly television ratings gave an incorrect date for the last week in which ''The CBS Evening News'' led NBC's ''Nightly News.'' It was the week that ended Dec. 14.


GAF in Settlement
LEAD: The GAF Corporation said that it had reached a settlement with five insurance companies regarding the coverage for asbestos-related health claims filed against GAF.
Along with an earlier agreement with a sixth insurer, GAF has now reached settlements representing most of its asbestos-related insurance coverage, a spokesman said.

Shoreham Plan Said To Violate Zoning
LEAD: Continuing a challenge to the opening of the Shoreham nuclear power plant, the Hempstead Town Board has voted to warn the Long Island Lighting Company that to use a building here as an emergency evacuation center would violate zoning laws.


DETAILINGS: ALMOST THE REAL THING
LEAD: LAST year, when Albert Pensis bought a weekend house in Water Mill, L.I., he liked its location near the ocean and its manageable size, but not its 1950's ranch style.


Devils Still Need to Improve
LEAD: With only a single point in their last eight games, all the talk about the improvement the Devils have made at the midway mark of their fifth National Hockey League season in New Jersey adds up to only 6 points over last season.


IRAN SEEN EASING HOSTILITY TO U.S. IN SHIFT OF POLICY ON SUPERPOWERS
LEAD: As they silence their critics of the secret arms deals with the Reagan Administration, Iranian leaders are portraying the United States less as the ''Great Satan'' than a defeated political giant that has finally come to recognize the durability of the Iranian revolution.


WHITE HOUSE PUTTING BLAME ON HIS AIDES
LEAD: As the Iran-contra affair unfolds, the White House finds itself in the strange position of defending President Reagan with the argument that some of his most powerful aides were incompetent or deceitful.


GEORGE R. MAREK, 84, AUTHOR AND EX-RCA VICTOR OFFICIAL
LEAD: George R. Marek, an author and formerly an influential record executive for RCA Victor who was perhaps best known for his associations with such artists as Arturo Toscanini and Arthur Rubinstein, died yesterday at St.
Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center.
He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.


2 West Bank Schools Shut
LEAD: The director of Aroudeh College in Nablus closed the school today for a week after a series of anti-Israeli disturbances, a military spokesman said.
The Israeli Civil Administration, which runs the daily affairs of the West Bank, closed Al Najah University, also in Nablus, for a week beginning last Saturday.


Plant Explosion Kills One
LEAD: An explosion rocked a chemical plant here today, killing one employee, burning another and forcing the temporary evacuation of about 100 people from nearby homes as an unidentified gas was released, the authorities said.
The blast blew a 20-foot hole in the roof of the Savage Industries Inc. plant.


HERS
LEAD: In the spring of 1855, Lucy Stone and Henry Blackwell embarked on an unconventional marriage - a marriage of equals that they hoped could escape the traditional invisibility of wives and the pre-eminence of husbands.
Together, they composed a protest to be read aloud at their wedding, announcing: ''This act on our part implies no sanction of, nor promise of, voluntary obedience to such of the present laws of marriage as refuse to recognize the wife as an independent, rational being, while they confer upon the husband an injurious and unnatural superiority.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: Frank Gansz, coach of the Kansas City special teams, which carried the Chiefs into the playoffs for the first time in 15 years, resigned yesterday.
Gansz, 48, said that he had accomplished all he could as a special-teams coach and that he wanted to become an offensive coordinator as a stepping stone to being considered for a head coaching job.


VETERANS' GROUP ASSAILS U.S. ON FINANCING OF MEDICAL CARE
LEAD: Federal spending on medical care for veterans may be inadequate now, even before President Reagan's proposed cutbacks in service, a report by a veterans' organization said today.


Mario Hare, Gary Tortoise
LEAD: I used to think that Mario Cuomo was the most likely person to get the 1988 Democratic nomination.
Accordingly, I put in a few zaps in this space about his avoidance of foreign affairs issues, which, after all, are kind of central to a campaign for leader of the free world.


Browns Already Heroes
LEAD: A hint of how Browns-mad Cleveland has become was indicated by a phone call to the team's owner this morning.


SALE'S RUSH IS TRADITION AT HARRODS
LEAD: As thousands of buyers and lookers, pursued by dozens of cameramen and reporters, rushed through the doors of the great store when it opened at 9 A.M. today, it seemed that whatever else happens to the British economy, there will always be a Harrods.

Undated Notes Post a Record Decline in Europe
LEAD: The problems of a troubled $17 billion sector of the Eurobond market deepened today as prices dropped by record amounts on perpetual floating-rate notes.

LEAD: John Cardinal O'Connor had a private lunch with Pope John Paul II today after the New York Archbishop's churchman's visit to Jordan and Israel.


Student Loan Debt Financing
LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association is planning to sell in the United States debt market $100 million (New Zealand currency) of 16.85 percent notes due in 1990 at a price of par through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.


Israeli Printers on Strike
LEAD: Printers on all of Israel's nine daily newspapers began a 48-hour strike today to press their demand for more pay, according to the union secretary general, Meir Goldstein.
The strike, which will prevent the dailies from appearing Thursday or Friday, was called after publishers and printers failed to reach agreement on how much more printers should be paid as compensation for learning to operate new computerized print technologies.

For Jobs That Look Ahead, Not Back
LEAD: The essential flaw in the Reagan Administration's new 1988 budget is that it's too little a budget and too much a bargaining position.
To budget is to choose how to divide the pie; the ultimate choices will depend on give-and-take with Congress in the coming months.
The Reagan budget nonetheless contains imaginative initiatives.


STUDY OF 1,835 WITH AIDS VIRUS ASSOCIATES TRAITS WITH GETTING ILL
LEAD: A study of men infected with the AIDS virus has identified five traits associated with development of the fatal disorder.

Reoriented
LEAD: Maybe some burdens of leadership are common burdens, but surely not all.
Consider the opposite examples of the Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, and Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan.


Talbott Heads Field for Squash
LEAD: Mark Talbott of Barrington, R.I., has drawn the top-seeded position for the $15,000 Rolex Greenwich Open squash racquets championship, which opens today in Greenwich, Conn.


Withdrawal of Consent
LEAD: To the Editor:


U.S. Says It Won't Ban Use of Apple Pesticide
LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it had rejected a request by several states, private groups and others to ban the use of the pesticide daminozide on the ground that it might cause cancer.


FAMILY NEAR SCENE DESCRIBES ATTACK ON BLACKS IN QUEENS
LEAD: A family living close to the scene of the Dec. 20 attack in Howard Beach, Queens, has provided the first independent description of a gang of white youths beating a black man.


AIR FORCE TO SEEK FUNDS FOR BOMBER
LEAD: The Air Force intends to ask Congress for a total of $600 million in the fiscal years 1988 and 1989 to help pay for added costs faced by contractors building the B-1B strategic bomber, officials said today.


FRENCH-ITT VENTURE PREDICTS PROFIT OF $260 MILLION FOR THE YEAR
LEAD: The telecommunications company formed last month by France's state-owned Compagnie Generale d'Electricite and the ITT Corporation forecast today that it will earn at least $260 million this year on expected sales of $13 billion.


Reagan Orders More Raises
LEAD: President Reagan signed an executive order on New Year's Eve that will result in automatic pay raises for more than 6,000 high level Federal employees, a Government official said today.


HOW THE POLL WAS CONDUCTED
LEAD: This New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Jan. 4, 5 and 6 with 900 adults in all parts of New York City.
Interviews were conducted in either English or Spanish.


CONFLICT OVER SIGNAL IN TRAIN INQUIRY
LEAD: The engineer of a Conrail freight locomotive that collided with an Amtrak passenger train Sunday testified today under oath that he received a signal that led him to proceed into the path of the speeding liner.


Charges Dismissed In Friedman Scuffle
LEAD: A judge yesterday dismissed assault charges against Stanley M. Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic leader; his wife, Jacqueline, and a New York photographer that resulted from a scuffle last November.


Vatican Announces Pope's Latin Itinerary
LEAD: Pope John Paul II is scheduled to meet with the Chilean leader, Gen.
Augusto Pinochet, and then celebrate Palm Sunday in Argentina during his spring visit to South America, the Vatican announced today.


RIGHTS PLEA MADE IN CZECHOSLOVAKIA
LEAD: On the 10th anniversary of its founding, the Czechoslovak human rights group Charter 77 has issued a document that calls on citizens to assert their rights in schools, unions, newspapers, churches and other institutions.


ASSEMBLY'S NEW SPEAKER DISAGREES WITH CUOMO
LEAD: Two hours after he was elected Speaker of the Assembly today, Mel Miller of Brooklyn staked out an independent position by disagreeing with Governor Cuomo on several major issues.


COLD ENOUGH EVEN FOR A MUSCOVITE
LEAD: A solitary jogger moved through the brittle air, his beard encrusted with ice.
A canopy of snow-draped trees overhead formed a crystal cathedral that sparkled in the sun.


PENTAGON SAYS GREEK VESSEL FIRED AT U.S. COPTER
LEAD: The Navy has identified the ship from which a missile was fired at an American helicopter over the Persian Gulf on Monday as a Greek dry cargo vessel, Pentagon officials said today.


PRETORIA TERMS SCHOOL ROLLS 'ENCOURAGING' AFTER BOYCOTTS
LEAD: The authorities said today that enrollment in the nation's segregated black schools was ''very encouraging'' at the start of a new academic year after months of boycotts.


BABBITT OF ARIZONA FIRST DEMOCRAT TO FORM KEY PRESIDENTIAL GROUP
LEAD: Former Gov.
Bruce E. Babbitt of Arizona, who left office Monday after two terms, today became the first Democrat officially to open a 1988 Presidential campaign committee.


WEST SIDE ROAD PANEL DISAGREES ON ESPLANADE
LEAD: After months of public unity, some members of the state panel charged with recommending a replacement for the aborted Westway project will dissent when the panel issues its final report this morning, panel members said yesterday.


U.S. Expansion By Honda Seen
LEAD: Honda officials are expected to announce today that the auto maker will build a components plant next to its engine plant in western Ohio.
Three Ohio newspapers -


U.S. CITES AMTRAK FOR NOT CONDUCTING DRUG TESTS
LEAD: The Federal Railroad Administration today issued a civil citation against Amtrak because the railroad failed to conduct drug and alcohol tests on a conductor and two assistant conductors after last Sunday's collision near Baltimore.


COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: *
American Motors Corp., Southfield, Mich., said it is considering a new line of Jeeps for assembly at its Kenosha, Wis., plant if the state of Wisconsin will meet certain criteria.


Money II
LEAD: American wage-earners who have received their first paychecks of the new year may have been pleasantly surprised to find less money withheld for Federal taxes.
For most, the pleasure is probably premature.
It simply means that the recipient has not yet filled out the complex new W-4 form - the first step in ''simplication'' of the tax structure - that will determine the number of exemptions the employer will use to determine the wage-earner's level of withholding.

William A. O'Neill's State of the State Address to the General Assembly today:


AUTO AND TRUCK SALES SET U.S. RECORD IN '86
LEAD: Sales of new cars and trucks in the United States totaled 16.3 million in 1986, easily exceeding the previous record of 15.7 million set in 1985.


TODAY'S NEIL SIMON TAKES ON EARLIER NEIL SIMON
LEAD: AFTER the Jerome brothers of Neil Simon's ''Broadway Bound'' sell their first comedy sketch to CBS Radio, they are stunned to discover that one innocuous gag hits home harder than intended: a punch line about ''ladies' pajamas'' proves to be a subconscious indictment of their father's philandering.


O'NEILL ASKS TAX RELIEF AND AID TO POOR
LEAD: William Atchison O'Neill, inaugurated for a second full term as the 84th Governor of Connecticut, called on the state today to share its current economic prosperity with all its people.


AD AGENCY AMONG CONCERNS GIVING TO THE NEEDIEST CASES
LEAD: Business concerns and an advertising agency are among the contributors to the 75th-annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

India Replies To Carbide
LEAD: The Indian Government charged today that the Union Carbide Corporation was aware of a potential disaster before the gas leak disaster at Bhopal, but failed to design its plant there to safeguard against it.


Dark Days of Post-World War II Czechoslovakia
LEAD: To the Editor:


F.C.C. INQUIRY FOCUSES ON BOESKY TV STATION
LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission said today that it was investigating the possibility of violations of its rules by the arbitrager Ivan F. Boesky and his wife, Seema, in connection with their Oklahoma City television station.


Hoyt Waivers Sought
LEAD: The San Diego Padres asked for waivers yesterday on LaMarr Hoyt, the imprisoned pitcher, for purposes of giving him his unconditional release.
The club contended that Hoyt had breached his contract by failing to abide by a good citizenship clause.


Chase Manhattan
LEAD: The Chase Manhattan Corporation yesterday began offering $250 million of 7 7/8 percent notes due 1997 at a price of 99.90, to yield 7.89 percent,through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.
Noncallable for life, the 10-year notes yield 83-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.


FEDERAL JURY ON ARMS CASE TO BE EMPANELED IN WEEKS
LEAD: A Federal grand jury will be empaneled before February to begin hearing testimony in the Iran-contra arms case, according to Government officials knowledgeable about the investigation.


NEGLIGENCE IS CITED IN DEATH
LEAD: The director of a school for severely autistic teen-agers and young adults was negligent in the death of a student who died while undergoing treatment, a judge said today.


Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q. Two years ago we added a bathroom wing to our house.
This wing has a crawl space under the floor.
The ground is covered with sheet plastic and a coating of cement, and the foundation walls are cinder block with a small vent in one side.
The problem is that although the Jacuzzi tub, sink and toilet in that room do not seem to be leaking, we are getting a dank, musty odor throughout the house that seems to come up through the floor.


From Florida, A Senator of Note
LEAD: As Governor of Florida, Bob Graham was on a trade mission to Brazil, flying from Brasilia to Rio de Janeiro, when the airplane suddenly began losing hydraulic pressure.


Dukakis Files Court Plea
LEAD: Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis asked the Massachusetts Supreme Court Tuesday to overturn a court order that would raise welfare benefits 30 percent and cost the state about $780 million a year.
The state filed a brief asking Justice Francis P. O'Connor to stay the welfare order issued Monday by Judge Charles Grabau of Superior Court.


Yields Rise On Funds
LEAD: Yields on money market mutual funds were higher for the week ended yesterday, as they continued to reflect the steep increase in the Fed funds rate during the final weeks of 1986.
Yields offered by banks and thrift institutions on certificates of deposit and money market accounts remained about the same in the week.


Money I
LEAD: The pay increases that President Reagan has approved for top Federal employees in all three branches of Government do not require approval by Congress.
But if a growing number of critics, ranging from political left to right, have their way, each member of Congress will have to stand up and be counted before they can fatten their own pay envelopes.


Lawyer Seeks to Bar Statements by Youth
LEAD: A lawyer for one of the white youths arrested in the Howard Beach, Queens, assault said yesterday that if his client was indicted, the attorney would seek to prevent the prosecution from using incriminating statements the youth reportedly made to a detective and a prosecutor.


CHINA REPORTS ATTACKS BY HANOI
LEAD: Chinese frontier guards drove back several Vietnamese attacks across the border, destroying a company of Vietnamese soldiers today and ''wiping out'' another 200 enemy troops, Xinhua, the official Chinese press agency, reported.


Worthy Women
LEAD: TO THE HOME SECTION:


Bianchi Fined for Fight
LEAD: Al Bianchi, assistant coach of the Phoenix Suns, was fined $1,500 and suspended without pay for one game by the National Basketball Association yesterday for fighting during the Suns' game with the Lakers in Los Angeles last Friday night.
Three players were also fined: Frank Brickowski of the Lakers, $2,500; Wes Matthews of the Lakers, $1,000, and Grant Gondrezick of the Suns, $750.


Bridge: After Nearly a Year of Play Standig Team Wins in Jersey
LEAD: Some bridge events, like the world chess championship and the America's Cup, may take many months to complete.
The New Jersey Double Knockout Team Championship, with 25 teams entered, took almost the whole of 1986 and ended recently in a victory for David Standig of Harrington Park, N.J.; Brian Trent of Cherry Hill, N.J.; Robert Heitner of Newton, N.J.; Brian Schroeder of Oakland, N.J., and Kurt Gandenberger of Hazelton, Pa.


Michigan Executive Takes Lilco Posts
LEAD: The Long Island Lighting Company has named Russell C. Youngdahl president and chief operating officer, filling posts that have been vacant for several years.


VIOLENCE FOUND IN PUERTO RICO LABOR RELATIONS THROUGH THE 1970'S
LEAD: Labor relations in Puerto Rico, where an arson fire destroyed the Dupont Plaza Hotel on New Year's Eve, were found in a 1983 study to have been characterized by violence.


CUOMO EMPHASIZES CURB ON SPENDING
LEAD: Governor Cuomo, opening a legislative year in which he will decide whether to seek the Presidency, presented his agenda for 1987 today, calling for new programs in education, criminal justice and housing but stressing that, above all else, state spending had to be curbed.


Zruce Declines Offer
LEAD: Earle Bruce, who said he was ''offered the moon'' to take over the football program at the University of Arizona, has decided to remain head coach at Ohio State University.

KENTUCKY STREAK HALTED BY ALABAMA
LEAD: Derrick McKey scored 25 points and Jim Farmer 22 as Alabama snapped Kentucky's 24-game winning streak in Rupp Arena by beating the Wildcats, 69-55, tonight in a Southeastern Conference game.


H.H. Robertson Stake Rises to 25%
LEAD: A unit of the First City Financial Corporation, a company controlled by the Belzberg family of Canada, has raised its stake in the H. H. Robertson Company to about 25 percent, or 1.47 million common shares, from 20.9 percent.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Belzbergs said they bought 302,700 shares of the Pittsburgh-based building products concern for $12 to $12.08 each.

LEAD: The State Department announced today that it had sent a message to all posts barring them from accepting private donations for embassy entertainment costs.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article Dec. 16 about the renovation of Carnegie Hall incorrectly identified the head of the company that did the work.
He is John L. Tishman, chief executive officer of the Tishman Realty and Construction Company.


Advertising;
LEAD: YOU are going to be hearing a lot from the cattle crowd, who suddenly have a bundle of cash in their jeans and are planning to spend $30 million for advertising to get the American people to grab the beef . . . at a good price.


Probation Set For Spangler
LEAD: Mark E. Spangler, who once managed $25 million of other people's money, has been placed on five years' probation.
He pleaded guilty Nov. 17 to charges that he defrauded investors of $297,000.
In a plea-bargain plan, the Government dropped 18 related charges and he agreed to set aside 20 percent of his future earnings for restitution.


Kay Practices With Broncos
LEAD: Clarence Kay, a tight end sidelined the last four weeks while he underwent drug rehabilitation, rejoined the Denver Broncos today and could be activated for Sunday's American Conference championship game at Cleveland.


The Passenger Railroad Worth Selling
LEAD: Sell Amtrak?
Few government enterprises have as loyal a following as the passenger rail system, and the proposal to privatize it is likely to get short shrift from Congress.
Yet the idea has considerable merit.


EASY NIGHT FOR NETS
LEAD: There was something almost too simple about the game.
It had begun to look like a routine practice session by the second period, like an emphatic blowout by the third.
There have not been many nights like this, not for the Nets.
Not this season.

The Catholic Church Is Also All Catholics
LEAD: To the Editor:


NEW AND POPULAR ORNAMENTAL GRASES
LEAD: SOME of my gardening friends tell me it would be possible to have a garden with practically nothing in it but ornamental grasses.
And certainly grasses are riding the crest of popularity these days.
I admire these grasses, but my admiration does not trespass into fanaticism.
There are too many other plants that I could not live without, like day lilies, old-fashioned roses, bee balm and sedums.


Bond Prices Up in All Sectors
LEAD: Bond prices rose modestly in all sectors yesterday, as revived investor demand outpaced the supply of new securities.


AFTER A DAY'S WORK, WHAT IS RELAXING?
LEAD: AT the end of the day, Natalie Cacciato looks forward to bath time. ''I used to look forward to going home and working, but I decided that I work better if I leave my work at work,'' she said the other afternoon before starting her 90-minute trip home. ''Because I have such a long drive, I like to go home and take a bath with my husband.

The ending of the current production at the Quaigh Theater is fitting and funny.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: Soccer Express 6, Sting 4: Fred Grgurev scored two goals and assisted on a third last night at Nassau Coliseum as New York held on to defeat Chicago for its first victory of the season after 13 defeats.
Njego Pesa had a pair of goals for the Express, which led at halftime, 3-1.
The triumph prevented New York from tying the Major Indoor Soccer League record of 14 consecutive defeats set by the Kansas City Comets in 1981-82.(AP) N.B.A.

About Mad Madge
LEAD: TO THE HOME SECTION:


New Lobbyist in Town
LEAD: With the Democrats now firmly in control of the Senate with a 55-to-45 majority, a chief architect of the recapture is setting up shop as a lobbyist.


SYNTHESIZED DRUG EASES KIDNEY ILLS
LEAD: A natural kidney hormone, made synthetically through biotechnology, has cured anemia and eliminated the need for blood transfusions in kidney dialysis patients, two medical reports say.


CONCERT: BRASS QUINTET AT MERKIN
LEAD: THE members of the Saturday Brass Quintet selected an unusually appealing program of works for the group's Tuesday evening program at Merkin Concert Hall.
Most of the music was unknown, with Bach's ''Little'' Fugue in G minor the only genuine warhorse.
Yet there was nothing radical about the evening; the rare and contemporary works were played in a spirit of friendly inquest, rather than one of evangelical fury.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo, reacting to the beating of three black men in Howard Beach, declared today that he would establish a Task Force on Bias-Related Violence to suggest state actions ''to deter bias-directed violence and to address its causes and effects.''


It'll Have to Be Off Broadway
LEAD: With Mayor Koch steadfast in his refusal to authorize a ticker-tape parade in the event of a Super Bowl victory by those he has taken to calling the New Jersey Giants, Governor Kean is savoring the prospect of filling the publicity vacuum.


TIGHTER VISAS MAY BAR LESSER-KNOWN ARTISTS
LEAD: The directors of some of the country's most prominent performing-arts groups have told the Immigration and Naturalization Service that proposed new criteria for work visas could significantly limit the variety of international artists seen on American stages.


Denial Made By Regulator
LEAD: Lee H. Henkel Jr., a new member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, denied today that he tried last month to aid a large California thrift institution with which he had had extensive dealings.


PIANO: ARTHUR GREENE IN RECITAL
LEAD: DANIEL BARENBOIM was to have given the first piano recital in the remodeled Carnegie Hall, but owing to what was reported as a last-minute illness could not take unto himself that honor.
The distinction fell instead, willy-nilly, to Arthur Greene, who last year won first prize in the University of Maryland International William Kapell Piano


Danskins to Margeotes
LEAD: Another ownership change that has led to happiness at at least one agency involves the purchase of the Beatrice Knitwear Group by Englewood Partners in June.
The group consisted of Danskins, women's bodywear, and Pennaco hosiery.
Now Danskins, which since June has gotten its advertising in-house, has been assigned to Margeotes, Fertitta &amp; Weiss after a major competition of big-name agencies.

British Widen Insider Study
LEAD: The British Government said today that it had received new information and was extending its investigation into purported insider trading by a senior London securities dealer.


MOSCOW HINTS AT AFGHANISTAN TROOP CUT
LEAD: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze returned to Moscow from Kabul today amid indications that the Soviet Union would soon announce a withdrawal of some of its troops from Afghanistan.


Figure in Crime Group Says He Took Part in 5 Slayings
LEAD: A former lieutenant in the Nicodemo Scarfo crime family has admitted taking part in five mob slayings that he said had been ordered by family leaders, Federal prosecutors say.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''Everyone knows how to switch sides in Lebanon but Israel.
The Syrians went from supporting the Christians to the P.L.O. and back to the Christians.
The Maronites were with the Syrians, then against them, then for them.
Amal was with the P.L.O., now it's against it.


CENTURY CLUB GROUPS OPPOSE ANTI-BIAS PACT
LEAD: Despite an agreement with the city that paves the way for the admission of women to the Century Association, two groups at the all-male club are exploring ways for it to remain outside the jurisdiction of the local human-rights law.


Yankees Spurn Gedman Overture
LEAD: The Yankees, who three weeks ago passed up the chance to add Jack Morris to their pitching staff, yesterday rejected the opportunity to snatch Rich Gedman from the Boston Red Sox and make him their catcher.
They also saw their chances of re-signing Ron Guidry and Willie Randolph dwindling as tonight's midnight signing deadline loomed.


FORD SELLS AN OHIO PLANT
LEAD: An auto transmission plant in Fairfax, Ohio, closed since 1979, has been sold by the Ford Motor Company to a closely held company, the auto maker said.
No price was given.
Red Bank Distribution of Cincinnati plans to remodel the plant's 580,000-square-foot main building for warehousing, distribution and light manufacturing.


Activision Agrees To Settle Lawsuit
LEAD: Activision Inc., a software producer in Mountain View, Calif., said it had agreed to settle a class action suit filed by a shareholder group for $4.75 million, of which at least $2.5 million will be in cash, with the balance in securities.
The group had complained about purported misstatements and omissions in the registration statement and prospectus that were issued when the company went public in June 1983.

'Amerika' Far From Ready
LEAD: Brandon Stoddard, head of ABC's entertainment division, said today that the network's mini-series ''Amerika'' was still being edited and was ''not remotely ready'' to be broadcast although it is scheduled to be televised in less than six weeks.


Rep. Martin Marries Judge
LEAD: Representative Lynn M. Martin, Republican of Illinois, was married today to a Federal District judge, Harry D. Leinenweber, of Chicago, in a private ceremony here.
Ms.
Martin, 47 years old, a former high school teacher and Illinois state legislator, was first elected to the House in 1980.
She has two daughters from a previous marriage that ended in divorce.

Reinhard A. Hohaus, Ex-Insurance Official
LEAD: Reinhard A. Hohaus, a former insurance executive and an adviser to governmental bodies, died Monday at his home in Westport, Conn.
He was 90 years old.


Union Pacific Sets Debenture Yields
LEAD: The Union Pacific Corporation is offering $200 million of 8 1/2 percent sinking-fund debentures due in 2017 at a price of 97 7/8, to yield 8.70 percent to maturity, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.


A Letter From Iacocca
LEAD: A sixth-grader in the Washington suburb of Silver Spring, Md., wrote a letter to Lee Iacocca not long ago in connection with a class project, and, like not a few others, asked the Chrysler chairman if he had any plans to run for President.
Mr.
Iacocca said no, as he has said repeatedly before, but he concluded with a deft politician's touch that partly explains why he is asked the question in the first place.

WARNING ON ACCIDENT ON FILM SET DESCRIBED
LEAD: A camera operator testified Tuesday that the director of the movie ''Twilight Zone'' responded to a warning about the impact that special effects explosions might have on the film's helicopter by saying ''we may lose'' the aircraft.


RANGERS RALLY, BUT FALL SHORT
LEAD: Everything in the Rangers' world had been on the rise.
New players had been adding glitter.
Everyone had been falling into roles.
And, as if in celebration of a new day, the fans came out last night to make Madison Square Garden rock.


ISLANDERS FRUSTRATE SIMPSON
LEAD: The Islanders, who completed the first half of their season with a 5-3 victory over Minnesota Tuesday night - their first triumph in six games - know their weak points well.
They are erratic, and coasting on a reputation they've managed not to tarnish, but certainly have not enhanced.


True Grit
LEAD: A few days after Christmas, Steve Wolterman went to the gym at Badin High School in Hamilton, Ohio, and began shooting free throws.
Each shot was missing to the left initially, but he quickly adjusted and began making two of every three.
He knew then that he would play basketball again.


QUINONES SEEKS 10.5% INCREASE TO RUN SCHOOLS
LEAD: New York City Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones proposed a $5.2 billion operating budget yesterday for the Board of Education's next fiscal year, an increase of $454 million - 10.5 percent - over the current budget, which expires June 30.


A Sensible Way to Sell the Air
LEAD: You can't see or touch the telecommunications spectrum.
Yet the space on the dial is a valuable Federal resource.
The Administration, which had been ready to give away unallocated frequencies, now wisely proposes auctioning them.
That could bring in $600 million next year.
As important, the switch to an auction system would assure efficient use of the resource.


MOTHER SAID TO CHANGE MIND AT BABY M'S BIRTH
LEAD: The husband of the surrogate mother of Baby M, Richard Whitehead, testified today that his wife, Mary Beth, had planned to surrender the child to her natural father, William Stern, until moments after her birth.


Dollar Is Mostly Higher; European Trading Busy
LEAD: The dollar generally rose yesterday as several European central banks entered the market to support their currencies against the strong West German mark.


CHINA REPORTS GAIN IN SUPERCONDUCTIVE ALLOYS
LEAD: Scientists in Beijing have reported producing an alloy that becomes superconducting, losing all resistance to electricity, at a temperature so high it would revolutionize the electrical industry.
If confirmed, it would be the second major superconductivity advance in a week.


ASSESSOR FOR COUNTY DROPS FROM PRIMARY FOR CHICAGO MAYOR
LEAD: Thomas C. Hynes, one of three major candidates running in Chicago's Democratic mayoral primary in February, formally withdrew from that race today.


New Products Shown by Atari
LEAD: The Atari Corporation, which has regained profitability largely because of the success of its 520 and 1040 ST personal computers, introduced a new ST today aimed at professional users.
It also introduced a new low-priced laser printer.


GOING OUT GUIDE
LEAD: HOME FOLKS As a New York City community, Greenwich Village began in the late 18th and early 19th centuries.
By 1850 it was home to middle-class and well-to-do Americans.
In 1875, with one resident out of three foreign-born, the Village was called the American Ward.
Then, Irish, Afro-Americans and Italians moved in, in that order.


Topics: Back to Work; Diet Month
LEAD: January needs no official proclamation to qualify as diet month.
December always qualifies as the opposite with its stuffed turkeys, mashed potatoes, cranberry sauce, frosted cookies shaped like reindeer and Santa Claus, hazelnut tarts, fudge balls, gourmet peanut brittle and the much-maligned fruitcakes.

LEAD: The intricacies of the minuet, sarabande, gigue and other dances of the 18th century will be demonstrated Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Fraunces Tavern Museum, 54 Pearl Street.
Members of the New York Baroque Dance Company will lead participants through the paces in the second in a series of six performances devoted to historic entertainment; the ensemble will also perform a program called ''Two French Children.

LEAD: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward yesterday renewed his criticism of a lawyer for one of three black men attacked by white teen-agers in a racial incident Dec. 20 in Howard Beach, Queens.

Investors Buy Control Of Entrepreneur Group
LEAD: The majority ownership of Entrepreneur magazine, which frequently covers the franchising industry, has just been bought by three men in the business themselves.
They are Barry Rupp, Peter Shea and Reinhold Pfahler, who run Stained Glass Overlay of Costa Mesa, Calif., a franchiser of 300 window-treatment product retailers.

LEAD: The House of Representatives, ignoring a compromise urged by President Reagan, overwhelmingly passed a Clean Water Bill today that is identical to one he vetoed last year.

NEEDIEST AID GIVEN TO HELP POOR IN CITY
LEAD: Several contributors to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases have said the city's great wealth makes the poverty in which many fund recipients live particularly outrageous.


Handke Theater Piece
LEAD: ''Self-Accusation,'' a theater piece by the Austrian playwright Peter Handke, will be presented for the next three weekends by the Women in Theater Network at the Women's Interart Annex, 552 West 53d Street.
The work features three actresses in a presentation of dance and theater.
The program is part of a director's workshop series sponsored by Women in Theater.


Ad Revenues Up 10.2%
LEAD: The Newspaper Advertising Bureau reported yesterday that ad revenues of the nation's daily newspapers were up 10.2 percent in October from the same month in 1985, to $2.5 billion, despite a drop in national advertising revenues.
Within that, retail advertising rose 10.4 percent, to $1.34 billion, and classified climbed 16.4 percent, to $845 million.


G.E. to Lay Off 1,400 at Factory
LEAD: The General Electric Company will lay off about 1,400 of its 12,000 employees in Lynn this year, with about 1,000 of the layoffs coming as a result of increased competition and reduced demand for the jet fighter engines it makes, a spokesman, William Kennedy, said.


Market Place; How 3 Stocks Bounced Back
LEAD: IF they were athletes, they might be given comeback-player-of-the-year awards.
For just like a player who is injured, undergoes major surgery and then has a stellar season, the stocks of Colt Industries, the FMC Corporation and Owens-Corning Fiberglas have bounced back with a vengeance.

LEAD: Representative Charles E. Bennett of Florida, the second most senior Democrat on the House Armed Services Committee, today became the House Democratic leadership's official candidate to become chairman of the committee.

Economic Scene; Symbolism Vs. Reality
LEAD: PETER F. DRUCKER, the Clarke Professor of Social Science at the Claremont Graduate School in California, contends that there has been a basic change in the world economy.
The ''real'' economy of goods and services and the ''symbolic'' economy of money, credit and capital are no longer bound tightly to each other, he says, and ''are moving further and further apart.

BABY-FACED SOLDIER OF 'PLATOON': KEVIN DILLON
LEAD: ONE of the most terrifying moments in the film ''Platoon'' belongs to the 21-year-old actor Kevin Dillon who plays Bunny, a swaggering, baby-faced young American soldier.
When the platoon descends upon a Vietnamese village that may or may not be an enemy stronghold, the seething powder keg of a young man indulges his berserk lust for violence by savagely beating a peasant with his rifle butt.

Sumitomo Unit Settles Suit
LEAD: The Sumitomo Corporation of America settled a sex discrimination suit yesterday, agreeing to train and promote women for management and sales positions.
But Sumitomo, a unit of a giant Japanese trading company, said the settlement preserved its ''right to give preference to Japanese nationals,'' usually men, in filling a few top jobs.

LEAD: Richard Davis-Sir Roland Hanna Quintet, the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037).
The bassist Richard Davis lights a fire under his quintets.
His jaunty countermelodies and springy riffs push soloists to take chances and keep the rhythm section jumping; there's a sense of daredevil camaraderie.

Bears Up for Grammy
LEAD: The Chicago Bears, who cut a record before winning last year's Super Bowl, can set a record this year by becoming the first pro football team to win a Grammy award.
The Bears' ''Shufflin' Crew'' - which features Jim McMahon, William Perry and Walter Payton, among others -has been nominated for best vocal recording by a rhythm and blues group.

COMPANY NEWS;
LEAD: The Sony Corporation of America agreed to pay the Government $1.75 million to settle claims it provided inaccurate prices on audio and video broadcast equipment sold to the Government between 1980 and 1984, the Justice Department said.
The department charged that Sony, based in Park Ridge, N.J., had failed to fully disclose the discounts it was offering other customers and did not pass on to Federal purchasers price cuts available to


DYNAMICS TAKES A CESSNA WRITE-OFF
LEAD: The General Dynamics Corporation, one of the nation's leading military contractors, said yesterday that it was writing off about $420 million of the $680 million it paid last year for the Cessna Aircraft Company.


On the Phone
LEAD: A new staff member of the House Select Committee on Intelligence was pleased to discover that the last three digits of his Capitol telephone extension were 007.


The Cardinal and Israel
LEAD: John Cardinal O'Connor is not only a prince of the Church; he is a prince of a man.
The extraordinary compromise he negotiated with Israel's leaders in Jerusalem this week is yet another example of what has impressed many of us about him.


Rare Items on Display At Numismatic Society
LEAD: Rare manuscripts, coins and other items documenting hundreds of years in the history of numismatics will be on view tomorrow through Feb. 21 at the American Numismatic Society, Broadway and 155th Street.
The exhibition includes books and papers dating from the 16th century; among them are volumes by the 18th-century writer Joseph Hilarius Eckhel, who is considered by collectors to be the ''father of modern numismatics.

BEHIND WALL STREET'S SURGE
LEAD: Most economic forecasters kicked off 1987 with a promise that it would be another year of decidedly unexciting economic growth.
It has turned out to be a promise that the stock market, so far at least, seems to be irreverently ignoring.


Double Drama for Lyubimov Premiere
LEAD: Tonight's American premiere of the Russian director Yuri Lyubimov's adaptation of ''Crime and Punishment'' here was preceded by some political suspense.


HUNGARIAN ENSEMBLE
LEAD: Traditional Hungarian music and dance will be presented by the Hungarian State Folk Ensemble, a group of more than 100 performers, Sunday night at 7 at Lehman Center for the Performing Arts, Goulden Avenue and Bedford Park Boulevard West, the Bronx.
The troupe, led by Sandor Timar, is based in Budapest.


Target Publishing
LEAD: Target Publishing Resources of New York will bring out a special newspaper supplement on May 17 called ''We the People . . .'' to mark the 200th anniversary of the United States Constitution.
In addition to carrying the entire text of the Constitution and the Bill of Rights, as well as a calendar of bicentennial events of national importance, the supplement will carry advertising.


REAGAN BACK AT WHITE HOUSE, SAYING 'I FEEL GREAT'
LEAD: Beaming and waving, President Reagan left the hospital today facing a gradual resumption of White House duties that aides hope will not become overburdened by the Iran arms affair.


Mackovic Released
LEAD: Coach John Mackovic, who led the Kansas City Chiefs to their first playoff appearance in 15 years this season, was dismissed yesterday after his fourth season with the team. ''The chemistry of an organization is an intangible that is crucial to its success,'' Lamar Hunt, the Chiefs' owner, said at a news conference.


Acquisitions and Shifts At PSC Publications
LEAD: PSC Publications, the limited partnership whose acquisition of Games magazine from Playboy Enterprises was announced New Year's Eve, also includes Needlecraft for Today and Needle Thread magazines, acquired from the Happy Hands Publishing Company of Fort Worth, according to Jerry Calabrese, Games publisher and one of the general partners.


Fixed Mortgages Fall to 8-Year Low
LEAD: Mortgage rates dropped again last month, reaching an eight-year low, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said yesterday.


Choice Dates No Help as Hialeah Opens
LEAD: The flamingos were on their infield island, the parrots were in their aviary, the horses were on the track.
As usual, all that was missing from opening day of Hialeah Park were the horseplayers of seasons past.


AFRICAN STUDENTS IN BEIJING MARCH IN OUTRAGE AT A RACIAL SLUR
LEAD: About 200 chanting African university students, reacting to a racial provocation, marched more than 12 miles across Beijing from their campuses to the capital's embassy district today to protest an apparently fraudulent letter slurring their behavior and manners.

LEAD: The World Music Institute (206-1050) will celebrate its second anniversary with Greek music, food and dancing in a party Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center, 179 Varick Street.
Admission is $15.

LEAD: In a sweeping pastoral letter on affordable housing, the Bishop of Long Island's Roman Catholic Diocese today urged that two-family houses be permitted throughout Nassau and Suffolk Counties.


Goodyear Begins Management Shifts
LEAD: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company yesterday announced moves to consolidate its management, including the appointment of a corporate vice president for worldwide tire manufacturing.

MOSCOW TRIES A NEW LULLABY: HEAVY METAL ROCK
LEAD: A leading Soviet jazz-rock composer today extolled the virtues of heavy-metal rock music as a way for young working-class Russians to work out their resentment toward more affluent members of Soviet society.


In the Mail
LEAD: Are Americans throwing away, unopened, letters that solicit donations or sell products?
The Armed Forces Journal thinks so.
The Washington publication, circulating a questionnaire to update its mailing list, printed on the envelope: ''Please, please, please open this envelope and reply.
We are not asking for any money, we promise!


Mr. Reagan's Choice
LEAD: The Reagan Administration's ''well-intentioned effort to find an opening to Iran,'' says Senator David Durenberger of Minnesota, ''met up with a scam and got taken to the cleaners.
But . . . it is not a thing by which you topple a Government or tie up Congress for a year.''


RESTAURANTS
LEAD: KITCHO is not a name that is bandied about often when gastronomic commandos huddle to swap intelligence reports on hot spots in the field.
This 20-year-old midtown Japanese restaurant is about as chic as a Honda Civic, notable more for its longevity than its luster.
Its formula for graceful aging is unglamorous and straightforward: a warm and efficient staff combined with dependably fresh and attractive Japanese food.


Guarneri String Quartet
LEAD: The Guarneri String Quartet will play works by Beethoven, Shostakovich and Brahms at the Metropolitan Museum of Art tomorrow night at 8.
The violist Samuel Rhodes and the cellist Joel Krosnick will be the guest artists in a performance of the Sextet No. 2 in G by Brahms.
Tickets are $15.
Information: 570-3949.


THE RACE IS ON AND ANYONE CAN WIN IT
LEAD: Nearly everyone predicted a wide-open race in the Big East this season, but not many could have predicted how wide-open.


COLECO SEES LOSSES IN QUARTER AND '86
LEAD: Coleco Industries, the company behind the popular Cabbage Patch Kids, said yesterday that it expected ''very large'' yearly and fourth-quarter losses, citing a continuing decline in sales of the dolls.


9TH GRADER DIES DURING STRUGGLE TO KEEP JACKET
LEAD: A ninth grader was killed Wednesday as he fought to prevent the theft of his leather jacket, and three juveniles have been charged with homicide, the police said today.


No U.S.F.L. in '87
LEAD: The United States Football League, which canceled its 1986 season, remains alive, although a lengthy court appeal will keep it dormant again in 1987, according to Commissioner Harry Usher. ''Given the time for appeal, we felt it unlikely there would be a season,'' Usher said yesterday. ''It will take about a six-month time frame to hear the appeal.

Then, when their losing ways continued, they seemingly could do no right.
Now, as they are about to play a game that could put them into Super Bowl X

LEAD: The franc remained under strong downward pressure today, but both France and West Germany continued to resist the idea of realigning their currencies.


FRICK AWAITS NEW DIRECTOR
LEAD: There's a widespread belief that things never change at the Frick Collection.
But they do, albeit slowly.
In June, Charles Ryskamp, for 17 years director of the Morgan Library, will replace Everett Fahy as the Frick's director.
Mr.
Fahy, who has headed the Frick since 1973, will become chairman of the department of European paintings at the Metropolitan Museum of


British Airways to Offer 720.2 Million Shares
LEAD: The British Government said today that it will offer 720.2 million British Airways P.L.C. shares to investors at a yet-to-be disclosed price when the company goes public in February.
The sale is expected to raise $:1 billion, or about $1.47 billion.


THE THEATER: 'SWEET SUE,' WITH MOORE AND REDGRAVE
LEAD: AS an articulate theatrical chronicler of WASP manners and mating habits, A. R. Gurney Jr. specializes in richly populated and furnished interior landscapes.
The playwright is at his most artful when he invents an apparatus as premise - the dining room as an unchangeable environment for multi-generational maneuverings; a ''party critic'' who reviews a social gathering as emblematic of a way of life.


Boom-Booms as Bonbons
LEAD: In the aftermath of World War I, there was a great campaign against the ''merchants of death'' who made fortunes selling arms and encouraging wars to use them up.
Making money is now an important factor for governments in the world arms trade, but the politics of trying to win friends and influence people, not to speak of buying back hostages, has overtaken it.


Wishful Thinking
LEAD: Coach Buddy Ryan, whose Philadelphia Eagles don't select until ninth in the college draft, on why they nonetheless have a shot at quirky Brian Bosworth: ''Really, what I'm hoping is that enough people think there's something wrong with him that he's still there when we pick.''


ICAHN ENDS HIS OFFER FOR USX
LEAD: Carl C. Icahn yesterday called off his $8 billion offer to purchase the USX Corporation.

Car Runs Into California Motor Vehicle Office
LEAD: A paramedic helping one of 23 people injured when a car, rear, crashed through a wall of the Department of Motor Vehicles yesterday in Chula Vista.
The driver, Augustine Medina, had suffered a slight stroke and jammed his foot on the accelerator.
He was listed in serious condition at a hospital.
About 200 customers were in the office at the time.

AT THE MOVIES
LEAD: NEXT Friday, Steven Spielberg's controversial movie ''The Color Purple'' will reopen in 725 theaters nationwide, just three months after the 1985 film was taken out of release.
The decision to have a new theatrical opening, with a large-scale national advertising campaign and new promotional material, is an unusual marketing strategy, since most films are released for video shortly after their first theatrical run.

LEAD: Mary Beth Whitehead, the surrogate mother of Baby M, said in tears today that she was powerless to overcome her desire to keep the child, even though she had planned to surrender the baby to her natural father until the moment of birth.

LEAD: In its second consolidation move in two weeks, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would close down its I.B.M.
Instruments Inc. subsidiary, ending the six-year-old venture to sell chemical analysis tools to laboratory scientists.

PHIL SEGHI
LEAD: Phil Seghi, who hired Frank Robinson as baseball's first black manager with Cleveland in 1975 and signed Pete Rose for the Cincinnati Reds in 1960, died today in Thousand Oaks, Calif., after a long illness with cancer.
He was 68 years old.


Movie Stunt Man Dies Trapped Under River
LEAD: A stunt man was killed when he drove a car into the Hudson River during the filming of a movie here today and divers could not pull him out of the car, the police said.

Two Firefighters Hurt in Midtown Blaze
LEAD: Smoke rising from a fire at a three-story building at West 28th Street and Avenue of the Americas.
Two firefighters were hurt and two people were missing.
A Fire Department official said he believed that the two who were missing had escaped the building, which housed several businesses. (NYT/Ruby Washington)


Portland General
LEAD: The Portland General Electric Company said it had established a reserve to write down its investment in the Washington Public Power Supply System's Nuclear Project No. 3.
The reserve will result in an after-tax earnings reduction of $1.64 a common share in 1986 for the Portland General Corporation, which has 46.1 million common shares outstanding.


U.S. TO WAIT TO PROSECUTE RACIAL CASE
LEAD: The Federal authorities will prosecute the three white youths arrested in the Howard Beach attack only if the state cannot go forward or otherwise cannot ''achieve substantial justice,'' a Federal prosecutor said yesterday.


G.M. Output Plan
LEAD: An executive vice president of General Motors, Lloyd E. Reuss, said the company was gearing its plants to build enough vehicles in 1987 to account for 42 percent of the projected 10.5 million American car market.
G.M. captured slightly more than 41 percent of the market in 1986.

Giving Love, or Selling Life?
LEAD: Who, short of Solomon, would choose to be in Harvey R. Sorkow's shoes these days?
He is the New Jersey judge who must decide the legality of the contract by which Mary Beth Whitehead agreed to bear a child for William and Elizabeth Stern.
Then Judge Sorkow must determine with whom the fruit of that contract, a little girl, should live - the biological mother and her husband, or the biological father (by artificial insemination) and his wife.


AROUND QUEENS BOROUGH HALL, MANES MYSTERY LINGERS
LEAD: What Donald R. Manes did in the seven hours before he was found after his first suicide attempt a year ago is still a mystery.
But for many people in Queens, an even greater mystery continues to be Mr.
Manes himself.


Parade Poll
LEAD: While New York's politicians debate whether there should be a ticker tape parade for the Giants should they win the Super Bowl, the city's public favors one, but just barely.

LEAD: BEIGNETS, the deep-fried pastry fritters that are synonymous with the French Quarter of New Orleans, were not what I had in mind when I dropped into Patisserie Lanciani on Prince Street late one evening, still hungry after a woebegone dinner in a tragically chic SoHo restaurant.
This pleasantly minimalist cafe and carryout, with gray walls and scattered


FEHR POSTS 67 FOR LEAD
LEAD: Most good rounds of golf include at least one moment when a player salvages par from bogey country.
But when a player gets birdies more than once from under the trees, he is going into four leaf clover territory.


Corrections
LEAD: A chart yesterday with a poll on race relations in New York City misidentified its sponsors.
Also, in some copies it incorrectly reported results of a question about Mayor Koch's handling of the situation that began with an attack on three black men in Queens last month.
The survey was a New York Times/WCBS-TV Poll; the correct results of the question about Mayor Koch appear today on page B2.


Davis Nominated
LEAD: Two men who have been keys to Raider football success and thorns to the hierarchy of the National Football League were among the 16 finalists named yesterday for possible induction into the Pro Football Hall of Fame in Canton, Ohio.
The two are Al Davis, former commissioner of the American Football League and now the principal owner of the Los Angeles Raiders, and Gene Upshaw, the Raiders' former All-Pro offensive lineman who is now head of the players' union.


REPORTER TO BE TRIED FOR CONTEMPT FOR REFUSING TO TESTIFY IN MURDER
LEAD: A Maine judge today charged a New Hampshire newspaper reporter with contempt of court for refusing to testify in a murder trial here.


Mitsubishi Motor
LEAD: Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America will become the first Japanese company to sell South Korean cars in the United States when it begins importing 1,500 cars made by the Hyundai Motor Company in early spring.
Mitsubishi Motor, a subsidiary of the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, will import and sell 30,000 Hyundai Excels annually under the name of Precis.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A front-page headline yesterday on a Washington dispatch reporting a vote to depose Representative Les Aspin as chairman of the House Armed Services Committee misstated the date for a second vote on the matter.
It will be Jan. 23.

LEAD: Kidder Peabody Mortgage Assets Trust Three yesterday began offering $500 million of collateralized mortgage obligations divided into five parts, one of which bears a floating interest rate.
Rated triple-A by the Standard &amp; Poor's Corporation, the obligations are backed by 9 and 9 1/2 percent Federal Home Loan Mortgage

WEEKENDER GUIDE
LEAD: Friday 'LEGENDS' OF JAZZ Sixty photographs of great Afro-American and Latin jazz artists go on display today at the Caribbean Cultural Center.
Framed to capture the mood, milieu and personality of each of the entertainers, these photographic portraits by Chuck Stewart feature such artists as Dinah Washington, Dizzy Gillespie, Machito, Tito Rodriguez, Miles Davis, Duke Ellington and John Coltrane.

A DARING U.S. STEP FOR HONDA
LEAD: The announcement today that the Honda Motor Company would invest $450 million to manufacture engine and drive train components in Ohio is yet another daring step by a company that has often set the pace for Japanese auto makers in this country.


BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Aetna Life and Casualty Co. is offering $200 million of triple-A rated 8 percent debentures due 2017 at a price of 97.75, to yield 8.203 percent, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
The issue is noncallable for 10 years and has a sinking fund beginning in 1998.

LEAD: France today played down the importance of a Libyan air attack in southern Chad on Wednesday, indicating that it was planning no immediate retaliation.

Her feelings spring from having known the singer-pianist since he was a teen-ager, but her enthusiasm is not unique.

The Jazz took the lead for good at home when Kent Benson scored with 43 seconds left in the first half.
John Stockton had a team-record 23 assists for Utah.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 377 money market mutual funds increased $2.8 billion, to $234.75 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 91 institutional funds were up $1.46 billion, to $65.43 billion.
Assets of the 194 general purpose funds were down $1.04 billion, to $62.9 billion.


JUDGE OVERTURNS A RULING LIMITING MILK SALES IN CITY
LEAD: A Federal judge held today that a state decision barring a New Jersey dairy from expanding its sales in New York City was unconstitutional.
The ruling could mean lower milk prices almost immediately and unravel a powerful group of milk distributors that has dominated the market for more than 50 years.


MAN WITH AIDS IS DENIED A WEDDING AT ST. PATRICK'S
LEAD: The rector of Saint Patrick's Cathedral has refused to perform a religious marriage ceremony for a man dying of AIDS who wanted to renew the civil-marriage vows he made to his wife three years ago.


DDB Needham Gets GTE Spacenet Account
LEAD: DDB Needham Worldwide, Washington, has won the GTE Spacenet account, which will add $2.5 million to $3 million in billings to the $50 million in GTE business already at the New York office.


Mexico Oil Sales Falter
LEAD: Mexico's oil sales fell nearly 60 percent in the first eight months of 1986 from a year earlier, the planning and budget department said Wednesday.
Mexico received nearly $3.56 billion from oil sales in the period in 1986, compared with $8.71 billion the year before.
And President Miguel de la Madrid said in a message to the nation that Mexico, despite its economic troubles, avoided ''what could have been a really chaotic situation.


MILLION-DOLLAR RESIDENCES IN A POLICE-HEADQUARTERS
LEAD: Moving into a gymnasium where New York policemen once dribbled basketballs may not immediately appeal to apartment seekers who can afford more than $1 million for a cooperative - especially when the gym is in a building in Little Italy.

Combustion To Get Accuray
LEAD: Combustion Engineering Inc., a diversified technology company, said today that it had won a bidding war and had agreed to acquire the Accuray Corporation for $45 a share, or $213 million.
Accuray, based in Columbus, Ohio, makes computer-aided sensors and measuring devices for pulp and paper manufacturers.


Nielsen To Drop Diaries
LEAD: THE A.C.
Nielsen Company announced yesterday that it was dropping its long-used but questionable diary system of evaluating TV audience composition in favor of the recently developed ''people meter.''

LEAD: Shots fired tonight into a group home for the retarded wounded a 36-year-old employee, the 11th such shooting in northern Rhode Island or nearby areas in Massachusetts since Dec. 8, the authorities said.
Two of the cases have been positively linked, and the police say they believe most if not all are related.

Givenchy and Round the Clock brands make up Pennaco.

LEAD: An unemployed construction worker charged with shooting at a United Airlines jet here last week said he was aiming for the pilot, an informer said in court documents released Wednesday.

ART: 2 LOOKS AT CLEVE GRAY'S WORKS
LEAD: CLEVE GRAY has had anything but a black and white career.
As a student at Princeton, he studied Chinese art with the noted scholar George Rowley.
In Paris after World War II, he studied painting with Andre Lhote and Jacques Villon, two painters passionate about structure whose work reflects the glory and decline of the School of Paris.

LEAD: In a move reflecting the weak conditions in the independent television market, the Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation said today that it had cut the price it would pay for WPGH-TV in Pittsburgh to $21.25 million, from $35 million.

Comings and Goings
LEAD: The Cincinnati Reds have traded Eddie Milner, an outfielder, to the San Francisco Giants for Frank Williams, a relief pitcher, and two minor-league pitchers.
Milner, 31 years old, hit .259 with a career-high 15 home runs and 47 runs batted in last season, but was unhappy about sharing center field with Eric Davis for the second consecutive season, and had sought a trade.

Y Chamber Symphony
LEAD: Yan Pascal Tortelier will lead the Y Chamber Symphony in a program of works by Dukas, Saint-Saens, Faure and Gounod at the 92d Street Y tomorrow night at 8 and Sunday afternoon at 3.

THEATER: 'CRIME AND PUNISHMENT'
LEAD: When Raskolnikov, the lapsed student turned ax murderer, is consumed by delirium in the director Yuri Lyubimov's adaptation of ''Crime and Punishment,'' he doesn't merely sulk or weep - he becomes almost literally unhinged.
Raskolnikov (Randle Mell) stands against the blood-smeared white door of the scene of his crime and writhes in pain as if crucified.

FRENCH FILM SERIES AT MODERN ART MUSEUM
LEAD: The Museum of Modern Art is opening a film series today showcasing French movies made from 1955 to 1965 - the decade that marked the French cinema's great resurgence.
The series features films by then-newcomers Jean-Luc Godard, Francois Truffaut and Alain Resnais, as well as by film makers who were already established, such as Henri-Georges Clouzot, Rene Clement adn Robert Bresson.


CHANGE CONSIDERED IN CONRAIL BRAKES
LEAD: The Federal railroad administrator said today that he might ask that all train engines operating in the Northeast Corridor be equipped with automatic braking systems that could help avoid collisions such as the one that killed 15 people Sunday.


Dole Hits the Road
LEAD: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas has not yet announced his candidacy for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination, but he is making what looks very much like a national campaign trip this weekend.
Senator Larry Pressler of South Dakota, who just announced his support of Senator Dole, has invited him to tour his home state, which will hold its Presidential primary on Feb.


VETERANS AGENCY FINED FOR DESTROYING DATA
LEAD: Ruling that the Veterans Administration had unlawfully and ''recklessly'' destroyed thousands of documents, a Federal judge today imposed about $115,000 in penalties against the V.A.
The agency had been ordered to produce the documents in a lawsuit by veterans charging that they were exposed to radiation.


BOOKS OF THE TIMES
LEAD: IRON &amp; SILK.
By Mark Salzman. 211 pages.
Random House. $16.95.
IN 1982 Mark Salzman, fresh from studying Chinese at Yale, arrived in China for a two-year stint teaching English at a medical college in Changsha, the capital of Hunan Province.
His first impressions were unpromising.
Changsha turned out to be dirty and drab; the college campus was a mass of gray concrete ''mired in a swamp of loose bricks, cinderblocks and grey mud,'' and the heavy hand of officialdom seemed omnipresent.


N.C.A.A. Opposes Playoff
LEAD: Despite the attention and high television ratings generated by the Penn State-Miami Fiesta Bowl game on Jan. 2, the National Collegiate Athletic Association is not going to establish any form of Division I-A football playoff in the foreseeable future, according to university presidents and athletic officials.


LEGACY OF THE SCANDALS: NEW RULES AND MORE CONFUSION AT CITY HALL
LEAD: A year after the corruption scandals of 1986 began, it is clear that they have forced New York City's government to make changes - substantive and stylistic, dramatic and limited - in the way it runs itself.


South Africa Tightens Curbs on Newspapers
LEAD: The South African Police issued an order today under emergency regulations banning newspapers from publishing reports or advertisements that improve the image or defend the policies of banned organizations.


TREASURY CHIEF SAYS REAGAN WON'T AGREE TO INCREASING TAXES
LEAD: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said today that President Reagan would not agree to increases in ''sin taxes'' on cigarettes or liquor or an oil import fee.


BROWNS ARE RUNNING AGAIN AS MACK DISCOVERS OLD FORM
LEAD: Kevin Mack works himself into a harness so his left shoulder will not be jerked around, and he fits his Browns helmet gingerly over his head, gently adjusting the chin strap to his swollen jaw.


REAGAN AIDE SAYS CONTRAS CAN FELL SANDINISTAS
LEAD: The Reagan Administration's top official on Latin American affairs predicted today that if Congress keeps supplying military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, the Soviet-backed Sandinista Government ''will not survive.''


ISRAEL REPORTEDLY PERSUADED U.S. TO RESUME IRAN ARMS SHIPMENTS
LEAD: A report by the Senate Intelligence Committee indicates that Israel played the central role in persuading the White House to resume arms shipments to Iran in January 1986 by assuring Washington that Teheran had promised to arrange the immediate release of American hostages in Lebanon, a senior White House aide said tonight.


53 FOR JORDAN
LEAD: Michael Jordan scored a regular-season career-high 53 points to lead the Chicago Bulls to a 121-117 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers tonight.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A television review in some copies Tuesday of ''Do Not Enter: The Visa War Against Ideas'' omitted the name of a co-producer.
The documentary was produced by Robert Richter and Catherine Warnow.


GUIDRY PARTS WITH YANKESS, BUT RANDOLPH RE-SIGNS
LEAD: Ron Guidry, the anchor of the Yankees' pitching staff for 10 years, failed to reach agreement on a new contract by last night's midnight signing deadline, effectively ending his glittering Yankee career in a negotiation that his agent called ''embarrassing and humiliating'' and that concluded with the two sides only $50,000 apart.


POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
LEAD: Vintage Jazz at the Vineyard, Vineyard Theater, 309 East 26th Street (683-0696).
The fourth year and seventh season of Vintage Jazz concerts is part of the Vineyard Theater's first Old Wave Festival, made up of one-time avant-garde music that is now rear guard - early music of the 18th century and traditional jazz from the early 20th century.


FORMER ALLY CHALLENGES MAYOR IN PHILADELPHIA
LEAD: Charging that Mayor W. Wilson Goode was guilty of ''ineptitude and mismanagement'' that crushed this city's renaissance under the ''rubble of unfulfilled programs and promises,'' a former District Attorney announced his candidacy today for the Democratic Mayoral nomination.

MEMO SAID ISRAEL SUPPLIED CONTRAS
LEAD: President Reagan was told by his advisers last September that American intelligence had detected Israeli arms shipments to the Nicaraguan rebels, according to Congressional and Administration sources who have seen a White House memorandum on the subject.


U.S. Oil Data Revised Down
LEAD: The drop in United States oil production during 1986 was about four times as sharp as the Government had previously reported, according to new statistics published today by the Energy Department.

LEAD: The Circle Repertory Company production of ''Burn This!,'' a new play by Lanford Wilson, starring John Malkovich, will play only 21 performances when it opens next month because of a film commitment by Mr.
Malkovich, the company said yesterday.

LEAD: The Opera Orchestra of New York, under the direction of Eve Queler, will present a concert performance of Verdi's ''Battaglia di Legnano'' at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts tonight at 8.
The cast will include Eva Baraian, Gregory Hopkins and Carlos Serrano.
Tickets are $11 to $15.
Lehman Center is on the campus of Lehman College on Bedford Park Boulevard West and Goulden Avenue in the northwest Bronx, a short walk from the Bedford Park subway stops of the IND D train and IRT No.

A SAMPLER OF DANCE WITH VERVE AND VISION
LEAD: ONE of the pleasures of the annual Joyce Sampler program at the Joyce Theater is that it offers the chance to see a wide variety of choreographic styles in a relatively concentrated form.
This weekend the program, which runs through Jan. 18, features Ze'eva Cohen and Dancers tonight and Sunday night, the Eleo Pomare Dance Company and Remy Charlip Dances tomorrow afternoon and evening, respectively, and Marta Renzi and the Project Company on Sunday afternoon.


Sulfite to Be Listed on Labels
LEAD: Meat and poultry processors will have to list sulfiting agents on labels when products contain confirmable levels of the chemicals, beginning on July 9, the Agriculture Department announced Wednesday.

It's a sound idea that deserves support.

CONTRA CASH LINKED TO NORTH
LEAD: Lieut.
Col.
Oliver L. North controlled cash and other money for Nicaraguan rebel expenses during two years of secretly overseeing an aid network for them, according to sources in the Administration and the rebels, who are also known as the contras.


VAST ARCS ENCIRCLE GALAXIES
LEAD: Highly sensitive photography has shown the existence of vast luminous arcs encircling at least two distant galaxies.
According to the National Optical Astronomy Observatories, which announced the finding, the arcs are the longest continuous features ever detected by optical telescope.


THRIFT UNIT INDICTMENT
LEAD: Allan H. Pearlstein, one of the principal shareholders of Old Court Savings and Loan Inc., was indicted today by a city grand jury on six counts of felony theft from the defunct thrift institution.
The indictment accuses Mr.
Pearlstein, 56 years old, of stealing $695,786 from Old Court and ''related entities'' from August 1983 through October 1984.

Age and Forgetfulness Do Not Go Together
LEAD: To the Editor:


NAVY TO CUT ROBINSON'S TOUR TO 2 YEARS
LEAD: David Robinson, the 7-foot-1-inch senior center who has been exciting pro basketball scouts since he started scoring points for Navy but who was thought to be untouchable until 1992, yesterday moved three years closer to a possible pro career.


The Facts of Life of Teen Pregnancy
LEAD: ''We were asked to look at information and the facts,'' said Dr.
Daniel D. Federman of Harvard Medical school, who headed a National Research Council panel on teen-age pregnancy.
The facts the group found are appalling - fully justifying an aggressive birth control campaign for youngsters.


LIMITED DUTY
LEAD: President Reagan in the study of the residence area of the White House working on his State of the Union Message.
He is scheduled to deliver the speech on Jan. 27.
It was his first full day home after undergoing prostate surgery Monday.
Mr.
Reagan is expected to resume a limited schedule next week.


For Soviet Emigres, Still a Curtain
LEAD: Mikhail Gorbachev continues to make remarkable changes in the Soviet Union.
Boris Pasternak's long-banned ''Doctor Zhivago'' will be published within the year.
The K.G.B. has expelled one of its own top officials for harassing a reporter seeking to expose corruption.
Yet in contrast to these positive changes inside the Soviet Union comes a seeming clampdown on emigration.


Chief Steps Down at Crazy Eddie
LEAD: Crazy Eddie Inc., the retailer that advertises ''insane'' prices, said yesterday that its founder, Eddie Antar, had resigned as chief executive, for personal reasons.
The company did not elaborate, but several analysts and other Wall Street sources said they understood that the 39-year-old executive was ill and had not been in the company's Edison, N.J., office since early


Fatal Crash in Southern New Jersey
LEAD: Firefighters at the wreckage of head-on collision early yesterday on the White Horse Pike in Atco.
Two people were killed when their westbound car veered into oncoming traffic and collided with another car.

LEAD: 'Bookies' Will End, But No Whimpering


Jennifer Ringo Married to James Conlon
LEAD: Jennifer Elizabeth Ringo, an opera singer, and James J. Conlon, a conductor, were married at St.
Patrick's Cathedral in New York yesterday.
The Rev.
Joseph F. Buckley performed the ceremony.


TURNER DISCUSSING SALE OF POSSIBLY LARGE STAKE
LEAD: Ted Turner, head of the financially troubled Turner Broadcasting System, may be negotiating to sell a significant piece of his 80 percent stake in the television and cable company, Wall Street analysts and sources close to Turner Broadcasting said yesterday.


WALL STREET CONTINUES 1987's RALLY
LEAD: Stock prices crept higher yesterday, giving Wall Street its sixth straight gain and permitting the Dow Jones industrial average to remain above the 2,000 level.


Baldrige Leaves Hospital
LEAD: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige was released today from a hospital here, where he had been treated for a lung ailment.
Mr.
Baldrige. 64 years old, was accompanied by his wife, Midge, and daughter, Megan Murray.
Dr.
Jonathan M. Samet said Mr.
Baldrige suffered from an irritation of the lining of his lungs and heart, which had been complicated by pneumonia.


BIG JOHANNESBURG STORE IS DAMAGED IN BOMBING
LEAD: A bomb ripped through parts of a leading department store in central Johannesburg today, causing a fire and extensive damage.


PURDUE TRANSFER
LEAD: Purdue's new football coach, Fred Akers, announced yesterday that the Boilermakers' quarterback, Jeff George, would transfer to another school. ''To build the kind of program I want at Purdue, I want young men who love Purdue and want to be here.
That is not the case with Jeff, so I wish him luck,'' Akers said, adding that he believed George would hold a news conference in Indianapolis today.


Correction
LEAD: A correction in this space yesterday in some copies, referring to a chart in Sports Pages last Tuesday, misidentified the league in which the Buffalo Bills and the San Diego Chargers played in 1964.
They were members of the American Football League, which merged with the National Football League in 1970.


Warning to Journalists
LEAD: Reed Irvine, chairman of Accuracy in Media Inc., is seeking contributions for an advertising campaign to persuade journalists to ''take a more serious view of their responsibilities'' in reporting the Iran arms affair.

LEAD: ''This is a very bullish employment report.'' - Jay N. Woodworth of the Bankers Trust Company.  [ 50:1. ]

LEAD: The singer Steve Winwood received five Grammy Award nominations Thursday to lead the rock category, while Peter Gabriel, Paul Simon and the jazz trumpeter Wynton Marsalis received four nominations each.
