LEAD: A mood of disquiet and fears of violence gripped France today as a succession of public-sector strikes continued to cripple the national railroad, the Paris subway and bus systems and the state-run power company.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: Golf  O'Grady Grabs Lead: Mac O'Grady stumbled a bit coming down the home holes yesterday but managed to hold on to a one-stroke lead after three rounds of the 35th Tournament of Champions, at Carlsbad, Calif.
The powerful hitter rescued a bogey 5 after two bunker shots on 18 to finish with two-under-par 70 for a 54-hole total of nine-under 207.

LEAD: THE seventh annual National Inventors Conference will be held at the Sheraton Crystal City Hotel in Arlington, Va., on Feb. 6.
The sponsors are the Bureau of National Affairs Inc., and the Patent and Trademark Office.

LEAD: Pat Quinn, the coach of the Los Angeles Kings,was expelled from the National Hockey League last night pending investigation of charges that he signed a contract and accepted money to become general manager of the Vancouver Canucks next season, the league announced.

LEAD: The Allied Stores Corporation is being forced into some drastic actions that it could have taken long before any acquirer hoisted its standard at the retailer's door.

BABY BOOM GENERATION MAKES UP THIRD OF POPULATION, REPORT SAYS
LEAD: The baby boom generation now makes up nearly one-third of the nation's population, a new study by the Census Bureau shows.


PHIL SEGHI
LEAD: Phil Seghi, who hired Frank Robinson as baseball's first black manager with the Cleveland Indians in 1975 and signed Pete Rose for the Cincinnati Reds in 1960, died Thursday in Thousand Oaks, Calif., after a long illness with cancer.
He was 68 years old.
Mr.
Seghi, who was the senior player-personnel adviser with the Indians, had served as vice president and general manager with the club after joining the organization in 1971.


KNICKS TOP 76'ERS ON ROAD
LEAD: It had been so long since the Knicks last won a game at the Spectrum against the Philadelphia 76ers that the lone survivor of that team, Bill Cartwright, didn't remember it without prodding.
He remembers the losses, however, almost all 17 of them - including two playoff losses - over more than five years.


OUTDATED TEXTBOOKS ARE CITED IN SURVEY
LEAD: More than half of the state's elementary school students are using outdated science textbooks, according to a State Board of Education study of programs in Connecticut public schools.

LEAD: Not long after a South Carolina schoolteacher sent his manuscript to a New York literary agent, the agent, Julian Bach, telephoned him to report that Houghton Mifflin had accepted the novel for $7,500.

CONSUMER DEBT RISE SLOWS
LEAD: Americans took on $4.02 billion more in consumer debt than they paid off in November, the lowest monthly increase since August, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.


JURY FINDS A MAN GUILTY OF RACIAL SLURS
LEAD: An Essex County jury found a 21-year-old Maplewood man guilty yesterday of painting racial slurs in 1983 on the home of a black family that lived near his home.


DUKE NAMES COACH
LEAD: Steve Spurrier, a Heisman Trophy winner while playing quarterback for the University of Florida in 1966, was named the head football coach at Duke University yesterday.
He replaces another former quarterback, Steve Sloan, who resigned earlier this week to become athletic director at his alma mater, the University of Alabama.

LEAD: Mayor Koch may have tried to disavow the Giants, calling them a foreign team because they play in New Jersey, but Mayor George Voinovich of Cleveland is riding the wave of popularity generated by the Browns.

LEAD: Five astronauts who have performed ambitious and dangerous missions in space were named today to fly the first space shuttle into orbit once the current repair operations on the shuttle fleet are complete.


PATENTS
LEAD: A speech-controlled electronic watch was patented this week for a Swiss company.
The user pronounces coded words that regulate starting, stopping, timing and an alarm.
The vocabulary may contain 15 words.
Patent No. 4,635,286, granted to N.C.
Bui and two co-inventors, was assigned to Asulab S.A. of Bianne, Switzerland.

LEAD: Texas Instruments said today that it had reached agreements settling its patent infringement lawsuits against two Japanese semiconductor manufacturers, but that it would continue its court action against seven other foreign companies.

FOR GIANTS' FANS, EUPHORIA IS TEMPERED WITH DISBELIEF
LEAD: The giddiness that Giants fans are feeling this week - the smiles they exchange that make words unnecessary - is still tinged with lingering disbelief.
Is this for real or a dream?
Yet fans talk confidently of spending Jan. 25 in Pasadena, Calif., where the Giants would make their first Super Bowl appearance.


RANGERS FALL A SAVE SHORT
LEAD: Considering what Bob Froese had done all night, the way he had stopped so many shots in so many contorted positions, and only considering that, then maybe he should have been expected to stop one more.


Black Leaders Meet Santucci Over Attack
LEAD: An ad hoc committee of 25 black civic, religious and elected leaders met yesterday with the Queens District Attorney, John J. Santucci.
Afterward, the group voiced confidence in the prosecutor's investigation into the racial attack in Howard Beach last Dec. 20.


Correction
LEAD: Because of editing errors, a Bangkok dispatch on Jan. 3 about Prince Norodom Ranariddh, a Cambodian guerrilla leader who is Prince Norodom Sihanouk's son, incorrectly described his travels and the relative size of the Khmer People's National Liberation Front.
Prince Ranariddh said he shuttled back and forth between the Cambodian border and Bangkok, not Beijing.


Diana Brooks Named President of Sotheby's
LEAD: Diana D. Brooks was named president of Sotheby's Inc., the North American division of the international auction house, yesterday, replacing John L. Marion, who retains the title of chairman.


Correction
LEAD: An article yesterday about former New York City officials who have faced prosecution because of the corruption scandal described Stanley M. Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic leader, incorrectly.
Last month, after he was found guilty of corruption, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court suspended him from practicing law.


Cutting Bank Card Interest
LEAD: IF consumer groups get what they are lobbying for this year in various states and in Washington, banks offering credit cards would be prohibited from charging interest rates as high as the 17 to 19 percent that most consumers now pay.


OFFICER SUSPENDED FOR TRAFFIC ACCIDENT
LEAD: An off-duty police officer who was driving the wrong way on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive early yesterday was arrested and suspended from duty after her car struck two other cars and injured two people, one of them critically, the police said.


Pretoria Bans Meetings By Educational Group
LEAD: The Government banned an unofficial education group today from holding meetings to discuss its alternative program for black schools.


BILL TYNES, ARTISTIC DIRECTOR OF NEW AMSTERDAM THEATER
LEAD: Bill Tynes, the founder and the artistic director of the New Amsterdam Theater Company, died yesterday morning at his parents' home in Placentia, Calif., of complications from acquired immune deficiency syndrome, his mother said.
He was 30 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Lighter Ignites Oil Fumes
LEAD: An oil company employee trying to determine the fuel level in an oil tanker truck lit a cigarette lighter, but he escaped serious injury in the resulting explosion, officials said Thursday. ''When he flipped the cigarette lighter, the vapors ignited and blew the end of the tanker out,'' a battalion chief said.


ACCORD REACHED ON AUTISTIC SCHOOL'S METHODS
LEAD: A 16-month legal dispute over treatment at a school for severely autistic teen-agers and young adults has ended with a judge approving an agreement that allows the school to use physical punishment as treatment in some cases.


DRUG SEEMS TO HALT AN INFECTION CAUSED BY THE AIDS VIRUS
LEAD: In a six-month study, the drug ribavirin appeared to halt the progression of an early form of infection caused by the AIDS virus, a drug company announced today.


Good Governor, Clever Candidate
LEAD: To judge by Governor Cuomo's annual report on New York, the state of the state is flourishing; the state of the candidate is not all it should be.
Whether or not the report is intended to support a run for President, it shows him to be talented and successful but also, as the British say, too clever by half.


SNOW BLANKETS THE MIDWEST
LEAD: Kerry Olson, left, and Ricky Barker trying out ski boards in St.
Louis in a snowstorm.
The storm left parts of the Middle West under up to nine inches of snow, forcing the closing of some schools and disrupting traffic.
One traffic death was attributed to the storm. (AP)


SMITHSONIAN SETS A MINORITIES GOAL
LEAD: The Smithsonian Institution today announced plans, including a greater diversification of exhibits, to attract more minorities to its collections and programs.

LEAD: In establishing retail beachheads on the Thames, a one-time public-relations man from Argentina, a Dane who was once an oilman and a former haircutter from Casablanca have skirmished with their predecessors and each other, embroiling London in what might be called ''designer wars.''


A NEW BLACK TOWNSHIP IS RESIGNED, NOT DEFIANT
LEAD: The weekend begins early here, a hiatus in a segregated black township from a workweek in a segregated white town, and it is celebrated in a ritualistic kind of way.

LEAD: To the Editor:


CHAIRMAN OF GUINNESS WITHDRAWS FROM POST
LEAD: The chairman of Guinness P.L.C., Ernest Saunders, announced tonight that he was stepping down until a British Government investigation of the brewing company was completed.


SUFFOLK POLITICS: DEMOCRACY IN ACTION BUT CHAOS IN CONTROL
LEAD: The recent organizational meeting of the Suffolk County Legislature had not received advance billing as an entertainment event.
But a crowd of 250 people, many carrying brightly colored, often witty signs, clearly anticipated a show.
They were not to be disappointed.
The chaos last Friday began soon after the Pledge of Allegiance, when two legislators started shouting at each other across the room, arguing bitterly about proper procedures and professional courtesy.

7% FOR ALL 1986
LEAD: The unemployment rate fell two-tenths of a percentage point last month, to 6.6 percent, the lowest level since March 1980, the Labor Department reported today.


3 CHARGED WITH SHIPPING OIL EQUIPMENT TO LIBYA
LEAD: A businessman from Scotland and two oil industry executives from a New Orleans suburb have been arrested here on charges of shipping oilfield equipment to Libya, in violation of an embargo ordered last year by President Reagan.


US Sprint Joins In Contract Bid
LEAD: US Sprint Communications said it had teamed up with the Electronic Data Systems Corporation to join the bidding war for a $4.5 billion contract to re-equip the Government's telecommunications system, the world's largest private phone network.
US Sprint, a joint venture of the GTE Corporation and United Telecommunications Inc., said it would act as the subcontractor in its bid for the 10-year Government contract.


MATCHING FUND FROM FAMILY PROVIDES $1,000 FOR THE NEEDIEST
LEAD: A gift of $1,000 from a family in Katonah, N.Y., to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund resulted from a matching fund in which all members of the family participated.
Sally and Robert Krefting explained in a note that the total spent by family members on Christmas gifts was matched by their contribution.


G.M. Layoffs
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it will place 350 workers on indefinite layoff at two Hydramatic division plants in southwestern Michigan effective Jan. 30.
The layoffs were prompted by lower demand for cars using automatic transmissions produced at the plants in Three Rivers and Constantine, according to Allen Coleman, manager of the division's St.


NOW, FOR CRIMSON TIDE, WINNINGS'S NOT ENOUGH
LEAD: For more than half a century, in a tradition that brought the South national championships and a cause for pride in the barren decades when it had little to rejoice about, the University of Alabama has been one of the nation's great football powers, quickening the region's blood flow on Saturday afternoons.

CITY IS ACCUSED OF IGNORING PACT COVERING SHELTER
LEAD: The Legal Aid Society charged yesterday that a city shelter for the homeless had violated a pledge made in court that it not admit pregnant women and young children because of the health threat posed by the presence of lead paint in the shelter.


PLAN TO BUILD BASIC HOUSING HITS COST SNAG
LEAD: Almost a year after a group of the city's leading developers offered to build 3,000 apartments for middle-income New Yorkers at no profit, the plan faces collapse unless the city helps pay for it.


BOND RULING ON HOLD
LEAD: The fate of Alan Bond's America's Cup syndicate remained tenuous in Fremantle, Australia, yesterday when a five-man jury adjourned, putting off for at least another day any action to resolve a dispute over a sail between Bond's Australia IV and Kevin Parry's Kookaburra team.
At stake is the Bond syndicate's continued presence as an America's Cup defender.

Giants Are Wound Up As Preparations Wind Down
LEAD: Before the Giants routed the San Francisco 49ers, 49-3, in the playoffs last Sunday, the Giants' intensity level was high.
It is so high for this Sunday's championship game against the Washington Redskins that even a player on injured reserve is almost a nervous wreck.


Platinum Rises to Limit; Oil Advances Strongly
LEAD: Platinum futures prices surged higher yesterday, with increased industrial demand cited for gains that reached the limit allowed for a day's trading.


N.C.A.A. Cuts Recruiting
LEAD: Recruiting seasons were reduced in football and basketball and players received permission to give one complimentary game pass to someone other than a relative or student as delegates ended the National Collegiate Athletic Association convention today.


CAR IS RAMMED BY DUMP TRUCK AT JAMAICA BAY
LEAD: A man and a woman were seriously injured yesterday when a sand-laden dump truck struck and overturned their car on a causeway over Jamaica Bay in Queens.
The police said up to three men in the truck fled on foot as another motorist halted and fired gunshots into the air.


'IDEOLOGICAL GROUNDS' ARE A MYTH
LEAD: Several individuals have complained to the media in recent months that the United States Government denied them visas on ''ideological grounds.'' This is untrue.
Those denied visas may coincidentally espouse positions that are unpopular in the United States.
But that is not the reason they are refused entry.


WILLIAMS SHOULDERS NETS' LATEST LOSS
LEAD: Buck Williams allowed the weight of the game to fall heavily on his shoulders.
He blamed himself when the night was done, assuming a large dose of responsibility because he was not in the game when the Nets needed his physical presence most.


Correction
LEAD: A Washington dispatch yesterday, about the Senate committee report on arms shipments to Iran, incorrectly attributed a comment about the report.
A reporter for The Times spoke by telephone not with Vice Adm.
John M. Poindexter but with his wife and understood her to be relaying a comment verbatim from the admiral.


RUSSIANS UPSTAGE A PLAY
LEAD: The nuances of the evening were not lost on Washingtonians Thursday as they gathered for the American premiere of the Russian director Yuri Lyubimov's production of ''Crime and Punishment'' at Arena Stage.


For Tasty Muffins, Smaller Is Better
LEAD: Most of the Brobdingnagian-size muffins that a lot of New Yorkers are eating for breakfast these days give muffins a bad name.
It is rare to find one of these giants that is moist.
Size, in part, is responsible; beating a lot of air into muffins makes them stale more quickly.

LEAD: Two days after his inauguration, Gov.
Bob Martinez took the witness stand in Federal District Court on Thursday and denied allegations that he took illegal campaign contributions and bribes when he was Mayor of Tampa.


DANGERS CITED 18 MONTHS EARLIER
LEAD: In an inspection 18 months ago, the Puerto Rico Fire Department found that the Dupont Plaza Hotel's fire alarm system was not working properly.


PATENTS
LEAD: Luther G. Simjian of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., received his 218th patent this week for a practice putting device that can be used indoors.
Golf balls are knocked across a ramp and a level area containing a cup.
Balls missing the cup land in a second pocket.
The equipment, called Multi-Zone, can be used in competition by several players.


BATTLE IS LOOMING ON ASBESTOS FUNDS
LEAD: Congressional proponents of Federal financing for a program to remove asbestos from public schools say they will oppose the Reagan Administration's attempt to rescind a $50 million appropriation for the program.

Owens-Illinois Stock Up Sharply
LEAD: The stock of the Owens-Illinois Corporation rose sharply in heavy trading yesterday on Wall Street primarily because of rumors that a new bid, perhaps at $60 a share, might be forthcoming.
The company received a takeover bid more than a month ago from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts &amp; Company.
At the end of the day, its stock was up $1.50 a share, to $55.25.

LEAD: Mike Estep, the tennis coach from Texas who since mid-1983 had guided Martina Navratilova to 10 Grand Slam singles titles, has parted company amicably with the world's No. 1 women's tennis player to move on to what he termed ''other challenges.'' ''Mike and I remain on very friendly terms,'' Navratilova said.

BROWNS' BYNER IS READY
LEAD: Earnest Byner and Kevin Mack, the tandem that rushed for more than 1,000 yards apiece for the Browns last season, will be reunited in Cleveland for tomorrow's American Football Conference championship game against the Denver Broncos.
The Browns said Byner would be activated today after being sidelined since the seventh game of the season with torn ankle ligaments.


2 Major Limits On I.R.A.'s
LEAD: A BIG negative in the new tax law is the two major restrictions put on the tax deductibility of contributions to Individual Retirement Accounts.

LEAD: There are precisely two spirited scenes in ''The Kindred'' - Kim Hunter's entire role.
She rises above this horror film's near-total banality as a dying scientist pleading with her son to end her secret experiment.
He must destroy her notebooks, the ''Anthony journals,'' she warns John.
When he asks, ''Who's Anthony?

LEAD: In the aftermath of the midnight madness in which talented free agents such as Ron Guidry, Tim Raines and Lance Parrish did not sign with their 1986 teams, people on both sides of baseball's combative labor front focused their attention yesterday on the effect the unprecedented departures could have on teams and players.

He sees everything, but with one possible exception when his team plays the Giants, and that's what worries Curtis Jordan of the Washington Redskins.


WILSON'S 'SALOME' WILL BE 'NORMAL'
LEAD: Robert Wilson is best known for putting on theatrical events that are silent or seven hours long or entirely lacking a story line or even all of the above.
Now he is trying very hard to stage an opera that can be considered ''normal.''


POLICE TRANSFER INTELLIGENCE CHEIF
LEAD: The head of the intelligence division of the New York City Police Department was transferred to another post yesterday, pending the outcome of an investigation into social contacts between the commander and a reputed organized-crime figure, the police said.

LEAD: Israeli jets rocketed Palestinian targets near Sidon today, and shellfire from Christian militiamen shut down the Beirut airport again.

LEAD: A Marine Corps helicopter practicing night landings crashed and burst into flames Thursday, killing all five crew members, officials said today.

Lena F. Edwards, who in 1964 received the Government's highest civilian honor, the Medal of Freedom, for her medical services to migrant laborers in Texas, died Dec. 3 at her home in Lakewood, N.J.
She was 86 years old.

He was 48 years old.

LEAD: The E.F.
Hutton Group said yesterday that it would report a ''substantial'' 1986 loss because of a $130 million reserve it has created to cover client losses on several types of securities and tax-shelter investments.


DEAD STUNT MAN IS REMEMBERED AS A TOP ARTIST
LEAD: Victor Magnotta was the consummate movie stunt man.
He drove cars off bridges, turned flips on horseback, rappelled down the sides of burning buildings and scrambled up 100-foot masts on tall ships.
He was known as ''the Bear.''

LEAD: Iran mounted a new offensive in the Persian Gulf war early today, and both sides reported heavy fighting near the southern Iraqi city of Basra.

LEAD: Jon L. Lester, one of three white youths charged in a racial attack on three black men in Howard Beach, Queens, will serve a one-to-three-year state prison term in another case in ''protective custody,'' the state Commissioner of Correctional Services ordered yesterday.

Irish Music
LEAD: The flutists Jack Coen, from Galway, and Michael Preston, from Sligo, will play Irish music tonight at 9 P.M. at the Eagle Tavern, 355 West 14th Street (924-0275).
Tickets are $5.

LEAD: A Manhattan doctor arrested on bigamy charges will probably not be prosecuted because of a legal technicality here and the unwillingness of prosecutors to pursue the case in Iowa, where he is said to have married his second wife in December.

LEAD: Arthur Rosenblatt has just returned from a field trip to help him with the planning of Washington's newest museum.
He shows off an album of color photographs he took on his trip, which was not a pleasant one.


AGNEW ASKS $6 MILLION IN A SUIT ON ARMS SALES
LEAD: Former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew has filed a Federal lawsuit charging he was defrauded of more than $2 million he earned for arranging a deal between a military contractor and the Argentine Government, according to court files unsealed yesterday.


An Embassy Ball
LEAD: Washington is home to 139 foreign embassies, from Afghanistan, Algeria and Antigua to Zaire, Zambia and Zimbabwe.
But few people are aware there is also a Confederate Embassy here.


UNION LEADERS CONDEMN RACIAL VIOLENCE
LEAD: Leaders of 20 trade unions holding a news conference yesterday at the offices of the American Federation of Musicians on West 42d Street.
The interracial group denounced ''the vicious, racist violence'' in Howard Beach Dec. 20, when white youths chased and beat three blacks.
One was killed by a car as he tried to run away.

OPPOSITION TESTS IT
LEAD: The Sandinista Government put a new Constitution into effect today, and opposition groups moved to take advantage of its provisions by staging protest marches in two cities.


SEARCH FOR CREW RESUMES
LEAD: Coast Guard rescue teams resumed their search today after finding one of five crew members who were missing after their fishing boat capsized.
The survivor, Allen Louzon, 30 years old, of Narragansett, was found in a life raft 30 miles south of Martha's Vineyard on Thursday.
The 73-foot fishing boat, the Andrew &amp; Allison, went down Wednesday night about 50 miles off Point Judith, officials said.

WITNESS IN BABY M TRIAL TESTIFIES ON DISEASE'S EFFECTS IN PREGNANCY
LEAD: A neurologist testified in the Baby M trial today that it was ''medically reasonable'' for Dr.
Elizabeth Stern to avoid pregnancy because she suffered from a mild case of multiple sclerosis.


VALENTINE HONORED
LEAD: Bobby Valentine, who in his second season as manager of the Texas Rangers, led them to a second-place finish, will receive the William A. (Bill) Shea Distinguished Little League Graduate Award at next Sunday's dinner of the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America.
Valentine, who played Little League baseball in Stamford, Conn., in 1961 and 1962, will be honored as the first former Little Leaguer to manage a major league team.


UNEMPLOYMENT RATE IN 1986 IN NEW YORK WAS AT 12-YEAR LOW
LEAD: The unemployment rate in New York last year was the lowest in 12 years, and the New Jersey rate was the lowest in 16 years, according to Federal statistics released yesterday.


SENIOR BOWL CHANGES
LEAD: In light of the dismissal Thursday of Coach John Mackovic by the Kansas City Chiefs, officials of the Senior Bowl football game at Mobile, Ala., announced yesterday a change of coaching assignments for the game among graduating seniors to be played next Saturday.
Mackovic had been scheduled to coach the North all-star team against a South squad coached by John Robinson of the Los Angeles Rams.


Oklahoma Bank Sold by F.D.I.C.
LEAD: The Security National Bank and Trust Company of Norman, Okla., has been closed and sold to two Arkansas bank holding companies by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
Security National, which was closed Thursday afternoon by the Comptroller of the Currency, had total assets of about $200 million and deposits of $175 million.

PIERRE M. GEORGE
LEAD: Pierre M. George, senior officer of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America, died Thursday at Roosevelt Hospital after a long illness.

Pratt &amp; Whitney Retirement Plan
LEAD: Pratt &amp; Whitney has announced that nearly 2,000 salaried workers in four states have agreed to early retirement or voluntary terminations under a program to cut payroll costs.
The voluntary response means the East Hartford-based jet engine builder does not expect to lay off any workers to reach its goals, a spokesman, David Long, said.

LEAD: Rupert Murdoch made another surprise move today in the Australian media battle by substantially increasing his offer for the Melbourne-based Herald and Weekly Times Ltd. from $1.2 billion (United States), to $1.5 billion.

LEAD: TEN years ago, George Steinbrenner introduced walkie-talkies to baseball.

In more recent years, he has continued to borrow football techniques, making extensive use of films, as football coaches do.

LEAD: Along with the Acropolis and a few other sites of antiquity, the museums of Athens are the principal attractions of a city that increasingly disappoints visitors by falling short of its renown.
The museums compensate, by their variety and interest, for a capital that has suffered more than most from rapid urban growth and the effects of air pollution, noise and traffic.


COMFORT IN AGING WITH GRACE
LEAD: The great days are gone - it is no matter; No lines come easy now upon my tongue.
The world has been in crisis all my life What else could I do but hold on as it spun And say my little say and sing my song?
My causes all were won - or they were lost; And now my friends depart and leave me lonely -And yet - to see the blossoms in the springtime To watch the sunset hover on the sea And know that the one I love is by my side Oh lucky was I - lucky I remain.

Peru
LEAD: To the Editor: We enjoyed Nicholas D. Kristof's views and coverage of Peru and Cuzco (Travel, Oct. 5), a country full of history and art.
Unfortunately there is an underside to a trip to these areas; currently the country is living in fear and anxiety due to terrorism.
As Mr.
Kristof says, the Peruvian army is quite visible everywhere; military and security guards armed with machine guns are part of the landscape.

NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Chicago; New Protection For Tenants
LEAD: A CONTROVERSIAL and far-reaching tenants'-rights ordinance has been added to the city's municipal code, strengthening the rights of some 1.5 million renters and alarming many landlords.
It allows tenants to withhold rent if landlords fail to make ''necessary'' repairs that the tenants request, or to have the repairs made themselves and deduct the cost from their rent.

BRAVING EPILEPSY'S STORM
LEAD: I WITNESSED AN EPILEPTIC seizure for the first time in 1979, when I was 18.
In the center of my college dining hall, a young man who worked in the kitchen had collapsed in a convulsion.
Four students quickly piled on top of him.
His arms and legs jerked violently and, in the process of trying to hold him down, the students seemed to be smothering him.

THE BIG BUSINESS OF SMALL BUSINESS
LEAD: ON any given day, 2.5 million of the country's businesses are up for sale.
And while much is heard about the large companies that come on the block, 98 percent of the businesses looking for buyers fall into the small- to medium-size category, those with yearly sales of less than $30 million.
Yet, the number of business-brokerage offices equipped to serve this huge market are few; only 3,000 nationwide, compared with 150,000 real-estate brokerage offices - even though business sales account for $300 billion a year, $50 billion more than real-estate sales generate yearly.

LEAD: An unsafe bridge the city has wanted to tear down for three years will not be dismantled until 1,500 salmon and sturgeon make their spring trek up the Connecticut River, a state engineer said Thursday.

A Poet's Subject
LEAD: To the Editor:
I would like to thank David Kirby, the reviewer of my book of poems, ''Dominion'' (Oct. 12), for his descriptive, nonjudgmental approach to my writing.
I would also like to register a complaint, not so much against him as against the literary climate that makes it unremarkable to review a book of poetry without referring to its subject.


K.G.B. Exposes Its Own Abuses
LEAD: The Soviet press routinely exposes the misdeeds of Government functionaries and agencies.
But rarely does it attack top officials, let alone suggest that the K.G.B. might abuse its enormous powers.


BONDS ISSUED, STATE DRAWS CLOSER TO TRASH-TO-ENERGY SYSTEM
LEAD: THE Connecticut Resource Recovery Authority has issued bonds for a $42 million waste-to-energy plant to be built in Wallingford.
The action, taken in the final week of 1986, signaled the overcoming of another of many obstacles by the authority, which is seeking to erect six of the plants.


TO SOME CHINESE YOUTHS 'PRIVILEGE' IS NOT ENOUGH
LEAD: FROM Kunming in the far southwest to Beijing in the north, tens of thousands of college students have marched through the streets of China's cities in the last month, demanding more democracy.


A LANDMARK OF MISFEASANCE
LEAD: Seven members of the New York City Landmarks Commission last week issued a gratuitous warning against any proposal that would obscure part of the rear of the New York Public Library on 42d Street.
It was an act of arrogance against normal process that calls not just for criticism but also for corrective steps.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: N.H.L.
Flyers 5, Bruins 4: A goal by Murray Craven at 13 minutes 5 seconds of the third period snapped a 4-4 tie and gave the Philadelphia Flyers a 5-4 victory over the Bruins yesterday in Boston.
Craven took a pass from Tim Kerr in a scramble in front of the Boston net and whirled round to beat the Bruins' goalie, Bill Ranford.


Richmond
LEAD: For many years the anti-paradisal view that Richmond was a dull, conservative, rundown red-brick industrial town induced many travelers to skip the city.
Things have changed so much, however, that visitors now wish they could spend more time in the Capital of the Confederacy.

And a program by Ze'Eva Cohen and Dancers, presented on Friday at the Joyce Theater as part of the Joyce Sampler series, was no exception.


AROUND THE GARDEN
LEAD: This Week:


Finding the Unusual in Singapore
LEAD: Where do all those pinstriped Singapore yuppies go at the end of their air-conditioned days at the office?
Rosalind Mowe knows.
Some of them return to neighborhoods untouched by two decades of development: to the shop-houses of hundreds of Malay, Indian and Chinese craftsmen, to tearooms and to temples.


LETTER FROM CHINA - YOUNG WRITERS TEST THE LIMITS
LEAD: THE Government crackdowns on the recent demonstrations in Shanghai, Beijing and other Chinese cities demanding greater democracy and freedom of expression are a striking example of the constantly shifting climate of intellectual freedom in China.
Even in the more liberal ideological atmosphere of Deng Xiaoping's economic reforms, Chinese find it extremely dificult to gauge the boundaries on freedom of expression.

LEAD: JOHN CARDINAL O'CONNOR'S visit to Jerusalem has left a bittersweet taste.

LEAD: Assistant Secretary of State Richard W. Murphy, right, during a meeting yesterday in Cairo with Esmat Abdel-Meguid, Egypt's Foreign Minister.
Mr.
Murphy, who has been shuttling between Israel and Jordan to try to revive stalled peace initiative, is in Egypt to affirm American policy against supplying of arms to Iran, despite the recent revelation of the secret sale of arms to Iran by the United States.


THE DEMOCRATS' DILEMMA
LEAD: Coming back to the leadership of both houses of the Congress for the first time in six years, the Democrats are confronted by both an opportunity and a danger.
And how they handle this dilemma may very well determine whether they regain control of the White House in l988.


RECITAL: SAMUEL RAMEY
LEAD: THE chief distinctions of Samuel Ramey's singing, all discernible in the song recital he gave Friday night in a sold-out Carnegie Hall, arise from a vocal technique appreciably finer than that cultivated by his bass colleagues on the operatic scene.
He sings with sonorous power, but stops short of the force that might jeopardize steadiness and control.


Trying to Preserve An Unusual View
LEAD: Viewed from the west, the New York Public Library provides passers-by with a striking facade.
Twenty-six bands of light marble alternate with dark, vertical windows, distinguishing the 75-year-old building from others in the Beaux-Arts style.


Murder Conviction Is Gained Without Reporter's Evidence
LEAD: Prosecutors won a murder conviction today without the evidence of a reporter who refused to testify about an interview he had with the defendant.

LEAD: WE HAVE dismantled the Christmas tree.
And the little electric train, which had wound its way through the tiny village under the tree, no longer makes its scheduled stops.
Also, I have put away the last of the red candles and plaid bows.

A New Era
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:  Regarding the New York Yacht Club's America's Cup campaign, I would like to note that although it is the first time since the inception of the America's Cup in the 19th century that the club has not been involved in the final series, it is also the first time the New York Yacht Club has had to compete to be involved in the final series.

Hold the Replays
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:  I would like to put in a vote for the abolition of the National Football League's replay rule.
It was a joy to watch Penn State play Miami in the Fiesta Bowl without having to wait 4 minutes 10 seconds between plays. (a la Rams vs. Redskins).
ROBERT NISSEN

STATES ARE MAKING RECYCLING A MUST
LEAD: RECYCLING, a fever of the 1970's that cooled when concern over shortages eased and markets for recycled materials were slow to develop, is on the rise again.
New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are in various stages of implementing plans to recycle at least 25 percent of their solid waste and incinerate much of the rest to produce energy.

LEAD: It is no secret that the Knicks win games when their two most important frontcourt players, Patrick Ewing and Bill Cartwright, play well enough to dominate their respective defenders.
And when the two have failed, it has often been because the Knicks did not have a deep threat whose outside shot kept the opposing defense away from them.

V.A. Is Fined For Purging Files In Radiation Case
LEAD: The Veterans Administration must pay an estimated $115,000 in penalties for trying to purge its files of potentially embarrassing documents, a Federal judge in San Francisco ruled last week.
The agency had been ordered to supply the documents to a group representing 5,000 veterans who were exposed to radiation in Japan after World War II and in postwar tests of nuclear bombs.

Putting a Career On Hold
LEAD: Barbara Basler's article ''Putting a Career on Hold'' (Dec. 7) causes me grave concern.
The women she describes have ''made it to the top'' and yet choose not to juggle the demands of career, marriage and family, even with the supports that their salaries can provide.
The attention paid to this minority of women serves to distract attention from the majority of women who have always juggled these demands.

Dining in Paris
LEAD: To the Editor: It may be time to re-evaluate our stereotype of the Ugly American tourist in Europe.
We travel to France often and enjoy the country, its culture and its cuisine.

LEAD: The Town Council will try to solve its budget problems with a raffle in which half the pot goes to the winner and half to Elsmere's general fund.
Robert McWilliams, the town mansger, said he expected the first drawing to generate $200 to $400.

GAZEBO SITE
LEAD: A gazebo, proponents say, would enhance the artistic and recreational life of Chappaqua.
It would provide a place for concerts, lectures, exhibits and plays.
It would be esthetically pleasing, would attract audiences to school concerts and would become a focal point for the community.
No one has publicly disagreed; nevertheless, the gazebo has remained only an idea for the last six years, and following the latest rejection of a proposed site, it is likely to remain so longer.

How Big A Problem Is the Use of Steroids?
LEAD: I liken the recent steroid scare to the first warnings concerning cigarette smoking.
In the early 1960's, the potential hazards of nicotine were made public.
Most smokers continued to smoke and, in time, passed their dangerous habit to younger generations.
Today, the initial warnings condemning the use of steroids are being similarly ignored.

IN SHORT: FICTION
LEAD: CLAY WALLS.
By Kim Ronyoung. (Permanent Press, $18.95.) This earnest novel about Korean immigrants begins with a Los Angeles matron and her hired help bent over the rim of a toilet.
The employer is pointing out a missed stain to the plucky Asian heroine, who calls her ungrateful benefactor sangnyun (''low woman'') and tells her where to put the job.

THE BUSINESS CYCLE ROLLS OVER AND PLAYS DEAD
LEAD: NOT so long ago, an awesome force known as the business cycle drove the economy along much as the moon drives the tides and the sun the seasons.
It was almost always there, a perpetual motion machine that propelled the nation through booms and busts.
Yet for more than a couple of years now, the cycle has been dormant, with the economy moving listlessly month after month.

Across Manhattan former ''foodies'' are forfeiting a final mousse, and leaving a souffle flat.

FANCY CHICKENS HAVE MANY FANS
LEAD: FRAMED, life-size portraits of chickens hang on the walls of E. Lea Marsh's home in Old Lyme.
About 40 chickens scratch and squawk in their coops in his yard.
And sometimes the birds get their feathers fluffed and their toenails trimmed in his laundry room.


AN OLD QUARTER OF PARIS IS NEW AGAIN
LEAD: The Kingdom of the Down and Out is how the Marais district of Paris was described some 30 years ago.


MUSIC: BOLCOM'S RENDERING OF BLAKE'S 'SONGS'
LEAD: FOR nearly three years, there has been talk of William Bolcom's massive setting, for a Symphony-of-a-Thousand-sized ensemble, of William Blake's complete poetic collection, ''Songs of Innocence and of Experience.'' Finally, Friday night, New Yorkers got a chance to hear this 140-minute score live, courtesy of the Next Wave Festival, Lukas Foss and the Brooklyn Philharmonic, who presented it at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Opera House (the third and final performance is today at 2 P.M.


MEASURING AN OMINOUS CLOUD OVER THE PORT OF NEW YORK
LEAD: LINED up hull-to-hull at New York's passenger ship terminal on the Hudson River are six of the newest and largest ocean-going vessels in the world, each bigger than the Titanic, with a hull four stories high and a deck the length of three football fields.

HOW TO SURVIVE HEALTHFUL FOOD
LEAD: I ORDERED an individual salmon sandwich on whole-wheat toast, no dressing, and orange spice herb tea.
This was a lunch I carefully selected for its low calories and because of the calcium in the salmon, the fiber and wheat in the bread and the absense of tannic acid or caffeine in the tea.
Next to me at the counter, a man ordered a super-deluxe cheeseburger, rare, with french fries and a chocolate malt.

ORIGINS OF KAZAKHSTAN RIOTING ARE DESCRIBED
LEAD: The Soviet press began reporting new details this week of the violent anti-Russian rioting last month in the republic of Kazakhstan, and it placed part of the blame on ethnic segregation in local universities.


A POLICY THAT'S FAILED
LEAD: When Adm.
John Poindexter was asked why he had condoned an apparently illegal diversion of funds from the Iranian arms sale to the ''contras'' trying to overthrow the Sandinista regime in Nicaragua, President Reagan's former national security adviser is reported to have replied: ''I felt sorry for the contras.


BUCKING THE CLEAN WATER TIDE
LEAD: Fifteen years after the Clean Water Act, many rivers and lakes are still disgracefully polluted with sewage and poisonous chemicals.
Congress ardently desires to make America's waters swimmable and fishable once again.
But President Reagan persists in opposing a bill to renew the Clean Water Act.
The new House has just insisted on this legislation and the new Senate is about to do the same.


CHURCH DESIGN
LEAD: PLANS are under way to rebuild the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church, the Scarsdale landmark that was destroyed in a suspicious fire seven months ago.


NASA MOVE TIED TO BUDGET THREAT
LEAD: A new book says Dr.
James C. Fletcher, head of the space agency, put the Marshall Space Flight Center in charge of the shuttle's ill-fated rockets because Federal budget cutters were threatening to close the Alabama center, not because it had any special expertise in the creation of solid-fuel rockets.


Stepping Up The Contra Battle
LEAD: Amid assertions that they must act decisively and soon, thousands of United States-supported rebels have recently entered Nicaragua, and the Reagan Administration contended last week that the Sandinista Government might yet be overthrown.


Dawn L. Gordon To Become Bride

Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Charles Luks of North Royalton, Ohio.
A June wedding is planned.


Anne Hay Gurin Plans To Wed Stephen J. Tall
LEAD: Anne Hay Gurin and Stephen J. Tall plan to be married in June, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs.
Richard S. Gurin of Richlandtown, Pa., have announced.
Mr.
Tall is the son of Mr. and Mrs.
Anthony D. Tall of Cheshire, Conn.


Dollars for Saving
LEAD: WHEN he got the results of a survey of salaries in the National Hockey League, Alan Eagleson, the executive director of the N.H.L.
Players Association, thought he had stumbled on a financial anomaly.
Goaltenders, he found, were the lowest-paid players on Canadian teams and the highest-paid on American teams.


DARKNESS DESCENDS ON THE CITY OF LIGHTS
LEAD: LIFE seemed gray and gloomily unpredictable in France last week.
People waited hours for subway trains that never came.
Patients in clinics that lacked emergency power had to do without X-rays.
Stores were lighted by candles, and traffic lights went out, causing colossal tie-ups at major intersections.


Austrian Lederhosen to Weather the Alps
LEAD: In Austria lederhosen are not so much a pair of trousers as a way of life.
Worn summer and winter, casually and as Sunday best, these leather shorts or knickers are passed down from father to son, so that buying lederhosen is an investment that might cost anywhere from hundreds to thousands of dollars depending upon length (almost kneecap or knicker), embroidery (without or with, machine or hand) and whether the lederhosen is readymade or custom fit.


Cable TV
LEAD: Some classics, including two imports and lesser-known bargains top the film week on cable.
Two Vittorio de Sica imports cited by the New York Film Critics are on Bravo: the raffishly endearing ''Miracle in Milan'' (1951), with its marvelous, skybound fadeout - Tuesday at midnight.; and ''Umberto D'' (1952), a poignant study of an elderly pensioner, with superb performance by Carlo Battista in the central role - 11 P.M.


OLD-FASHIONED AND MODERN
LEAD: High Up Downtown Jan. 11 - There will be a buffet, dancing, an open bar and songs by Jean Carne at the annual New Year's reception of the Manhattan branch of the New York Urban League at Windows on the World.
Festivities from 1 to 5 P.M.
Tickets, $75, at the door.
A Switch for the ABT Jan. 19 - Dancers and directors of the American Ballet Theater will be displaying some of their lesser known talents as they host and help prepare a fund-raising black-tie dinner at the QV Restaurant, 63d Street at Madison Avenue.


How Big A Problem Is the Use of Steroids?
LEAD: Whether the use of anabolic steroids should be allowed is controversial; to deny their popularity and desired effect is foolish.
I am amazed at the continued lack of acknowledgement that anabolic steroids increase muscle size and strength.
Maybe there is little evidence to prove this but how many scientific studies have been conducted?


JAPANESE EDUCATION FADES AT THE FINISH
LEAD: AMERICANS hoping to improve education have cast many an envious glance at the Japanese.
In Japan, 95 percent of high school students graduate, compared to about 75 percent in the United States.
In subjects like math, the best American high school students barely reach the level of the average Japanese.


A CORRECTION
LEAD: An item in the Postings column Dec. 28 on Butler Plaza, a new condominium development at 44 Butler Place off Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn, incorrectly identified the architect.
It is Hirsch/ Danois Partnership, Architects &amp; Planners.


Is a Long- or Short-Term Loan the Best Strategy?
LEAD: THE new Federal tax law, which decreases the Government subsidy of mortgage-interest payments, raises some fundamental questions about borrowing strategies for home buyers and for owners thinking about refinancing to take advantage of current low rates.

JIRI MENZEL'S BITTERSWEET 'VILLAGE'
LEAD: In 1968, Jiri Menzel's ''Closely Watched Trains'' - a compassionately funny tale of a railway crew in Nazi-occupied Bohemia - won the Academy Award for the best foreign-language film.
The Czech director remembers that it was a turbulent time in America and that he received the Oscar two days after the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr.

KENNEDY PLANS RENEWED PUSH FOR LIBERAL AGENDA
LEAD: Senator Edward M. Kennedy today issued an unabashed liberal manifesto calling for new programs to assist the needy and criticizing ''ideologies such as laissez-faire and survival of the fittest.''


Bank Ethics
LEAD: To the Editor:  Before Mr.
Bennett continues to make broad-based accusations of ''scrappy marketing'' and misrepresentation by commercial banks (''Now, the Age of Fast Buck Banking,'' Dec. 14), let him attend a sales training session.
The strong presence of integrity that he will encounter will far outweigh the wrongs some banks have done while entering the ''financial services revolution.

LEAD: JAZZ GUITARIST AT 'Y' Barney Kessel had played jazz guitar with celebrity musicians for more than 40 years and had recorded 50 albums before he appeared in New York City for the first time as a headliner on his own.


COAST GUARD BOARDINGS PROVOKE COAST FISHERMEN
LEAD: Fishermen from Maine to Rhode Island are complaining that the Coast Guard's practice of routinely halting and boarding their vessels at sea is dangerous, costly and unnecessary.


AIR TRAVEL SETS SOME UNWANTED RECORDS
LEAD: LURED by discount fares and long weekends, travelers flocked to the skies in record numbers over the holiday season.
From the Friday before Christmas through the Sunday after New Year's Day, 21 million people, 8 percent more than last year, boarded flights in the United States.
In New York, all three airports matched or surpassed previous records for passenger levels on the holiday weekends.

TENNESSE DEFEATS KENTUCKY BY 75-68
LEAD: Tony White hit 32 points, including 8 in a row in a second-half run, as the Volunteers beat Kentucky, 75-68, today in a Southeastern Conference game.
White scored 22 of his game-high points in the second half when the Vols opened a 16-point lead.
Tennessee raised its record to 8-4 over all and 2-1 in the S.E.C.


A MARKET WHERE CHEMICAL IS KING
LEAD: *
When one of Chemical Bank's British lending officers was reassigned to Manhattan's garment district not long ago, he began to study more than just the American rag trade.
The heavily Jewish garment district is a place where speaking the language goes a long way, so the banker took up Yiddish.

LEAD: FOR a sport that attracts an upscale market, sailboat racing has attracted surprisingly little corporate support in the United States.

RACIST THREATS FAIL TO BREAK EFFORTS FOR A FREEDOM MARCH
LEAD: When Charles A. Blackburn moved to this hilly, rustic North Georgia county five years ago from the San Franciso Bay area, he thought is was a perfect balance: a cabin on a lake in woodsy country just 30 miles north of metropolitan Atlanta.
Mr.Blackburn is a white man, and he did not notice at first, so close to that city of racial harmony, that there were no black people in Forsyth County.

LEAD: WEDNESDAY night's ''Magic Flute'' by the Opera at the Academy company seemed specifically intended to enrage pious Mozarteans and at the same time cause the iconoclastic heart to beat a little faster.


Giving Credit To Chamberlain
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:  In the annual review of the year in sports (The New York Times, Dec. 28), Dave Anderson noted that the Celtics' overall record of 82-18, an .820 percentage, was the best in National Basketball Association history.
Actually, two championship teams led by Wilt Chamberlain - the 1971-72 Lakers, who were 81-16 (an .835 percentage), and the 1966-67 Philadelphia 76ers, who were 79-17 (an .823 percentage) - had better records according to winning percentage.


Q and A
LEAD: Releasing the Sponsor  Question: When my apartment building was coverted into a cooperative, the sponsor promised in amendments to the plan to make some repairs, including patching some serious leaks in the parking garage.
Recently, the board of directors gave the sponsor a general release from all claims concerning repairs in exchange for the sponsor's cooperation in renegotiating the building's mortgage at a lower interest rate.

LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
LEAD: NO PARKING RANDY GOTTLIEB, a senior at Great Neck North High School, may have the definitive answer to the school's lack of student parking space: The family chauffeur delivers him to and from school each day in a limousine.


THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER
LEAD: WITH the release last year of the Macintosh Plus, it looks as if Apple is beginning to make real inroads on business computing.
The current dominance of the I.B.M. standard has thrust into virtual oblivion the fact that brokers, insurance agents and financial analysts snapped up the original Apple II to computerize their work on their own individual machines.


ARE VOTERS ENTITLED TO REAGAN'S DIAGNOSIS?
LEAD: PRESIDENT REAGAN is back at the White House, recuperating from his third major operation since his inauguration, his second in 18 months.
A trans-urethral resection of Mr.
Reagan's prostate went smoothly last week, and a checkup found no evidence of a recurrence of the colon cancer removed in July 1985.

LEAD: Kelly Stouffer, the Colorado State quarterback, completed his first nine passes today, including two for touchdowns of 34 and 48 yards, to lead the West to a 24-21 victory in the 62d annual East-West Shrine Football Classic.


INFIGHTING HURTS TAMILS' CAUSE IN INDIA
LEAD: In a major development in the Sri Lankan civil war, infighting among rival Tamil rebel groups has begun to anger India and damage the guerrillas' reputation in the eyes of sympathizers.


A NEW SETTING FOR L'AMBROISIE
LEAD: Throughout his career, the Parisian chef and restaurateur Bernard Pacaud has lived by three common-sense rules: Keep the restaurant small, keep the menu simple, make sure the food is fresh.
Those rules managed to win him two Michelin stars in a very short time, and so it only made sense that when he outgrew his nine-table restaurant, L'Ambroisie, on the Left Bank, the new one would follow the same principles.


HOW THE GIANTS LIFTED THEIR GAME
LEAD: IN the far corner of the Giants' locker room, beyond the trainer's room, beyond the equipment room, beyond the washers and the dryers, is their big brightly lighted weight room.
It is here that the Giants players, quite literally, have lifted themselves into today's National Conference championship game.

LEAD: Although the economy of the New York-New Jersey region continued to grow last year - adding 135,000 jobs -a report released last week said that several suburban counties were beginning to show some signs of decreased economic strength.

LEAD: A Marine guard who had access to classified documents in the United States Embassy in Moscow is being held on suspicion of espionage after confessing he gave secrets to a female K.G.B. agent, Defense Department sources said today.

CARLESIMO STARTS TO LOOKUP
LEAD: PJ.
Carlesimo had sort of curled up at one end of the gymnasium, his knees tucked tightly under his chin, his back resting stiffly against a padded wall, as he studied the workout that unfolded before him.
In the past few days, there had been a victory of great importance and a defeat of great disappointment, and these were two things that Carlesimo could not fully dispatch from his mind as he watched his Seton Hall basketball team practice the other day.

THE 100TH CONGRESS IS FULL OF PARTISAN RISK
LEAD: AT the outset of the 100th Congress last week, the leaders tried to strike a bipartisan chord.
The new Democratic Speaker, Jim Wright of Texas, told the House of Representatives, ''We seek not confrontation but cooperation.'' At almost the same moment, Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader in the Senate, was saying, ''It is necessary that we start off on a totally nonpartisan, bipartisan basis.


Jazz
LEAD: Whenever two or more jazz musicians get together to play the same instrument on the same stage, tradition dictates a ''battle,'' an evening of virtuosic muscle-flexing and crowd-pleasing.
The ''Trumpet Summit'' at Fat Tuesday's this week looks more complementary than competetive, though, and that's a good sign.

CONNECTICUT GUIDE
LEAD: BRASS RUBBINGS Brass rubbing is an old craft that produces quickly and easily a respectable piece of art at minimal cost.
It requires no artistic skill and is an enjoyable way to spend half an hour or so.
Those who have never tried it may treat themselves to an introductory workshop under the watchful eyes of experts from the Brass Rubbing Center in London and its branch in Washington D.C., courtesy of the Museum of Art, Science and Industry in


INDIAN FARE ADDS SOME OF SPICE OF LIFE
LEAD: FOR Christmas this year an enterprising friend gave me a large basket filled with Indian spices in small bags tied with ribbon.
Of course, as soon as I smelled it, I craved Indian food.
For the next two weeks, the house was filled with the warm, musky aroma of an Indian bazaar as I set about cooking my favorite dishes and tried some new ones.

Immigrants
LEAD: To the Editor:  Mr.
Chiswick's contention that the amnesty provisions of the Simpson-Rodino Immigration Reform Act will make ''illegal aliens ... more likely to become a permanent feature of the labor market ...'' simply ignores the fact that the group to which amnesty applies is already a permanent feature of the labor market.


CORRECTION
LEAD: A picture caption last Sunday in Portfolio of '86, the special Year in Review section, misstated the birthday of Martin Luther King Jr.
He was born on Jan. 15, 1929, and the birthday is observed as a national holiday on the third Monday of January.


An F.A.A. Reply
LEAD: To the Editor:  Neither William F. Bolger nor Jack A. Blum have properly defined the problems in aviation (''Breaking a Budgetary Logjam,'' Forum, Dec. 7).
For example, Mr.
Blum refers to the ''continuing erosion of the margin of safety.'' No one has ever defined what ''margin of safety'' is, let alone figured out how to measure it.


Making a Grim Case for Precious Metals
LEAD: WHILE most eyes are again on Wall Street, as the Dow finally broke the magical 2,000 level, some experts argue that recent stirrings of life in precious metals prices may portend tougher times ahead for stocks and bonds.


POP: BUFFY SAINTE-MARIE
LEAD: OF the many socially engaged singer-songwriters who emerged out of the folk music movement of the 1960's, few have offered a more clearly focused vision of injustice than Buffy Sainte-Marie, the longtime crusader for American Indian rights.


A Trucker Surrenders After a Queens Crash
LEAD: A 26-year-old Brooklyn truck driver who fled from an accident that left two people seriously injured in Queens Friday surrendered to the police yesterday.
His lawyer said the suspect fled because a passer-by had fired gunshots he thought were aimed at him.

LEAD: Among the more familiar sights on Cape Cod this winter are the ''Help Wanted'' signs in virtually all the large supermarkets, department stores, pharmacies and restaurant chains, from Sandwich to Orleans.


How Big A Problem Is the Use of Steroids?
LEAD: Just how big a problem steroid use is among the professional athletes can only be determined through mutually agreed-upon testing procedures.
But before a sweeping policy of testing is instituted, some important questions need to be answered: How reliable is the testing procedure?
What would the consequences of steroid use be - suspension?

IN TODAY'S OPERA WORLD STARS CAN CALL THE TUNE
LEAD: The first thing to understand about bidding for the services of opera's superstars is that it's a singer's market.
There are far, far more blank slots on opera house calendars waiting to be filled by a Domingo or a Freni than there are nights in Placido Domingo's or Mirella Freni's datebooks waiting to be filled by an opera engagement.


Miss Roberts To Be Bride
LEAD: Dr. and Mrs.
Albert Dee Roberts of Dallas have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hillary Roberts, to Peter Alan Rinfret, the son of Dr. and Mrs.
Pierre A. Rinfret of New York.
The wedding is planned for March 21.


IN PAPUA NEW GUINEA, RITUALS OF ANOTHER AGE
LEAD: One of the last purchases I made in Papua New Guinea was a man's pocketbook.
Clutch-shaped, it was deftly fashioned from natural-colored, dried sago palm fibers and worked in a herringbone pattern.
But what clinched the sale were the decorations.
To avert the potential hazard posed by the two sharp wooden sticks framing the mouth of the purse, the weaver had swaddled them in bubble-gum wrappers.


Boos or Cheers?
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:  Does booing a professional athlete help or hinder his performance?


ENHANCED TV STANDARDS STILL ELUSIVE
LEAD: At the outset of a new year, engineering executives entrusted with long-range planning invariably wax eloquent about things to come.
In television, they usually tell us that everything is obsolete, that we ought to chuck the whole system and start from scratch.

LEAD: HE'S an assistant athletic director with an established interest in basketball and some of the best seats in the school arena, but Lefty Driesell hasn't used them to watch Maryland play this season.

FOR THE ATHLETES
LEAD: The United States Postal Service will issue a commemorative stamp Jan. 29 to honor the Tenth Pan American Games.
The sports competition will be held in 23 sites throughout Indiana from Aug. 7 to 25.
The first day of issue ceremony will be held in Indianapolis, the site for many events.


Biotech's Stalled Revolution
LEAD: Many people in the medical community are relieved to hear that the ''Biotech revolution'' has stalled (''Biotech's Stalled Revolution,'' by Keith Schneider, Nov. 16).
The danger of inadvertently creating new pathogens against which we have no effective treatment and no innate immune defense far outweighs the touted benefits of this technology.


THE NETWORKS ARE RE-MEASURING THE MINI-SERIES
LEAD: Whether fighting for their honor, their lovers or their fabulous multinational companies, the heroes and heroines of mini-series are in unusual jeopardy this year: Viewers have become bored with their problems.
Except for Linda Evans as an American woman facing the Australian outback in ''The Last Frontier,'' ratings for these special events have ranged from disastrous (''George Washington: The Forging of a Nation'') to mediocre (''A Year in the Life.


A French 'Riposte' In Chad's War
LEAD: France and Libya crossed an important line in Chad last week.
Libyan planes bombed two towns south of the 16th parallel, the so-called Red Line established by French forces as the southern boundary for Libyan incursions.
In retaliation, French jets bombed an airstrip in Libyan-controlled territory.

LEAD: OF THE 40,000 to 60,000 books published each year, many address a particular need (for example, how to raise a child successfully).


PROGRESS MAY NOT, AFTER ALL, BE OUR MOST IMPORTANT PRODUCT
LEAD: Communities confused or discontent in the present often strongly rediscover the moral and spiritual meaning of the traditional objects of their past.
This has usually been associated with so-called ''traditional'' societies - certainly not industrial ones.
Recently, however, the inexorable recognition that the technology of the industrial system is not a surefire solution to all life's problems has, in a strange paradox, begun to focus broad and appreciative attention on the old ''classical'' objects of the industrial way.


Business Sense
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:  In response to Marvin Miller's charge that George Steinbrenner was part of an owner conspiracy not to sign Jack Morris as a free agent, Steinbrenner is quoted as saying: ''If Marvin Miller can run a business better than me, then he should be rich.
And he's not.''


Children at the Art Museum
LEAD: To the Editor:
Our new book, ''Visiting the Art Museum,'' obviously made your reviewer, Grace Glueck (Dec. 21), very uncomfortable.
It is a children's book after all, not an adult guide as she seems to assume.
And it is just Ms.
Glueck's didactic attitude toward the mix of children and art museums we are trying to dispel with this book.

City Taxes
LEAD: To the Editor:  Your Dec. 14 article on Woodhaven, Queens  [ ''If You're Thinking of Living in Woodhaven'' ]  says that houses there selling for $150,000 to $300,000 have taxes ranging from $600 and $1,200 a year, which means they are assessed at less than 5 percent of market value.


Photography
LEAD: Ten years ago, Virginia Zabriskie took a leap of faith and opened a Paris branch of her Zabriskie Gallery, which she devoted exclusively to photography.
Situated in the shadow of the Centre George Pompidiou, the elegant and intimate Galerie Zabriskie has presented the work of American photographers such as Harry Callahan and Lee Friedlander to a European audience.

LEAD: FRANK GANSZ was named the Kansas City Chiefs' head coach last night.
The 48-year-old Gansz succeeds John Mackovic, who was dismissed Thursday despite the Chiefs' 10-6 regular-season record in his fourth season and Kansas City's first playoff appearance in 15 years.

RECENT CASSETTES
LEAD: The Streisand Specials: My Name Is Barbra and Color Me Barbra.
CBS/Fox Video. 60 minutes. $29.95.
Barbra Streisand's landmark CBS television specials in the mid-60's turned the star of the Broadway show ''Funny Girl'' into a household face as well as a household voice.
Both shows, staged by Joe Layton, are unrelenting star vehicles in which the singer, then in her mid-20's, paraded front and center, without the support of famous guests.

More Champions
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:  Although I enjoyed the champions listed in the 1986 sports review section, I noticed it failed to include the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's volleyball champions.
If there was room to list the men's winners, I'm sure there was room for the women's team - which, by the way, was the University of the Pacific, in Stockton, Calif.


BULLS TOP NETS, 119-109
LEAD: Michael Jordan scored 31 points and Charles Oakley added 21 tonight, leading the Chicago Bulls to a 119-109 victory over the Nets.


Driver Sentenced
LEAD: REJECTING a defense request for a delay in the proceedings, a judge in St.
Augustine, Fla., sentenced John Lee Paul, the race car driver, to 20 years in prison for attempting to murder a witness in a Federal drug case.
Paul also faces charges that he and his son, John Paul Jr., conspired to smuggle 200,000 pounds of cocaine into the United States between 1975 and 1983.


Funerals
LEAD: To the Editor:  ''What's New in the Funeral Business'' (Dec. 14) made no reference to the country's 150 Memorial Societies.
These are consumer-controlled, non-profit organizations that help their 250,000 members plan in advance the service and disposition of body they want.
Some societies negotiate low prices with funeral homes; others simply collect prices for a set of simple funerals.


Jacqui Mitchell, a New Number One
LEAD: Baseball fans are told within seconds when Pete Rose breaks a long-standing batting record, but in bridge everything is more leisurely.
Unofficial calculations strongly indicate that the title of world's top-ranked woman player changed hands in September, but the World Bridge Federation does not appear to have noticed this, let alone revealed the fact to a waiting world or the players involved.


DEATH HALTS FAIRFIELD GAME
LEAD: The basketball game between Fordham and Fairfield was suspended with 1 minute 42 seconds remaining today when the grandmother of one of the Fairfield players collapsed and died in the stands, officials said.


PURSUIT OF CULTURE AT A YOUNG AGE
LEAD: MY mother was born in a tough section of Chicago, near the Loop.
To her, this was a nonpareil social blight.
It had to be erased at all costs.
My mother's solution took the form of a frantic, lifetime pursuit of culture as she understood it.

It Has Declined, But Still Not Enough
LEAD: WITH the United States trade deficit remaining stubbornly high, controversy has arisen about whether the dollar has fallen as far as the standard indexes say it has.
Some analysts contend that the dollar has fallen hardly at all from its February 1985 peak, which explains the continuing large deficits.

LEAD: ''SURROGATE mother'' seemed a cruelly clinical euphemism last week as competing parents fought over a baby in a New Jersey courtroom.

LANGUAGE IS SMARTER THAN WE ARE
LEAD: I THINK it is past time to put aside other business and to turn our energies to the remystification of virtually everything.
I am as firmly persuaded as anyone that things can be explained, or usefully described, but I am convinced that our methods at this point are crude, and premature, and that they lead us to ignore such experience or intuition as cannot be accommodated by them.

'SAVE THE ROLLS': RULES FOR THE FLORIDA VISIT
LEAD: MY mother has become a ''snowbird.'' She flew to Florida before the first snowflake fell on Long Island, and she's not returning home until spring.
I'm killing two birds with one stone this winter.
I'll visit my mother and soak up some Florida sunshine at the same time.

IN SHORT: NONFICTION
LEAD: CELEBRATING BIRD: The Triumph of Charlie Parker.
By Gary Giddins. (Beech Tree/Morrow, $15.95.) Charlie (Yardbird) Parker, coming out of Kansas City, Kan., in the Depression, struggled in Harlem to find a voice on saxophone.
He hit his stride in the 1940's and liberated improvisational rhythms with brilliant innovations that have exerted a profound influence on jazz since World War II.

Jamaica's Ackee and Callaloo
LEAD: Most Jamaican hotels routinely include a few native dishes on their menus or offer a Jamaican buffet one night a week.
The authentic tastes of Jamaica - aromatic vegetable stews, spicy meats and fish - are best sampled, however, on the oilcloth-covered tables in small roadside and beach stands.

Headliners; Hidden Asset
LEAD: Dashiell Hammett, who died a quarter-century ago owing the Government $100,000 in back taxes, apparently had something in the bank after all.
Among the papers of Mr.
Hammett, whose many detective novels include ''The Maltese Falcon'' and ''The Thin Man,'' curators at the University of Texas have found a half-dozen unpublished stories and many stories that never appeared in English.


For Baseball Fans
LEAD: It isn't easy to be a major league baseball fan in Washington.
Since the Senators left town in 1971 to become the Texas Rangers, only an occasional unsanctioned contest, usually between creaking old-timers, has raised any diamond dust at R.F.K.
Stadium.
But now local fans of the New York Mets are excited because their World Champions have been booked into R.F.K.


High Technology
LEAD: To the Editor:  For over 35 years we have closely watched the short- and long-term effects of marketing American technology abroad, mainly through licensing (''The U.S. Giveaway,'' Dec. 7).
More than any other nation we have generously offered our technology to outsiders.
As a result, the entire world has been able to advance the automation of assembly line manufacturing, as well as the handling and processing of material.

LEAD: THE America's Cup challenge has brought new excitement - and new revenue - to sailing, and focused the eyes of the boating world on Australia.
But the overwhelming message of the New York National Boat Show that winds up today at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center is that America's weekend sailors are still motorboat-mad.


Submarine Strategy
LEAD: Richard Halloran's portrayal of the submarine-stalking games played by the United States and the Soviet Union sounds as if it's right off some admiral's drawing board.
But his omission of any mention of the recent severe collision between an American nuclear submarine and a Russian counterpart does little to warn the public of the peacetime dangers of this ''cat and mouse'' technique.

IS RESOURCE RECOVERY THE WAY TO GO?
LEAD: IT'S NO secret that public officials at the local, county and state levels are grappling with the unenviable task of determining what to do with the more than 9 million tons of garbage collected in New Jersey each year.

If in the public mind a five-year-old could make a painting that looked like a Picasso, it didn't even take an infant to make a Warhol.

LEAD: President Reagan has railed against big deficits for five years now, but his 1988 budget offers fresh proof that he doesn't really care.

A BITE ON THE WAY TO...
LEAD: New Yorkers, to say nothing of visitors, have a lot to do: working, shopping, going to the movies, the gym, the hairdresser.

With hardly a break in stride, men, women and children on the go can grab a chewy pretzel (sometimes even a warm one), a hot dog (sometimes even a hot one) or a piece of fruit (bananas, which don't drip on fur coats, are extremely popular).

Off-Duty Officer Shot at a McDonald's
LEAD: An off-duty correction officer shot another man twice early yesterday after the two got into a fight in a fast-food restaurant in the Melrose section of the Bronx, the authorities said.
The wounded man was arrested.

LEAD: Following a slump in its trade surplus and foreign exchange reserves, Brazil is now planning to seek between $2 billion and $3 billion in ''new money'' from its creditors, as part of upcoming negotiations to restructure foreign debt, according to officials in Brasilia.

LEAD: The management of North Castle Partners of Greenwich, Conn., has bought the agency back from Foote, Cone &amp; Belding Communications because of conflict-of-interest problems perceived by prospective clients.
F.C.B., the nation's ninth-largest advertising agency, acquired North Castle two years ago.

LEAD: IT has been almost 20 years since the little boy from Scotch Plains, N.J., gained one of those personal insights that can change a life.
It happened, he recalled the other day, on Jackson Avenue, a side street near his home on Front Street, when he was about 8 years old.
He and some other boys from the neighborhood challenged each other to a block race.

LEAD: Red tide has reappeared in the Gulf of Mexico, forcing an indefinite halt to shellfish harvesting along a part of the coast ravaged by an outbreak of the toxic bloom last year.

LEAD: A new twist in the rules for the defense of the America's Cup has paved the way for the winner of the defense trials to substitute boats for the actual cup match.


COMPTROLLER GENERAL'S POWER UPHELD
LEAD: A Federal appeals court has upheld the power of the Comptroller General of the United States to block the awarding of Government contracts while he investigates possible irregularities.

LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Palestinian Rights - 10:30 A.M.


Gasoline Prices Jump
LEAD: Retail gasoline prices jumped an average of 3 cents a gallon nationwide the last two weeks, a reflection of continuing volatility in the oil industry, the Lundberg Survey reported today.
The average price was 87.9 cents a gallon.


Governors Take Office
LEAD: Governors were sworn in yesterday in Illinois, Kansas, Ohio, Oklahoma and Oregon.


United Financial Officer
LEAD: Frank R. Jarc, executive vice president and chief financial officer of the Wilson Foods Corporation, will join United Airlines as senior vice president and chief financial officer, effective Feb. 2.
Mr.
Jarc, 44 years old, worked for Gould Inc. before joining Wilson, which is based in Oklahoma City.


MAURICE VILLENCY, DESIGNER OF MODERN FURNITURE
LEAD: Maurice Villency, a pioneer in the design of contemporary furniture whose signature served as the logo for his chain of stores in the New York metropolitan region, died Sunday morning of heart failure at his home in Brookville, L.I.
He was 85 years old.


Curb Urged on Japanese Cars
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company's president, Harold Poling, called on Japan today to curb car exports to the United States to less than 2 million annually, from the current 2.3 million.

LEAD: It is the refrain that touches off the stormiest applause.

CARSON'S BAD TIMES LONG GONE
LEAD: So now the guy's a big-shot columnist.
His helmeted face rests on a prominent shelf in a bookstore near you.
The face does not smile on the jacket cover, but it does most everywhere else these days.
His voice is on the radio, telling you where your dial is tuned.
Like the song says, the future's so bright, he's gotta wear shades.

Plasma And AIDS
LEAD: SCIENTISTS have found that blood plasma of some persons infected with the AIDS virus has large quantities of antibodies that inactivate the virus in the testtube.

NEW GRAND JURY IN WALKER CASE TO INVESTIGATE SIZE OF SPYING RING
LEAD: A new Federal grand jury in Virginia will investigate to determine whether John A. Walker Jr. hid hundreds of thousands of dollars in espionage payments and whether others who have not been charged were involved in his Soviet spy ring, Federal law-enforcement officials said today.


Some Record Figures
LEAD: Wade Boggs and the Boston Red Sox turned in record-tying and record-breaking numbers yesterday in submitting their numbers for salary arbitration.
Boggs, who has filed for arbitration for the third successive year, went in at $1.85 million, the Red Sox at $1.6 million.
The Red Sox figure is the highest ever submitted by a club, eclipsing the $1.35 million they submitted for Boggs last year.

Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q.When my grandfather was young his eyes were dark brown, but now that he's old, they are hazel.
Is it possible for eye color to change with age?
A.The color of the iris does not change with age, but the pupil, the apparently black hole at the center of the iris, may shrink with age causing the iris to appear lighter in color, according to Dr.

Real pros these Giants, then and now, their victories workmanlike, not flashy.

LEAD: Harold Eliot Krents, whose struggle to overcome blindness and become independent was the inspiration for the Broadway play ''Butterflies Are Free,'' died of a brain tumor yesterday at the Calvary Hospital Hospice in the Bronx.
He was 42 years old and lived in Washington.

LEAD: INVESTORS have stood in line to buy shares, the stock market index has raced upward at a dizzying pace and a general investing frenzy has gripped Mexico as the nation's stock market enters what analysts here call a ''superboom.''

LEAD: The buoyant, optimistic American West, whose economic growth has outpaced the nation over much of the past 20 years, has begun the new year facing a new set of realities: declining population growth, persistent problems in important industries and growing apprehension about the future.

What to Take With the Fifth
LEAD: No matter why Bess Myerson, Mayor Koch's Cultural Affairs Commissioner, took the Fifth Amendment before a Federal grand jury last month, she should have told her boss before he saw it on the evening news.
The Mayor lacks the right to dismiss employees for invoking their privilege against self-incrimination, but he is entitled to know when they have done so.


NEW FINDINGS REVEAL ANCIENT ABUSE OF LANDS
LEAD: RECENT discoveries in the southwestern United States, southern Greece and the South Pacific have persuaded a growing number of archeologists that primitive people were much more destructive to their habitat than had been generally believed.


F.D.U. Regains Division I Status
LEAD: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today restored Fairleigh Dickinson University to Division I status.
The action clears the way for the school's teams to compete in championship competition this year, said Roy Danforth, the school's athletic director.


FELONY CHARGES FILED AGAINST GOODEN
LEAD: The Hillsborough County state attorney today filed two third-degree felony charges against Dwight Gooden, the Mets' pitching star who was involved in a Dec. 13 scuffle with Tampa police that the prosecutor pledged would be dealt with in ''a very stern fashion.''


Designing the Forms Everyone Loves to Hate
LEAD: Anyone who has struggled with the Internal Revenue Service's new four-page W-4 withholding form brought on by the recently enacted Tax Reform Act can only be fearing the worst about what it will be like next year to file a return under the new law.


E.D.S. Acquisition
LEAD: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation said that it had acquired Societe Pour L'Informatique, a French computer services company, for an undisclosed amount.
The purchase of the subsidiary of Pechiney added 600 employees to the 230 workers at E.D.S.
International S.A., the French operating unit of the Dallas-based concern.

Spermicide Shown to Kill AIDS Virus
LEAD: Tests have shown that a widely used contraceptive substance is capable of killing the virus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome, a researcher at France's Pasteur Institute said today.


SAFETY RECORD OF U.S. AIRLINES SHOWS BIG GAIN
LEAD: United States airlines enjoyed one of their safest years in 1986, a turnaround from a 1985 toll that was one of the highest on record, according to official figures made public yesterday.

LEAD: The American Motors Corporation announced plans to renovate its aging Kenosha auto plant and to begin manufacturing a new Jeep in 1989.
