KEAN, CRITICIZING WELFARE, PROPOSES WORK REQUIREMENT
LEAD: Governor Kean, in his State of the State Message today, called the state's welfare system a failure.
He said he wanted to start a program to require all able-bodied recipients to go to work to support themselves and their families.


MAN MAY THREATEN EAGLE'S WINTER HABITAT
LEAD: UNDER a half moon rising in a winter sky, two bald eagles float on a current of air forced out of the North Cascades.
While they look for salmon in a gravel bar of the icy Skagit River, tourists look at them.


Dravo President Resigns
LEAD: The directors of the Dravo Corporation accepted the resignation today of Thomas F. Faught Jr. as president and chief executive.
Robert Dickey 3d, Dravo's chief executive from 1965 until 1983, was elected chairman, president and chief executive.


Business and the Law; Board Liability In Delaware
LEAD: LAST June, the state of Delaware - home to most of the nation's largest companies - passed a law allowing corporations to limit, or even eliminate, their directors' financial liability for some kinds of mistakes.
Under the Delaware law, shareholders can vote to eliminate the directors' liability, except in cases of disloyalty, bad faith or intentional misconduct.


Toxic Tests at Bronx Border
LEAD: Sverina Rosa, 87 years old, being carried from her home yesterday near an abandoned warehouse as Federal environmental workers began testing toxic chemicals left in the building on the Bronx-Mount Vernon border.
Outside the warehouse, left, a crew demonstrated the testing procedure.
About 90 residents were evacuated for part of the day.

LEAD: The Supreme Court declined today to review a lower court's ruling that shields cigarette manufacturers from liability for injuries or death caused by smoking in suits based on allegedly inadequate health warnings or improper advertising.

LEAD: Gen.
Wojciech Jaruzelski today began his first official visit to the West since he imposed martial law in Poland five years ago.


THIOKOL DELAYS FULL-SCALE TEST OF SHUTTLE BOOSTER
LEAD: Morton Thiokol has delayed until mid-March the first full-scale test-firing of its redesigned space shuttle booster, originally planned for the first week of February.


HEART UNITS CLOSED AT 4 HOSPITALS
LEAD: The Veterans Administration today identified four of its hospitals, including two in the New York City area, where heart surgery is being halted because of concerns over death rates and quality of care.


Coaches Reported Out
LEAD: Coach Vladimir Vasiliev of the Soviet Union junior hockey team and his assistant, Valentin Gurayev, have been dismissed, according to a report in yesterday's issue of The Toronto Globe and Mail.
The Soviet Union and Team Canada were disqualified from the world junior championships Jan. 4 after the two sides participated in a bench-clearing brawl that resulted in the match being called off.


CHRISTIE'S TRIAL OPENS IN A MANHATTAN COURT
LEAD: A trial began today in State Supreme Court in Manhattan in which Christie's, the auction house, is being sued for breach of contract in failing to sell eight Impressionist paintings that it had told a client could bring more than $10 million at auction.


People
LEAD: *
Mark D. Goldstein promoted to president of the Washington office of Earle Palmer Brown Inc., Bethesda, Md.


A World of Speed
LEAD: When Renaldo Nehemiah left track in 1982 to play for the San Francisco 49ers, he held four world best times for indoor hurdle events and the 10 fastest indoor clockings for the 60-yard and 55-meter events.
Now, after leaving pro football and petitioning successfully to return as an amateur hurdler, his times remain unmatched.


LORAL TO ACQUIRE GOODYEAR DIVISION
LEAD: After several failed efforts to expand its military electronics business, the Loral Corporation has catapulted itself into one of the biggest companies in the field.


Councilman Guilty Of Cocaine Charges
LEAD: A Manville Borough Councilman faces up to 15 years in prison after he pleaded guilty yesterday to possessing and distributing cocaine, the Somerset County Prosecutor said.


BOOKS OF THE TIMES
LEAD: THE FATAL SHORE.
By Robert Hughes. 688 pages.
Illustrated.
Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.
IN 1770, Capt.
James Cook claimed possession of the eastern coast of Australia, which he and his men had been the first Europeans to sight, in the name of George III.
The actual process of colonization began some 18 years later, when a fleet of 11 British ships sailed into what was soon to be called Sydney Harbor.


Fox Broadcasting Assigned to Chiat/Day
LEAD: The Los Angeles office of Chiat/ Day has officially been assigned Rupert Murdoch's Fox Broadcasting Company, which is supposed to reach a $20 million billing level.
Six agencies had competed for the account.


A BUYOUT OF SCHWAB IS SEEN
LEAD: The BankAmerica Corporation has tentatively agreed to sell its Charles Schwab &amp; Company discount brokerage unit to a group headed by the unit's chairman, Charles R. Schwab, industry sources said today.


DANCE: FOLK PERFORMERS OF HUNGARY, IN BRONX
LEAD: THE Hungarian State Folk Ensemble is not still another folk group.
It is marvelous -crackling with dancing that snaps like a whip in a program framed successfully by a sophisticated context.


Murray Ohio Chief Quits
LEAD: The Murray Ohio Manufacturing Company, maker of mowers and bicycles, said yesterday that Richard W. Sappenfield had resigned as president, chief executive and a director in differences over the ''future strategic direction of the company.'' William M. Hannon, the chairman, whose grandfather founded the company, was appointed interim chief executive.


CANADA OPENS MARKETS' DOORS
LEAD: One of Canada's leading investment companies recently summoned electronics experts to its offices in a high-rise tower overlooking Lake Ontario and ordered anti-bugging devices installed on its top executives' telephones.


A NEW CHIEF SPOKESMAN FOR THE PRESIDENT: MAX MARLIN FITZWATER
LEAD: When Marlin Fitzwater entered the White House press briefing room today for the announcement that he would become President Reagan's new chief spokesman, reporters broke into spontaneous applause.


Brooklyn Academy to Honor Gershwins
LEAD: Mayor Koch paid tribute yesterday to the Brooklyn Academy of Music -one of the country's oldest performing arts centers - on its 125th anniversary.


ON PLATO, CAVES AND SPELUNKING
LEAD: AS a writer, I am interested in word processors.
And as a curmudgeon of the old school, I have yet to find a word-processing package that truly suits me.
According to certain members of my family, in fact, the reason I periodically aspire to add geese to our farm menagerie is solely to assure myself of a steady supply of quill pens.


BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JANUARY 13, 1987
LEAD:  Markets


NEW REPORT OF SAUDI MONEY FOR CONTRAS
LEAD: Robert C. McFarlane told Congress that Saudi Arabia had contributed millions of dollars for the Nicaraguan rebels, increasing to at least $40 million the amount gathered for the rebels that now cannot be accounted for, sources familiar with the Congressional investigation said today.


The Vatican Shows a Schizophrenia About Jews; Palestinian Hostages
LEAD: To the Editor:


RICHARD K. SYKES
LEAD: Richard K. Sykes, president of Dresner-Sykes Associates Inc., political campaign consultants with offices in Manhattan and San Diego, drowned Jan. 6 while exploring a tidal pool on Molokai Island in Hawaii.
He was 35 years old and lived in Manhattan and Molokai.


MOST ENERGY FUNDS FOR MILITARY USES
LEAD: The Energy Department's budget request would increase the share of agency funds that are spent on military programs while reducing funds for energy conservation and renewable energy programs, according to a Congressional study made public today.


A Need for Sprinklers
LEAD: To the Editor:


GRAND JURY ASSAILS HOSPITAL IN '84 DEATH OF 18-YEAR-OLD
LEAD: A Manhattan grand jury, in a report issued yesterday, determined that ''woefully'' inadequate care and repeated mistakes made by unsupervised interns and junior residents at a New York hospital resulted in the death of a young woman there in 1984.


Test Shows Students Master Basic Skills
LEAD: Students know the basic skills, but falter in applying higher-order skills such as interpreting written passages and performing mathematical functions with fractions, the state education commissioner said yesterday in releasing results of the Connecticut Mastery Test.


WILLIAM M. JUDD, 70, MANAGER OF MAJOR CLASSICAL MUSICIANS
LEAD: William M. Judd, a manager of major classical musicians for more than 40 years, died of heart failure yesterday in Southampton (L.I.) Hospital.
He was 70 years old.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A front-page article yesterday about the Giants' playoff victory over the Redskins and a related article on the first page of SportsMonday misreported the results of the coin flip before the game.
The Redskins' captain called tails and the coin landed heads.


Prince Edward Quits The Royal Marines
LEAD: Prince Edward, Queen Elizabeth's youngest son and fifth in line to the British throne, quit the Royal Marines today, breaking a century-old tradition of princes serving tours of duty in the armed forces.


BYRD HINTS AT EARNINGS CURB
LEAD: The Senate majority leader said today that he might propose new restrictions on senators' outside earnings as part of a plan to allow a Congressional pay increase to take effect.


FRENCH STRIKES: THE LINE BETWEEN PRESSURE AND PROVOCATION
LEAD: When workers on the Paris subway and bus system decided to continue a long, intermittent strike here today, they announced beforehand to the public, almost as a matter of courtesy, that the trains and buses would not be running from noon until 4 P.M.


Doctors' Fees, Doctored
LEAD: One triumph of the Reagan Administration has been its firm, fair control of hospital costs for the $64 billion Medicare program.
Now it wants to impose similar discipline on individual doctors.
Yet the method Congress has put in place is neither firm nor fair.
Just how complicated and confusing is known mainly to readers of physicians' newsletters.


Coke Unit Joins In TV Colorization
LEAD: Coca-Cola Telecommunications Inc. said it had joined with a unit of Color Systems Technology Inc. to convert black and white filmed material into color.
Herman Rush, chairman of the Coca-Cola unit, said the venture would focus mainly on colorizing some of unit's library of vintage television series, including ''Ivanhoe'' with Roger Moore, ''The Real McCoys'' and ''Wyatt Earp.


ONE OF HOLLYWOOD 10 REVISITS MOSCOW
LEAD: Fifty-three years after his last visit and four decades since his association with Communism fractured his career as a screenwriter, Ring Lardner Jr. returned to Moscow last week.


The Background; Verdi's Political Chameleon
LEAD: In 1848, when Verdi began his 14th opera, ''La Battaglia di Legnano,'' Europe was in the throes of political upheaval.
In Italy, citizens of Milan drove out the occupying Austrian troops after five days of street fighting, and republican revolutionaries in other cities were overthrowing aristocratic or foreign rulers.


DENVER FANS ARE A MILE HIGH
LEAD: ''This is an unbelievable feeling,'' said Coach Dan Reeves, whose Denver Broncos beat the Cleveland Browns Sunday, earning the right to represent the American Football Conference against the Giants in the Super Bowl in Pasadena, Calif., on Jan. 25.


Interest Rates Close Mixed
LEAD: Interest rates were mixed yesterday with little change in short-term rates, while note and bond yields rose modestly.


Japan Car Engines In Canada Venture
LEAD: The Daihatsu Motor Company, Japan's sixth-largest auto maker, has agreed to provide a Canadian vehicle manufacturer with car engines and is considering forming a joint venture to build cars in Canada, according to Tomonaru Eguchi, the company's president.
Mr.
Eguchi said Daihatsu was working out final details on providing 850 cubic-centimeter engines to Bombardier


MASSACHUSETTS MILL DESTROYED IN FIRE:
LEAD: Firefighters in Falls River trying to contain fire at the Kerr mill complex.
Blaze, fanned by stiff winds, spread to all eight buildings of the complex.
Officials esti-mated damage at $10 million; 650 workers will lose jobs because of fire.
Complex, which had some buildings converted to commercial and manufacturing space, was once owned by American Thread Company.

LEAD: The nonjury trial of a police officer who fatally shot an elderly woman during an eviction began yesterday in the Bronx, with spectators interrupting a defense lawyer's opening statements when he said the family of the woman shared responsibility for her death.


A.B.A. REPORT ON LIABILITY CASES
LEAD: An American Bar Association commission studying personal injury claims is recommending that there be no limits on awards for pain and suffering, but says the courts should try to make sure the awards are not excessive.


CONFUSION ON ISRAELI ROLE
LEAD: Recent disclosures of policy memorandums by the White House and the Senate Intelligence Committee seem to suggest that Israel somehow led the Reagan Administration into the Iran affair by repeatedly promising, on the basis of Iranian-Israeli contacts, that with one sale of arms to Teheran all the American hostages in Lebanon would be released.

LEAD: Emphysema reduced Kathryn Kennedy's voice to a barely audible whisper, but it commanded the attention of the audience when she testified yesterday on proposals to limit smoking in New York City.

Don't Think It's Easy to Become a Teacher in New York State
LEAD: To the Editor:


RJR Nabisco Move Possible
LEAD: RJR Nabisco Inc., the tobacco and food products company, said yesterday it was considering moving its headquarters from Winston-Salem, N.C., where Richard Joshua Reynolds established his tobacco company in 1875.
A company spokesman, Bill Ruffin, said RJR Nabisco ''does have studies under way with respect to the potential relocaton of its corporate headquarters.


Financial Director Quits Guinness Amid Inquiry
LEAD: The management turmoil at Guinness P.L.C. continued yesterday with the resignation of the brewer's 36-year-old director of financial strategy and development, Olivier Roux.


NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JANUARY 13, 1987
LEAD: International


NOTES ON FASHION
LEAD: PITY poor fashion models: despite the gobs of money they earn, they get precious little respect.
But the disrespect is delicious in ''Dial M for Model,'' John Epperson's satirical musical dressed in 60's styles.
It is on view at Pyramid (101 Avenue A), the downtown area's most consistently different nightclub.


DOLE SEEKS TO ADD TO STRATEGY TEAM
LEAD: Senator Bob Dole has asked the man who was dismissed as Ronald Reagan's strategist in 1980 to play a major role in his Presidential campaign, a move that has disturbed some conservatives.


KNOPF PRESIDENT WILL SUCCEED SHAWN AS NEW YORKER EDITOR
LEAD: Robert A. Gottlieb, president and editor in chief of Alfred A. Knopf, will succeed William Shawn as editor of The New Yorker, a magazine that for years has been a magnet for many of the country's leading writers.


New Apple IIe Is Introduced
LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. today introduced an updated version of the Apple IIe personal computer that has as features an expanded keyboard with a built-in numeric keypad, improved training materials and the company's new platinum color scheme.


BEYOND THE SKIPPERS, TALENTED TEAMS BRING SMOOTH SAILING: AMID THE PRIDE, SOME MISGIVINGS
LEAD: The inky black tower that houses the Bank of New Zealand is Wellington's version of the World Trade Center.
At Christmastime, a mammoth snowflake of tiny white lights twinkles into the night on all four sides.


Night Trading Under Study
LEAD: The Chicago Board of Trade may begin trading at night on several contracts during the next few months to attract business from the Far East.


Parcells's Fate Tied to Reeves
LEAD: In the twists of history that often accompany a Super Bowl plot, the Giants have used three Denver Broncos draft choices to acquire two linebackers, Gary Reasons and Pepper Johnson, as well as Ottis Anderson, the running back.
And indirectly, Bill Parcells is the Giants' coach because the Giants chose in 1979 not to hire Dan Reeves, now the


REBECCA H. REYHER
LEAD: Rebecca Hourwich Reyher, a veteran suffragist, author and lecturer, died of pnuemonia last Saturday at the home of her daughter, Faith Jackson, in St.
Inigoes, Md.
Mrs.
Reyher was 89 years old.


DEVILS END VICTORY DROUGHT
LEAD: The Devils and Pat Verbeek shook off a lot of frustration and disappointment tonight, the Devils by posting their first victory in 11 games and Verbeek, the team's leading goal scorer, by scoring his first goal in 13 games.


GOING OUT GUIDE
LEAD: SOUTHERN EXPOSURE Glover is a town in the northeast corner of Vermont along Route 91, some 20 miles south of the Canadian border.
Glover boasts a population of 846 and a Bread and Puppet Theater.
In the late 1970's some students who took part in Bread and Puppet activities formed the only dance-theater company in the area, the Expanding Secret Company.


Dominick Labino, 76, Artist And Inventor of Glass Works
LEAD: Dominick Labino, an artist whose works made of glass are shown in more than 100 museums, universities and public and private collections, died Saturday in his home at Grand Rapids, Ohio.
He was 76 years old.


OIL PRICES END ABOVE $19 A BARREL
LEAD: Crude oil reached prices yesterday not seen since last winter on world markets, and oil-industry stocks soared in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange.


Dynamics Fighters
LEAD: The Government of Greece signed a contract for the purchase of 40 F-16 fighter planes from the General Dynamics Corporation.
The first four aircraft, each costing $940 million, will be delivered in January 1989.


Black Extremists and Howard Beach
LEAD: The one good thing to come of the tragic beating in Howard Beach last month was the hope it raised of rejuvenating a multiracial civil rights movement in New York City.
But that hope is already vanishing, ruined by black extremists determined to exploit racial polarization rather than join forces with decent whites committed to a racially integrated city.


SENATOR SAYS REAGAN MUST FACE 'MISTAKE' ON IRAN
LEAD: The top Republican on the Senate intelligence committee asserted today that President Reagan could not ''escape responsibility'' for his Administration's ''mistake'' in selling arms to Iran and using the profits to aid the Nicaraguan rebels.


BEYOND THE SKIPPERS, TALENTED TEAMS BRING SMOOTH SAILING: IT'S NOT ALL GLAMOUR IN A WINNING EFFORT
LEAD: On the way out to racing one day, the crews on Dennis Conner's first and second-string boats noticed a group of schoolgirls hailing from shore.


Insider Figure Is Sentenced to 30 Days in Jail
LEAD: David S. Brown, a former lawyer and investment banker, was sentenced yesterday to 30 days in jail, 300 hours of community service and 3 years of probation for selling inside information about pending takeovers to Dennis B. Levine.


YOUTH IN GOETZ SHOOTING IS DENIED STATE VICTIM AID
LEAD: The state agency that administers New York's crime victims law has ruled that one of the four youths shot by Bernhard H. Goetz in 1984 is ineligible for state aid because ''it appears'' he was ''in the process of robbing'' Mr.
Goetz when the shooting occurred.

LEAD: John Drew, a former Atlanta Hawks' forward who had been scheduled to go on trial yesterday on drug charges, instead pleaded guilty to selling and possessing cocaine.

He already has served three months since his arrest Oct.

LEAD: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger today endorsed the deployment of an initial defense against nuclear missiles, provided that it served as a cornerstone for a nationwide shield.


Quick Work
LEAD: Computer and laser-beam technology can significantly speed the process of archeological field work, according to an anthropologist at the University of Pennsylvania.
The anthropologist, Dr.
Harold L. Dibble, an assistant professor of anthropology, has adapted the traditional surveyor's tool, a theodolite, with a laser-beam measuring device to locate artifacts.

LEAD: Prostitution-related charges against Timothy Grimes, a victim in the Howard Beach, Queens, racial attack, were dropped yesterday because of insufficient evidence, officials said.


TEST TRAIN STOPS IN ENOUGH TIME TO AVOID CRASH

BRUINS DOMINATE RANGERS
LEAD: It should be called the Boston Garden price, and if one is a hockey player on an opposition team, he should be prepared to pay it upon entrance.
This comes as no surprise to the Rangers, for they have been here before and come away battered and injured.
But they still seem unwilling to meet the harsh terms of winning here - checking and checking hard.


Social Security Tax Rule Wins
LEAD: A Federal court yesterday upheld the law requiring Social Security recipients to include their income from municipal bond interest when calculating the tax they may owe on Social Security benefits.
The ruling was issued in Manhattan by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.


CONTRIBUTORS TO THE NEEDIEST RECALL CHILDHOOD DIFFICULTIES
LEAD: Some donors to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund recall their own difficult childhood experiences in contributing to the 75th annual appeal.


STUNG BY CRITICS, CARDINAL SEEKS APOLOGY
LEAD: John Cardinal O'Connor, still smarting from a sharply critical statement that Jewish leaders issued shortly before he arrived in New York from a trip to the Middle East, said yesterday that he felt he deserved an apology.


U.N. REPORT LINKS DRUGS, ARMS TRAFFIC AND TERROR
LEAD: Illegal drug production and trafficking are closely linked to the illegal arms trade and international terrorism, according to a United Nations report made public today.

LEAD: Following are excerpts from Governor Kean's annual State of the State Message to the Legislature, released today.
The Governor will deliver a speech, based on his 95-page message, to the Senate and Assembly on Tuesday.


Ferment in Iowa
LEAD: With the key Iowa Presidential caucuses a little over a year away, the Iowa Democrats are in the throes of choosing a new party chairman.
The 30-member state central committee meets Saturday to pick a successor to A. Arthur Davis, who has announced he will not seek re-election.


3 SEEKING TRADES BY DEADLINE
LEAD: When Scotty Stirling, the Knicks' general manager, speaks of hoping to be able to complete a major deal before the league's Feb. 15 trading deadline, he has plenty of people sharing his sentiments.
Among them are three Knicks, each of whom hopes by then not to be a member of the team.


Reagan's Drug Policy: a Bust
LEAD: President Reagan's proposal to reduce drastically Federal anti-drug funding in fiscal 1988 and 1989 proves he never really believed in his own drug abuse policies.


NETWORKS SCORE BIG IN N.F.L. PLAYOFFS
LEAD: From frigid Cleveland to the windy Meadowlands, from Bob Costas's hello on NBC at noon to Brent Musburger's goodbye on CBS at 7:30 P.M., Sunday was Football.
It was also another one of those days when television sports deserves our attention and gratitude.


NEW ENTRIES IN THE LOW-COST ARENA
LEAD: WHILE the rest of the world awaited more rumors about new computers from Apple and I.B.M., two home-computer makers were busy announcing new products last week at the winter Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.
Several people who tried to wedge their way into the crowded Atari and Commodore booths said that if crowd size was any indication, the home-computer market is primed for a resurgence in 1987.


On the PAC Front
LEAD: A year ago, the Federal Election Commission reported that the number of political action committees making special interest contributions to candidates had actually decreased, from 4,009 at the end of 1984 to 3,992, the first time this politically popular activity had ever experienced a decline.


WAITE RETURNS TO LEBANON
LEAD: Terry Waite, envoy of the Archbishop of Canterbury, arrived in Beirut today and said he had spoken with one of his contacts within an hour of his arrival on a new bid to free Western hostages held in Lebanon.

REAGAN PLAN ON VERIFYING NUCLEAR TESTS FAULTED
LEAD: Government intelligence officials say a far more comprehensive approach should be taken to verifying Soviet and American compliance with limits on nuclear testing than has been proposed by the Reagan Administration, according to newly obtained secret documents.


TEXACO-PENNZOIL HEARING STRESSES SIZE
LEAD: David Boies, the lawyer representing Texaco Inc., had a difficult argument to make to the United States Supreme Court today.

Argentina Loan Accord
LEAD: Juan Sourrouille, Argentina's Economy Minister announced today that the World Bank had granted Argentina a $2 billion loan.


The Vatican Shows a Schizophrenia About Jews; Holocaust Politics
LEAD: To the Editor:


CONTINENTAL IS BUYING PRESIDENTIAL AIR'S GATES
LEAD: Continental Airlines said yesterday that it was aquiring all the gates and airport facilities of Presidential Airways.


Hope From A Scholar
LEAD: Fellow academics have called her ''a living legend,'' one of the founders and a key developer of African studies in the U.S.
At her 80th birthday party last year, Dr.
Gwendolen Carter said she was greatly relieved that ''no one suggested I should resign or give up anything.
That would have annoyed me very much.


New Shearson Research Chief
LEAD: Jack L. Rivkin has been named director of equity research at Shearson Lehman Brothers, the investment firm said yesterday.


GEORGETOWN HOLDS OFF VILLANOVA, 80-73
LEAD: Reggie Williams scored 20 points tonight as Georgetown built a 21-point lead midway through the second half and survived a Villanova rally for an 80-73 Big East victory.


BACKERS OF ORGAN GIFTS CRITICIZE REAGAN CUTS
LEAD: Organ donor advocates, including families who received help from the Reagans in seeking transplants for their critically ill children, have attacked a White House proposal to end Federal spending on donor programs.


Flying Tiger Line Plans to Expand
LEAD: In a significant expansion, Flying Tiger Line Inc. said it would increase its jet fleet by more than 18 percent and put 23 percent more pilots on its payroll.
The move comes less than a month after the financially troubled Flying Tiger, the nation's oldest and largest scheduled air-cargo concern, was granted significant wage and benefit concessions by its unions and imposed similar cuts on its executive and administrative staff.


REAGAN IS SAID TO SEEK BILLS TO EASE TRADE GAP
LEAD: President Reagan will soon ask Congress for changes in antitrust laws, restraints on imports of counterfeit goods and a $200 million war chest to help American companies sell goods abroad, according to Administration and Congressional officials.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''No just society can deny the right of its citizens to the health care they need.
We are the only industrial society that does.'' - Joseph A. Califano, former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.  [ B7:1. ]


Diet-Brand Promotion Set at Coke
LEAD: IT is common knowledge among marketers of diet food and drink products that the post-holiday-pigout period is their best time of the year.
Oh, yes, there is profit to be made from guilt.


9 Garbage Haulers Face Jail or Work
LEAD: Nine Long Island garbage haulers who pleaded guilty to scheming to control Suffolk County collection routes were ordered today to choose between jail or community service.


After the Contras Are Gone
LEAD: By all accounts, the contras and their sponsors in the State Department are trying desperately to make some headway in their war before the question of United States support for the insurgency comes up again in Congress.
Nevertheless, it is not too soon to look ahead to the post-contra era that now seems in sight.


Ex-Chief of Macmillan Joins Simon &amp; Schuster
LEAD: Jeremiah Kaplan, who retired last month as chairman and chief executive of the Macmillan Publishing Company, has joined Simon &amp; Schuster.


Joiner Retires
LEAD: At the age of 39, Charlie Joiner, the San Diego wide receiver who holds the National Football League record for receptions and receiving yardage, has retired after an 18-year career in which he caught 750 passes for 12,146 yards.
He also holds the record for most games played by a wide receiver, with 239.


School Bars Musical, Charging Sexual Bias
LEAD: School officials have told high school students that they cannot stage the Broadway musical farce ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum'' because, the officials say, it is morally unacceptable and degrading to women.


Bridge: Two Young German Players Surprised American Expert
LEAD: Historically speaking, neither tennis nor bridge have been popular recreations in Germany.
But the changing pattern in tennis, exemplified by Boris Becker and Steffi Graf, may soon be matched in bridge, judging from some evidence from the 1986 world championships in Miami Beach.


CULTURAL ISOLATION
LEAD: Momentum appears to be gathering for an attack on what many educators regard as Americans' ignorance about the world beyond their shores.
Foreign failures and difficulties that have developed in recent years, from Vietnam to Iran, have led to calls for a general bolstering Americans' knowledge of unfamiliar languages and cultures.


3 Banking Organizations Market 10-Year Notes
LEAD: Three banking companies sold 10-year notes through Salomon Brothers yesterday, joining a large and growing list of corporate borrowers attracted to the debt market this year by a combination of strong investor demand and interest rates that are near their lowest levels in nine years.


Stars &amp; Stripes Finds a Groove
LEAD: If Dennis Conner's Stars &amp; Stripes is able to beat New Zealand today on the America's Cup race course in Fremantle, Australia, it may be due in part to a new ''secret weapon'' that Conner's syndicate revealed yesterday.


Mortgage-Backed Securities Offered
LEAD: Securities dealers offered $700 million of collateralized mortgage obligations yesterday.
Demand for the high-quality securities, which offer yields well above Treasury issues, remains strong from foreign and domestic investors.

Philadelphia Candidate
LEAD: John Egan, a Republican stockbroker who was beaten in 1983 by W. Wilson Goode in his first try for Mayor, said today that he would run for his party's nomination again.
Mr.
Egan is the first candidate in the Republican field, which is expected to include the former Democratic Mayor, Frank Rizzo, who last month changed his party registration, and City Councilman Thacher Longstreth.


Allied Stores Chief Resigns From Post
LEAD: Thomas M. Macioce, the 67-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Allied Stores Corporation, has resigned in the wake of the recent merger of Allied into the Campeau Corporation, the Canadian builder.


'Silver Gun' Theory Attacked By Lawyer in Trooper Death
LEAD: A defense lawyer in the trial of two men charged with killing State Trooper Philip J. Lamonaco today attacked the state's contention that one of the men had a silver gun the day of the shooting.


GREYHOUND TO BUY G.M. UNIT
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its North American transit-bus manufacturing operations to the Greyhound Corporation for an undisclosed price.


REAGAN GIVES KAMPELMAN ADDED STATE DEPT. POST
LEAD: President Reagan today appointed Max M. Kampelman, the chief American negotiator at the Geneva arms talks, to serve as counselor of the State Department.


Denver Fans Glued to TV
LEAD: A remarkable 88 percent of Denver television viewers were watching their Broncos on Sunday, the ''overnight'' ratings disclosed yesterday.


THERAPISTS SEEK CAUSES OF CHILD MOLESTING
LEAD: WHILE courts and communities confront allegations of sexual abuse of children in schools and day care centers around the country, researchers and therapists are struggling to understand what causes child molestation and devise better treatment.


EX-AIDE SAID TO ALTER MEMO ON REAGAN ROLE IN IRAN SALES
LEAD: Robert C. McFarlane, the former White House national security adviser, took part in a plan last November to put the best face on President Reagan's role in the Iran-contra arms case, a source close to Mr.
McFarlane said today.

Immunity Is Claimed
LEAD: ''Tysonitis'' is the fanciful tag that Don King, the boxing promoter, uses for the abruptly horizontal condition to which most opponents of Mike Tyson have been reduced.
But at a news conference yesterday, Tyson's next opponent, James (Bonecrusher) Smith, claimed to be immune to ''Tysonitis.'' Smith is the World Boxing Association champion who is to meet Tyson, the World Boxing Council champion, on March 7 in Las Vegas, Nev.


On the Way to Losing The Middle Class
LEAD: SUMMIT is an upper-middle-class suburb of 21,000 people, popular among New York City executives.
People here tend to vote Republican - there has not been a Democrat elected to the City Council in 60 years.


FOR FASHION, A GLITTERING NIGHT OF HONORS
LEAD: It could be viewed as a comfortable family gathering, or as a glittering assembly of stars.
Last night 450 people in evening clothes gathered at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for a dignified fashion awards ceremony followed by a home-style meat loaf dinner.
The atmosphere was both stylish and glamorous, the kind of mixture the fashion industry manages to pull off with panache.


CHINA OUSTS UNIVERSITY SCIENTIST WHO ADVOCATED BROADER RIGHTS
LEAD: A Chinese scientist who became a hero among thousands of students who demonstrated for greater democracy over the last month was dismissed today as the Communist Party moved to reassert control over intellectuals with unacceptable views.


KOCH PRESSES BOROUGH CHIEFS FOR THEIR SHELTER PROPOSALS
LEAD: The Koch administration yesterday said that it would go forward with its plan for 20 new homeless shelters in the five boroughs, unless the borough presidents offered alternatives shortly.


EXECUTIVES
LEAD: *
Acme Electric Corp., Cuba, N.Y., said G. Wayne Hawk, president, had succeeded James W. McLaughlin as chief executive.
Mr.
McLaughlin will remain chairman of the board.


Secondary and Oil Issues Spur Rally
LEAD: Wall Street's rally kept rolling along yesterday, but this time secondary stocks and oil issues, which have long been out of favor, provided the excitement that was lacking in the blue chips.

DEBUT OF 'MORNING PROGRAM' ON CBS
LEAD: HOW do you like your morning television?
Who's for intimate and jolly? ''The Morning Program'' yearns to be loved; Mariette Hartley, Rolland Smith and the gang want to be members of the family.
Maybe they will be in time, but yesterday they were self-conscious.
It wasn't just that they were meeting us for the first time; they also seemed to be meeting one another.


CUOMO AND SANTUCCI CONFER ON RACIAL ATTACK
LEAD: Governor Cuomo met with the Queens District Attorney here today to discuss turning the case of the Howard Beach racial assault over to a special prosecutor.


OPERA: 'SALOME' IN MILAN, STAGED BY ROBERT WILSON
LEAD: Robert Wilson is best known for the conception, direction and design of his own visionary spectacles, from ''Deafman Glance'' to ''Einstein on the Beach'' to ''The Civil Wars.'' But now he is venturing into the staging of the classics.
He had already done Marc-Antoine Charpentier's Baroque opera ''Medee'' in Lyons, and, just last month, Gluck's ''Alceste'' in Stuttgart.


U.S. HEALTH CARE FAULTED IN SENATE
LEAD: Testifying before a Senate Committee today, Joseph A. Califano Jr. called health care in this country ''a pothole system because it damages our people and shatters their lives.''


DOLLAR FALLS 1% FURTHER VS. MARK
LEAD: The dollar fell to a new six-year low against the West German mark in heavy trading on world currency markets yesterday, one day after European finance ministers acted to relieve tensions within the European Monetary System.


Corrections
LEAD: A dispatch yesterday from Baton Rouge, La., about the trial of three men accused of killing a Government witness against drug smugglers, misstated the date of the killing.
It was Feb. 19, 1986.


Ex-Wheeling Head Sold Stake Far Below Value
LEAD: Lloyd C. Lubensky is a friend of Allen E. Paulson, so good a friend that Mr.
Lubensky paid only $100,000 for Mr.
Paulson's 34.2 percent stake in the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Company, it was disclosed yesterday.
Analysts had estimated that, had Mr.
Lubensky paid the market price for the stock, he would have paid $13.5 million.


The U.N. Today: January 13, 1987
LEAD: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Commission on the Status of Women - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.


Head Start on Head Start
LEAD: Nothing should count higher in a society than the care of its children, yet in the United States children have become a neglected constituency, comprising 40 percent of the poor.
Head Start, one of the jewels of the Great Society, has proven that high-quality early childhood education for the disadvantaged produces youngsters much more likely to finish high school, hold a job and avoid welfare and crime.


Chip Index Posts Gain
LEAD: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator showed its strongest rebound yet, as chip makers in the United States, Europe and Japan reported increases in both orders and shipments, a trade group reported today.


Mellon Sees Lower Net
LEAD: The Mellon Bank Corporation said it expected to post lower year-end earnings next week, reflecting higher loan losses and the bank's decision to increase its reserves.
Mellon said it expected net income for 1986 to be $183 million, or $6.20 a share, down 9 percent from 1985.
Mellon Bank's stock fell $1.125, to $54.625.


I.B.M. Drop Holds Dow Gain to 3.52
LEAD: Despite a poor performance by I.B.M., the Dow Jones industrial average advanced for the eighth straight time yesterday.
But stock prices were mixed over all, ruining Wall Street's perfect record for 1987.


RIFT OVER HIGH-TECH EXPORTS
LEAD: Creating a storm of protest, a National Academy of Sciences report has derided the Reagan Administration's efforts to restrict exports of high-technology goods.


U.A. Cable Stake
LEAD: Telecommunications Inc. of Denver, the nation's largest cable system operator, has raised its stake in United Artists Communications Inc. to about 64 percent, or 26.6 million shares, from 55 percent.
Telecommunications bought a controlling 51 percent stake in United Artists in July for $390 million.


What the Riots in Soviet Asia Were About
LEAD: To the Editor:


KOHL ASSURES PUBLIC OF NO SHIFT TO RIGHT IF HE WINS ELECTION
LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl sought today to reassure the West German electorate that a victory for his center-right coalition in parliamentary elections this month would not mean a rightward shift in foreign policy.


Bethlehem Gain
LEAD: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said that as a result of improved operating results it would report a profit for the fourth quarter instead of the operating loss it had expected.
Bethlehem, the nation's third-largest steelmaker, said a $130 million investment tax-credit refund would be recorded in 1987, instead of in the fourth quarter of last year.


HISPANIC UNITS PROTEST ATTACK ON 2 IN QUEENS
LEAD: Several Hispanic organizations asked officials yesterday to name a special prosecutor to investigate charges by two Hispanic teen-agers that they were beaten by a group of white men in Queens and later abused by officers whom they had summoned.


NEW ICN DRUG PUTS CHIEF IN SPOTLIGHT
LEAD: In the 26 years since Milan Panic founded ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc., the company has gone from obscurity to the limelight and Mr.
Panic has acquired a reputation as a good promoter.
Some would say too good.


Mayor Has Plan to Regulate Food Vendors in Midtown Streets
LEAD: To the Editor:


WHEN THE LANGUAGE BARRIER BECOMES A BARRICADE
LEAD: For weeks, the signs posted outside banks and post offices in this southern port city have remained defaced, offering testimony to the intractability of India's oldest language dispute.


Bus Drivers' Duty
LEAD: The Transit Authority allows senior citizens to travel on city buses at half fare; they must show a Medicare card when challenged by a bus driver who believes they are too young for the subsidy.


WHO ARE THE POWERS BEHIND OFF BROADWAY?
LEAD: When Alan J. Schuster learned that Tina Howe's ''Coastal Disturbances,'' one of the most acclaimed plays of the fall season, had completed its limited run uptown without being picked up by a commercial producer, he put in an urgent call for the script.


RICHARD H. EVENSEN, AUTHORITY ON BRAILLE, AND WIFE ARE KILLED
LEAD: Richard H. Evensen, an authority at the Library of Congress on transcribing material into Braille, and his wife Lorraine were killed Monday evening when they were struck by a car while crossing a busy street.

LEAD: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced last night that John Cardinal O'Connor would hold an open meeting on Friday ''with interested parties'' to discuss his recent trip to the Middle East.

Apology for Miami
LEAD: Coach Jimmy Johnson of the University of Miami has apologized for his football team's behavior leading up to the Fiesta Bowl and promised to take steps to prevent such attention-grabbing incidents.
The coach said he would request stricter off-field supervision of the players and implement a dress code.


CUOMO NAMES AGRICULTURE CHIEF
LEAD: Dr.
Donald G. Butcher, president of the State College of Agriculture and Technology at Morrisville, has been chosen by Governor Cuomo as the state's new Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets, administration officials said today.


EX-CHRISTIE'S CHIEF TESTIFIES AT TRIAL
LEAD: The former president of Christie's, David Bathurst, testified yesterday in a State Supreme Court trial in Manhattan, giving an unusually detailed picture of the normally secret negotiations between an auction house and a seller of valuable works of art before a sale.

100 DIE IN EUROPE AS COLD CONTINUES
LEAD: Europe is experiencing one of its worst cold spells on record, with icy Siberian blasts sweeping across the region in recent days causing more than 100 deaths, avalanches, transport chaos, food hoarding and power-failure warnings.

GOING OUT GUIDE
LEAD: NOW IT CAN BE TOLD?
Three prominent sports reporters who recorded the day-in, day-out successes and failures of the Brooklyn Dodgers, and who helped create the legends of Ebbets Field will talk about the good ol' days tonight, under the aegis of the Brooklyn Historical Society (718-624-0890).
The program begins at 6 P.M.


DENG'S CRUSHING OF PROTEST IS DESCRIBED
LEAD: One day after several thousand university students held a protest for democracy here Jan. 1, Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader, ordered the suppression of any further demonstrations, Chinese sources said today.

KUWAIT CUTS KEY RATE
LEAD: Kuwait cut one of its key interest rates by half a point today in a widely expected move to bring them more in line with rates in the United States.
The central bank reduced its intervention rate in the domestic money market to 6.5 percent.


SUPREME COURT OVERTURNS NEW YORK'S MINIMUM LIQUOR PRICING
LEAD: The Supreme Court today struck down New York State regulations on liquor pricing that it said allowed wholesalers to dictate artificially high retail prices.


TROOPER-CASE DEFENDANT CALLED A LIAR
LEAD: The defendant Thomas W. Manning lied when he testified about the slaying of a state trooper five years ago on Interstate 80, Deputy Attorney General Anthony G. Simonetti said today in summarizing the two-month murder trial.


60-MINUTE GOURMET
LEAD: THE popularity of various foods, it seems to me, sometimes rests on the lure of their names.
Catfish, for example, one of the most American of fish, immediately calls forth delectable possibilities.
Food experts heartily list and promote its delightful qualities.
The name monkfish, on the other hand, does not readily entice, and it has only recently caught on at American restaurants and in homes.


LARGE DONATIONS FOR NEEDIEST ARE SENT BY COMPANY GROUPS
LEAD: A gift of $375 from Consolidated Edison employees to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund marks the 16th year that the systems planning department of the utility has contributed to the fund.


WEDTECH OFFICERS ARE REPLACED
LEAD: The top officers of the Wedtech Corporation, a Bronx military contractor that is the subject of several state and Federal investigations, resigned yesterday and were replaced, as the company struggled to find new financing to resume operations.


PREGNANCY TRANSFERS BY A.T.&amp;T.
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it had banned all pregnant women from its semiconductor production lines, in response to a University of Massachusetts study that found a sharply higher incidence of miscarriages among workers who produce computer chips.


UNDER SCRUTINY, SHE COPES WITH PRESSURE
LEAD: On Monday night, seated before her television set, one of Bess Myerson's friends watched New York City's Cultural Affairs Commissioner sail out of a long and trying meeting with Koch administration officials and past a tangle of clamoring reporters.


SOVIET AIDES EAGER ON GENEVA TALKS
LEAD: Soviet officials indicated new interest today in reviving the arms control talks in Geneva, which have languished since the summit meeting in Iceland.

LEAD: The Democratic Business Council, founded six years ago primarily as a fund-raising mechanism, is about to get a formidable new chairman, W. Verdi's Political Chameleon
LEAD: In 1848, when Verdi began his 14th opera, ''La Battaglia di Legnano,'' Europe was in the throes of political upheaval.
In Italy, citizens of Milan drove out the occupying Austrian troops after five days of street fighting, and republican revolutionaries in other cities were overthrowing aristocratic or foreign rulers.


RESORT FIRE IS TERMED ARSON
LEAD: A smoky fire damaged a showroom today at a resort hotel beset by labor problems, and investigators said it was arson.


Former Felon Elected Sheriff In a South Carolina County
LEAD: A pardoned felon was elected sheriff of McCormick County today, defeating a former acting sheriff charged with trying to fix the election.

DR. MILTON WERBEL
LEAD: Dr.
Milton Werbel, president of the Podiatry Society of the State of New York in the mid-1950's, died of a heart attack Jan. 8 at Palm Beach Lakes Hospital, Fla.
He was 77 years old and lived in Royal Palm Beach.


Howard Beach and the Governor
LEAD: Governor Cuomo, who has been taxed for his lack of visibility regarding the Howard Beach racial assault case, has now moved adroitly and decisively by appointing Charles Hynes as special prosecutor.
Mr.
Hynes, who is already serving as the state's special prosecutor for official misconduct, apparently has won the confidence of the victims of the attack - enough so for them to pledge the cooperation they had withheld from Queens District Attorney John


The Rumsfeld Rumor
LEAD: A new candidate has emerged in speculation around town concerning a possible successor to William J. Casey as Director of Central Intelligence.
He is Donald H. Rumsfeld, the former Congressman, Secretary of Defense and corporate executive.


DEVIL RELIEF GOALIE SAVORING SUCCESS
LEAD: Craig Billington, the 20-year-old goaltender for the Devils, has had plenty of success in a spot where three other goalies have failed this season, but he has not allowed the success to bother him.


Economic Scene; What Feeds A Bull Market
LEAD: WHAT explains the disparity between the roaring bull stock market and the sluggish economy?


Ridding Leeks of Grit
LEAD: DURING the winter months I always have a bunch of leeks in my refrigerator to add to soups and stews and to prepare as a side dish or appetizer.
Cold poached leeks with vinaigrette, for example, are among the most popular appetizers in France.
While leeks are versatile, healthful and delicious, they have one potential pitfall: sand.


SKETCHES OF THE PLAYERS
LEAD: Mitchell Wiggins: The 6-foot-4-inch Wiggins was another in the long line of box-score names that few bothered to learn about until last season's playoffs. . . .
After being used sparingly during the regular season, averaging 6.8 points a game, he had 24 points in first game of the Western Conference final against the Los Angeles Lakers.


FOOD NOTES
LEAD: Kosher Sausages


Teamster Leader Has Tumor
LEAD: Jackie Presser, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, underwent what was described as successful surgery today to remove a tumor on his lung, a spokesman for the 60-year-old union leader said.
Mr.
Presser underwent the surgery at the Cleveland Clinic after it was discovered in a routine checkup, according to his spokesman, John Climaco.


Citicorp Auction
LEAD: Interest rates were mixed at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper yesterday.
The average rate for $50 million of 91-day commercial paper was 5.812 percent, down from 5.915 percent last week and the lowest since Nov. 25, when the average was 5.801 percent.
Citicorp also sold $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 5.798 percent, up from 5.777 percent last week.


SAN FRANCISCO AIDS PROJECT TRACING WOMEN
LEAD: In an effort to curb the spread of AIDS, the Department of Public Health is tracking down and warning women who have had sexual relations with men later diagnosed as having AIDS.


JOB RIGHTS BACKED IN PREGNANCY CASE
LEAD: In a case of major importance to working women and employers, the United States Supreme Court ruled today that states may require employers to grant special job protection to employees who are physically unable to work because of pregnancy.


Guinness Picks Finance Officer
LEAD: Guinness, the British brewing company, named James Bryant, an accountant and merchant banker, as its finance director today after the resignation of Olivier Roux.


Advertising; New Drive By Ladies' Journal
LEAD: ON the basis of focus group interviews of ad agency media planners and their supervisors in New York and Chicago, certain important people at The Ladies' Home Journal believe that though those respondents are bright to many ways of the modern world, they do not generally read women's service magazines nor the publications in which they advertise.


PSYCHIATRIST FILES A LIBEL SUIT OVER FILM OF PLATH'S 'BELL JAR'
LEAD: A Boston psychiatrist who says she is the basis for a character in Sylvia Plath's 1961 novel about suicide, ''The Bell Jar,'' has filed a suit contending defamation, invasion of privacy and intentional infliction of emotional damage, growing out of a 1979 movie version of the book.


FARSIGHTED PROSECUTOR: CHARLES J. HYNES
LEAD: Even before he was named to investigate the Dec. 20 Howard Beach racial attack, Charles J. Hynes was preparing for the job.

LEAD: Four thousand police officers and firefighters lined Fifth Avenue yesterday for four blocks for the funeral of Officer Francis J. La Sala, who died Saturday from injuries suffered while helping to rescue a dozen people from a burning building.

LEAD: THE photocopying business is getting personal.
Several companies have recently introduced hand-held devices that slip easily into a briefcase and can copy narrow strips of text.

LEAD: The Federal grand jury that called Bess Myerson to testify is hearing evidence on whether Carl A. Capasso, a wealthy contractor, improperly billed to his company the cost of improvements made to two personal residences, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

LEAD: SWISSAIR, known in the airline industry for the quality of its in-flight food, faced a crucial culinary decision the other day: to sprinkle slivered almonds over its curried shrimp entree or to leave it plain.

LEAD: A Marine Corps guard arrested last month as a suspected spy by the American authorities in Vienna was lured to work for Soviet intelligence by a Russian woman employed by the American Embassy in Moscow, a State Department official said today.

LEAD: A planned conversion of the Beacon Theater into a nightclub would meet zoning rules now that its dance area has been reduced, the City Buildings Commissioner, Charles M. Smith Jr., said yesterday.

LEAD: It was an unusual scene in a country famous for harmonious labor relations: hundreds of union members shouting at each other and finally throwing punches as they debated whether to go along with a Government plan to privatize the national railways.

The U.N. Today: Jan. 14, 1987
LEAD: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Commission on Status of Women -10 A.M. and 3 P.M.


EATING IN KANSAS CITY: ULTIMATE UN-DIET
LEAD: There are at least three Kansas Citys.
There is the Kansas City of the ear, where Charlie Parker, Count Basie and Jay McShann blued the air over 12th Street and Vine.
There is the Kansas City of the memory, a town bustling with cattle, cowboys and frontier wildness.
And there is the Kansas City of the stomach: a metropolis devoted to lard, sugar, salt, beef and other dietary unspeakables.


South Korea Is Urged To Free 3 Journalists
LEAD: Amnesty International and the Committee to Protect Journalists have issued appeals for the release of three South Korean journalists who were arrested last month for exposing a purported Government campaign to censor the press.


Airbus Joins Lease Venture
LEAD: Airbus Industrie, the European aircraft-building consortium, said it had formed a leasing operation with Ireland's Guinness Peat Aviation and that the venture was ordering $2 billion worth of Airbus jetliners.


Market Place; Beneficiaries Of Stock Surge
LEAD: LARGE-CAPITALIZATION issues - drugs, papers and oils, among others - figure prominently on the expanding list of stocks scoring new 52-week highs on the New York Stock Exchange.
But the market's broad advance also saw new highs set last week by components of the long-depressed oil-service industry, as well as by stocks in such ''niche'' sectors as check printers, funeral-related businesses and New Jersey home builders.


FRENCH WRITER SEIZED IN BEIRUT
LEAD: Gunmen today kidnapped a French reporter covering Terry Waite's mission to free American and other foreign hostages held in Lebanon.
They pistol-whipped and shot at another French journalist, but he escaped.


Metropolitan Life
LEAD: A county judge has reaffirmed his decision to allow the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company of New York to assume life insurance policies issued by subsidiaries of the bankrupt Baldwin-United Corporation.
The Sun Life Guaranty Company of Arkansas had asked Judge Perry Whitmore of the Pulaski County Circuit Court to reconsider his decision.

Consumers Power Co., Jackson, Mich., announced yesterday that it had received approval from the Michigan Public Service Commission to issue $500 million in new debt securities.


OMAHA VOTES TO OUST ITS MAYOR OVER HIS CONDUCT
LEAD: Mayor Michael Boyle lost his bid to remain in office today as residents voted to remove him for alleged abuse of power.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration let it be known today that it wants the dollar, now the weakest it has been since the start of the decade, to decline still further.

LEAD: Iran asserted tonight that its attacking forces had broken through Iraq's ''strongest defensive line east of Basra'' and pushed forward six miles.

MOVING DAY:
LEAD: A helicopter lifting the historic Cape Poge lighthouse from the tip of Chappaquiddick Point yesterday at Martha's Vineyard, Mass.
The lighthouse was moved to a new site 500 feet away because the bluff on which it sat since its construction in 1893 was eroding. (AP)


Arms and the Mail
LEAD: Intervention by Representative Mario Biaggi, Democrat of the Bronx, has persuaded the Postal Service to cancel a plan to allow delivery of ammunition through the mail.
Sweeping changes in the nation's gun control laws adopted by the last Congress allowed gun owners to order ammunition by mail, beginning last Nov.


PERES ASSERTS ISRAEL WARNED OF 1-IN-4 ODDS IN IRAN DEAL
LEAD: When Israel recommended to the United States in January 1986 that it engage in an arms-for-hostages deal with Iran, Israel cautioned the Reagan Administration that there was at best a 25 percent chance of success, Foreign Minister Shimon Peres was quoted as saying today.


Ernest O. Melby, 95, An Education Dean At N.Y.U. 11 Years
LEAD: Ernest O. Melby, a former dean at New York University and a former president of Montana State University, died Sunday in Boca Raton, Fla., where he had lived for the last six years.
He was 95 years old.


THE CASE FOR BAKING PASTRY SHELLS 'BLIND,' AT LOW HEAT
LEAD: NANCY SILVERTON didn't realize that it was unusual to bake tart shells ''blind'' (unfilled) at a moderate-to-low oven temperature.
But that is precisely what Ms.
Silverton, a pastry chef and consultant in California, recommends in her new book, ''Desserts'' (Harper &amp; Row, $22.50).

LEAD: President Reagan asked the Senate today to approve two 1970's treaties that limit the size of underground nuclear explosions.

LEAD: The Secretary of Labor told a Senate committee today that there was a ''dangerous trend'' in which American workers with insufficient skills were seeking jobs that demanded ever greater skills.


Topics: Rejuvenated; Flower Beds
LEAD: Envy the indoor gardeners blessed with green thumbs: Bougainvillea cascades from hanging pots in their sun-filled windows; their desks overflow with ivy.
But for each of them, surely, there are a dozen whose thumbs remain dispiritingly brown.
Their yuccas look leggy, and their African violets refuse to flower.


FINDING ON RADIOACTIVITY MAY UPSET PHYSICS LAW
LEAD: Experiments conducted deep in a South Dakota gold mine have reportedly produced evidence for an extremely rare form of radioactive decay whose existence, if proved, would overthrow one of the basic laws of physics.


54 Are Killed in in Ethiopia Crash
LEAD: An Ethiopian Air Force plane carrying 54 passengers and crew members crashed today in the Eritrean provincial capital of Asmara, killing everyone on board, the official Ethiopian radio reported.

Mr.

LEAD: A 26-year-old man arrested Monday at a Milan airport carrying about 24 pounds of plastic explosives is being investigated for possible links to Middle East terrorist groups, Italian officials said today.

LEAD: Alfred Y. Allee, a former Texas Ranger who gained national attention fighting political bosses and breaking up farmworker strikes in south Texas, died of cancer Monday.

3 State Governors Sworn In
LEAD: Roy Romer, a Democrat, was sworn in yesterday as Colorado's 59th Governor.
Mr.
Romer, who had been the State Treasurer since 1977, succeeded Richard D. Lamm, a Democrat who held the office for 12 years.
Also sworn in were Gov.
Bill Clinton of Arkansas, to a fourth term, and Gov.
Joe Frank Harris of Georgia, to a second term.

LEAD: Liquor retailers in New York State generally expressed disappointment and anger over yesterday's Supreme Court ruling invalidating the state's pricing law for distilled spirits.

She and several of her friends came to Merkin Concert Hall Sunday night, playing a program of largely American music from our time.

TICKET ON THE 50-YARD LINE? IT'LL COST $1,500 IN PASADENA
LEAD: For some Giants fans who have their hearts set on being in Pasadena for Super Bowl XXI on Jan. 25, money is apparently no object.
The face value of a Super Bowl ticket is $75, but agencies that legally deal in buying and selling tickets on the open market say that prices may go as high as $1,500 for a prime seat.

LEAD: The Knicks tried three players on Rolando Blackman last night.

LEAD: A former Justice Minister who until recently headed Colombia's anti-drug campaign was shot and seriously wounded today in Budapest in an apparent extension of the country's drug war into Eastern Europe.


CBS PRESENTS 'MY DISSIDENT MOM'
LEAD: ORIGINALLY scheduled for an afternoon broadcast last October as a CBS ''Schoolbreak Special,'' ''My Dissident Mom'' was suddenly pulled, prompting rumors that the little drama may have been too outspokenly ''liberal'' in its stance against nuclear weapons.
But as it turns out, the program was merely being saved for prime time and a presumably larger audience.

LEAD: Prison sentences of 40 to 100 years were imposed yesterday on eight men convicted as top leaders and key associates of the ''commission'' that ruled the Mafia in the United States.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An obituary yesterday of Harold Eliot Krents, the lawyer whose life story inspired ''Butterflies Are Free,'' gave an incorrect date for the funeral.
The service will be at 1 P.M. today, not tomorrow, at the Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street.


Robins Deadline
LEAD: Federal District Judge Robert R. Merhige Jr. has given the A. H. Robins Company three weeks to submit a reorganization plan, saying he has unhappy with what he called the lack of cooperation from lawyers involved in the 16-month-old bankruptcy proceeding.
Judge Merhige said Monday that he had had ''less cooperation in this case than any other case in 20 years'' on the bench.

LEAD: When the Telenet Communications Corporation started a big advertising push for its data communications network, it seemed silly to ask executives to clip out and send a coupon for more information about electronic messaging.
So Telenet wisely opened its lines to allow respondents to send, via computer and modem, their ''electronic business reply cards.

LEAD: A city social worker yesterday described in court testimony the ''commotion'' and ''struggle'' that he heard between police officers and Eleanor Bumpurs before she was fatally shot by one of the officers during an eviction dispute two years ago.

LEAD: In a preview of the preliminary city budget he will present Thursday, Mayor Koch proposed yesterday to set aside an extra $75 million for school maintenance from surplus funds from the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

LEAD: Law-enforcement officials today seized two men, one of whom was charged with setting the fatal fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel on New Year's Eve.
The other was described as an accomplice.

LEAD: Dennis Conner's Stars &amp; Stripes took an early lead and held on to defeat Chris Dickson's New Zealand by 1 minute 20 seconds today in the opening race of the four-of-seven-race America's Cup challenger's final series.

Myerson's friend.

LEAD: The Amtrak and Conrail trains involved in a fatal collision near Baltimore early this month were exceeding speed limits immediately before the collision, investigators for the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

LEAD: A spot check of New York City's ambulance services found that despite improvements over the last few years, many people with life-threatening conditions are facing unnecessarily long waits for service, City Council President Andrew J. Stein said yesterday.

Every muscle has the ability to contract and relax, expand and shrink.

LEAD: THESE are hard times in the wine world.

Understand, I'm talking about wine and not about the highly popular drinks made from it.
The popularity of wine coolers is a remarkable phenomenon and a great boon to the companies that make them.

CONCERT: VERDI'S 'BATTAGLIA DI LEGNANO
LEAD: ''LA BATTAGLIA DI LEGNANO'' is one of several Verdi operas whose action, though set in remote times, sent patriotic juices surging through the veins of his countrymen in the 19th century, when Italy was a jumble of separate city-states.
Although rarely revived, it is not an inconsequential work, a fact that could be glimpsed Monday night in the Opera Orchestra of New York's concert performance at Carnegie Hall.

The Right Minimum Wage: $0.00
LEAD: The Federal minimum wage has been frozen at $3.35 an hour for six years.
In some states, it now compares unfavorably even with welfare benefits available without working.
It's no wonder then that Edward Kennedy, the new chairman of the Senate Labor Committee, is being pressed by organized labor to battle for an increase.


POLITICAL SATIRE IN 'SPITTING IMAGE'
LEAD: PROBABLY the last thing Ronald Reagan needs these days is a volley of satirical darts aimed in his direction, but that's just what NBC has in store for him this evening at 9:30, courtesy of a gang of British puppets spawned by a TV production called ''Spitting Image.'' The show became a popular success in England by using its puppets' wicked caricatures to spoof and puncture everybody from the Royal Family and Margaret Thatcher to the latest batch of rock stars.


Enron Sees Charge
LEAD: The Enron Corporation said that for the fourth quarter it expected to take a number of nonrecurring charges against earnings that would virtually offset a gain of $123 million from the sale of its petrochemical unit.
The company said the charges included employee relocation and severance costs, building-lease obligations and write-downs in the value of assets.

LEAD: As general counsel of Flying Tiger Line Inc., Lawrence M. Nagin has had few chances recently to ruminate about the fortunes of the air cargo industry.
Flying Tiger, the world's largest air cargo carrier, narrowly avoided liquidation a few weeks ago by negotiating substantial wage concessions from its pilots and announcing a major cost-cutting program.

LEAD: Another of the new stadium courses will become part of the PGA Tour Wednesday when the long and tricky PGA West course serves as the host track for the $900,000 Bob Hope Chrysler Classic.
This second event on the 1987 PGA Tour is a pro-amateur event played for five days over four courses.

LEAD: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou was reported today to have agreed to restore a statue of Harry S. Truman, which was dynamited last March by leftist militants, to its original place on a central Athens square.

LEAD: The Great American Ski Chase is not a familiar event to most of the American sports public, but this winter it will attract between 12,000 and 14,000 participants.

Governor Kean of New Jersey now declares it his top priority for 1987 and he outlines a plan that combines decency, common sense and intelligent research on welfare and poverty.

ROCKETS DISCUSS DRUG TEMPTATION
LEAD: On Tuesday morning, the Houston Rockets were stunned by the news that two of their teammates - Lewis Lloyd and Mitchell Wiggins - had been banned from the National Basketball Association after testing positive for cocaine.


South Carolina Inducts Republican Governor
LEAD: Carroll Campbell was sworn in as Governor today, becoming South Carolina's second Republican Governor since Reconstruction.
He immediately extended an olive branch to the Democratic-dominated Legislature.

Data Department
LEAD: The American Library Association, concerned from the outset of the Reagan Administration about the President's vow to cut back on the ''blizzard of paper'' produced by the Government, has compiled a six-year chronology that it says shows steadily constricting access to Government information.


UNION SAYS INQUIRY CLEARS IT OF BLAME ON PUERTO RICO FIRE
LEAD: Union officials here said today that they had been vindicated by the results of the investigation into the fire that took 96 lives at the Dupont Plaza Hotel.


GOTTI PROSECUTORS PALY TAPE, THEN REST CASE
LEAD: The prosecution rested its case yesterday in the Federal racketeering trial of John Gotti and six co-defendants after playing recordings of a secretly taped conversation in which the reputed underboss of the Gambino crime family berated a captain in the organization for ''disrespecting'' him.

AUSTIN ROVER CAR
LEAD: Austin Rover introduced a new luxury car that marks the British auto maker's return to the American market after a six-year absence and carries many of its hopes for financial recovery.
The car, called the Sterling, was developed jointly by Austin Rover and Japan's Honda Motor Company and sells in Europe as the Rover 800.


S.E.C. Rule Change
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission voted unanimously today to ease a restriction governing the underwriting of securities offerings by borkerage firms.
The rule change would allow a firm to solicit brokered transactions except during a designated ''cooling-off period'' immediately before the offering is completed.


Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on the Washington Talk page yesterday about immigration visas incorrectly listed the three Soviet republics eligible for such visas.
The three are Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania; Liechtenstein is a sovereign European nation outside the Soviet bloc.


Oil Imports Rose 22% in '86
LEAD: Oil imports last year rose to their highest level since 1980, an oil industry trade group said today, citing the drop in prices in the United States.


STAGE: 'DAVID LEVINSKY,' AN IMMIGRANT'S STORY
LEAD: IN ''The Rise of David Levinsky,'' Isaiah Sheffer and Bobby Paul's musical about the Jewish immigrant experience in turn-of-the-century America, Larry Kert bites deeply into a title character who is practically identical to his much smaller role in the recent, ill-fated Broadway show ''Rags.'' But where ''Rags'' failed to make coherent drama out of the story of Eastern European Jews flocking to New York's Lower East Side, ''The Rise of David Levinsky,'' adapted from a novel by Abraham


U.S. UPSETS ALLIES BY LETTING DOLLAR EXTEND ITS DECLINE
LEAD: The dollar tumbled again today, driven by continued signals from the White House that the Government would not support the currency.


SENATE DELAYS VOTE ON CLEAN WATER ACT AT G.O.P.'S REQUEST
LEAD: The Senate today postponed until next Wednesday a vote on a bill to renew the Clean Water Act in a move to accommodate Republicans who asked that action be delayed so that President Reagan would not have to veto the bill before his State of the Union Message on Jan. 27.


Reagan's Role
LEAD: To the Editor:


Rodgers to Run Again
LEAD: On April 26, the day of the New Jersey Waterfront Marathon, Bill Rodgers and some other renowned distance runners will be competing in a considerably shorter race.

LEAD: John Morton of Seton Hall heading downcourt after stealing the ball in the first half against Pitt last night.
Pitt won, 87-85. (NYT/Larry C. Morris)

Two directors were also asked to quit.

Credit Card Issue By Republicbank
LEAD: A unit of the Republicbank Corporation in Texas yesterday announced plans for a $200 million sale of notes backed by credit card receivables, which it said would be the first public offering of such securities.

FABRICS: STRUDY, HAND-PAINTED
LEAD: MARK FEIGENBAUM, standing, and Raymond Wenzel offer hand-painted textiles they designed.
These include sturdy cotton poplin and cotton blended with silk taffeta, said Mr.
Wenzel of Marc-Raymond, their company.
The fabrics are used for upholsteries, wall coverings and draperies, and can be washed by machine or dry-cleaned.


ST. JOHN'S OUTCLASSES BROOKLYN
LEAD: Playing without two starters and continuing its search for an outside shooter, St.
John's sprinted, then stalled and finally rumbled past Brooklyn College, 70-48, at Alumni Hall last night.


Morgan Notes
LEAD: J. P. Morgan &amp; Company is offering $200 million of 7 1/2 percent senior notes due in 1997 at a price of 99.275 to yield 7.605 percent, through Morgan Stanley &amp; Company.
Noncallable for five years, the notes carry the highest triple-A ratings from Moody's and S.&amp; P.


GOVERNOR SUED BY L.I. UTILITY ON ATOM PLANT
LEAD: The Long Island Lighting Company asserted in a Federal suit filed today that Governor Cuomo's efforts to block the opening of the Shoreham nuclear power plant violated the constitutional and civil rights of the company and its stockholders.

Canadian Debut
LEAD: The Farm Credit Corporation of Canada made its debut in the American bond market yesterday with a $100 million issue of 7 1/2 percent notes due in 1996 at a price of 99.375 to yield 7.59 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company.
With the backing of the Canadian Government, the notes are rated triple A.


Harry Avirom, 72, Supervisor Of Demolition of Ebbets Field
LEAD: Harry Avirom, the supervisor of the demolition of many New York City landmarks, including Ebbets Field, the old Belmont Park and the Polo Grounds, died of heart disease Sunday at St.
John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif.
He was 72 years old and lived in Santa Monica.


NOTORIETY OF THE QUEENS ATTACK BUILDS ON ANGER LEFT FROM EARLIER ASSAULTS
LEAD: The Howard Beach assault, far from being an unusually grievous case, is disturbingly similar to other incidents of racial violence in New York City in recent years.
Yet a combination of factors beyond the incident itself has elevated this case to a notoriety unlike that of any other.


Memorial for Lost Rhode Island Fishermen
LEAD: Relatives and friends facing the ocean at service yesterday at the Point Judith Lighthouse in Naragansett for four fisherman who were believed to have drowned when their boat sank.
Alan P. Gelfuso of Cranston, owner of the ill-fated trawler, organized the service. (AP)


King's 'Dream' Is Kept at a Distance
LEAD: During the national holiday Monday honoring the Rev.
Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr., we will no doubt hear a number of high-toned official pronouncements that his legacy lives on.
But the tributes to Dr.
King, whose chief goal at the time of his death was to end poverty, are painfully ironic when viewed alongside the harsh facts about the growing numbers of poor and powerless in this country.

Yields Fall On Funds
LEAD: Yields on money market mutual funds began returning to near normal levels for the week ended yesterday, after surging along with the higher Fed funds late in December and earlier this month.
During the same week, yields offered by banks and thrift institutions for certificates of deposit and money market accounts were unchanged to slightly lower.

LEAD: A pardoned felon was elected sheriff of McCormick County Tuesday, defeating a former acting sheriff charged with trying to fix the election.

THE STAGE: ONE-ACTS AT PUNCH-LINE
LEAD: IN David Ives's ''Words, Words, Words,'' three actors pretend to be caged monkeys taking part in a laboratory experiment.
Mr.
Ives suggests that if the monkeys keep typing long enough, sooner or later one of them will write ''Hamlet.'' One monkey (Helen Greenberg) finally begins to write ''Hamlet'' - at least she arrives at the word ''contumely'' - but the other two are so self-involved that they cannot tell the difference between gibberish and Shakespeare.


PIANO: CHRISTOPHER O'RILEY
LEAD: CHRISTOPHER O'RILEY is a pianist one would like to hear again, though preferably not in the renovated Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall, where he played Tuesday evening.
The room's acoustics - always glaring and now more so, especially from the balcony - conspired with the pianist's impressive but overemployed command of the instrument's extreme dynamic possibilities to approach the threshold of pain at some of the fortissimo climaxes.


Stadium Course Criticized by Pros
LEAD: ''There is no way I can have fun on this course,'' said Ben Crenshaw.

CONCERT: RECENT MUSIC AT MERKIN
LEAD: THE emphasis was on the keyboard Tuesday night at Merkin Concert Hall, when the Group for Contemporary Music presented a program of works by Igor Stravinsky, William Hibbard and Stefan Wolpe.
Two pianos were on hand, and three pianists - Ursula Oppens, Alan Feinberg and Garrick Ohlsson.
Benjamin Hudson was the token violinist.


Gala Benefit Planned for Lincoln Center
LEAD: Scores of entertainers ranging from Jim Dale to Bernadette Peters to Milton Berle to the Radio City Music Hall Rockettes plan to converge at Lincoln Center for a gala $500,000 fund-raising benefit, Nathan Leventhal, the center's president, announced yesterday.


NETS DO NOT FEEL AT HOME ON ROAD
LEAD: In the brightest moments of a generally dreary season, the Nets always seemed to point to their defense, the one facet of their game that had become dependable.
But even that failed them tonight, and now they are staring at another forgettable losing streak.


Talking Deals; Merger Games, Play-by-Play
LEAD: CORPORATE takeovers have become a spectator sport.
The business world follows these predatory dealings today with the same fascination shown professional football games, as the press provides play-by-play accounts and dazzling descriptions of tactics and personalities.

Canada's Trade Surplus
LEAD: Canada had a trade surplus of $811 million (Canadian) in November, compared with an upwardly revised $946 million surplus in October, the Government said today.


Chubb-Sovereign
LEAD: The Chubb Corporation, one of the nation's largest insurance companies, said it had agreed in principle to acquire the Sovereign Corporation in a stock transaction that would be valued at about $9.75 a share, or about $112 million, at Chubb's current stock price.
Under terms of the deal, each of Sovereign's 11,534,944 shares outstanding would be exchanged for 0.15 shares of Chubb.


U.S. TO CONSULT WITH PAKISTANIS ON AFGHAN MOVES
LEAD: The United States and Pakistan plan to consult early next week on a common approach toward the seeming Soviet effort to bring about a political settlement to the war in Afghanistan, Reagan Administration officials said today.


Whither Griscom?
LEAD: With Marlin Fitzwater moving from Vice President Bush's office to become the chief White House spokesman, the Bush staff is searching for a new press secretary, and one of those featured in early speculation is Thomas C. Griscom, who recently completed two years as executive director of the National Republican Senatorial Committee.


Gold Rises as Dollar Dives
LEAD: As the dollar plunged yesterday to another six-year low against the West German mark in heavy and often hectic trading, gold prices climbed further.


DIGITAL NET SOARS 98% IN QUARTER
LEAD: Continuing its remarkable surge while the rest of the industry flounders, the Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that net income for its second fiscal quarter soared 98 percent, to $270 million.

HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: PENETRATING finishes such as those achieved by old-time craftsmen with linseed-oil have a depth and luster quite unlike those of surface coatings such as varnish or lacquer.
They help to accent the natural grain and color of many fine hardwoods, and the finish is much easier to touch up than lacquer or varnish.

Q &amp; A
LEAD: Q.I used rubbing alcohol to remove a gummy adhesive (left when a price tag was removed) from a marble table top.
Unfortunately, the alcohol also left a dull-looking spot.
How can I restore the finish?
A.Chances are that the marble was originally protected with a coat of wax or some type of sealer.

That Sticky Salary Wicket
LEAD: In theory, it looked easy, maybe even too easy.
A blue-ribbon commission would propose pay increases for members of Congress, Federal judges and senior Federal employees.
The President would review the proposals, perhaps modify them a bit and transmit them to Congress.
Then, without any member of Congress needing to lift a finger, the raises would take effect automatically in 30 days unless both houses passed resolutions of disapproval.
