PORTRAIT OF ELDERLY: STILL INDEPENDENT DESPITE LIMITATIONS
LEAD: MOST Americans age 65 and older do not have private pensions and rely on Social Security, according to a study conducted by Louis Harris &amp; Associates for the Commonwealth Fund's Commission on Elderly People Living Alone.
Although their incomes are limited, most of the elderly do not receive money from their children; in fact, they are four times more likely to give regular financial assistance to their children than they are to receive it.

INSPIRATONAL IDEAS FROM EUROPE'S BEST
LEAD: THERE are gardeners who are as rooted to their plot of ground as any plant they cultivate.
Suggest a trip that involves two days from home and they will find it impossible: who would water the petunias?
Some who wrap themselves in their private visions work wonders.
Uncontaminated by outside influences, they create personal gardens of powerful charm, naive perhaps, but sometimes coherent and articulate as only single-mindedness can make them.

Pou.

URBAN HOMICIDE RATES IN U.S. UP SHARPLY IN 1986
LEAD: Homicides in some of the nation's largest cities rose sharply last year as officials grappled with an increase in shootings among teen-agers and the seemingly intractable spread of cocaine and its derivative, crack.

RETAIL SALES SURGED BY 4.4%
LEAD: Retail sales surged 4.4 percent in December, the Commerce Department reported today.
The gains were propelled by Christmas shoppers and by car buyers rushing to claim sales tax deductions for the last time.


Crude Oil Prices Gain On Saudi-Soviet Move
LEAD: Crude oil prices moved higher on world markets yesterday in the wake of a Saudi Arabian diplomatic initiative to the Soviet Union and growing support for oil prices in the $18-to-$20-a-barrel range among key oil-producing countries outside the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.


Holly Sugar Bid Considered
LEAD: Shamrock Holdings of California Inc., an investment firm controlled by the Roy E. Disney family, said that it was considering making an offer to acquire the Holly Sugar Corporation.


Summing It Up
LEAD: The Hartford Whalers, who had lost four straight games before playing the Boston Bruins last night, may have been experiencing a midseason slump.
But Coach Jack Evans, according to an Associated Press interview in which he described his team's plight, was still able to display metaphorical wizardry: ''As of late, our whole game has gone sour.


HOMELESS REPORT ACCUSES PENTAGON
LEAD: A program to make under-used military facilities available as shelters for the homeless has largely failed because of inaction on the part of the Defense Department, the National Coalition for the Homeless said yesterday.


JUSTICES UPHOLD RIGHT TO SUE BY PUBLIC HOUSING TENANTS
LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled today that tenants in federally subsidized, low-income housing projects are entitled to a Federal court hearing on purported violations of their rights under Federal housing law.


OPERA: MOORE'S 'BALLAD OF BABY DOE'
LEAD: DOUGLAS MOORE'S ''Ballad of Baby Doe,'' once hailed as a landmark American opera and fondly remembered by many from New York City Opera performances with Beverly Sills in the title role, has not joined the standard operatic repertory, but holds to a spot on its fringe.
The Bronx Opera has revived it in a well-managed production heard Sunday afternoon at Lehman College in the company's home borough and bound for the Hunter College Playhouse in Manhattan this weekend.


SUPPORTERS SAY PRESIDENT OWES APOLOGY ON IRAN
LEAD: Many of the Republican lawmakers investigating the Iran-contra affair, including some of President Reagan's strongest supporters in Congress, now say they believe the President should take full responsibility for his Administration's mistakes, apologize to the American public and appeal to the people to forgive him.


Hialeah Loses Dates
LEAD: ''Do we want to have to explain to the world that we allowed Hialeah to disappear?'' That was the question asked yesterday by Barry Richard, the attorney representing the race track.


Alexander Leitch Dies at 86; An Ex-Secretary of Princeton
LEAD: Alexander Leitch, secretary of Princeton University for 32 years and a senior administrative officer for another decade, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Pennington, N.J.
He was 86 years old.


U.S. Bridges for Costa Rica
LEAD: A unit of 247 United States Army engineers will begin building seven bridges in Costa Rica this month, the Public Security Ministry said.
A ministry statement on Tuesday said construction of two large bridges and five small ones in the southern Pacific coast region would allow year-round use of a highway that was often closed by floods.


AS TRUCE BEGINS, AFGHAN CAPITAL SHOWS ITS VISITORS A RELAXED FACE
LEAD: For a city surrounded by a war, this arid capital tucked amid the snow-covered Hindu Kush mountains seemed strangely placid today as Government forces prepared to begin a unilateral cease-fire.


7 WILL BE NAMED TO ETHICS PANEL WITH WIDE POWERS TO INVESTIGATE
LEAD: A bishop, a former newspaper editor and a retired judge are among those who Governor Cuomo will name to a commission with broad powers to investigate ethics in government.
The appointments will be formally announced Thursday.


Canadian Tire Bid By CTC Blocked
LEAD: Government regulators blocked a takeover bid worth $270 million, or about $198 million in United States currency, for the Canadian Tire Corporation, Canada's largest automotive and hardware retail chain, by a group of Canadian Tire store operators.
A ruling by the Ontario and Quebec securities commissions stopped the store dealers, represented by CTC Dealer Holdings Ltd., from acquiring 49 percent of Canadian Tire's common shares at a price of $160.24, or about $117.76 American, each.


PENTAGON OFFICIAL, LIKED TO CONTRA AID, TO RETIRE
LEAD: The Defense Department's senior official concerned with Central American affairs, Nestor D. Sanchez, will leave office on Jan. 31 amid reports from Administration and Congressional sources that investigators are questioning the nature of his role in the Iran-contra affair.


RACIAL GANG FIGHT IN LOUISIANA
LEAD: About 40 teen-age boys armed with knives, chains and clubs attacked each other in racial gang fighting Tuesday in Algiers, a racially integrated suburb of New Orleans, the authorities said.
No injuries were reported


US Sprint Rate Cut
LEAD: The US Sprint Communications Company, responding to lower long-distance telephone rates recently announced by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said that it too would lower its rates.
The Sprint reductions on long-distance services would be 9 percent for residential consumers, 13 percent for businesses, effective Feb.


Last Chance in Geneva
LEAD: Either something very important will happen in the arms talks that resume today in Geneva or the talks will soon dissipate into the usual diplomatic minuet.
The Russians want action; they have challenged the Administration by appointing an able and influential Deputy Foreign Minister to lead their negotiating team.


MEXICO TIE TO REPUBLIC WRITE-DOWN
LEAD: The Republic National Bank of New York has become the first of Mexico's major American lenders to write down a significant portion of its Mexican public-sector debt, Wall Street sources say.


Market Place; Thrift Stock Opportunities
LEAD: WHILE many savings and loan institutions have recently posted record earnings -mainly from taking in more interest than they pay out - in many instances stock prices have failed to reflect those gains.


NEW STORM DOORS
LEAD: AN alternative to the functional, although not particularly decorative, aluminum storm door might be a storm door made of wood.
The Old Wagon Factory in Clarksville, Va., manufactures ornamental storm doors in Douglas fir or poplar.
The doors come in numerous designs, including Victorian, Chippendale and styles for the modern home.


Treasury Bonds Drop Again
LEAD: Treasury bond prices declined yesterday for a third consecutive day, as developments in the domestic economy and foreign exchange markets reduced demand from investors and speculators.


Bozell Quits Account, Sells Houston Office
LEAD: In two other moves yesterday, Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon &amp; Eckhardt quit about $20 million in McDonald's co-op advertising-association business, and sold its Houston office to a local shop.


Bridge: Ross Spiro Has Twice Been An Elephant-Killer in Jersey
LEAD: It seems very unlikely that a mouse has ever killed an elephant, but the equivalent in bridge terms does occur from time to time: the bottom-seeded team upsets the top seed in the first round.

U.S. SEES SETBACK FOR CHINA'S PLANS OF MODERNIZATION
LEAD: An attack by China's leader on a writer widely seen as the most influential intellectual figure to have emerged since the Cultural Revolution could undermine China's modernization program by frightening many intellectuals, State Department officials and other specialists said today.


HERS
LEAD: AT the age of 27 I became the head foreign-exchange options trader at a major commercial bank in New York.
I managed hundreds of millions of dollars' worth of options.
I ran offices in New York and London.
It was a powerful and demanding position.


Greek Power Workers Strike
LEAD: Greek electricity workers stayed away from their jobs today ahead of a 24-hour general strike that is expected to bring Greece to a standstill over demands for an end to a Government wage freeze.
The 48-hour stoppage by 30,000 power workers resulted in blackouts in Athens and northern Greece.


Meat Department
LEAD: The Department of Agriculture is seriously considering and expected to act favorably on a proposal from a health-oriented consumer group that it change the name of one classification of beef from Good to Select.


National Car Rental Chooses Chiat/Day
LEAD: Chiat/Day New York has been designated the agency for National Car Rental, which has been under new ownership since Jan. 1.


ELIZABETH TAYLOR'S PASSION, A PERFUME
LEAD: CAN Elizabeth Taylor's Passion compete with her friend Calvin Klein's Obsession?


CONCERT: KAMIKAZE CREW
LEAD: WEARING marching-band uniform jackets and baggy pants, the Kamikaze Ground Crew were dressed to match their music - mixing precision and drollery - on Monday at Dance Theater Workshop.
The concert opened the workshop's fortnightly Bands on the Run music series.


The Palestinians Want Their Own Democracy
LEAD: To the Editor:


For Top Executive, Big Career Change
LEAD: Jane Evans, a leading woman corporate executive, is changing careers.
She is joining Montgomery Securities, an investment firm in San Francisco, as a general partner, the firm announced yesterday.


Dressing Pork for Success
LEAD: SOME health experts consider pork a red meat rather than a white meat.
The National Pork Producers Council, however, prefers to go along with the dictionary, which lumps pork right in the white meat category along with chicken and turkey, meats with a steeper growth curve.


Italian Labor Leaders Meet With Jaruzelski
LEAD: Italian labor leaders urged Gen.
Wojciech Jaruzelski today to allow Polish workers greater freedom in organizing trade unions.


CBS CHIEF HAS A SHARP KNIFE
LEAD: From the day in September when he took over as acting president and chief executive of CBS Inc.
Laurence A. Tisch made it clear that he thought the company was badly in need of cost-cutting and realignment.


Teen-Agers Seek Guidance From Parents
LEAD: To the Editor:


OFFICIAL KNEW OF INQUIRY
LEAD: New York City's Commissioner of Investigation, Kenneth Conboy, said yesterday that he was aware last month that Bess Myerson had been called before a Federal grand jury in an investigation of the business activities of her regular companion, Carl A. Capasso.
But he said that he could not tell Mayor Koch at the time because his office was participating in the investigation.


DRUG TRACE FOUND IN 2 CONRAIL WORKERS AFTER FATAL CRASH
LEAD: The two men operating three Conrail locomotives that moved past a closed switch and were struck by a speeding Amtrak train used marijuana before the fatal accident, Federal railroad officials said today.


Norton to Take Additional Charge
LEAD: The Norton Company, a marketer of abrasives and products for the petroleum and mining industries, said its board had approved an additional $78.5 million after-tax charge against its fourth-quarter earnings.
In addition, Norton said about 300 employees, mostly in Worcester, Mass., would lose their jobs in a consolidation of its ceramics businesses.


A MINISTER, A PORTFOLIO AND JOKES
LEAD: Wearing a mortarboard with a comic yellow tassel, Hans-Dietrich Genscher told a fictional anecdote about his appearance before the Bonn parliamentary committee that investigated payoffs by the giant Flick concern.


DOCTOR DISPUTES PREGNANCY RISKS IN BABY M CASE
LEAD: A neurologist testified today that Dr.
Elizabeth Stern, the wife of Baby M's father, had an extremely mild case of multiple sclerosis and faced less than a 5 percent chance that the disease would worsen as a result of childbirth.


BENNETT ASSAILED ON EDUCATION CUTS
LEAD: Education Secretary William J. Bennett sparred with Republicans and Democrats today in testimony before two Senate committees as he defended his support for cutting the education budget.


DANCE: ROSE AND EPSTEIN PRESENT COMIC WORKS
LEAD: IMAGINE a choreographer calling for seven volunteers from the audience to come onstage and be the instruments of a not-so-creative process.
Imagine that each volunteer plugs in the headphones of a Walkman and then performs simple movements he or she is instructed to do by the tape.
Imagine an audience doubling over with laughter as each ''dancer'' interacts with the others while gesturing as stipulated and some Herbie Hancock music is added.


PITT EDGES SETON HALL ON SMITH'S BASKET
LEAD: Charles Smith, touted with the ability to develop into one of the nation's best big men, scored only 11 points tonight.
But his last 2 represented the game-winning basket in Pitt's 87-85 Big East Conference victory over Seton Hall.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: Horse Racing Fly Me Again Scores With Stretch Drive: Fly Me Again rallied wide through the stretch to prevail in a driving finish yesterday in the $45,000 allowance feature for 4-year-olds and up at Aqueduct.
Carrying 112 pounds, Fly Me Again went a mile and an eighth in 1:50 3/5 on the fast track under Chris Antley to reach the wire a neck ahead of Belocolus.

TEHRAN REPORTS OPENING 2D FRONT
LEAD: Iran said today that it had opened a second front in its six-day-old offensive against Iraq, as fierce fighting continued near the southern Iraqi city of Basra and Iraqi bombers pounded Iranian cities.


CHEMICAL UP 4.9%; CONTINENTAL GAINS
LEAD: The Chemical New York Corporation, reporting its second consecutive quarter of disappointing results, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income rose just 4.9 percent, to $102.4 million, from $97.6 million.


FALSE BIDS WERE CALLED, CHRISTIE'S JURY IS TOLD
LEAD: In an auction of eight Impressionist paintings at Christie's in May 1981, six of the pictures received no bids at all from potential buyers, although the auctioneer called several apparent bids for each of the pictures from the podium.


Boston Ballet Begins Renovation Campaign
LEAD: The Boston Ballet has begun a campaign to raise $7.6 million to renovate and expand the turn-of-the-century building that houses its studios and offices.


MARKETING 'TOP GUN' CASSETTE
LEAD: When ''Top Gun,'' the No. 1 box-office success of 1986, is released on video cassette March 11, it will be accompanied by a marketing campaign worth $8 million.
This is as much or more than is usually spent to send a new movie into theaters, and millions of dollars more than has ever been spent to advertise a new video cassette.


CITY BALLET: 'SWAN LAKE'
LEAD: THE current setting for ''Swan Lake,'' which was performed by the New York City Ballet on Tuesday at the New York State Theater, has suggested to balletgoers everything from strip mines to glistening caverns.

LEAD: IT is no disrespect to the memory of the Rev.
Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr. to report that tonight's birthday tribute, ''In Remembrance of Martin,'' on Channel 49 at 8 o'clock and on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock, is for most of its hour as exciting as you would expect excerpts from memorial services and commemorative meetings to be.


GUINNESS OUSTS HEAD IN SCANDAL
LEAD: Guinness P.L.C. dismissed its chairman and demanded the resignation of two directors tonight amid indications that the British Government is widening its investigation of the big brewing company.

LEAD: Dave Schmidt, a relief pitcher, became a free agent when the Chicago White Sox did not tender him a contract.

LEAD: Mayor Harold Washington continues to hold a substantial lead in his Democratic mayoral primary race with former Mayor Jane M. Byrne, according to a broadcast poll released tonight.


2 Missing Guns Found At Carolina Army Base
LEAD: Two submachine guns missing since last week have been found and most of more than 500 soldiers at Fort Bragg who had been detained in their barracks during the search have gone back to their normal activities, officials said today.


PANEL QUESTIONS SCHEDULE ON SHUTTLE CHANGES
LEAD: The space agency will be unable to evaluate or incorporate any safety changes if it tries to meet the target date of Feb. 18, 1988, set for the resumption of space shuttle flights, according to the National Research Council, which has been directed to monitor the shuttle redesign.

The 26 stations along the conductor's route are not mere subway stops but opportunities to reflect on the diversions above ground and the efficiency with which his train will reach them.

Learning to Live With the Iran Cloud
LEAD: Before Christmas, some White House officials and Republican lawmakers were talking confidently about getting the Iran arms scandal ''behind us'' early in the new year.
Now, the Reagan Administration and its supporters concede that there is no ''big bang'' solution that will bring the problem to a quick end, and that it will continue to cloud life in the capital indefinitely.

Resident Status Is Granted To Woman Who Aided Fliers
LEAD: A woman who helped downed Allied fliers escape from Nazi-occupied Belgium in World War II was granted permanent resident status in the United States today and President Reagan urged Congress to make her an American citizen.


Reagan's Role
LEAD: To the Editor:


Holland Rejoins Yanks
LEAD: Al Holland, who left the Yankees angrily when they released him last August, will rejoin the team in spring training, trying to pitch his way into an already-crowded left-handed side of the bullpen.


S.E.C Ban on Insider
LEAD: Robert Salsbury, a former arbitrage analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., has been barred from the securities industry for three years in the settlement of Securities and Exchange Commission charges arising out of his participation in an insider-trading ring.

JUSTICES UPHOLD BANKS ON DISCOUNT BROKERAGE
LEAD: The Supreme Court cleared the way today for national banks to establish or acquire discount brokerage outlets anywhere in the country without regard to Federal geographical restrictions on bank branches.

ANTI-AIDS BIAS BY UNDERTAKERS RULED A HUMAN-RIGHTS BREACH
LEAD: Funeral parlors that discriminate against AIDS victims are subject to the same human-rights laws that protect handicapped people, a judge in Manhattan has ruled in a decision that city officials said is the first of its kind.


Clevite Sets Sale
LEAD: Clevite Industries said it had entered into a definitive agreement to sell its engine parts division to J. P. Industries for $120 million in cash.
The unit had sales of more than $150 million in 1986.
The sale is subject to expiration of a waiting period because the Federal Trade Commission has made a second request for information about the deal.


Cars From Thailand
LEAD: Chrysler Canada Ltd. is expected to import as many as 20,000 compact cars from the MMC Sittipol Company of Thailand, a spokesman for the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation said today.


Game Plan for Party
LEAD: Most of the Giants' season-ticket holders will be unable to obtain Super Bowl tickets.
But all of them will soon be mailed an invitation to a celebration of the 1986 season that will be held on Jan. 27 at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J.
The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority is organizing the event, hoping to raise private funds to help pay for the post-Super Bowl party.


Burmese Sentenced to Hang
LEAD: A 63-year-old woman has been sentenced to hang for trafficking in heroin, the official News Agency of Burma said today.
It said the woman, Daw Kyi, was arrested in Mandalay in June 1985 with 7.7 pounds of heroin.
Executions for drug offenses are rare in Burma and the woman can appeal against the sentence to a higher court.

The Worm and the Apple: Curbside Improvements; 14th Street Sweep
LEAD: A special program that allows property owners in business areas to tax themselves for block improvements is bearing impressive fruit in one Manhattan neighborhood.
Twice a day, every day, a seven-person crew armed with brooms and sporting distinctive green and white uniforms sweeps litter from the sidewalks and gutters along the length of 14th Street and around newly refurbished Union Square

McReynolds Agent Asks Mets for Raise
LEAD: Kevin McReynolds made his first appearance in New York yesterday as the newly anointed left fielder of the Mets, and his agent wasted no time disclosing that he and the Mets were ''several hundred thousand dollars apart'' in negotiations on a contract.


NEW YORK HOSPITAL DISPUTES ALLEGATIONS ON PATIENT'S DEATH
LEAD: New York Hospital took issue yesterday with a grand jury report that said ''woefully'' inadequate care and repeated mistakes by unsupervised interns and junior residents had resulted in the death of a young woman at the hospital in 1984.

Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''It would be better if the President would say, 'The buck stops at my desk.
If I didn't know I should have known.''' - Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah.  [ A12:5. ]


Donahue Will Decide
LEAD: Terry Donahue, the head football coach at U.C.L.A., is expected to decide in the next few days whether he wants to take over as coach of the Atlanta Falcons.


6,900 IN FARM FEDERATION GET UPBEAT MESSAGE
LEAD: Dean Kleckner, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, had an upbeat message for his group about American farming this week.


Soviet Consulate in Montreal Seriously Damaged in a Fire
LEAD: A blaze engulfed the Soviet consulate today, but diplomats kept firemen outside for 15 minutes while they grabbed documents and tried to put out the fire with extinguishers and buckets of snow, witnesses and fire officials said.


Good for the U.S. and for Mexico
LEAD: To the Editor:


West Point Cadet Earns His Star
LEAD: In and around the Multi-Purpose Sports Facility at West Point, N.Y., the story has been circulated so many times that its time and place are occasionally forgotten or confused.
On a basketball court at Fort Knox, Ky., in the summer of 1985, a group of enlisted men gathered for a pickup game.
When they chose sides, they overlooked a cadet who had also wanted to play.

CATHOLIC UNIVERSITY DROPS CLASSES OF PRIEST CENSURED FOR SEX VIEWS
LEAD: Officials at Catholic University announced today that they were canceling three courses scheduled to be taught this spring by the Rev.
Charles E. Curran, a liberal theologian censured by the Vatican last year for his views on sexual issues.

CUOMO PLEDGES $5 MILLION BUDGET IN ANNOUNCING CORRUPTION PANEL
LEAD: Governor Cuomo yesterday promised a budget of $5 million and ''all the resources they need'' to a newly formed state commission to investigate corruption, and ordered the panel to follow ''every lead, no matter where it takes them.''


Epton Is Off Chicago Ballot
LEAD: The Chicago Board of Election Commissioners has ordered the name of Bernard Epton removed from the Feb. 24 Republican mayoral primary ballot.
The board said Wednesday that Mr.
Epton, who ran for Mayor in 1983, had fallen short of the required number of signatures on his nominating ballots.


RJR Nabisco Plans to Move
LEAD: RJR Nabisco Inc. said yesterday that its board had approved plans to move its headquarters from Winston-Salem, N.C., to Atlanta in September.
The company, formerly R. J. Reynolds Industries, began as a tobacco company in Winston-Salem in 1875 and grew to be a major conglomerate, changing its name after it acquired Nabisco Brands Inc.


EXECUTIVES
LEAD: *
Combustion Engineering Inc., Stamford, Conn., named W. Mack Torrence to the newly created position of president and John A. Cunningham as executive vice president of its Resource Recovery Systems division.


New York No Longer Has Hospital-Bed Surplus
LEAD: To the Editor:


Chief Resigns At Datapoint
LEAD: The Datapoint Corporation said today that Edward P. Gistaro, president and chief executive, had resigned.
Doris D. Bencsik, executive vice president and chief operating officer, will temporarily assume the position of chief executive until a replacement is chosen, the company said.

CONBOY TO BE RECOMMENDED FOR JUDGESHIP, D'AMATO SAYS
LEAD: The New York City Investigations Commissioner, Kenneth Conboy, who has played a major role in the inquiries into city scandals in the last year, will be recommended for a Federal judgeship, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said yesterday.

SNOWSTORM DRIVES BRONCOS INDOORS
LEAD: A howling snowstorm blanketed this city today, but inside a pressurized bubble the Broncos staged their first practice for their Jan. 25 game with the Giants in Super Bowl XXI.


ART: 47 FIGURAL PAINTINGS OF DAVID PARK ON VIEW
LEAD: UNTIL a full-scale museum retrospective is organized, the work of David Park, who died of cancer in 1960 at the age of 49, may be doomed to perennial rediscovery.
The current exhibition of his paintings at Salander-O'Reilly (22 East 80th Street) is the third this gallery has mounted in almost as many years; it is the best yet and should win Park even more admirers.


British Joblessness Down
LEAD: Unemployment in Britain fell to a seasonally adjusted 11.3 percent of the work force in December, from 11.4 percent in the previous month, according to preliminary estimates released by the British Department of Employment.


Spectra-Physics Filing by Reliance
LEAD: The Reliance Financial Services Corporation, which is controlled by the New York investor Saul P. Steinberg, said that it might seek control of Spectra-Physics Inc., the world's largest commercial laser manufacturer.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Reliance said that it ''cannot continue to be merely passive investors'' in Spectra-Physics because of a proposal to change the company's incorporation from California to Delaware.

BENNY'S GOOD MEN
LEAD: Benny's Good Men, former members of the Benny Goodman band, will perform Sunday at 5 P.M. at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street (369-8040).
The group will include Peter Appleyard on vebraphone, Warren Vache Jr. on cornet and fluegelhorn, John Bunch on piano, Bucky Pizzarelli on guitar, and others.


Envoy Says Pretoria Barred Visit to Priest
LEAD: An American diplomat says he was unable to persuade South African officials to allow him to see a missionary imprisoned for nearly a month in a black territory.


SOVIET TO CUT FORCES IN MONGOLIA
LEAD: An infantry division and several other military units stationed in Mongolia will be withdrawn this spring, the Soviet Union announced today.

BROADWAY
LEAD: ALMOST anyone would be grateful to have his life saved but, depending on who does the saving, the gratefulness can wear pretty thin.
Take, for instance, if the savior is an absolute nerd and if this nerd turns the saved life into a complete shambles.


Volkswagen Plans New U.S. Import
LEAD: Volkswagen U.S., a unit of Volkswagen A.G. of West Germany, said it planned to begin selling low-cost compact cars made in Brazil in the United States market.
The new car, called the Fox, carries a price tag of $5,690 for a two-door model and $6,490 for the four-door Fox-GL, with a wagon due in the spring, company executives said.


CAROLINE GRUSS, 76, PHILANTHROPIST WHO SUPPORTED JEWISH EDUCATION
LEAD: Caroline Gruss, who with her husband donated millions of dollars to educational institutions in this country and in Israel, died Wednesday at her home in Manhattan after a long illness.
She was 76.
Mrs.
Gruss was born in Poland, where she received a law degree and studied classical languages at the University of Lvov.

LOUISVILLE TIMES TO END PUBLICATION ON FEB. 14
LEAD: The Gannett Company said today that it was closing The Louisville Times and would replace it with two new afternoon editions of the morning Louisville Courier-Journal.


Contract for John Lucas
LEAD: John Lucas, a veteran guard who tested positive for drugs last year for the second time in two seasons, has reached an oral agreement to sign with the Milwaukee Bucks.
Bill King, a spokesman for the Bucks, said that the contract for the remainder of this season must still be put in writing and signed before Lucas can practice with the team under National Basketball Association regulations, but that should take place by the middle of next week.


Bobby Watson Trio
LEAD: The alto saxophonist Bobby Watson is leading a trio tonight and tomorrow at Cafe Jupiter, 228 West 10th Street (924-9292).
Sets are at 9 and 10:30 P.M. and midnight, with a $5 cover for the first two sets, no cover for the late set, and a $5 minimum.


The White House Mystique
LEAD: It is next to impossible, given what we know, to conjecture intelligently whether or not President Reagan could have remained ignorant while White House staff members took certain liberties regarding arms to Iran and siphoning the proceeds for the benefit of the contras.
But it seems to me that the President could very well have been kept in the dark by staff members who believed they were doing the right thing.

LICENSE MOVE NEARS FOR AIDS DRUG
LEAD: Amid impassioned debate over what access a patient with a fatal disease should have to experimental drugs, the Food and Drug Administration is nearing a decision on whether to license the only drug shown to prolong life in a group of AIDS victims.


PROTEST AT NEW YORKER IS CRITICIZED
LEAD: New York literary figures are stunned by the unusual public protest by 154 members of The New Yorker asking Robert A. Gottlieb to withdraw his acceptance as editor of the magazine.
Some writers and editors are decidedly unsympathetic toward the protesters, and while most would not speak for attribution, some were willing to speak on the record.

Economic Scene; Currency Rift: Fog Thickens
LEAD: THE conflict raging among the United States, West Germany and Japan over the values of their currencies has been compared to a game of chicken, in which the players with the least nerve lose.
If nobody chickens out, the result would be a general smash-up, with ruinous consequences for all - and for the world economic and monetary system.


Solitary Performer
LEAD: Kimberly Hanzlik as she prepared for an audition with the Ice Capades yesterday at Madison Square Garden.
The ice show is appearing there until Jan. 25.
The audition was open to all, but Miss Hanzlik was the only one to show up.
After her performance, she was invited to try out again in the spring.


OPERA: THE METROPOLITAN'S FIRST 'TANNHAUSER' OF THE SEASON
LEAD: THE trouble with coming upon real quality at the opera is that it makes you impatient with anything less.
That happened last night at the season's first ''Tannhauser'' when Jessye Norman suddenly illuminated the Metropolitan stage with her second-act ''Dich, teure Halle'' and went on to create as vocally electrifying and dramatically moving an Elisabeth as that stage has known in years.

Bentsen Urges A Simpler W-4
LEAD: The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee urged the Internal Revenue Service today to come up with a simpler W-4 form for Americans to use in computing how much tax should be withheld from their paychecks.


SCIENTISTS VOICE DOUBTS SOVIET BREACHED TREATY
LEAD: Experts from the United States nuclear laboratories today questioned Administration charges that the Soviet Union has probably exceeded the limits of an unratified 1974 treaty that limits the size of underground nuclear tests.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who returned from a six-nation tour of Africa late Wednesday, has become embroiled in criticism over his assertion that Liberia has made progress in human rights.


ARMS DEALERS LINKED TO U.S. POLICY SHIFT
LEAD: For more than a year before the Reagan Administration began to consider selling arms to Iran, many of the arms dealers who eventually helped carry out the change in policy had been planning among themselves to sell American arms to the Teheran Government, according to American and Iranian sources and documents.


Diner's Journal
LEAD: LE REGENCE, the opulent French restaurant in the Hotel Plaza Athenee, wasted no time picking up the pieces after losing its chef, Daniel Boulud, and two sous chefs, to Le Cirque last fall.
Managers of the hotel, which has a sister establishment in Paris, recruited the flying Rostang family - Jo, the chef-owner of the two-star (Michelin) La Bonne Auberge on the French Riviera; Philippe, his son and co-chef, and Michel, another son whose own two-star establishment in Paris bears his name - to oversee the new regime.


TESTS IN REDESIGN OF SHUTTLE ROCKETS DISCLOSE UNEXPECTED PROBLEMS
LEAD: The National Research Council said today that preliminary tests on improvements for the space shuttle's booster rockets had disclosed unexpected problems that would complicate efforts to repair the shuttle for relaunching in February 1988.

Carol Perrenot Longone, 94; The Founder of Operalogues
LEAD: Carol Perrenot Longone, the developer of operalogues, a combination of opera and narrative, died of pneumonia Jan. 4 at Roosevelt Hospital.
She was 94 years old and had lived in Manhattan since 1924.


14-WEEK RETROSPECTIVE OF NEW YORKER FILMS
LEAD: Their names are famous now, and many works by directors such as Werner Herzog, Rainer Werner Fassbinder and Yasujiro Ozu are familiar to the sophisticated American filmgoing audience.
But 20 years ago such film makers were often hard-pressed to find an outlet for their work in the United States.

LEAD: Moody's Investors Service Inc. said yesterday that it may downgrade $3.4 billion of debt issued by the Chase Manhattan Corporation and its lead bank, Chase Manhattan Bank.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: Mel Bridgman, the captain of the Devils, has a fracture in his left foot rather than a bruise, which was the original diagnosis.
Bridgman was injured Monday night during the victory over the Hartford Whalers, but he finished the game.
He missed Wednesday night's victory in Chicago. . . .
In a plea-bargaining agreement, Michael Dokes, a former World Boxing Association champion, pleaded guilty in Las Vegas, Nev., to possession of a controlled substance, cocaine.

K Mart Debentures
LEAD: The K Mart Corporation is offering $300 million of 8 3/8 percent debentures due in 2017 at a price of 97.125 to yield 8.644 percent through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley &amp; Company.
Nonrefundable for 10 years, the debentures yield 1.05 percentage points more than the 9 1/4 percent Treasury bond due in 2016 and are rated A-1 by Moody's and A by S.&amp; P.

The Editorial Notebook; Courts and Quarts
LEAD: It has been a splendid few days for New York's imbibers, whether their weakness be alcohol or cholesterol.
State regulations restricting competition in the sale first of milk and now of liquor have been wiped off the books, setting the stage for a 10 to 20 percent plunge in retail prices.
The only regrettable aspect is that the state's consumers had to turn for relief to the Federal courts; their elected representatives sided with the dairy and liquor lobbies.


Help for Pretoria's Neighbors
LEAD: The ad in Gaborone's Gazette says ''Now you can jet to Jo'burg in 40 mins.'' South African Airways adds that via Johannesburg it can provide connections with ''non-stop S.A.A. flights to London and direct flights to New York and various destinations in Europe.''

Rooney, Pace Broker Closing
LEAD: Rooney, Pace Group Inc. said yesterday that it was liquidating its stock brokerage operations.


F.C.C. SEEKS NEW OWNERSHIP RULES
LEAD: In an effort to bolster struggling AM radio stations, the Federal Communications Commission today proposed a loosening of its ownership rules.


ROGER KELLWAY'S MANY FACETS
LEAD: ROGER KELLAWAY, the pianist, composer and conductor, has been described by the lyricist Gene Lees as bearing ''the curse of unclassifiability.'' He is a jazz pianist whose repertory ranges from Dixieland through be-bop to avant-garde.
He is a classical composer who wrote a ballet score for George Balanchine and the New York City Ballet in 1971 and has just received a commission from the New York Philharmonic Society for a tuba concerto to be performed in 1988.


Love Those Revolutions
LEAD: A Washingtonian attending a performance of the Broadway-bound ''Les Miserables'' the other evening at the Kennedy Center discovered the Soviet Ambassador, Yuri V. Dubinin, in an adjoining box with three aides.
In the course of the musical, French peasants and work-ers storm the barricades with red flags in an 1830's uprising, and the Russian theatergoers responded enthusiastically, standing to applaud during the curtain calls.


NEW ARMS SESSION BEGINS IN GENEVA
LEAD: The chief Soviet and American arms negotiators began a new round of talks in Geneva today.
They held an unexpected two-hour luncheon that appeared to underscore recent Soviet efforts to project a new face at the 22-month-old negotiations.

LEAD: The soprano Lucille Field will present a program entitled ''Songs: With Women in Mind'' at the Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67 Street, Sunday night at 8.

LEAD: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Commission on Status of Women -6 P.M.


REPUTED MOB FIGURE FATALLY SHOT IN BROOKLYN CLUB
LEAD: A reputed organized-crime figure was killed in a Brooklyn social club late Wednesday by one of five armed men who forced several patrons to lie on the floor while they robbed them of money and jewelry, the police said yesterday.


Inventories Fell 0.2% in November
LEAD: Business inventories, which had shot up in October, edged down two-tenths of 1 percent in November, while total business sales rose three-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department said today.

LEAD: Robert Swanton Driscoll, former managing partner of Lord, Abbett &amp; Company, an investment management firm, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in Chappaqua, N.Y.
He was 75 years old.

Bridge: Deal in World Championship Inspired an Unusual Message
LEAD: There are many ways in which a player can instruct his partner to select one of two specific suits.
The selection is normally made on the basis of length, and if the length is equal the choice may be trivial.

LEAD: To the Editor:


G.E. PROFITS UP 14.4% IN QUARTER
LEAD: The General Electric Company, buoyed by the acquisition of the RCA Corporation, reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 14.4 percent on a 40.5 percent increase in sales.


Former Judge Named To Inquiry of Myerson
LEAD: Mayor Koch yesterday appointed Harold R. Tyler Jr., a former Federal judge, as the special investigator examining the activities of Bess Myerson, who has stepped aside as the city's Cultural Affairs Commissioner.


FILM: 'BEDROOM WINDOW,' A THRILLER
LEAD: ONE rainy night after leaving an office party early, Terry Lambert (Steve Guttenberg), a young, cheerfully on-the-loose Baltimore bachelor, returns to his apartment.
There, by pre-arrangement, he meets his boss's sexy young wife, Sylvia (Isabelle Huppert), who's also managed to slip away from the festivities.


Deng Versus Deng in China
LEAD: Suddenly, China is torn by political crisis.
Leading liberal intellectuals have been denounced and purged.
Hu Yaobang, the Communist Party General Secretary, is rumored to be on the way out.
And China's top leader, Deng Xiaoping, is said to have called, in a chilling secret document, literally for the blood of the defiant students who two weeks ago staged their own long march through the streets of


Hoechst Sets F.T.C. Talks
LEAD: The American Hoechst Corporation said today that it would go ahead with its $2.8 billion acquisition of another chemical maker, the Celanese Corporation, despite a Federal Trade Commission vote to seek an injunction to block the deal.

LEAD: A group of automotive executives and companions were having dinner before the Detroit Auto Show last week and the conversation ran to the usual topics: sales, new models and potential bonuses.
Then the group was joined by an official of a California-based car company who immediately blurted out: ''I don't care about any of that.


Gorbachev Invites a Hart
LEAD: Gary Hart, the former Democratic Senator from Colorado now preparing for a 1988 Presidential campaign, received an unexpected dividend on his recent trip to the Soviet Union.
At a six-hour meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader invited Mr.
Hart's daughter, Andrea, to visit the Soviet


Joint Venture Set On Barter TV Time
LEAD: An agreement to establish a joint venture to sell barter TV time has been signed on the Coast by Coca-Cola Telecommunications and Gulf and Western Entertainment, both creators and syndicators of programming.


QUARREL PRECEDED BLAZE AT HOTEL
LEAD: The union member charged with setting the fire that killed 96 people at the Dupont Plaza Hotel had a quarrel with hotel security officers shortly before the blaze was set, a union official said today.


CENSURED PRIEST DROPS TEACHING PLANS FOR SPRING
LEAD: The Rev.
Charles E. Curran, a liberal theologian who was censured by the Vatican last year for his views on sexual issues, announced today that he was abandoning his efforts to teach this spring at Catholic University of America.
He emphasized, however, that he would continue to fight for an eventual return to the classroom.


Quaker Oats Plans Charge in Closing
LEAD: The Quaker Oats Company said that it would close its pet foods plant in Rockford, Ill., leading to a $20.9 million after-tax charge against earnings.
Quaker said the closing was part of its plan to reduce overcapacity resulting from its recent acquisition of Gaines pet food.
The Rockford plant, which employs 324 workers, is the oldest of its five pet food units and is unable to produce dry dog food, an area Quaker has chosen as a target for growth.

Decision in Jockey Case
LEAD: In what it says is the final word on the apprentice jockey weight allowance matter that arose last month, the New York Racing Association has redistributed purse money of approximately $76,000.
Seventeen horses were involved.
The action was taken after stewards' rulings had disqualified horses that had finished fourth or better in the 53 races in question from Nov.

Little Program Trading As Stock Indexes Soar
LEAD: As expected, stock index futures soared yesterday, along with their underlying market averages.
What was not expected was that the index futures would follow the stock market and not lead it, as has usually been the case.

LEAD: Preston County Commissioners, who had been trying for more than a week to break a tie and elect a president, today unanimously chose one on the 482d ballot.

HIJACKING SUSPECT ARRESTED BY BONN
LEAD: The West German authorities have arrested a Lebanese whom they believe to be one of two men who hijacked a Trans World Airlines plane to Beirut in June 1985.
After the hijacking, 39 Americans were held hostage for 17 days.


SHAMROCK TURNS DOWN PICKENS BID
LEAD: The board of the Diamond Shamrock Corporation rejected today a $15-a-share cash offer for 18 percent of the company's stock announced last week by an investor group led by T. Boone Pickens.


'TELEVISION MAKERS' EXAMINES DIRECTORS AT WORK
LEAD: TELEVISION, we all know, is impossible.
Most of the programming we see in prime time is produced on an entertainment assembly line, not unlike the kind that used to churn out movies several decades ago.
Budgets are limited, schedules are ridiculously tight, and artistic considerations are not quite as crucial as getting the thing done and moving on quickly to the next project.


Gooden, Mattingly File for Arbitration
LEAD: Don Mattingly and Dwight Gooden, who last year negotiated their 1986 salaries after filing for salary arbitration, took the same first step yesterday, joining 95 other players in asking for arbitration on the final day of the filing period.
That brought the arbitration total this winter to 104 players.


Fermenta Stock Expelled
LEAD: Fermenta A.B., the Swedish biotechnology concern, was expelled from the Stockholm stock exchange after a team of independent auditors reported on the company's financial problems to the exchange directors.
Fermenta is under investigation by the police, the Swedish bank inspection board and the stock exchange itself over its business practices.

OKLAHOMA BEATS KANSAS BY 76-74
LEAD: Tim McCalister's jump shot with nine seconds remaining broke a tie and Ricky Grace blocked a last-second shot as Oklahoma defeated Kansas, 76-74, tonight in a Big Eight Conference game.


CLASHES CONTINUE IN PAKISTAN
LEAD: A shopkeeper in Karachi running for water to put out a fire after rioters set his shop ablaze.
Since Monday, 13 people have died in fighting between Mohajir and Pathan tribesmen.
According to witnesses, two people were killed and more than 50 others were wounded yesterday when police fired at mourners returning from the funeral of a man who was shot by police during rioting Wednesday.


E.P.A. FINDS LAKES OF WEST ARE FREE OF ACID RAIN
LEAD: A survey made public today by the Environmental Protection Agency found that no lakes in mountainous areas of the Western United States were currently polluted by acid rain but that a large number were potentially susceptible.


ENIGMATIC HARD-LINER: NAJIB
LEAD: So mysterious is Afghanistan's leader that there is not even agreement about the rendering of his name.

THE EVENING HOURS
LEAD: THERE was a party the other evening that was not as joyous as it might have been.
It was planned by Margaret Whiting and Jean Bach to toast Larry Carr, a singer and piano player as well as record producer and writer on music and films, on the occasion of his new record.
Mr.
Carr died a few days before the occasion, but the evening went on as scheduled as his jazz musician pals made it a musical salute to their friend.

Hana Mandlikova seeded second, defeated Anne Smith, and Pam Shriver, seeded third, beat Elna Reinach.(AP) Horse Racing The Rogers Four Wins at Aqueduct: The Rogers Four, the longest price in the field of five, closed fast on the rail to outfinish the favorite, Rexson's Bishop, in Aqueduct's $40,000 allowance feature for 4-year-olds and up yesterday.


Executive Changes At McKinney &amp; Silver
LEAD: Robert C. Doherty, a 56-year-old former New York ad agency executive, has been promoted to president of McKinney &amp; Silver, a $103 million agency in Raleigh, N.C., and L. Lloyd Jacobs, 48, has been named executive vice president.
Charles C. McKinney, 55, who gave up the president's title, remains chairman and chief executive.

POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
LEAD: Oliver Lake Quartet, Carlos 1, 452 Avenue of the Americas, between Ninth and 10th Streets (982-3260).
Phrases as dry yet slippery as a rattlesnake come slithering out of Oliver Lake's alto saxophone.
But so do gospel-ish celebrations, wry ironies and melodies of love.
His quartet, which just made what may well be Mr.

Welcomed Demotion
LEAD: A former major league catcher, Barry Foote, who managed the Yankees' Class AAA team in Columbus, Ohio, last year before being replaced by Bucky Dent for this season, has had enough of that level.

Money Fund Assets Off
LEAD: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell by $673.2 million, to $234.09 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 91 institutional funds were down $420.9 million, to $65.01 billion.
Assets of the 193 general purpose funds dropped $703.8 million, to $62.2 billion.

KOOKABURRA III SAILS TO 1-0 LEAD
LEAD: Iain Murray and his Kookaburra III team survived a dramatic gear failure today within a half-mile of the finish in the America's Cup defense finals and beat Australia IV by 1 minute 34 seconds.


DAVIS INDICTED ON 9 COUNTS OF ATTEMPTED MURDER
LEAD: Larry Davis, already awaiting trial in four Bronx killings, was indicted yesterday on nine counts of attempted murder of a police officer and 16 related counts, Bronx District Attorney Mario Merola said.

LEAD: The pianist McCoy Tyner is leading a trio tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785).
Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $7 minimum tonight and tomorrow, a $10 cover and a $6 minimum Sunday.


Calamitous Clip
LEAD: ''This was like winning the World Series,'' said Cedric Maxwell of the Los Angeles Clippers. ''It was like being in Pasadena for the Super Bowl.'' What had happened?
Why, the Clippers had actually won a game Wednesday night, by 18 points over Denver.
Even at that, their 5-31 record (.139) left them on a pace for the worst N.B.A.


SAM WAGSTAFF, 65, A CURATOR AND PHOTOGRAPHY COLLECTOR
LEAD: Sam Wagstaff, a former museum curator who became a leading collector of photography, died of pneumonia Wednesday morning at his home in Manhattan.
He was 65 years old.


Lockheed Cuts Air Force Price
LEAD: A unit of the Lockheed Corporation agreed today to trim an added $253 million from the cost of the Air Force's C-5B program, accepting a $1.95 billion contract to build the last of the cargo planes.

LEAD: Should Ronald Reagan apologize to the nation for the blundering acts of omission or commission that led to the arms-to-Iran scandal former Secretary of State Cyrus Vance has termed ''severely damaging to our national interest''?

LEAD: The special prosecutor in the Howard Beach attack discussed the case for more than an hour yesterday with two lawyers representing the black victims, one of the lawyers said.

THE BUDGET IS AGAIN HOSTAGE TO POLITICS
LEAD: The sad thing about American politics today is that even if the new Democratic Congress liked President Reagan's fiscal 1988 budget, they would have to throw it out.
Having wrested Congressional power from the Republicans last November, the Democrats must demonstrate their independence of Mr.
Reagan or risk being derided as second-rate players in the political game.

SCREEN: A TV SPINOFF, 'WANTED DEAD OR ALIVE'
LEAD: ''WANTED: DEAD OR ALIVE'' was a 1958 television series starring Steve McQueen.
It has now, in the process of becoming a feature film, lost its colon, and that's not the half of it.
Even to those of us who have become more or less used to the cultural cannibalism that passes for inventiveness these days, the film ''Wanted Dead or Alive,'' which opens today at the National and other theaters, will seem outstandingly unnecessary.

Mighty Mites
LEAD: Its most illustrious alumnus is Carl Yastrzemski, but baseball is no longer the big sport at Bridgehampton (L.I.) High.
It's basketball, which is, in fact, the school's only sport these days. ''We've tried to get them to play baseball, but they won't do it,'' says John Niles, Bridgehampton's basketball coach.

Panel to Review Pay Of Top City Officials
LEAD: Richard R. Shinn, executive vice president of the New York Stock Exchange, will head a new commission that will recommend pay levels for top New York City officials, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.


U.S. TRIAL STARTS FOR EX-OFFICIAL OF QUEENS PARTY
LEAD: The Federal trial of Richard L. Rubin, an influential Queens Democratic figure, opened yesterday with the prosecution portraying him as a man who used his influence to defraud New York State of more than $49,000 to pay the salaries of two private secretaries in his own law firm.


VOLUME IS RECORD AS STOCKS EXTEND STREAK TO 10 DAYS
LEAD: Wall Street erupted with another explosive rally yesterday that sent trading volume to a record.
The advance made the stock market's winning streak the longest - and most productive - in 14 years.


ART: 'OIL SKETCHES FROM THE ECOLE DES BEAUX-ARTS'
LEAD: ''OIL SKETCHES FROM THE ECOLE DES BEAUX-ARTS: 1816-1863'' offers a fresh perspective on academic art.
It is the first exhibition to bring together oil sketches that won prizes in the French Academy.
It is the first exhibition that demonstrates the academic importance of the sketch, which throughout modernism has been identified with freedom, instinct and the avant-garde.


OTHER TALKS ON PAN AM REPORTED
LEAD: Another potential buyer expressed interest in Pan American World Airways before American Airlines began exploratory talks with the ailing carrier, an industry source said yesterday.


AUCTIONS
LEAD: AUCTIONS of corporate art collections, although still few in number, are becoming increasingly important in the 1980's, as values of art and antiques soar and companies expand their investments in both.
Corporate holdings are sold for the same reasons that any art collection is dispersed - deaths, partnership changes, financial distress.


Soviet Cancer Patient Given Visa to Get Treatment in U.S.
LEAD: The wife of a well-known Soviet dissident said today that she had been granted an exit visa and would leave the Soviet Union on Sunday to receive cancer treatment in the United States.


In Support Of Bill Curry
LEAD: One measure of the alumni fury that has resulted from Alabama's hiring Bill Curry as football coach is that the Crimson Tide's sports information director felt compelled to issue a press release the other day defending the appointment and dealing the critics a history lesson.


Dow Jones Raises Stake in Telerate
LEAD: Dow Jones &amp; Company increased its stake in Telerate Inc., a distributor of government securities data, to about 45 percent.
Dow Jones, which publishes The Wall Street Journal and Barron's, said it bought 4.4 million shares of Telerate common stock from the the Oklahoma Publishing Company for $30 a share, or $133.1 million.

CALIFORNIA TURNS TO DEVELOPER FEES
LEAD: Facing expanding enrollment and hampered by tax limits created by a taxpayer revolt in the 1970's, many California school districts are rushing to take advantage of a new state law that encourages them to charge fees to building developers to help pay for new schools.


The Prophecy
LEAD: With a tough schedule ahead and half his roster made up of freshmen, Hal Smith, basketball coach at Malone College in Canton, Ohio, chose ''No Easy Road'' as the team slogan this season.
On the Pioneers' first road trip, one of their two vans broke down.


C.B.A. Suspensions
LEAD: The Mississippi Coast Jets of the Continental Basketball Association have dropped from their roster Billy Goodwin and Bobby Parks after they refused drug testing ordered by the league, The Sun Herald in Biloxi, Miss., reported yesterday.
According to the Jets' owner, Ted Stepien of Cleveland, the players informed Coach Keith Fowler yesterday morning that they would not submit to urinalysis set for later in the day in Denver, where league offices are situated.


MEESE BACKS ADMINISTRATION OVER CUTS IN DRUG CAMPAIGN
LEAD: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d denied today that the Reagan Administration was scaling back its campaign against drug abuse.
He charged that critics who protested cuts in some Federal drug law-enforcement programs were ''more interested in politics than progress.''

Martha Graham Gets Danish Arts Award
LEAD: Martha Graham has been awarded Denmark's gold medal ''Ingenio et Arti'' for distinction in the arts and sciences.
The American modern-dance pioneer has taken her company to Denmark several times in recent years.
Only one other non-Danish artist, the Swedish soprano Birgit Nilsson, has received the irregularly presented medal.


ART: EXHIBITION MARKS DUCHAMP'S CENTENARY
LEAD: THERE never was a more implausible centenarian than Marcel Duchamp.
Even in his 80's, he carried his age lightly, imperceptibly.
Erect, steady and precise in all his movements, debonair in his bearing, he measured his every word, yet let it slip all but noiselessly.
When present, he seemed to displace no air and demand no attention.


People
LEAD: *
James A. Sanfilippo has joined Backer &amp; Spielvogel as senior vice president and management supervisor.


Juilliard Quartet
LEAD: The Juilliard Quartet will continue its 40th-anniversary subscription series at Alice Tully Hall tomorrow afternoon at 3 with a program of works by Mendelssohn, Brahms and Dvorak.
Tickets are $15.
Information: 874-6770.


SPOTLIGHT CONTINUES TO GLOW FOR TYSON
LEAD: Ever since he knocked out Trevor Berbick on Nov. 22 for the World Boxing Council title, Mike Tyson has been in demand.


FINANCE BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Federated Department Stores Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $500 million of debt securities.


Fifth Suspect Is Held In Death Over Jacket
LEAD: A fifth suspect has been arrested in the slaying of a 15-year-old boy who refused to give up his leather bomber jacket, the police said yesterday.

Dining Out Guide; Pre-theater
LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times.
Stars are followed by the date of original publication.
Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.
CAFE 43 RESTAURANT AND WINE BAR, #147 West 43d Street (869-4200) -*(Dec. 21, 1984) Just a few doors east of Times Square is this comfortable and bright restaurant that has one of the more extensive wine-by-the-glass menus in town and a table d'hote dinner that is just right for pre-theater dining.


OPENING SALVOS ARE FIRED ON N.B.A.'S CONTRACT
LEAD: Making a trade in the National Basketball Association may be more difficult than in most other sports.
It requires a conference call between the trading teams and the league office, and after an agreement has been reached a computer determines whether either team would exceed its salary cap by making the trade.


Another Questionnaire In Army Agency Search
LEAD: All hope that the Army would announce the agency winner of its $100 million recruiting account disappeared yesterday as word got around that the finalists had received still another questionnaire that had to be back in the Army's hands in Washington by 1:30 P.M. next Tuesday.


PARTIAL ANTIMISSILE DEPLOYMENT WEIGHED
LEAD: The Reagan Administration is considering deployment of defenses against missiles, with some units installed in space, in the early 1990's, experts said today.
They estimated the cost at roughly $100 billion.


EXCERPTS FROM MAYOR'S LETTER ON PRELIMINARY BUDGET PLAN
LEAD: Following are excerpts from Mayor Koch's letter to the Board of Estimate, the City Council and the Financial Control Board that accompanied his plan for the next four fiscal years.


CHINESE ACROBATS
LEAD: A display of skill and folk arts will be presented by the Chinese Golden Dragon Acrobats and Magicians of Taipei tonight at 7:30 at the Colden Center for the Performing Arts at Queens College, Long Island Expressway and Kissena Boulevard, in Flushing.
The 23-member troupe, directed by Danny Chang, will perform music, dance and acrobatics in elaborate costumes decorated with centuries-old designs.


GIANTS ARE GIVEN TWO SETS OF PLANS
LEAD: The Giants received part of their game plans today for the Super Bowl: one set of plans for what to do on the field and another set for off the field.

SKATING AND SKIING DURING SEAPORT FESTIVAL
LEAD: Lovers of sea and ice might enjoy a trip the the South Street Seaport this weekend for the beginning of a two-week Winter Festival.
A temporary ice-skating rink has been set up at Pier 17 for a series of daily shows, beginning today at 5:30 P.M.
Bleachers have been set up to accommodate 150 viewers and there is plenty of standing room for the 20-minute shows, which are free; there will also be shows at 6:15 and 7 P.M.


POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
LEAD: Sphere, the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037).
Sphere started out in 1982 as a quartet with two longtime associates of the pianist-composer Thelonious Sphere Monk - the saxophonist Charlie Rouse and the drummer Ben Riley - and two compatible outsiders, the pianist Kenny Barron and the bassist Buster Williams.

TEST FLIGHT OF NAVY'S MISSILE CALLED A SUCCESS
LEAD: A Trident 2 missile designed to be used by submarines was lofted from a launching pad here today on a maiden test flight of the Navy's newest and most powerful rocket.
It was a success, the Navy said.

U.S. SEES IRANIAN SETBACK IN PUSH ON SECOND FRONT
LEAD: The United States said today that Iran had apparently suffered a setback in its one-day effort to pierce Iraqi defenses 75 miles northeast of Baghdad.


DEAL TO GIVE MURDOCH AUSTRALIAN NEWS GROUP
LEAD: Rupert Murdoch appears to have won his $1.5 billion bid to control Australia's largest newspaper group by making a dramatic last-minute deal with his rival, Robert Holmes a Court, the Perth entrepreneur.


TRUE CHRISTMAS GIFTS HELP THE NEEDIEST
LEAD: For some, giving to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund took precedence over giving Christmas presents to family members and friends.


The Parachuting Dollar
LEAD: The dollar's sharp recent drop is not bad news, not as long as it doesn't drop too far or too fast.
The decline can mean a certain amount of good news for the United States.
Some reduction in the dollar's value may well reduce the dangerous trade deficit and relieve the pressure already evident for protectionist legislation in


PUERTO RICO ACTS TO BOLSTER FIRE LAWS
LEAD: Hoping to counter possible damage to the tourist industry from the New Year's Eve fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel, the government of Puerto Rico has acted quickly to try to dispel fears that it could happen again.


Brookehill Filing On Holly Sugar
LEAD: The New York brokerage Brookehill Partners Inc. became the third concern to express an interest in seeking control of the Holly Sugar Corporation.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Brookehill said that it was considering a higher offer than that by the company's management.


College Basketball Notebook; Coaches Upset Over Cutbacks
LEAD: Nearly a week has passed since delegates to the National Collegiate Athletic Association convention in San Diego approved measures designed to cut costs and reduce what many think is an overemphasis on intercollegiate athletics.
The week has not diminished the chorus of complaints from coaches who think that their programs are being jeopardized by the N.C.A.A.


CONVICTED CRIME CHIEF CHARGED IN BID RIGGING
LEAD: A convicted Mafia boss and several associates were charged yesterday with rigging bids on more than $30 million worth of concrete work for the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan.


Bias-Violence Panel To Begin Programs
LEAD: The new State Task-Force on Bias-Related Violence will soon begin working on programs in education, law enforcement and housing, the State Human Rights Commissioner, Douglas H. White, said yesterday.

RAY BOLGER, SCARECROW IN 'OZ,' DIES
LEAD: Ray Bolger, the loose-limbed song-and-dance man who became known to millions as the Scarecrow in ''The Wizard of Oz,'' died yesterday of cancer in Los Angeles.
He had his 83d birthday last Saturday and lived in Beverly Hills.


A Practice Run for Spring
LEAD: A man napping in the shade of the Brooklyn Bridge as the temperature climbed to an almost balmy 57 degrees.
Winter is expected to return somewhat breezily today with a high temperature of 40 degrees. (NYT/Keith Meyers)


VICTIMS DETAIL RACIAL ATTACK TO SPECIAL PROSECUTOR
LEAD: The surviving black victims of the Howard Beach racial assault have detailed their stories to a special state prosecutor and have provided ''essential evidence which will significantly aid our inquiries,'' the prosecutor said yesterday.


M'FARLANE ADMITS U.S. INTELLIGENCE ON IRAN WAS POOR
LEAD: The Reagan Administration official who initiated the arms shipments to Iran acknowledged today that the United States had virtually no independent intelligence to support its policy.


G.O.P. COMMITTEE, UNDER FIRE, REDEFINES 'BONUS'
LEAD: The National Republican Senatorial Committee, criticized for giving 87 bonuses to staff members and consultants after the November election, now says the two largest such payments were not really bonuses.


COLGATE SLIDE ENDS
LEAD: Within five games of the National Collegiate Athletic Association record for most consecutive losses by a Division I team, the Red Raiders of Colgate ended a 32-game losing streak Thursday night with a 76-64 victory over Manhattanville, a Division III opponent, at Hamilton, N.Y.
A home crowd of 350 danced on the court after Colgate won for the first time in 14 games this season under the new coach, Joe Baker, and stopped worrying about tying or breaking the record of 37 straight losses set by The Citadel in 1954 and 1955.


GRAND MET TO BUY NABISCO'S HEUBLEIN
LEAD: RJR Nabisco Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Heublein Inc. wine and spirits subsidiary to Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British brewing, hotel and leisure concern, for $1.2 billion.


BONN MAY BALK AT EXTRADITING TERROR SUSPECT
LEAD: The West German Government said today that a Lebanese believed to be a pro-Iranian terrorist could be extradited to the United States only if a commitment was given that he would not be subject to the death penalty.


GRETZKY LEFT OUT
LEAD: Wayne Gretzky, the record-breaking center of the Edmonton Oilers, was snubbed by fans in selecting the National Hockey League all-star team, which was announced yesterday.
Mario Lemieux of the Pittsburgh Penguins, currently sidelined with a knee injury, topped the balloting for starting center with 247,222 votes.


TWO GIANT PANDAS TO VISIT THE BRONX ZOO
LEAD: Two giant pandas will be sent to New York City by China for a three-month stay at the Bronx Zoo, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

European Joblessness
LEAD: Unemployment in the 12-nation European Community rose by 130,000 in November, pushing the total number of registered jobless to 16.2 million, the community said.


CHAD SAYS LIBYANS BOMB 3 OASIS SITES
LEAD: Chad said Libyan planes bombed three oasis towns in northern Chad today, killing a young girl and seriously wounding two women.


TEXAS PRISONS STOP ACCEPTING INMATES UNDER FEDERAL ORDER
LEAD: The beleaguered Texas prison system today was forced to temporarily stop admitting new prisoners after its population crept above levels mandated by a Federal court order.


HOLIDAY MONDAY
LEAD: The birthday of the Rev.
Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr., actually Jan. 15, will be observed on Monday in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
Following are holiday schedules:
Parking - Alternate-side rules suspended.
Sanitation - Regular collections.
Governmental offices - Closed.
Post offices - Closed; special delivery and express-mail delivery only.

LEAD: Among many debates in New Orleans stirred up by depressed oil prices, two have meshed in a hot political battle to be decided this week.
The issues are crime and taxes.

DOUBLEDAY PRESIDENT NAMED
LEAD: Nancy Evans, editor in chief of the Book-of-the-Month Club, has been named president and publisher of Doubleday.
Previously the book columnist for Glamour magazine, Ms.
Evans is also an author and is the co-host of ''First Edition,'' the book club's review and interview program on public television.


EDWARD D. KUEKES
LEAD: Edward D. Kuekes, whose editorial cartoon on the irony of young men going to war before being old enough to vote won him a Pulitzer Prize in 1953, died Tuesday in a retirement home in Oklahoma City.
He was 85 years old.

LEAD: A mixture of comedies and adventure films made 1986 a successful year for the motion picture industry and left the box-office recession of 1985 only a bad memory.

LEAD: At noon today there were several hundred people - among them unemployed artisans wrapped in solid leather jackets and scarves, homeless men with tattoos and five days of stubble, women with children in tow -crowded into the line at what is euphemistically called the Restaurant of the Heart here in this bleak, semi-industrial suburb just south of Paris.

LEAD: Ricky the Third Avenue barber -or hair stylist, or landscaper, depending on the particular head of hair she is presented with -is from the Netherlands.
She was asked whether she was going to watch the Super Bowl. ''I don't like football,'' she said. ''What is it?
All these big guys bending over a ball and then they fight about it.

TENTATIVE PACT IS REACHED IN LONG USX STEEL DISPUTE
LEAD: Negotiators for the USX Corporation and the Unitd Steelworkers of America reached a tentative settlement early today that would, if approved by the union's members, end the longest work stoppage in the United States steel industry.


MOCK SECURITY HIJACKING ALARMS INDIANS, INCLUDING SOME OFFICIALS
LEAD: Indian security forces staged a mock hijacking of a commercial plane by supposed Sikh extremists today in an operation so realistic that for hours several officials said they believed a real hijacking was under way.


What Health-Maintenance Groups Do Well
LEAD: To the Editor:


Suspects Plead Not Guilty In Puerto Rico Hotel Fire
LEAD: Hector Escudero Aponte being led from Federal Court in San Juan after he and Armando Jimenez Rivera, above, pleaded not guilty to Federal charges in the New Year's Eve fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel that killed 96 people.
They also face murder and arson charges filed by the commonwealth.


Takeover Rejected By Western Union
LEAD: The Western Union Corporation said today that it had rejected a revised takeover offer from an investor group headed by Resource Holdings Ltd.


Iran, Iraq and America
LEAD: The fierce upsurge of fighting in the six-year-old war between Iran and Iraq has caught American policy in disarray.

SPEEDUP URGED IN AIR SAFETY EFFORTS
LEAD: The midair collision Thursday near Salt Lake City brought new pressure yesterday for a speedup in persistently delayed programs to install new equipment and impose new rules designed to prevent such accidents.


Reagan Supporters Unite
LEAD: After some initial disarray and hesitancy, President Reagan's grass-roots supporters appear to have formed a united front.
A coalition, America at Risk, organized last month, has now coalesced with the active support of three of the Administration's point men.


Caterpillar Unit Sit-In
LEAD: About 370 Caterpillar Inc. workers spent a third day in a factory that the American farm equipment manufacturer says it plans to close this year, with a loss of 1,220 jobs.


New York's Poor Children: A Tinderbox
LEAD: Unless New York City dedicates itself to making 1987 the year for a concerted effort to improve the lives of the children of poverty, we will contribute to the creation of a social tinderbox.


Wardair in Pact With Airbus
LEAD: Wardair International, the Canadian airline, said that it had agreed to buy 12 wide-body A310 aircraft from the European Airbus consortium in a deal valued at $780 million.
The agreement was made public Thursday night in connection with the twoday Canadian visit of the French Foreign Minister, Jean-Bernard

L.I.R.R.

BID TO ADD TIME TO VISIT BABY M IS TURNED DOWN
LEAD: Mary Beth Whitehead, the surrogate mother in the Baby M custody case, was denied her request today to spend more time with the infant.

OUTPUT UP STRONG 0.5% LAST MONTH
LEAD: The nation's industrial production rose a solid five-tenths of 1 percent in December, the third consecutive monthly improvement, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

LEAD: INVESTORS have a new way of getting capital gains, income or both in the real estate field, thanks to the Tax Reform Act of 1986.

LEAD: Based on a story by Ray Bradbury and set in the future, ''Walking on Air,'' the first new production this season in the ''Wonderworks'' series, is the tale of a wheelchair-bound boy who yearns to walk free in space.

THE DANCE: NEW BALLETS BY MARTINS
LEAD: ''Ballet No. 1,'' as the New York City Ballet lists its first premiere of the season every year, turned out on Thursday night to be Ballet No. 1, A and B. Peter Martins, in fact, choreographed two unrelated short ballets and chose to present them on the same bill at the State Theater.


ENERGY PRICES LOWER; CATTLE MOSTLY HIGHER
LEAD: Energy futures prices were mostly lower yesterday, appearing to have found a temporary niche while awaiting further word out of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.


ARTHUR DREXLER, 61, AUTHORITY ON ARCHITECTURE
LEAD: Arthur Drexler, for 35 years the highly influential curator and director of the Department of Architecture and Design at the Museum of Modern Art, died of pancreatic cancer in New York yesterday.
He was 61 years old.


Memorial Will Be Held For Rev. Mother Ruth
LEAD: A memorial service will be held at 10 A.M.
Monday in the Cathedral Church of St.
John the Divine in Manhattan for the Rev.
Mother Ruth, founder and headmistress of St.
Hilda's and St.
Hugh's Episcopal day school.
The Reverend Mother, who died Dec. 22 after a brief illness, was 89 years old.

ERICH LEINSDORF CONDUCTS THE PHILHARMONIC
LEAD: The pieces that began and ended Thursday night's New York Philharmonic concert at Avery Fisher Hall shared not only a common tradition but an unusual informality.
Thus the Mozart Symphony in A (No. 29) and Beethoven's ''Pastoral'' seem to burst in on the listener unannounced.
There are no preparations, no introductions; they simply appear with a startling abruptness.

ROCKETS GET MAXWELL
LEAD: The Houston Rockets, attempting to fill the void created by the ban earlier this week of Lewis Lloyd and Mitchell Wiggins, acquired Cedric Maxwell from the Los Angeles Clippers yesterday for a first-round 1987 draft pick and a third-round choice in 1988.
The Rockets had re-signed an eight-year-veteran guard, Allen Leavell, earlier this week.

LEAD: Mark S. Fowler, who has championed deregulation of the nation's telecommunications industries for the Reagan Administration, today announced his resignation as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.

PANEL BACKS LICENSING OF AIDS DRUG
LEAD: In a highly unusual step, a panel of expert medical advisers to the Food and Drug Administration recommended today that a promising drug against AIDS be licensed for sale despite what the scientists described as major gaps in knowledge about its effectiveness and safety.


LIST WINDS DOWN
LEAD: Baseball's salary arbitration list of 106 players shrank to 100 yesterday.
Ricky Horton of St.
Louis and Bill Krueger of Oakland reached agreement with their teams Thursday not long after filing for arbitration (Horton for $410,000, Krueger for $175,000).
Then yesterday four more players who had filed settled with their clubs - Ed Lynch with the Chicago Cubs, Steve Crawford with Boston, Bill Schroeder with Milwaukee and Donnie Hill with the Chicago White Sox.


Soviet Leader at Arms Talks Plans Absences From Geneva
LEAD: The new head of the Soviet arms control delegation, Yuli M. Vorontsov, has told American officials that he does not plan to be in Geneva for the entire round of negotiations, which began this week, Administration officials said today.


PLANT USE SHOWS GAIN
LEAD: The operating rate at the nation's factories, mines and utilities in December climbed to the highest level since last February, the Federal Reserve Board said today.
The report is another sign of a recovery in the nation's manufacturing sector.

DONAHUE TO STAY PUT
LEAD: Despite reports that he would take the job, Coach Terry Donahue of U.C.L.A. has decided not to become head coach of the Atlanta Falcons of the National Football League, spurning an offer reported at $2.5 million over five years.
Taylor Smith, the Falcons' executive vice president, announced that Donahue had ''decided it was in his best interest to remain at U.C.L.A.


FIRST JERSEY SETTLEMENT
LEAD: First Jersey Securities has agreed to pay $10 million to settle a class action suit charging that the brokerage firm defrauded customers by charging excessive markups in a number of stocks.


U.S. EXPECTING TO ESTABLISH TIES WITH MONGOLIA SHORTLY
LEAD: The United States was reported today to be close to establishing diplomatic relations with Mongolia, a Soviet ally on the Soviet-Chinese border.


IRAN CLAIMS GAINS ON KEY ISLAND
LEAD: Iran asserted today that it had captured most of a strategic island southeast of Basra in the Shatt al Arab, the waterway at the head of the Persian Gulf.


Correction
LEAD: An article in some copies yesterday about an anti-apartheid protest at Citibank headquarters in Manhattan gave an incorrect account of Coretta Scott King's involvement.
Mrs.
King was in Atlanta on Thursday, and was not among the 21 people seized on trespassing charges.
A spokesman for the protest group in New York had read statements attributed to Mrs.


PARENTS ENCOURAGE CHILDREN TO DONATE TO NEEDIEST CASES
LEAD: Some parents hope donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund will help teach their children the importance of charity.


New Zealand Trims U.S. Rival's Sails
LEAD: A startling spinnaker foul-up on Dennis Conner's Stars &amp; Stripes today allowed Chris Dickson and his New Zealand team to come from behind and win their first race in the challenger finals for the America's Cup.


U.S. SEEKS PROSECUTOR IN NOFZIGER CASE
LEAD: The Justice Department announced today that it had asked for a special prosecutor to investigate Lyn Nofziger, President Reagan's former political director, and his efforts to lobby the White House on behalf of a California rice company.


MCA Will Take $50 Million Charge
LEAD: MCA Inc., one of the largest American entertainment companies, said it would take a $50 million pretax charge against fourth-quarter earning, blaming the slump in the television syndication market.
The company said the charge, which could offset operating income for the period largely reflected a downward revision of its estimates of what TV stations could pay for syndicated
