HEALTH CHIEF WARNS AIDS WILL ALTER CITY
LEAD: New York City's Health Commissioner, Dr.
Stephen C. Joseph, warned yesterday that the projected rise in AIDS cases ''will change everything about the city, its demography, the political and economic life of the city.''


Citibank Pact On Manila
LEAD: Citibank N.A., which was purportedly blocking a Philippines debt rescheduling, has agreed to terms outlined by other foreign banks, banking sources said today.


A $46,000 Celebration
LEAD: A group of graying civil rights and antiwar demonstrators from the 1960's, who after many years have finally wrested a damage settlement from the Government for excesses committed under a counterintelligence program of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, will hold a modest gathering next week to celebrate the victory.


AFTER THE COURT BATTLE, A WAR OVER LIQUOR PRICES
LEAD: At 3 P.M.
Wednesday, the day after the United States Supreme Court declared illegal a New York State law setting a minimum markup on liquor prices, Steve Hollister posted in his East Side window new low costs for about 20 items.


At Kennedy, Long Lines Trudge the Welcome Mat
LEAD: To the Editor:


2 LEADERS FOLLOWED PARALLEL CAREERS WITH CONTRASTING STYLES
LEAD: Though they have markedly different political styles and personal backgrounds, Zhao Ziyang and the man he replaced yesterday, Hu Yaobang, both owe their rise through the Chinese hierarchy to the same factor: the sponsorship of the country's paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping.


Correction
LEAD: An article on Thursday about a proposed change in milk licensing laws in New York State incorrrectly described a Federal court decision this week.
The court ruled that in the case of Farmland Dairies, the state's application of its licensing law was unconstitutional.
The court declined to rule on the constitutionality of the law itself.


Did He Drop Protege Or Was He Forced?
LEAD: The abrupt ouster of Hu Yaobang, China's Communist Party chief, raises the question whether the move was engineered by Deng Xiaoping, the country's paramount leader, or was forced on Mr.
Deng by increasingly powerful hard-liners in the party.

Fires in Mississippi Kill Five
LEAD: A 4-year-old boy, his mother and his grandmother died early today when fire engulfed their home here.
The blaze followed two other fires late Thursday in Clinton and Meridian that killed an infant and an elderly man, officials said.


GUINNESS TELLS OF WRONGDOING
LEAD: Guinness P.L.C., the embattled British brewer, admitted today that its management used illicit deals and made unexplained payments in a multibillion-dollar corporate takeover last year.


SCHLICHTER ARRESTED IN BETTING INQUIRY
LEAD: Art Schlichter, a former all-America quarterback at Ohio State whose National Football League career was interrupted by a 1983 suspension because of gambling, was one of seven men arrested here today in an investigation of a multimillion-dollar college and professional sports betting operation.
Warrants were issued for six other suspects.


DRUG TESTING FOR CUSTOMS AGENTS IS ABANDONED BY THE WHITE HOUSE
LEAD: In a major retreat, the Reagan Administration announced today that it would not require drug testing for agents and investigators hired by the United States Customs Service.


LENGTHY HELMSLEY INQUIRY IS SEEN
LEAD: Federal and state grand juries are expected to take weeks, or even months, to complete a tax investigation of Harry and Leona Helmsley, who head major hotel and real estate operations in New York City.

LEAD: Preliminary screening of potential jurors in the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz resumed yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan as the long-delayed case entered its final approach to trial.

UNIFORM CHANGES BUT TROUBLES CONTINUE
LEAD: Beneath the slightly ironic smile, Mark Haynes leaves the impression that, on second thought, he'd rather be back with the Giants.


'Ranch Fur' Cruelties
LEAD: To the Editor:


GRUMMAN TO END 1,500 JOBS ON L.I.
LEAD: Long Island's largest employer, the Grumman Corporation, said today that it planned to eliminate about 1,500 jobs in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
It is the first time in more than decade that Grumman has cut its Long Island work force.


THE LIBRARY BRINGS READING TO THE HOMELESS
LEAD: Priscilla Bassett reading to a group of younsters at the Hotel Martinique and, left, Peggy Levin using a puppet to animate a tale yesterday.
The two librarians were taking part in a program in which children's librarians at the New York Public Library visit the hotel, a city shelter for the homeless, to read to the children and to advise them and their families of the special programs and services available at library branches around the city.


Up the Mountain, Then and Now
LEAD: Ah, but skiing has changed.
There's a whole generation of skiers now who've never ridden a Poma lift (straddle the round metal plate that pulls you up on your skis) or a T-bar (different shape, same effect).
Who've never buckled more than two buckles per boot.
Who've never chosen their skis by matching the tips to the midpoint of their forearm held high.


Loan Rate Cut
LEAD: The Veterans Administration said today that it would lower the maximum interest rate on federally backed V.A. mortgages to 8.5 percent, the lowest level in almost nine years.


CHRONICLER OF SHOW BUSINESS
LEAD: Earl Wilson, who chronicled New York's night life for four decades in a chatty syndicated column that originated in The New York Post, died yesterday at St.
Joseph's Medical Center in Yonkers.
He was 79 years old and lived in Yonkers.


LEADER OF PARTY IN CHINA IS OUSTED FOR HIS 'MISTAKES'
LEAD: Hu Yaobang, the chief of the world's largest Communist Party, was forced to resign today after being accused of major ''mistakes'' during his tenure.
His dismissal followed recent demonstrations for freer expression and democracy in China.


Topics: Sense and Spectacle; Wow at BAM
LEAD: Everything about Robert Wilson's ''the CIVIL warS: Act V - The Rome Section'' seemed calculated to turn away baffled audiences during its recent run.
Characters in this avant-garde work include Lincoln (hobbling on enormous stilts), a Snow Owl, Hercules, Robert E. Lee (seen turning in the porthole of a spaceship) and a troupe of Hopi Indians and Italian Redshirts.


30 Dead and 57 Hurt In Mindanao Fighting
LEAD: The military said today that it had shelled Moslem positions on the southern island of Mindanao on the fourth day of fighting in which at least 30 people have been killed and 57 wounded.


SMALL PLANE IS A FOCUS OF INQUIRY INTO COLLISION
LEAD: A small private plane apparently flew into the flight path of a larger commuter aircraft before the two collided over this Salt Lake City suburb Thursday, killing all 10 people aboard, a Federal safety official said tonight.


REAGAN STATEMENT ON IRAN DELAYED
LEAD: The White House said today that President Reagan would make no effort to dispel the public confusion over details of the Iran-contra affair until he has a more complete picture of the secret dealings.

Books of The Times; 15 Years of Confidence
LEAD: AMERICAN HIGH: The Years of Confidence 1945-1960.
By William L. O'Neill. 321 pages.
Illustrated.
Free Press. $19.95.
Postwar America was a rich hunting ground for social critics.
Everywhere they turned, there was something to shoot down.
They took particular aim at conformity, peppering such weak sisters as the Organization Man and the Other-directed Type.

Dutch Dance Theater To Perform at the Met
LEAD: The Netherlands Dance Theater, which has not danced in New York since 1982, will return to the Metropolitan Opera House on June 22 for a week of performances.
The company, under the direction of Jiri Kylian, will present two programs of works by Mr.
Kylian.
The repertory includes six New York premieres by him, among them ''Heart's Labyrinth,'' ''L'Enfant et les Sortileges,'' ''L'Histoire du Soldat,'' ''Six Dances,'' ''Silent Cries,'' which is a solo staging of ''L'Apres-Midi d'un Faune,'' and ''Stamping Ground.


AT 8 A.M.., OR 7, THE HAIRDRESSER'S THERE
LEAD: There may still be women who get up late, go to lunch and spend the afternoon at the hairdresser.
But Eileen Ford, Heidi Freund and Rosalie Stern are not among them.
They are members of a growing constituency of busy women (and men, too) who schedule their hair appointments before 9 A.M. - sometimes before 8 -to get a fast start on the day.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''Would it have been reasonable for me, for example, without any Presidential approval, in the obvious opposition of the Secretary of Defense, to tell Israel: 'Go ahead and deliver arms, and then you can come to the Pentagon and buy arms from a Secretary of Defense who is fundamentally opposed to it?


LANGER FIRST IN PALM SPRINGS
LEAD: Bernhard Langer of West Germany didn't quite bring the new PGA West course to its knees.
That may never happen.


N.F.L. Said to Fine Hill for Hit on Rice
LEAD: Sources indicated yesterday that the National Football League had fined but not suspended Kenny Hill of the Giants for a late hit on Jerry Rice of the San Francisco 49ers during the Giants' 49-3 playoff victory Jan. 4.

Tandon Job Cuts
LEAD: The Tandon Corporation said it would eliminate 175 jobs at its southern California facilities as part of its cost-cutting program and the consolidation of its production facilities in Singapore.
The eliminations, which will take place over the next six to eight weeks, will pare the company's staff to about 500 employees, Ranjit Sitlani, a Tandon spokesman, said.

TOLLNER JOINS BILLS
LEAD: Ted Tollner, the former head coach at Southern California whose recent losses to Donahue's U.C.L.A teams were a factor in his dismissal Dec. 8, was named yesterday as receivers coach for the Buffalo Bills.
The Bills' chief offensive weapon is the passing of Jim Kelly.
The Bills also hired Ted Marchiboda, the head coach of the Baltimore Colts from 1975 to 1979, and named him the quarterback coach and passing-game coordinator.

Correction
LEAD: An article on Thursday about the arrest of a New York City police officer charged with stealing money from the bank account of his estranged wife misstated part of the accusation.
The officer, Robert Fioretti, is charged with having used a forged withdrawal slip - not a deposit slip - to steal $18,000 from her bank account.

No Airplanes Necessary
LEAD: EVERY Giant football fan has a vivid recollection of the Philadelphia Eagle game on Nov. 19, 1978, which football history refers to as The Fumble game.
That disaster, and the resulting loss, did not cost the Giants a division title, a playoff game, or even a winning season.
Yet, it set into motion a chain of events that can best be described as total fan outrage.

NEW YORKERS, ETC.
LEAD: THE other night an executive, dining at a moderately sized restaurant, paid his check with a credit card and added a rather generous tip.

LEGALLY BLAMELESS, BUT ACCIDENT-PRONE
LEAD: THE bare facts are, I got in the car and just as I was passing my next-door neighbor's driveway, wham, slam! she backed up, bang into the side of my car.
What a way to meet.
I had not seen Kathie since she went off to college.
Shaken up as I was, I could not help noticing what a pretty woman she had turned out to be.

THE MET MAKES ITS MOVE INTO THE 20TH CENTURY
LEAD: The opening of the Metropolitan Museum's expansive new Lila Acheson Wallace wing for 20th-century art is not only a major event in the history of this august institution, but in the history of New York as a center for that art.
With the $26-million Wallace addition - housing an international survey of painting and sculpture from 1900 to now - the Met has established, in essence, a separate museum that becomes the fourth big one in Manhattan devoted solely to the present century.

But it might never have reached its 100th birthday had it not been for an unusual partnership between a prominent local law firm and municipal officials.

I'd say that's not only asking for too much, I'd say that's something only an extremely greedy individual would do.

THE WORLD'S WORST CRITICS
LEAD: SELF-CRITICISM is an art not many are qualified to practice.
Despite our best efforts it is probable that, apart from the most immediate, pragmatic, technical revisions, the writer's effort to detach himself from his work is quixotic: knowing too much is a way of knowing too little; or, conversely, how can we expect to know more about ourselves than we know about anything else?

MAFIA BOSSES ARE SENTENCED TO CENTURIES
LEAD: Seven of the eight men convicted in November of operating or helping operate a New York-based Mafia ''commission'' were sentenced last week to jail terms of 100 years; the eighth received 40 years.
Included among the seven were three men convicted as bosses of major crime families: Anthony (Fat Tony) Salerno, 75 years old, of the Genovese family; Anthony (Tony Ducks) Corallo, 73, of the Lucchese family, and Carmine (Junior) Persico, 53, of the Colombo group.


Shopping Malls
LEAD: To the Editor:  Shopping malls are of interest to sociologists for reasons other than esthetics and traffic patterns. ALASKA
LEAD: To the Editor: What an accurate description of the ferry ride to Alaska!
My husband and I did the seven-day Inside Passage trip on the Matanuska this past September.
And we, too, had only 200 people aboard and found the food and accommodations just fine.
But it was the scenery that made the voyage memorable.

CARNIVAL
LEAD: To the Editor: To get wet feet in Venice, it is not necessary to visit during the Carnival period.
My wife and I arrived in the Queen of the Adriatic on the heels of a huge low-pressure area that had bounced our plane around en route from Milan in September 1968.
That evening we went from the Hotel Metropole to Piazza San Marco to hear the municipal band, which was playing selections from ''Norma'' and ''Tannhauser.

CRIME
LEAD: Two cult writers of mystery fiction have published new books featuring series characters -and both live up to their reputation.
Joseph Hansen's latest book is THE LITTLE DOG LAUGHED (Holt, $15.95), and Tony Hillerman's is SKINWALKERS (Harper &amp; Row, $15.95).
They are cult figures because they write well, have staked out an area of their own and have attracted a discriminating and faithful audience.


AN OLD FAVORITE IS BACK IN TOWN
LEAD: ACCESSORIES of alligator and crocodile skin have long been chic.
But since laws were passed to protect those reptiles, such adornments have not been as visible as they were a couple of decades ago, when they added a special touch to many a smart woman's attire.
Now, however, handbags and belts made from the skins are back and despite their price tag - bags start at around $800 and can run into the thousands - customers have been lin ing up to buy them.


Foundation Dug for Long-Delayed Queens Project
LEAD: AFTER seven years of delays, backhoes are finally scratching a foundation into the frozen ground at Queens Boulevard and Union Turnpike in Kew Gardens, Queens.
But Sidney Esikoff, the developer, still is not certain exactly what he can build there.


Langer Holds One-Shot Lead
LEAD: Bernhard Langer returned to a conventional golf course today but turned in a rather unconventional round to barely hold on to his lead through four rounds of the 28th annual Bob Hope Chrysler Classic.

LEAD: The American Indian had no word for art and believed that a beautifully made object was ''a prayer made visible.'' Avarice, ignorance and indifference are allowing the destruction of our most profound cultural heritage.
J.
REZENDES  New York City

Freshman attitudes
LEAD: American college freshmen are more interested in financial success according to a new survey by the University of California at Los Angeles and the American Council on Education, and less interested than their predecessors in helping others.
The study, based on responses from 204,491 students who entered college last fall, also reported less support for the preservation of the environment and a significant drop in support for the legalization of marijuana.

HERO AND GOAT
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:


WHEN SALT MUST BE RESTRICTED, THERE ARE TASTY ALTERNATIVES
LEAD: SOME seasonings are roughly interchangeable.
Tarragon can stand in for chervil and, in a pinch so can parsley.
Vinegar instead of lemon is another effective substitution as is black pepper for cayenne.
But no seasoning does exactly the same job of bringing up flavor as salt.
When a diet requires salt to be restricted it becomes a challenge for the cook.


Alaska
LEAD: To the Editor: ''Through Alaska On Your Own'' by Virginia Van der Veer Hamilton (Travel, Dec. 21) reminded me of a favorite part of my own independent trip through the Canadian Rockies and Alaska last summer.
We took a local train from Anchorage to Denali National Park and saw a rich variety of people and scenes: professional couples heading for their weekend cabins, retired railroad workers debarking at their front doors, a horde of people netting king salmon in a stream, a load-carrying huskie and its owner, mail tossed out the window at specific locations and an anxious-looking man from


A PASSION FOR WHEELS, WINGS AND ENGINES
LEAD: The photographs of Jacques-Henri Lartigue, who died last summer at the age of 92, are art photography's best-known version of primitivism.
Most were taken in the early years of this century, when Lartigue was a boy, and they have the freshness and spontaneity of an eye unjaundiced by the conventions of the photography of the day.

ON LANGUAGE
LEAD: IT BEGAN IN A NEW YORK minute after a piece about geographical derogations, the use of place names as modifiers to sneer at a trait or an occupation.
My colleague Russell Baker passed along a cryptic message - ''Larchmont lockjaw'' - which I took to mean the pronunciation affected by yuppies.
I then passed it along to the Philadelphia lawyers who read this column as the speech affected by ''upper-class lowerclassmen returning to suburbia.

STRANDED BY POLITICS AND WAR: NICARAGUA'S LOVED, NEGLECTED POET
LEAD: ONE can hardly imagine how remote the newborn republic of Nicaragua must have been from the world's cosmopolitan centers during the last century.
It was perceived, not quite correctly, as a tropical backwater, steamy, inert and destitute of learning and culture.
Yet from a wretched Nicaraguan village, by some amazing mystery, emerged Ruben Dario, the vagabond poet who was to influence Latin American and Spanish literature forever and dazzle Europe as no provincial ever had.

These players should put some money away so they don't have to be so greedy.

City as Landlord
LEAD: To the Editor:  Your article headed ''New York Plays Reluctant Landlord'' on Dec. 14 misses one very important point: Many of these buildings coming under city control were previously rent-controlled or -stabilized.
The consequent severe restrictions on rent increases caused the buildings to be unprofitable, and therefore neglected, and finally abandoned by their owners.

SHAW'S PLAYS GO ON TALKING TO MODERN AUDIENCES
LEAD: George Bernard Shaw's contemporaries would have been astonished to know that his plays were still being performed around the world toward the end of the 20th century (''You Never Can Tell'' is now winding up a revival in New York).
A playwright was the last thing they considered him to be.
If theater reviewers agreed on nothing else, they were certain that he could not write for the stage.

RECALLING THE DAYS OF 'WE SHALL OVERCOME'
LEAD: Chapters of American history most regretted by Americans have sometimes been those for which people in the rest of the world have most admired the United States.
Watergate comes to mind.
What many in the international community remember most about Watergate is not the criminality of a President but the effective working of the civil machinery that removed him from office - the way in which the will of the people truly prevailed.


LEFTISTS IN MEXICO SEEKING A MERGER
LEAD: Mexico's political left, traditionally divided, is trying to unite into a single party that could present a greater challenge to the governing party.


NAMING BABY FOR HISTORY'S SAKE
LEAD: Linda Liefland's essay on ''Finding a Surname for Baby''  [ Dec. 28 ]  reminded me of my childhood in Hungary where many of us came from mixed marriages, the mothers being Catholic and the fathers Protestant.
For most of us the egalitarian division fell so that the girls went to the Catholic church and the boys to the Protestant church, which made us believe that the niceties, colors and elaborate decorations in our church were meant for women while the men went to more down-to-earth and masculine houses of worship.


CASTING LIGHT ON THE USE OF FLASH
LEAD: FOR some photographers, night football games are enormously funny.
Not that the game itself is all that amusing; it's the sight of thousands of fans in the stadium firing off thousands of electronic flash units.
Too bad for the fans that such bursts of light are ineffectual.

LEAD: Confirmed incidents of racial bias in New York City, after dropping sharply in most of 1986, have jumped more than 150 percent in the month since the racial attack in Howard Beach, Queens, according to police officials who investigate crimes of bias.


Venetian Lace
LEAD: To the Editor: I read with much interest Anne Marshall Zwack's article ''Splendor of a Fading Art'' (Travel, Dec. 14).
The descriptions of Jesurum's museum and shop brought back wonderful memories.
In October 1980 while on vacation in Italy, I visited Jesurum with a specific task in mind.
My oldest daughter was to be married the following August and was going to wear my wedding gown, which was then 30 years old.

RING AROUND THE KREMLIN
LEAD: Forty years after he paid dearly for his faith in Communism, Ring Lardner Jr. concedes some disappointment but no regrets.
Mr.
Lardner, whose promising career as a screenwriter was aborted in 1947 when he was blacklisted after refusing to answer questions from the House Un-American Activities Committee, reflected on his long association with Communism while visiting Moscow as a tourist last week.

Small-College Back Scores 4 for South
LEAD: Christian Okoye, a Little all-American from Azusa Pacific College, a member of the National Association for Intercollegiate Athletics, set a Senior Bowl record with four touchdowns today as the South edged the North, 42-38.
Three of Okoye's scores came on 1-yard runs, and he had a 6-yard touchdown with 1 minute 6 seconds to play.


Art
LEAD: At a moment of considerable interest in the possibilities of abstraction, the Luise Ross Gallery, 50 West 57th Street, has brought together four little known artists whose work defines, each in its own way, an edge between abstraction and figuration.
The diptychs of Cynthia Gallagher and the vertical slabs of George Hildrew are paintings with precise figurative and sculptural associations.


RURAL AREAS BECOME DEBRIS SITES IN WAKE OF DUMP CLOSING
LEAD: SINCE the closing of the Croton landfill last summer many towns have discontinued or limited pickup of bulk trash.
Commercial carters, the alternative to municipal pickup, refuse to remove a lone discarded sofa or refrigerator, while the larger loads that they agree to remove are likely to cost homeowners more than four times as much as a year ago.


In a Hot Market, the Bargains Evaporate
LEAD: WITH the stock market flying on afterburners, analysts are hard-pressed to find stocks that look undervalued by such traditional measures as price-earnings ratio and book value.
Indeed, among many analysts surveyed, few could come up with a classic value play.
John Johnson, of Johnson, Valliant &amp; Broadfoot, noted that the entire ''emerging growth'' sector - generally smaller companies with fast earnings gains -looked undervalued from one perspective: the average price-earnings ratio about matches the overall market's; in 1983, smaller growth companies commanded twice the market's P/E ratio.


CO-OP HUNTING IN THE OUTER BOROUGHS
LEAD: WHEN Bill Dillard was not on the road, singing and acting in musicals or playing his trumpet with Louis Armstrong, he lived in rental apartments in Harlem.
Last year, at the age of 75, he and his wife, Celestine, became impatient with waiting lists for new rental projects and began looking for a better home outside Manhattan.

LEAD: IF the Philadelphia Phillies want a precedent, they need look back only three years.
The Kansas City Royals finished the 1983 season in second place, 20 games behind the Chicago White Sox, then won the American League West championship the following season.

The block of four depicts butterflies from the south Pacific island nation and enhances a popular topical specialty: butterflies-on-stamps.
As with the butterflies themselves, the stamps are collected because of their beautiful colors and great variety.

WHEN SALT MUST BE RESTRICTED, THERE ARE TASTY ALTERNATIVES
LEAD: SOME seasonings are roughly interchangeable.
Tarragon can stand in for chervil and, in a pinch so can parsley.
Vinegar instead of lemon is another effective substitution as is black pepper for cayenne.
But no seasoning does exactly the same job of bringing up flavor as salt.
When a diet requires salt to be restricted it becomes a challenge for the cook.


All in One's Stride
LEAD: To walk with a spring in one's stride is no longer a mere phrase.
Scientists at Leeds in England have measured the springiness in the arch of the human foot.
Running, in their analysis, is a matter not of sweat and endurance but of storing and expending energy between strides - ''like a rubber ball bouncing along.

Learning On the Job
LEAD: Cheers to A. M. Rosenthal.

WHAT'S DOING IN CRANS-MONTANA
LEAD: The Crans-Montana plateau in Switzerland was once scorned by local peasants as fit for little more than cow grazing; 60 years ago it was a destination for tuberculosis patients seeking crisp, dry air.
Since then, skiers and golfers seeking the same weather conditions for winter and summer sports have come to predominate the 5,000-foot-high resort community.

Murdoch Wins an Autralian Dust-Up
LEAD: Rupert Murdoch came out on top of the battle of the media titans in Australia.
In a deal struck with his rival, Robert Holmes a Court, Mr.
Murdoch cleared the way to take control of the Herald and Weekly, Australia's largest media group.
In turn, Mr.
Holmes a Court, who agreed to withdraw his $1.4 billion bid, is to purchase the group's two Perth newspapers and its Melbourne television stations, which many analysts said were what he really wanted.

Give Foreign Borrowers a Break
LEAD: IF 1982 marked the emergence of the international debt crisis, 1987 could the year the notion of debt relief becomes respectable.
Developing countries in Latin America and Africa, whose outstanding debt totals an estimated $973 billion, have been rumbling about relief for at least two years.
Stringent adjustment programs, they say, which buy them payment extensions from creditors, also sap their economies and threaten their political stability.


LIVING BY THE BOOK IN RETIREMENT
LEAD: YOU CAN always tell a new resident of an adult condominium community from the other gray-haired types because one shoulder is always lower than the other.
This comes from carrying the prospectus around from condo meeting to condo meeting.
What is this prospectus?
It is the thick, telephone directory-size book of rules and regulations for living in a condominium, the thing that all condo real-estate ads clearly state you can't buy one of their homes or apartments without.


UNSINKABLE SOUTH AFRICA
LEAD: It's not hard to figure why South Africa's white rulers are excluding foreign journalists, like reporters for The Times, and stifling what was once the freest press in Africa.
President P. W. Botha wants fewer television pictures and better newspaper headlines.
He wants his National Party to overwhelm all opponents in the election looming this spring.


About Men; The Comfort of Pals
LEAD: RECENTLY, WHILE I WAS CON-valescing from an operation, Bert and Buddy, two old friends whom I rarely see because they live far away, visited me.
I couldn't use the stairs, so my wife brought them up to my study and left us alone.
For hours, we talked nonstop, pouring ourselves out for one another, drinking one another in, joyously celebrating the sacrament of friendship.

LIFE'S BEST THINGS ARE PRICELESS
LEAD: ONCE upon a time, when I still believed that mothers had the duty and power to grant wishes, I promised my last child, then an 11-year-old girl who dreamed of owning a horse, that if we ever moved away I would buy her one.
It was an easy promise, one I thought I would never have to keep.
Friends who passed down to her their own daughters' castoff velvet riding caps, hoof-pickers, horsefly spray and crops assured me that Kate, too, would automatically trot out of the horsey stage when she was 13 or so.

ARE BASEBALL PLAYERS ASKING TOO MUCH?
LEAD: I think it's only natural that in a free enterprise system some ''market correction'' develops.
It was the owners who were responsible for the explosion of player salaries in the 1970's; they have now realized the risky economics of continued bidding wars and longterm contracts.
There is no premeditated ''collusion'' here - it's just that they're all thinking and acting the same way.

IN ANIMATION FOR CHILDREN, THE OLD DAYS WERE BETTER
LEAD: They come from two different worlds: she is a se rene thoroughbred, he's a street-smart scoundrel with radical ideas.

JAZZ: GEORGE SHEARING
LEAD: THE delicate pianism of George Shearing, who combines one of the most feathery touches in jazz with an English-parlor gentility, has an almost sleight-of-hand quality in club performance.
Especially when Mr.
Shearing calmly wings his way through a series of interlocking blues progressions, the music almost seems to emanate from a magical source separate from the pianist's fingers.

IN SHORT: FICTION
LEAD: THE CASE OF THE FRAGMENTED WOMAN.
By Cleo Jones. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) Mary Sable, the heroine of Cleo Jones's third novel, is a Marin County housewife and aspiring writer; she takes care of a husband who neither appreciates nor understands her, and three children, who treat her as little more than a maid.

Gail Weisen Married
LEAD: At Temple Emanuel in New Hyde Park, L.I., last night Gail Robin Weisen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
Irving Weisen of Merrick, L.I., was married to Louis Alan Gossert, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
George Gossert of Palm Harbor, Fla.
Rabbi Robert Benjamin officiated.
Mrs.
Gossert, a certified public accountant for Ernst &amp; Whinney in New York, graduated from the State University of New York at Buffalo.


Foster Elated
LEAD: GREG FOSTER was jubilant, with good reason.
It was one of the rare times in Foster's track career that he had beaten Renaldo Nehemiah in the hurdles.
He was so happy, Foster said afterward, that he didn't notice when Nehemiah tried to congratulate him after Foster's world-indoor record clocking of 7.36 seconds in the 60-meter hurdles Friday night at the Sunkist Invitational meet in Los


SLOWING DOWN, SLIGHTLY, AT 94
LEAD: SOMEONE looking for a man in his 95th year could not be faulted for taking the search to a hospital.
And in the case of Jack Horwitz, the search would bear fruit when it reached the Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park.


For Immigrants, a Rough Road
LEAD: FOR years, the prevailing wisdom on how immigrants fare in the labor market has been based on the notion that assimilation is a key, even determining, factor.
Drawing mainly on 1970 Census data, studies concluded that while earnings of new immigrants were lower than those of comparably situated native workers, earnings of immigrants who had been here for more than a decade exceeded those of native workers of the same age, education and so on.


The Historical Jesus
LEAD: To the Editor:


Raiders Of the Sacred Sites
LEAD: I am an archeologist who has worked for the last 10 years on protecting archeological sites.
I have come to the conclusion that the only way we will have any sites left is by educating the public about the importance of these sites and about their desecration by looters.

M. L. Grass, a Chain-Store Executive, Engaged to Jody Harrison, a Designer
LEAD: The engagement of Jody Leigh Harrison to Martin Lehrman Grass has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs.
Stanley L. Harrison of Norfolk, Va.
Mr.
Grass is a son of Alexander Grass and Lois Lehrman Grass, both of Harrisburg, Pa.
The wedding is planned for May 17.


DISSIDENTS IN ECUADOR AIR FORCE SIEZE PRESIDENT
LEAD: Last year, Ecuador locked up Gen.
Frank Vargas Pazzos, an Air Force commander, after he staged two revolts within a week.
The authorities turned aside General Vargas's insistence that he was merely protesting against corruption in the armed forces.
Later the national congress voted to grant the officer amnesty, and he became something of a folk hero.


50 People Die as Boat Sinks Near Central Philippine Isle
LEAD: A boat carrying participants in a Roman Catholic festival sank near an island in the central Philippines on Friday, killing at least 50 people, the authorities said today.


KEAN AIMS FOR WELFARE REFORM THAT WORKS
LEAD: IF the Legislature goes along, as expected, New Jersey may soon be the first state in the nation to require every able-bodied welfare recipient, including mothers of young children, to work or attend school.
Governor Kean, announcing the new direction for the state's $1 billion welfare system last week in his State of the State message, called it ''a bold and reasonable plan.


FOR THE RECORD
LEAD: To the Editor: In his interesting article on the troubles facing the music publishing industry, Bernard Holland writes that the time is long gone when the market for printed music was ''voracious'' and reminds us of the success of the old Etude magazine as a sharp contrast to today's sad situation.


SCARSDALE OFFERS HOMELESS A HOUSE
LEAD: Because of a production error in last Sunday's Westchester Weekly, the following story appeared with a section omitted.
A LITTLE white house with a picket fence may become the home of a now-homeless family if the village of Scarsdale, which owns it, and the county, which has hundreds of homeless families to shelter, can come to an agreement.

COLLEGES PRODDED TO PROVE WORTH
LEAD: American colleges and universities, which have operated for more than three centuries on the premise that the fruits of higher education are self-evident, are facing mounting pressure to prove that their students are being educated.

SETON UPSETS HOYAS
LEAD: With six seconds remaining, a surprised Mark Bryant made a pair of free throws today that enabled Seton Hall to upset Georgetown, 66-65, in a Big East game at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.
It was Seton Hall's second defeat of Georgetown this season, the only losses the Hoyas have in 14 games.


MURDOCH HOLDINGS ISSUE IN AUSTRALIA
LEAD: The overnight transformation of Rupert Murdoch's Australian newspaper holdings into a national chain with two-thirds of the country's circulation has raised concerns here about the concentration of so many newspapers in the control of one individual.


NETWORKS AND N.F.L. ARE DRAWING THE BATTLE LINES
LEAD: For many years, the three major television networks and the National Football League have formed a partnership that has handsomely benefited everyone involved.
ABC, CBS and NBC paid top price for exclusive rights to the games, filling the coffers of team owners, helping to fund increased player salaries, and, most years, earning millions of dollars in profits for themselves.


GREEKS' PLANS FOR OLYMPIAD ARE IMPERILED
LEAD: The event is nearly a decade away, but the Greek Government may already have lost what it considers a historic right: the ''Golden Olympiad'' of 1996.


SEA MUSEUM SEEKING FUNDS
LEAD: IN the 19th century, an inspector would sit up on the roof of the Customs House in New London and peer through his spyglass at the busy harbor ''to make sure nobody got away without paying customs,'' said the president of the New London Maritime Society, Lucille Showalter.

LEAD: To the Editor:  When the Environmental Protection Agency and the Surgeon General join hands to argue that the slightest involuntary exposure to tobacco smoke is worse than anything else, except breathing asbestos, are they playing a political game?

LEAD: THE Citizens Legal Defense Fund, approved by the Suffolk County Legislature last year, continues to be controversial even as leaders attempt to set up the nonprofit agency that would contract with the county.

UNLIKELY GAME JOINS ROSTER OF WINTER SPORTS
LEAD: LIGHT snow fell on the D. Fairchild Wheeler municipal golf course in Fairfield, atop the four inches from a previous storm.
It looked like no day for a round of golf.
Not even for a diehard.


RELUCTANTLY, JAPAN IS CONTEMPLATING THE PILL
LEAD: MORE than two decades after the birth control pill launched a sexual revolution in the United States, the Japanese Government is close to officially condoning its use.
Instead of praise, however, the move has met with criticism from feminists and wariness from the public, which is not expected to switch en masse to oral contraception.


BETTING WITH THE ODDS
LEAD: The card-playing enthusiasm of the British aristocracy has added more than one word to the English language.
In the 18th century the third Earl of Sandwich, a diplomat and politician of some notoriety nicknamed Jeremy Twitcher, was unwilling to take time out from his game to eat.
He asked the waiter to bring him some meat between two slices of bread and millions now use his name daily.


PREGNANCY LEAVE FOR WOMEN, AND MEN
LEAD: For women serious about both career and family, life can quickly become a difficult balancing act.
A new Supreme Court decision promises to make the balancing a bit easier.
It allows states to guarantee job-protected leave to pregnant workers.

Dr.
Wallace McPherson Alston, president emeritus of Agnes Scott College in Decatur, Ga., died Wedesday at his home in Lithonia, Ga.

Old Giants Rate The New
LEAD: WHEN the Giants were winning six Eastern Division titles in eight seasons, from 1956 through 1963, their Hall of Fame defensive end, Andy Robustelli, was known as the Pope in the locker room.
To his teammates, the Pope was infallible.
When the Pope spoke, they agreed.
They still do.
When the Pope invited several Giants alumni to a dinner for the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness at ''21'' the other night, they agreed.


Fishing on Thin Ice
LEAD: As the trout and salmon season on inland lakes begins today, officials are warning anglers to beware of thin ice. ''Most of the lakes that are usually frozen and safe by now aren't,'' said John Hall of the Fish and Wildlife Department. ''There are dangerous conditions near the mouth of rivers, near points of land, bridges, and over reefs.


Weinberger Aide to Retire
LEAD: Vice Adm.
Donald S. Jones, the top military aide to Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, will retire March 1 after more than 35 years of active service, the Defense Department said Friday.
Admiral Jones, 58 years old, a native of Madison, Wis., has been Mr.
Weinberger's military assistant since last spring.


2 ESCAPE FROM A U.S. CENTER
LEAD: Two inmates, lowering themselves down bedsheets from a fourth-floor recreation area, escaped yesterday from an Immigration and Naturalization Service detention center in lower Manhattan, immigration officials said.

LEAD: Do as I say, not as I do.
That would seem to be President Reagan's maxim on Medicare for the elderly.

LEAD: TO catch up on the backlog of mail, this week's column is again devoted to readers' questions about common home-repair and maintenance problems.


Salvador State of Siege to Expire
LEAD: A state of siege that had been in effect almost continuously since 1980 has expired after members of the conservative minority in the National Assembly, who are on strike, refused to act on a bill to renew the restrictions.


WORKERS ARRESTED IN HOTEL ARSON
LEAD: A maintenance worker has admitted setting the fatal fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel, apparently because he was angry at the management, Federal and Puerto Rican officials said last week.
Hector Escudero Aponte, who had worked at the San Juan hotel for 10 years, was charged with arson and with separate counts of murder for each of the 96 people who died in the New Year's Eve blaze.


WHEN SALT MUST BE RESTRICTED, THERE ARE TASTY ALTERNATIVES
LEAD: SOME seasonings are roughly interchangeable.
Tarragon can stand in for chervil and, in a pinch so can parsley.
Vinegar instead of lemon is another effective substitution as is black pepper for cayenne.
But no seasoning does exactly the same job of bringing up flavor as salt.
When a diet requires salt to be restricted it becomes a challenge for the cook.


MUSIC: FOSS AND 'MODERNS'
LEAD: LUKAS FOSS, that indefatigable champion of contemporary and American music, brought his customary zeal and a widely diversified program to Cooper Union Friday night as part of the Brooklyn Philharmonic's ''Meet the Moderns'' chamber series.


PREPARING FOR HIGH WATER
LEAD: Residents of Sodus Point, N.Y., near Rochester, on the shore of Lake Ontario building sand-bag walls yesterday.
The United States Army Corps of Engineers predicts that the lake, already unusually high, will rise another two feet or more in the spring. (NYT/Joe Traver)

WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING
LEAD: In his new budget, President Reagan has proposed raising Congressional salaries to $89,500 a year, from $77,500.
The increase will take effect automatically next month unless both houses of Congress vote to block it.


SUZANA AMARAL: HER 'HOUR' HAS COME
LEAD: Suzana Amaral was married at age 20, and in the next 10 years had eight children.
At 37, she entered the University of Sao Paulo film school, and went on to get a master's degree in film at New York University.
She is now 54, and her first full-length theatrical feature, ''The Hour of the Star'' - a film about the troubled life of a young woman in Sao Paulo that the Brazilian director shot in four weeks for $150,000 - opens Wednesday at Film Forum 1, after having won awards at the Berlin, Brasilia, Havana and International Woman's Film Festivals and having been selected as


CORRECTION
LEAD: A caption in last Sunday's Westchester Weekly section accompanying an article about a playwriting contest incorrectly identified two of the judges, Ruis Woertendyke and Norman Kline, whose names were transposed.


DIJON'S CASSIS ENJOYS ANOTHER VOGUE
LEAD: Dijon, which is renowned for its mustard, is also the source for cassis, without which the popular aperitif Kir would be an ordinary glass of wine.
Indeed, the drink has given the black currant juice a certain repute not only in France but also in the United States, where wine has become a popular substitute for hard liquor as a cocktail.


GREATS OF CLASSIC JAZZ IGNITE A REISSUE
LEAD: When Orrin Keepnews and Bill Grauer Jr. compiled ''The Riverside History of Classic Jazz'' in 1956, the overview of jazz was much different than it is from the perspective of 30 years later, and the availability of jazz records for reissue was much more restricted.
To encounter this five-disk set today, newly reissued (Riverside B-005) in an exact reproduction of the original boxed album, including the artwork and a warm, colorful, introductory essay by Charles Edward Smith, a pioneer jazz enthusiast and historian (in that order of preference), is both an encounter with a jazz Rip Van


Quake Jolts Northern Japan
LEAD: A strong earthquake jolted the Pacific coast of northern Japan today, but the police said there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage.
The Central Meteorological Agency said the quake, which struck at about 7 P.M., registered a preliminary 5.5 on the open-ended Richter scale.


FOR AIR TRAVEL, 1986 WAS SAFE, BUT JUST BARELY
LEAD: The numbers for 1986 suggest that the nation's airlines are flying closer than ever to disaster, but by some combination of wit and luck are emerging with an improving safety record.


In Big League Sailing, Pressure Is Intense
LEAD: MENTAL pressure could have at least as much to do with winning the America's Cup as secret keels, new sails or subtle differences in hull design.
It is a matter of who breaks first.
Of the four skippers who reached the finals of the challenger and defender selection series, only one - Dennis Conner of Stars and Stripes, has steered in a cup match before.


LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
LEAD: CABINS AND KINGS ANNIE OAKLEY, Will Rogers, even the Duke of Windsor would have been pleased.
What John H. Meyer calls their ''old hangout'' in Massapequa is being preserved by the local Kiwanis Club.


POSTINGS: 316 for Garden City; New Condos on Old Site
LEAD: The remaining undeveloped segment of one of Garden City's most venerable sites will soon be home to one of Long Island's newest condominium projects.
Construction will start this spring on the Wyndham at Garden City, a $125 million, 316-unit condominium complete with pond, gazebo and health club.
The development will cover the 12.5 acres that form part of the historic 21-acre site of the 100-year-old, Georgian-style Garden City Hotel, which was razed in 1974 and replaced with a new hotel in 1983.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A picture caption on Jan. 4 with an article about Kariba, Zimbabwe, misidentified a herd of animals in a field.
The animals were African buffaloes, which are also known as Cape buffaloes.


ISLAND LIVING, ENGLISH STYLE
LEAD: Barbados, the easternmost island of the Caribbean, combines the beauty of a rocky Atlantic shore on the east and sandy Caribbean beaches on the west.
Between lie miles and miles of sugar plantations with winding roads running like narrow corridors through fields of towering sugar cane.
Though Barbados only gained independence from Britain in 1966, the lower house of its Parliament, the House of Assembly, has been active since 1639.


Cold Wave in Russia Alarms Soviet Chiefs
LEAD: Soviet leaders have expressed alarm at the possible harm to the economy by the exceptionally harsh weather that has gripped the Soviet Union since the start of the year.


ARCHIVES OF BUSINESS: THE DOW IN PERSPECTIVE  TRACING THE UPS AND DOWNS OF THE 20th CENTURY THROUGH THE EYES OF WALL STREET; Despite Quirks, the Dow Stands for the Market
LEAD: PERHAPS no animal is possessed of a shorter memory than the bull who lives on Wall Street.
So it seems useful amid the euphoria over the breaching of the 2,000 barrier on the Dow - and the buying spree of last week - to step back and put a historical perspective on the index's recent climb.


CAGE CENTER: YOUTHS FIGHT FOR A FUTURE
LEAD: WHILE a tall, clean-cut boy of 17 galloped around the ring throwing punches in too-rapid succession for his balance, a rugged 16-year-old hit a heavy bag that hung across the room.


Raiders Of the Sacred Sites
LEAD: As a former Bureau of Land Management ranger, I witnessed firsthand the archeological-site destruction in southern Utah and Colorado documented by Derek Goodwin in ''Raiders of the Sacred Sites'' (Dec. 7).
Artifact collectors are professional and elusive; despite back-country patrols and aircraft surveillance, most of my time was spent reburying the remains of Native Americans scattered across the surface of prehistoric sites.


DANCE: KATHRYN POSIN
LEAD: THE Joyce Theater gave a performance Friday night, but the choreographer of honor seemed conspicuously absent.
The program by the Kathryn Posin Dance Company, the closing group in the Joyce Sampler Series, proceeded from one trivial or poorly thought-out dance to another, performed with an understandable lack of conviction.


ARE BASEBALL PLAYERS ASKING TOO MUCH?
LEAD: The debate is always are players asking for too much?
I would like to know how much income the owners derive from the team.
I know how much each player and the managers of the Steinbrenner Yankees and the Wilpon/Doubleday Mets earn, but how much money did George and Fred make in 1986 on their respective teams?


STRIKES ARE GETTING FEWER BUT LONGER
LEAD: WHIPSAWED by automation, increasingly anti-union managements and a large pool of unemployed people willing to break a strike, many union members are finding that ''givebacks'' - cuts in wages and benefits - have become a fact of life.
One result appears to be fewer but longer strikes.
While the rank and file often regarded concessions as onerous from the start, labor leaders strove mightily to put the best face on them, calling them temporary measures to strengthen companies and, above all, protect jobs.

His immediate predecessor, Vice Adm.

LEAD: THEY stand like sentinels at the southwest corner of Third Avenue and 60th Street - a trio of sleek, smoothly curved black towers with only white back-lighted symbols of a telephone receiver hinting at their purpose.

TALKING: Insurance; Covering Mortgage Payments
LEAD: WHEN a borrower takes out a mortgage loan, the lender customarily offers insurance to cover payment of the outstanding balance in the event of the borrower's death or disability.


Exemption From Rent Regulations
LEAD: To the Editor:  A question was raised in your Q. &amp; A. column on Nov. 16 about creating exempt status on rent-regulated apartments.
The answer stated: ''The only way to rid a building of its rent-regulated status is through a gut-rehabilitation includingnew ceilings, floors, walls, etc.''


EUROPE'S INNOVATIVE RADIO ORCHESTRAS
LEAD: When the BBC Symphony Orchestra made its first tour in 1936, it took along Schoenberg's Orchestral Variations, Op. 31, and played it in the composer's native city of Vienna.
The work caused total mystification for an audience used to Mozart and Schubert, and when the conductor, Adrian Boult, was introduced to the Austrian President after the performance, the President asked, ''Who is this Schoenberg anyway?

Next Week; Who Will Win the Super Bowl, And Why?
LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036.
Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.


PRESERVING AMERICA'S PAST
LEAD: Scarcely a major city in the United States has not been touched, or even transformed, by preservation.
From coast to coast, the impulse to save old buildings - from the gabled house on Main Street, to the Beaux-Arts railroad terminal - has helped to preserve the past, and provide an anchor for our collective memory.


A TALE OF THE HOUSE THAT SACK BUILT
LEAD: When Israel Sack, a Lithuanian immigrant, began selling New England highboys and Philadelphia chairs to Bostonians at the turn of the century, the experience of collecting American antiques was akin to high adventure.
That, in any case, is the way Harold Sack and Max Wilk describe it in ''American Treasure Hunt,'' published recently by Little, Brown and Company ($24.95).


DARED BY THE BUTLER'S DAUGHTER
LEAD: FAMILY LAUNDRY By Dorie Friend. 300 pp.
New York: A Peter Weed Book/ Beaufort Books. $17.95.


PREVENTIVE DETENTION: A CONCEPT GOES ON TRIAL
LEAD: IN one of the more important criminal law disputes of the decade, the Supreme Court will hear arguments Wednesday on the constitutionality of the ''preventive detention'' of allegedly dangerous but unconvicted criminal defendants.
The issue is at the center of the great divide between civil libertarians and advocates of tougher law enforcement.


More Bosses
LEAD: To the Editor:  ''When the Boss Is Unbearable'' (Dec. 28) offers a variety of ''solu tions'' for dealing with ''weak, willful and devious'' bosses.
All of these so-called solutions, be they ''keeping your distance,'' ''apple polishing'' or ''grinning and bearing,'' have one fatal flaw.
All are based on the assumption that an individual worker can and must continue to deal on an individual basis with a monstrous boss.


HARRY DARBY
LEAD: Harry Darby, a Republican political figure in Kansas, died yesterday at the Bethany Medical Center in Kansas City, Kan.
He was 91 years old.

30,000 Hail Penn State
LEAD: This small college town was decked in blue and white today as a crowd estimated at 30,000 by the State Police honored Penn State's national championship football team at a parade through the campus and downtown.
Penn State (12-0) defeated Miami, 14-10, in the Fiesta Bowl Jan. 2 for the title.


COLOMBIA'S PRESS UNITED TO FIGHT DRUGS
LEAD: Colombia's newspapers and radio and television stations, reacting in concert to a surge of drug-related violence, are warning that this country is in danger of falling under the ''total domination'' of narcotics traffickers.

Tarragon can stand in for chervil and, in a pinch so can parsley.
Vinegar instead of lemon is another effective substitution as is black pepper for cayenne.

SECONDARY IMAGES IN VAN GOGH'S LANDSCAPES
LEAD: To the Editor: While Michael Brenson is haunted by the faces in van Gogh's landscapes  [ Jan. 4 ] , I am haunted by many of his statements: First of all, by his contention that ''van Gogh has never been identified with reason.'' I do not know (nor do I care) with what Mr.
Brenson identifies van Gogh, but let him show us, in the three volumes of the painter's collected letters, a single unsound passage or argument.


NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JANUARY 18, 1987
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL 3-19


Fighting Imports
LEAD: To the Editor:  I can't help but think that I have met the enemy - and he is Jerry K. Pearlman of Zenith Electronics Corporation (''Save the Lectures, Give Us Some Help,'' Forum, Dec. 14).
Why shouldn't I be allowed to trade peacefully with any other citizen of the world?
Why shouldn't I be allowed to buy a color TV from Korean, Japanese or


GAMBITLESS VERVE
LEAD: It is unusual for a game to be seriously considered for a brilliancy prize if it does not feature sacrifice of material.
One may surmise that, if a player ingeniously maneuvers to obtain a clearly better position and presses the attack relentlessly and with great style, the judges still feel he is not venturing anything and hence is not making the supreme prize effort.


OPERA: 'ATYS', BY LULLY, IN PARIS
LEAD: Jean-Baptiste Lully was the great operatic composer of the high French Baroque, the man who defined French opera in the age of Louis XIV.
His works are rarely heard today, but that omission may be ending now that the French early-music movement has grown so confident and accomplished.
Friday night at the Salle Favart, the Paris Opera presented Lully's ''Atys'' for the first time since 1760, when Lully's works were swept aside in the enthusiasm for the new music of Rameau and then Gluck.


Learning On the Job
LEAD: Having worked as a newspaper reporter, wire-service foreign correspondent, magazine editor and publisher for more than 50 years, I found myself in complete agreement with A. M. Rosenthal's articulate defense of the First Amendment (''Learning on the Job,'' Dec. 14).
It would be a better world if the freedom to write and the freedom to think were universal.


JEWISH GROUP ACCEPTS NEW EXPORTS TO SOVIET
LEAD: An American advocacy group on Soviet Jewry has told the Government that it will not contest the decision on Thursday to allow exports of gas and oil technology to the Soviet Union.


Holiday Tomorrow
LEAD: The birthday of the Rev.
Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr., actually Jan. 15, will be observed tomorrow in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
Following are holiday schedules:
Parking - Alternate-side rules suspended.
Sanitation - Regular collections.
Governmental offices - Closed.
Post offices - Closed; special delivery and express-mail delivery only.

Finding Tax Shelter in a Second Home
LEAD: FOR the thousands of individuals who own second homes, 1987 will mark a key turning point for tax benefits.
People who rent out their vacation houses must decide whether to begin using the home as a second residence, so they can deduct the mortgage interest, or whether to continue renting so they can claim a loss on the business venture.

ARE BASEBALL PLAYERS ASKING TOO MUCH?
LEAD: I am in the minority who believe that baseball players are not asking too much.
First of all, for most of the game's history, ballplayers were virtual slaves of the owners.
Secondly, ballplayers are entertainers just as actors are.
Yet there is no outcry when stars receive millions of dollars for cameo roles in films, even though those fees help push up the cost of our ticket prices.

Fuming
LEAD: To the Editor:  While the gathering of evidence regarding the effects of passive smoking on the non-smoker may eventually put an end to this controversy, there is already a Federal law that should be used to eliminate smoking in public places - the one insuring equal access to public places for handicapped people.

THE BARBARISM OF THE STEEL-JAW TRAP
LEAD: THE Suffolk County Legislature recently voted for a bill to ban the use of steel-jaw traps to capture animals.
I was amazed to read that this is the first ban of these in this state, as I would have thought that these barbaric and cruel traps would have been banned long ago, particularly in the suburbs where the population is increasing and the habitat of small wild animals is rapidly dwindling.

THE ROOF OF THE WORLD BY BUS, CAR AND FOOT
LEAD: Benares, India's ancient holy city astride the Ganges, houses the only temple built by Mohandas K. Gandhi.
It has neither Sivas nor Gneshes, only a huge relief model of India.
Gandhi included Tibet in his vision of a unified India.
Mao Zedong disagreed.

LEAD: MARRIED couples have many joyous firsts among their mementos to look back upon with fondness as they travel through life together.
The first kiss, first argument, first child, first home, etc., are events that are rife with vivid memories.
But there are others that somehow become memorable although the occurrences in themselves are not usually associated with unforgettable times.

Question Box
LEAD: QUESTION: Let's say the Yankees and Red Sox are playing in an inning with none out, a Boston player perched on each base and Wade Boggs at bat.
On a 3-2 pitch, all three runners begin advancing, confident that Boggs will make contact and most likely hit the ball on the ground.
Instead, Boggs laces a low liner past the pitcher's mound that strikes the umpire standing behind the mound and ricochets off his left shoe to Willie Randolph, the second baseman, who catches the ball before it hits the ground.


Mexico Gives OPEC a Symbolic Lift
LEAD: Mexico will support the effort of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to reduce world crude oil surpluses and force oil prices higher by cutting its own oil exports.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: Skiing A First for Gaspoz: Joel Gaspoz of Switzerland won his first World Cup slalom yesterday with a skillful performance on the steep Lauberhorn course in Wengen, Switzerland.
The 24-year-old Swiss was timed for the two heats in 1 minute 36.86 seconds.
Dietmar Koehlbichler of Austria finished second in 1:37.40, giving an unexpected lift to the Austrian team, which has been lackluster this season.

LEAD: Too little and six years late, the Reagan Administration has finally come to appreciate the importance of the International Development Association.

The Administration stopped its growth in 1981.

LEAD: Wild and crazy.
Earvin Johnson liked the sound of the words.
They still fit.
They still made him laugh aloud when he said them, because even now - in the eighth winter of his wondrous professional career - he remains an unpredictable sort, an artist with a touch of magic.
The thought was appropriate.

WHAT BECOMES A LEGEND MOST?
LEAD: That fun couple of rodentdom - we're speaking here, of course, about Mickey and Minnie Mouse - are nothing if not enduring.
Besides their notable career in films, the pair have appeared in countless children's books and on the face of watches that are often worn by grown-up children.
Mr.
Mouse also serves as guest host at huge amusement parks in California and Florida and for several years, about a generation ago, had his own club on television (he was the leader of the band that's made for you and me).


DROP-INS: VISITORS OR INVADERS?
LEAD: KAREN MARCING, a Chicago purchasing agent, planned to spend a recent evening working on an oil painting, but she never had a chance to pursue her hobby because an old friend stopped by.


High Costs, Low Prices Seen Ahead for USX
LEAD: To relight its furnaces, the USX Corporation, which has reached a tentative contract settlement with the United Steelworkers of America to end a six-month work stoppage, will sustain a large cash drain, industry analysts predicted yesterday.

LEAD: IT has nothing to do with his generous waistline, but Bill Parcells seems to be two people.

The other is the little boy who grew up five minutes from where Giants Stadium would be built, dreamed of coaching the

LEAD: BETWEEN phone calls last week, George Young was munching on a turkey sandwich in his Giants Stadium office when Bill Parcells appeared in the doorway.

LEAD: The decision late last week by MCA Inc. to take a $50 million pretax charge against fourth-quarter earnings underscores the problems faced by the once-booming television syndication industry, according to analysts and other industry experts.

Crime, Race, Prejudice, Fear
LEAD: In the aftermath of the Howard Beach incident, we must restate certain truths about the evil of racism, the need for racial tolerance and the importance of the fight against discrimination.
But we will not advance racial understanding unless we also attempt to come to grips with the fear of crime in general and white fear of black crime in particular.

LEAD: The police, firefighters and immigration officials quelled what one official called ''a small disturbance'' yesterday involving Cuban inmates at the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service detention center in lower Manhattan, where two prisoners had escaped a day earlier.

LEAD: IT might be that Michael Weiss, 25-year-old entrepreneur, has struck upon a winning idea for a campus publication: Make national campus ''celebrities'' out of certain students.


Atom Plant Is Unable to Say What Happened to Uranium
LEAD: Officials at the idled Browns Ferry nuclear power plant have been unable to account for 27 milligrams of uranium in a recent inventory, the second such loss since October, according to a plant spokesman.

LEAD: Under heavy military protection, President Corazon C. Aquino flew briefly today to this city, which for the last week has been the center of the heaviest Moslem fighting in years.

Knight Meets With Orioles
LEAD: Ray Knight and his agent, George Kalafatis, met with Hank Peters, general manager of the Baltimore Orioles, for about two hours yesterday.
The Orioles need a third baseman and offered Knight a one-year contract for about $425,000.
Knight, who rejected the Mets' $800,000 offer last month, asked for two years, and they discussed the possibility of a second year that would be triggered by the number of games Knight started.


Stonewalling by Any Other Name
LEAD: Debate over the Iran-contra affair has turned down a blind alley: Should President Reagan apologize or not?
Almost daily, some responsible legislator or another calls for the President to acknowledge his errors, as if a little contrition would cleanse the deeds and put the matter to rest.
It won't.


WELLINGTON IN CALIFORNIA
LEAD: Football players are notorious for putting on their ''game face'' but Wellington Mara puts on his ''practice hat.''


Classes at S.I. School Canceled After Fire
LEAD: A fire set by vandals at a Staten Island high school has forced the cancellation of classes today, the city's Board of Education reported yesterday.


AN OIL CITY STUMBLES; IS ITS FUTURE IN THE JUNGLE?
LEAD: Balikpapan, strung out along a coastal road facing the Makassar Strait on the eastern shore of Borneo, has always been an oil town.
At night, the lights of cafes and shops are mirrored offshore by the beacons and flares of drilling rigs.


ORR IS IMPROBABLE HERO WITH HIS SHOT AT BUZZER
LEAD: After Gerald Henderson, Bill Cartwright and Gerald Wilkins carried the Knicks to the brink of their rout of the Boston Celtics, and after Larry Bird brought the defending champions to the verge of a comeback, it was Louis Orr who left his team laughing.


HAWAII'S IMPOSING VOLCANOES: STILL POWERFUL BUT LESS DEADLY
LEAD: ''Landslides were numerous and precipices fell thundering into the sea.
The earth rent in a thousand places; fissures opened from one inch to six, eight and ten as unexpected breadth.
The streets and fields of Hilo cracked, and seams opened all around us, where we had supposed that volcanic forces had long ago left their final traces.


BROODING IDOLS EVOKE AN ANCIENT NICARAGUA
LEAD: A collection of massive stone idols carved by Indians as long as 1,000 years ago has quietly gone on display in this stately colonial town.

LEAD: The Export-Import Bank, preparing for a surge of exports from the cheaper dollar, will announce lower fees, simplified paperwork and broader loan guarantees Tuesday under revamped programs for exporters.

LEAD: Responding to market rumors that touched off a sharp rise in the price of its stock, Home Shopping Network Inc., the television retailer, disclosed yesterday on the advice of its lawyers that it was discussing two possible acquisitions.

SHV Cuts Pretoria Tie
LEAD: SHV, a Dutch-based multinational company plagued by anti-apartheid arson attacks in the Netherlands, announced today that it would halt business operations in South Africa.
SHV, which owns a 40 percent interest in five Makro department stores in South Africa and has a coal trading office in Johannesburg, is the first major Dutch company to pull out of South Africa.

CHEMICAL CARD RATE CUT
LEAD: The Chemical Bank is reducing the interest it charges on some credit cards, it said yesterday.
Starting Feb. 1, the rate on Visa and Mastercard balances linked to a Chemplus account will be 16.8 percent, down from 19.5 or 19.8 percent now, depending on the card holder's home state.
The rate cut also applies to all Gold Mastercard customers, Chemical said.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article on Saturday about air safety proposals after a collision near Salt Lake City referred incorrectly to a plane involved in a 1984 collision near San Luis Obispo, Calif.
The private plane that collided with a Wings West commuter airliner in that accident was a single-engine piston-powered Rockwell Commander, not a jet.


TEXAS PRISONS RESUME ACCEPTANCE OF INMATES
LEAD: The Texas prison system began accepting new convicts today after weekend paroles cut the prisoner population below a mandated ceiling designed to avoid overcrowding.

LEAD: The Nicaraguan Embassy here said today that Ambassador Carlos Tunnerman would ask the United States to investigate the assault in Miami on Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo, the Roman Catholic Primate of Nicaragua.


'CONSERVATIVES' STUDIES HISTORY OF A MOVEMENT
LEAD: HOW did conservatives come to loom so large on the political landscape?
By persevering, ''The Conservatives'' says; out of obscurity and a certain amount of scorn, conservatives came to inherit, if not the earth, at least a large piece of the Republican Party.
The knowledgeable documentary, on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight, traces the history of a movement.

LEAD: IT will be the best of computers; it will be the worst of computers.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in The Living Section on Jan. 7 about Myrtle Allen, co-owner of Ballymaloe House in Ireland, misstated the tax rate for Irish restaurant bills.
It is 10 percent.


Bonn to Sell VEBA Stake
LEAD: The West German Government, confident of support for its economic policies just a week before a general election, announced today that it would sell off its 25.6 percent stake in the giant industrial group VEBA in March.
The state hopes to receive about 3 billion marks, or $1.7 billion, from the sale to the public of its holding in VEBA, an energy and chemicals company.

LEAD: A third ferry line between New Jersey and Manhattan began yesterday.

LEAD: About 2,800 nonteaching employees at Rutgers University walked off the job today, disrupting the first day of spring classes for about 48,500 students on three campuses.

VERSATILITY IN A WRAP HANDMADE IN KENYA
LEAD: ''I don't want to tell Americans how to wear these things - I want them to tell me.''


The Taking of Ecuador's President
LEAD: These have not been democracy's finest days in Ecuador.
Last Friday air force commandos seized President Leon Febres Cordero at gunpoint, holding him until he secured the release of an air force general imprisoned for attempted coup-making.
Now the newly released President is threatened with impeachment for infractions against the Constitution and the national honor.


CONTRA ARMS CREWS SAID TO SMUGGLE DRUGS
LEAD: Federal drug investigators uncovered evidence last fall that the American flight crews covertly ferrying arms to the Nicaraguan rebels were smuggling cocaine and other drugs on their return trips to the United States, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: Moving into the mainframe computer arena, the Digital Equipment Corporation will announce today a $2.5 million system that links four of its most powerful VAX computers into one, giving it the speed of some of I.B.M.'s largest systems.

CONCERT: THE VIENNA OCTET
LEAD: COLLECTORS will remember the original Vienna Octet, an ensemble that made several splendid disks for London in the 1950's.
A younger group assumed the name in 1973, and the new Vienna Octet's recital on Sunday afternoon at Town Hall offered eloquent proof that the tradition lives on.

LEAD: When the afternoon was over, Magic Johnson talked mostly about the third period, about how he had simply decided that the game would be won or lost at that point, that he might have to place the burden of the offense on his own shoulders.


Toyota, Nissan See Export Fall
LEAD: The Toyota Motor Corporation and the Nissan Motor Company, Japan's largest car makers, said today that their exports fell in 1986 because of the Japanese yen's rise against the United States dollar, which made Japanese cars more expensive abroad.


IMMIGRATION RULES TO ASK NEW PROOF FROM JOB SEEKERS
LEAD: Employers across the country will have to verify the citizenship status of all new employees, Americans and aliens, within 24 hours after they are hired, under rules drawn up by the Immigration and Naturalization Service.


Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q. Will an alcoholic drink keep you warm in cold weather?
A.Alcohol dilates the blood vessels, which causes a brief sensation of warmth as the blood rushes to the skin, according to Dr.
Roger Maickel, professor of pharmocology at Purdue University.
This effect causes many people to flush when they drink.


White Man Attacked By Brooklyn Blacks
LEAD: A white man who was walking on a street in Brooklyn with two black women was beaten late Sunday by a group of young black men who said, ''You don't belong here,'' the police said yesterday.
They called the attack racially motivated.

Steel Output Up 3.3%
LEAD: Steel production rose to 1.36 million tons in the week ended Saturday, an increase of 3.3 percent from the previous week's 1.316 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 59.5 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 57.5 percent in the previous week.

SPAIN TELEPHONE STOCK
LEAD: Telefonica, Spain's telephone company, plans to place its shares on the New York Stock Exchange next June.
A company spokesman, Alberto Martinez, said there would be 45 million shares valued at about $300 million and representing 5 percent of the company's capital.
Foreign ownership in Telefonica is limited to 25 percent.

DANCE: FROM CITY BALLET, BALANCHINE'S 'EPISODES'
LEAD: THE New York City Ballet offered George Balanchine's ''Episodes'' for the first time this season Sunday night at the New York State Theater. ''Episodes'' is just what its name implies: a series of choreographic sketches to brief orchestral pieces by the 20th-century composer Anton von Webern.
Yet, though none of the ballet's scenes last long, all are rich in implication.


IN WINTER, THOUGHTS OF SUMMER
LEAD: ''It's my favorite season of the year,'' said Donna Karan, speaking of summer. ''In the middle of winter, I'm always thinking about warm weather.''


HART, 'THE LOCAL BOY,' BEGINS RACE IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
LEAD: When the man with the square jaw and blue blazer sauntered into the city garage shortly after 7 A.M. today, the plow operators and the truckers all knew who he was.
A lot of them had met him before and many had even voted for him once.


VOLCANIC SCENARIO
LEAD: LAST August a flood of water mixed with toxic gases overflowed Lake Nyos in the Cameroon and swept into the valleys below, leaving more than 1,700 people dead and destroying crops.
British scientists who have examined the lake have now come up with a probable scenario of how volcanic gases caused the disaster.

8 PHILANTHROPIES ARE WINNERS OF FORD FOUNDATTION GRANTS
LEAD: With a $500,000 grant from the Ford Foundation, a community foundation in Florida says, it hopes to forge a coalition among the ethnic populations in the Miami area.


Cocoa Rules Discussed
LEAD: Cocoa-trading nations decided unanimously today to bring into force on Tuesday a new agreement to stabilize prices, said Kelvin Scott, spokesman for the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development.
Delegates said the accord, negotiated last July to defend minimum and maximum prices for cocoa, would not operate immediately, as rules for intervention in the market had not yet been settled.

1,000 CHINESE IN U.S. ENDORSE A PROTEST
LEAD: As many as a thousand Chinese nationals studying in American colleges and universities have now endorsed an open letter to the leadership in Beijing voicing concern over the removal of Hu Yaobang as the Communist Party leader and the disciplining of Chinese intellectuals.

LEAD: Negotiators for the Long Island Rail Road and 11 unions met yesterday for the first time since the line was struck, but any optimism about an early end to the walkout soon faded.

Mellon Net Drops 65.3%
LEAD: The Mellon Bank Corporation yesterday reported a 65.3 percent drop in fourth-quarter net income, to $15.6 million, from $45 million in the corresponding 1985 quarter.
On a per-share basis, net income fell to 42 cents, from $1.57.


INTERIOR DEPARTMENT WEIGHS BID TO PRESS A MINERALS PROGRAM
LEAD: The Interior Department is considering a new policy statement that would explicitly make one of its key agencies an advocate for minerals development.


INDIA HOPES TO SPEED VERDICT ON BHOPAL
LEAD: The Indian Government, bolstered by a recent decision by the nation's highest court on a chemical leak in New Delhi, has adopted a novel legal strategy that lawyers say could force an early verdict against the Union Carbide Corporation in the lawsuit over the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster.

SHELLING BY IRANIANS CAUSING MANY TO FLEE BASRA
LEAD: The relentless Iranian shelling of the southern Iraqi port city of Basra has led to the exodus of much of its population of one million, the first time that so many of its people are said to have fled, according to American officials, military analysts and diplomats closely following the war.

LEAD: These are the positions of unions and management on some major issues in the Long Island Rail Road labor dispute, as detailed in a document provided by the railroad:


CABARET: RETTADEL TUPPER
LEAD: RETTADEL TUPPER, a veteran pop singer and dancer who once worked with Ray Eberle's band, returned to public performance after 25 years at a Greenwich Village club.
This past weekend, she concluded a two-weekend engagement at a supper club, Ristorante Eleonora, where she was accompanied by a piano-bass duo.


Ciba-Geigy Plans Venture in China
LEAD: Ciba-Geigy A.G., Switzerland's biggest chemical and pharmaceuticals company, said it plans to begin production in China in 1989 with a large local manufacturer, the Beijing General Pharmaceuticals Corporation.
The initial capital investment for the venture will be the equivalent of $12 million at current exchange rates, according to a Ciba


TOP STRATEGISTS HEDGING BETS
LEAD: These are times that try even the most firmly anchored stock market strategies.
An air of unreality pervades the giddy rises of the last two weeks, leaving professional strategists delighted, but flinching at the thought that just at the moment they throw caution to the wind the market could dive.

Budd Plans Kentucky Plant
LEAD: The Budd Company, one of the nation's largest automotive suppliers, said it would build a $100 million plant here that would employ as many as 400 people.
Construction on the 75-acre site will begin this spring and is scheduled for completion in early 1988.
The plant will be used to stamp and assemble such components as hoods, fenders, quarter panels and doors.


SAN JUAN BARTENDER A SUICIDE
LEAD: A bartender at the Dupont Plaza Hotel committed suicide Saturday, three days before he was to be questioned about the New Year's Eve fire at the hotel that killed 96 people.
However, he was not listed as a suspect, an official said today.

BETTORS GET INTO ACTION
LEAD: The Giants had their first practice of the week today for Super Bowl XXI.
The Denver Broncos are scheduled to begin their workouts Wednesday.


The Visibility Was . . . Well, Invisible
LEAD: A passenger on board the Staten Island ferry yesterday during a day dominated by freezing rain, snow and sleet and various other forms of precipitation in the metropolitan area.
A respite is expected today, with sunny skies and a high in the mid-30's. (NYT/Chester Higgins Jr.)


Airborne Pollutants
LEAD: Twice as much airborne pollution is deposited above 3,000 feet in the Appalachian Mountains as in lowland areas, two Yale University geochemists have found.
Dr.
William C. Graustein, an associate research scientist, and Dr.
Karl K. Turekian, chairman of geology and geophysics, also found that 40 percent to 60 percent of the pollutants came from the lowest layer of the atmosphere and were, therefore, more likely to be deposited within 50 miles to 100 miles of where they originated.


CUOMO BUDGET IS EXPECTED TO CALL FOR 2 NEW PRISONS
LEAD: Governor Cuomo will propose building two new state prisons, to accommodate a total of 1,400 inmates, in the budget plan he will present Tuesday, law-enforcement officials said today.
