JUDGE SUGGESTS RACISM IS MOTIVATING INQUIRY
LEAD: Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings of Miami, who is facing possible impeachment charges, has filed a report in Congress suggesting that his critics on the bench were motivated by racism.


Cotton and Cocoa Soar; Livestock Prices Down
LEAD: Affected by the sharp drop of the dollar, cotton futures rose yesterday by the daily limit.
In other markets, cocoa was sharply higher, livestock declined steeply and energy prices were lower.


Spencer Charged With Murder
LEAD: Brian Spencer, who played for the Islanders in the 1970's, was arrested in West Palm Beach, Fla., yesterday and charged with murder and kidnapping in the death of a man five years ago.
Spencer, 37 years old, was charged with the murder of Michael James Dalfo, who was found on a roadway on Feb. 4, 1982.


Advertising; Publisher Set at Time Magazine
LEAD: REGINALD BRACK JR., the new chief of the Time Inc. magazine operation, announced further changes in the operation yesterday.
The most important shifts are the naming of Richard B. Thomas to the new position of top advertising sales executive in the group and Robert L. Miller to replace him as publisher of


Bridge: Knockout Final at Regional Reverses Last Year's Result
LEAD: The final of the Tri-State Regional Knockout Team Championship played Saturday in Port Chester, N.Y., proved to be a rematch of the 1986 event, but with a different result.

Working Oil Rigs Drop
LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States dropped this week to 886, down 30 from last week, officials of the Hughes Tool Company said today.
Last week's rig count of 916 was down 46 from the previous week. ''This is a period of seasonal decline,'' Ike Kerridge, keeper of the rig count, said.

LEAD: More than 14.7 million shares of Compagnie Financiere de Paribas, the state-owned financial and banking group, went on sale in France today.

MATTINGLY SEEKING $1.97 MILLION PACT
LEAD: Don Mattingly, generally recognized by baseball people as the best player in the game, surprised a lot of baseball people yesterday by submitting a figure of less than $2 million for salary arbitration.
Dwight Gooden surprised the Mets by handing in a salary nearly $500,000 greater than their figure.


U.S. MIGHT SEEK CONSECUTIVE TERMS IN HIJACKING
LEAD: A senior Justice Department official said today that the department might seek consecutive prison sentences for a Lebanese man accused of hijacking an American jetliner in 1985 and killing an American passenger.


Defense in Gotti Trial To Start This Morning
LEAD: After nearly four months of testimony from prosecution witnesses, the defense is to begin presenting its side this morning in the Federal racketeering trial of John Gotti and six co-defendants.

FRIGID TEMPERATURES LESSEN IN EUROPE:
LEAD: Fishermen clearing ice from around their cutter at mouth of the Elbe River in Friedrichskoog, near Ham-burg, West Germany.
The cold wave has claimed more than 300 lives in Europe, but temperatures have moderated in Britain and some parts of the Continent. (AP)


EXCERPTS FROM REGULATIONS TO CARRY OUT NEW LAW ON ALIENS
LEAD: Following are excerpts from Part 274A and Section 245A.1 of regulations drafted by the Immigration and Naturalization Service to carry out the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986.
Part 274A deals with aliens' eligibility for legal employment.
Section 245A.1 concerns the establishment of legal residency by aliens who have been in the United States since Jan.


MOTIVATIONS OF SURROGATE MOTHERS
LEAD: WOMEN who choose to become surrogate mothers have motivations ranging from selflessness to egocentricity, from guilt to joy, according to the handful of researchers who have studied them.


Credit Market Trading Slow
LEAD: The Treasury market was closed yesterday for the holiday honoring the Rev.
Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr., leading to very light activity in other sectors of the credit markets.


Trial's Site Ordered Changed In Killing of a Drug Witness
LEAD: A state district judge ordered the trial of three Colombian nationals accused of killing a key government drug prosecution witness moved to another city after a futile week of jury selection.

LEAD: William R. Hewlett, who founded the Hewlett-Packard Company with David Packard in 1939, will retire as vice chairman effective Feb. 24, the company said yesterday.
Mr.

JAPAN MINISTER RUSHING TO U.S. ON DOLLAR'S FALL
LEAD: At the end of a day when the dollar plunged again, the Treasury Department said tonight that Japan's Finance Minister would fly to Washington to meet with Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d on Wednesday.


Broadway Gets 'Coastal Disturbances'
LEAD: The Circle in the Square Theater announced yesterday that it will present the Second Stage production of ''Coastal Disturbances,'' beginning Feb. 14.


2 Researchers Share Prize in Medicine
LEAD: Prof.
Pedro Cuatrecasas, an American biochemist, and Prof.
Meir Wilchek of the Weizmann Institute in Israel have been awarded the Wolf Prize for medicine, the prize foundation announced today.


Harrah Retires as Player
LEAD: Toby Harrah, a three-time American League all-star, announced his retirement as a player yesterday and said he would manage the Texas Rangers' rookie league farm club.
The 38-year-old Harrah, who played the last two years with the Rangers, will manage the Gulf Coast Rangers, a Gulf Coast League team that will play at Port Charlotte, Fla.


LONG WAIT ENDS FOR BILL ARD'S FATHER
LEAD: From this week forward, no one will be able to laugh at the sense of timing of Bill Ard Sr., a Giant fan and the president of a real-estate appraisal firm in northern New Jersey.
His loyalty has taken the form of a season ticket since 1964, when the last of the reserved bleacher seats at Yankee Stadium were sold on a season basis.


IRANIAN WARSHIPS NOW USING MISSILES FOR NIGHT ATTACKS
LEAD: Iranian warships in the Persian Gulf are using Italian-made Sea Killer missiles against oil tankers in night attacks for the first time, according to United States intelligence officials.


How to Avoid a Rail Strike
LEAD: As Long Island Rail Road commuters struggle to find other ways to get to work, let Congress heed the lesson of a strike that takes the public hostage: The L.I.R.R. labor negotiations ought to be governed by local, not Federal rules.

Paul Kalmanovitz, 81; Owned Pabst Brewing
LEAD: Paul Kalmanovitz, owner of the Pabst Brewing Company and several other breweries and a prominent figure in the beer industry for more than 40 years, died at his home here Saturday after a long illness. day.
He was 81 years old.

LEAD: Greg Foster's time for the 60-meter high hurdles in the Sunkist Invitational, at first announced as a world indoor record, will not be submitted for recognition because of a false start.

LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee drafting convention against recruitment, use, financing and training of mercenaries - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.


DOLLAR'S PLUNGE UNCHECKED
LEAD: The dollar was battered again yesterday in foreign-exchange markets, closing well below Friday's levels in spite of new signs that West Germany and Japan might be about to cut their interest rates.


'SQUARE ONE' TO TEACH MATH TO VIDEO-LITERATE
LEAD: Graduates of ''Sesame Street'' will soon have a television show all their own.
On Monday, the Children's Television Workshop, which introduced Big Bird and Kermit to preschoolers 18 years ago, will unveil its newest project, ''Square One,'' aimed at 8- to 12-year-olds.
The show will be broadcast on most local public television stations on weekday afternoons.


OTHER OBSERVANCES ACROSS NATION
LEAD: As many as 15,000 people braved freezing weather in Phoenix yesterday to march on the Arizona Legislature with petitions demanding that lawmakers establish a state holiday honoring Dr.
King.

LEAD: Everybody, a nice round of applause for John Cardinal O'Connor and the Israeli leaders.
Between them they managed recently to destroy two old stereotypes about people and that of course is always healthy.

BRITISH TO SUPPLY NATO SATELLITES
LEAD: British Aerospace P.L.C. and Marconi have won a $136 million contract to supply two military communications satellites to NATO, The Financial Times has reported.
The first of the satellites, known as the NATO-4 series, is to be launched in 1990 aboard the United States space shuttle, the paper said.


RACIAL VIOLENCE A FOCUS AS DR. KING IS HONORED
LEAD: Marches in a frigid rain, solemn memorial services in houses of worship, cultural programs and speeches against racial violence yesterday culminated the observance in the New York metropolitan region of the holiday that marks the birthday of the Rev.
Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr.
A common thread running through most of the observances was the attack last month on three black men by white youths in Howard Beach, Queens.

Talking Businesswith Rep. Schroeder of Colorado; 'Family Rights' For Employees
LEAD: Last week the United States Supreme Court ruled that states could require employers to grant job protection to workers disabled by pregnancy.
It was a ruling of major importance and has been hailed by women and labor groups as a big step toward protecting ''family rights.''


G.O.P. TO PRESS CUOMO ON TAX CUTS
LEAD: New York State Republicans plan to push for larger tax cuts this year than Governor Cuomo has proposed, partly to keep him occupied with state matters as he is making critical decisions on a possible Presidential candidacy.


Mets Name Minors Managers
LEAD: Butch Hobson, a former third baseman with the Yankees, and John Tamargo have been named minor league managers for the Mets.
Hobson was named manager at Columbia of the South Atlantic League.
Tamargo, who played for the St.
Louis Cardinals and Montreal Expos, was named manager of Lynchburg of the Carolina League.


Who's Who at Bargaining Table

McIver  President, Long Island Rail Road  Born in Great Falls, Mont. . . . 46 years old . . . married, father of five children, appointed president of the railroad in 1985 . . . was chief labor negotiator for the City of New York from 1979 to 1983 . . . held the same post with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority from 1983 to 1985 .

Champion's Net Rises 69.3%
LEAD: The Champion International Corporation said today that its fourth-quarter profit rose 69.3 percent from a year earlier despite an 8.3 percent drop in sales.
The manufacturer of papers, newsprint and other wood products attributed the earnings gain to improved business conditions and internal cost-cutting.

The Lugar Lesson and the Aspin Appeal
LEAD: Politicians tell much about themselves by whom they choose to lead them.
In the Senate, Republicans have rejected Jesse Helms, a rock of the right, and retained Richard Lugar, an experienced moderate, as their senior member of the Foreign Relations Committee.
But in the House Les Aspin has been deposed, at least for the moment, as chairman of the Armed Services Committee because some


RECITAL: LUCILLE FIELD, SINGER
LEAD: THE soprano Lucille Field chose a program of unusual interest for her Saturday evening recital at Merkin Concert Hall.
Entitled ''Songs: With Women in Mind,'' the program contained not only repertory classics such as Beethoven's ''Adelaide,'' Schubert's ''Lied der Mignon'' and Richard Strauss's ''Cacilie'' but also several songs by Josephine Lang, a German composer of the 19th century who studied with Felix Mendelssohn, and recent works by Nancy Van de Vate, Robert Starer, Miriam Gideon and Patsy


NOTES ON FASHION
LEAD: ''I HAVE a last name, but I'm not going to use it until I'm 21,'' said 20-year-old Walter S., who got into fashion at age 13 as a Seventh Avenue sketch artist.
Three years later, he began publishing a photocopied fashion magazine, Key, which led to his becoming a fashion stylist and a feisty fashion columnist, taking swipes at Seventh Avenue in New York Talk.


Acquisitions In Software Up
LEAD: The computer software and services industry held onto its reputation for hot financial activity in 1986 as the number of mergers and acquisitions rose 50 percent, a survey released yesterday says.


Bucks Sign Webster
LEAD: The Milwaukee Bucks yesterday signed the veteran 7-foot-1-inch center, Marvin Webster, to a 10-day contract.
The 34-year-old Webster had been playing with Pensacola in the Continental Basketball Association, where he was averaging 11 points a game.
If Milwaukee decides to sign Webster to a standard National Basketball Association contract for the rest of the season, it would have to reach an agreement with the Knicks, Webster's last N.B.A.

Hot-Dogs and Robbery
LEAD: A 37-year-old man was charged with holding up a savings and loan institution using a package of hot-dogs as a ruse.
The police said the suspect, Murshin A. Rahman, told a bank teller at a branch of the Broadview Savings and Loan Saturday that his briefcase contained a bomb.
The teller gave him about $2,400.


K-Car Package Set by Chrysler
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation has an America version of its K-cars waiting in case the American Motors Corporation does not reach an agreement with labor that would let it build Chrysler's Omni and Horizon models, the Automotive News has reported.
Members of the United Automobile Workers at A.M.C.'s Kenosha, Wis., plant on Saturday refused to reopen their contract to negotiate changes that A.M.C.

Goodyear's Shares Top Tender Offer
LEAD: Shareholders of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company tendered more than 85.2 million shares under the company's offer to buy back up to 40 million common shares at $50 each, Goodyear said.
The tender offer expired at midnight Friday, and because the number of shares tendered exceeded the buyback offer, some shares will not be accepted.

The Ordeal of Maputo
LEAD: A senior Mozambican official answered the general question about his country's direction with a wry smile. ''What you in the West used to say about us was never quite right, and what you're saying now isn't quite right either,'' he said.


BARYSHNIKOV IS INVITED BY BOLSHOI TO DANCE AGAIN IN SOVIET UNION
LEAD: Mikhail Baryshnikov, the Russian ballet star whose defection in 1974 stunned the dance world, has been invited to return to the Soviet Union to dance as a guest at the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow, the artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet said here yesterday.

LED F.B.I. OFFICE IN NEW YORK
LEAD: John F. Malone, head of the regional F.B.I. office in New York from 1962 to 1975, died of a stroke last Thursday at St.
Joseph's Hospital in Carbondale, Pa.
He was 76 years old and had lived in Carbondale since his retirement in 1975.


MARKET LURING SMALL BUYERS
LEAD: The small investor is coming back.
Tempted by a bull market streak that is verging on a new record, Wall Street's retail customers are stepping out on their own to buy stocks at a faster clip than they have for several years.

Talk of the Ivies
LEAD: Who is the most versatile basketball player in the Ivy League?
Here's a vote for Guido Casparis, Columbia's center, a freshman from Switzerland who is fluent in English, Italian, German and French, and is now studying Russian.
His most difficult language? ''American slang,'' he says. ''Like, if you 'dog it,' you don't play hard enough, but a 'hot dog' is a show-off.


APPLE BRANDY: HARD CIDER TRANSFIGURED
LEAD: AS president of the oldest American company producing aged apple brandy, Larrie Laird of Laird &amp; Company in Scobeyville, N.J., must take the long view of apples.
His fruit must withstand the rigors of fermentation, distillation and seven and a half years of aging.
When the essence of those apples is poured into a snifter in the 1990's, it must prove itself worthy of being savored like Cognac or like apple brandy's French counterpart, the Calvados produced in


OFFICIALS IN NEW YORK CITY FAULT CUOMO'S BUDGET PLAN
LEAD: New York City is to receive an 11.5 percent increase in state assistance in Governor Cuomo's proposed 1987-88 state budget, administration officials said today.
But city officials said the plan rejected several key concerns, and was not likely to offset cuts in Federal municipal aid.

LEAD: The Philadelphia Phillies will confer Friday with a representative of Lance Parrish to determine if the club is interested in signing the free-agent catcher.

A Funny Little Jugf
LEAD: 1. Syrup With a Smile


A's to Sign Blue
LEAD: Vida Blue, who broke into the major leagues with the A's in 1969, is returning to Oakland.
The signing of the 37-year-old pitcher, who became a free agent after going 10-10 with the San Francisco Giants last season, will be formally announced today, a spokesman for the A's said.
Another former A's star, Reggie Jackson, has also rejoined the team for next season.

TICKET FOR COMMUTERS: RADIOS, CARDS AND PATIENCE
LEAD: Thousands of Long Island commuters rose before dawn today, packed into cars and buses, crowded through tunnels and over bridges and somehow or other, sooner or later, got themselves to work.


COLLECTIONS CONNOISSEUR: WILLIAM SLATTERY LIEBERMAN
LEAD: When William S. Lieberman came to the Metropolitan Museum in 1979 as chairman of its department of 20th-century art, the Lila Acheson Wallace wing wasn't even a gleam in anyone's eye.
The department's collection was sparse and its shows were mounted in space borrowed from the European-paintings department.


Democratic Fits and Starts on Nuclear Testing
LEAD: Early this month it looked as if the Democratic leaders in Congress had decided to make a big push on the issue of nuclear testing.


Topics: In the Wind; Continental Drift
LEAD: Campaigning for the Presidency seven years ago, Ronald Reagan called for a ''North American Compact'' to bind the United States, Canada and Mexico.
Nothing came of the idea, but acid rain brings it back to mind.


DEVILS COME UP SHORT AGAIN
LEAD: The Devils got caught short on defense tonight several times, the most costly breakdown coming on a 3-on-1 attack early in the second period.


Stocks Gain in Tokyo and London
LEAD: Stock prices rose sharply in Tokyo yesterday, and the London market also rallied before tapering off at the close.


Murdoch Bid Is Topped
LEAD: Rupert Murdoch's $1.5 billion bid for Australia's largest news group came under renewed pressure today as a rival company, John Fairfax Ltd., offered $1.63 billion for the Herald and Weekly Times.
There was no immediate response from the Melbourne-based Herald, which had accepted Mr.
Murdoch's offer of $9.75 a share, provided no other bidders came forth.


P.&amp; G. Offering Has 8 1/4% Yield
LEAD: The Procter &amp; Gamble Company is offering $200 million of 8 1/8 percent sinking-fund debentures, due in 2017, at a price of 98.625 to yield 8 1/4 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company.


BUDGET SEEKS TO RAISE SCHOOL AID $405 MILLION
LEAD: Governor Cuomo proposed today a $405 million increase in state aid to public schools in the next academic year, with half going to economically disadvantaged communities.


Kenya Denies as 'Scandalous' Charges by a U.S. Legislator
LEAD: Kenya's Foreign Minister described as ''scandalous and unfounded'' today criticism by a United States Congressman of this nation's human rights policies.


2 KEY SENATORS VOW TO DEFEAT MISSILE SHIELD PLAN
LEAD: Two key Democratic Senators said today that they were confident of defeating any Reagan Administration proposals to speed the installation of defenses against ballistic missiles when the military budget is debated this year.


LORENZO SEEKING TO CUT EASTERN PAY UP TO 60%
LEAD: Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, will disclose today a plan for Eastern Airlines that calls for deep cuts, in some cases as much as 60 percent, in the pay of most of Eastern's 43,000 employees, an Eastern spokesman said yesterday.


DOW UP 13TH TIME, CLOSING AT 2,104.47
LEAD: The Dow Jones industrial average set records yesterday - but just barely.
After an up-and-down day, the popular yardstick of 30 blue-chip stocks finished with a small gain for a 13th consecutive advance, its longest string ever.

CITICORP GAINS 25.9% IN QUARTER
LEAD: Citicorp yesterday reported a healthy 25.9 percent increase in fourth-quarter net income, to $306 million, from $243 million.
It was buoyed by strong profits from its consumer and business banking operations, which more than offset flat results in its investment bank.


DENG TELLS MUGABE THE OPEN-DOOR POLICY WILL BE PRESSED BY CHINA
LEAD: The strain of the Chinese political crisis spilled into the domain of the economy today with calls both for increased openness to the outside world and for greater economic centralization.


The Wow! in the Dow
LEAD: The dollar is plummeting, the trade accounts are a mess and every day the national debt grows by a half-billion dollars.
But sobering news from Washington and Tokyo seems to have little impact on investors' enthusiasm.
The Great January Rally has lifted the Dow Jones Industrial Average by 11 percent, increasing the value of all traded stocks by an astounding $270 billion.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: The Boston Celtics have signed Conner Henry, a rookie guard, for the rest of the season.
Henry, 6 feet 7 inches, was originally selected by Houston in the fourth round of the 1986 draft out of the University of California at Santa Barbara.
He was waived by the Rockets Dec. 12 and had received two 10-day contracts from the Celtics this month.


We Still Need the Minimum Wage

Model Assesses Routes Of Hazardous Shipments
LEAD: More than 1.5 billion tons of hazardous materials are transported along the country's roads, rail lines and waterways each year, and both the tonnage and the number of truck accidents involving dangerous cargo are on the rise.
In the growing debate over what routes these materials should follow through populated areas, industry often thinks in terms of economics while the public thinks in terms of safety.

LEAD: Many contributors to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund express the wish that others will follow their example.

LEAD: Karl Mecklenburg's active mind is on Joe Morris this week, conjuring ways to bedevil the little speedster.


SETON HALL SUFFERS 79-75 UPSET
LEAD: Dana Barros scored 19 of his game-high 30 points in the second half to lead Boston College to a 79-75 come-from-behind victory over Seton Hall tonight in a Big East Conference game at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.


FUTURE SHOCKS: A NEW AUTO SUSPENSION SYSTEM
LEAD: THE Lotus Esprit sports car screams around a tight corner at 105 miles an hour.
While most cars would list sharply to one side as the driver struggled desperately to hold the road, the Lotus takes the turn effortlessly, almost as if it were cruising down a straight, flat country lane.

LEAD: WHENEVER stocks move sharply in one direction or another for a sustained period, the eyes of Wall Street inevitably turn to the giants of the market, the institutional investors, for a reading of what to expect next.

Col.
Oliver L. North begin the network to supply weapons to the Nicaraguan rebels three years ago, even as Congress moved to prohibit military assistance to them, according to a former senior rebel official and other sources.

Widow of Manes Resigns From Post

EXERCISE WITH A FRIEND LIKE CURLY ARM CURL
LEAD: EXERCISE machines that talk?
Count repetitions for you, urge you to push harder, tell you when to rest and even urge you on with little quips like ''no pain no gain.'' Right.
A personal exercise coach can help when motivation falters, but the expense could easily cripple one's budget.
Enter Powercise, a group of exercise machines with built-in personal fitness coaches.

ADS PUSH MERITS OF RED MEAT
LEAD: America's beef industry is blanketing the nation with a $29 million advertising campaign intended to reverse a trend away from red meat among cholesterol-conscious consumers.


Tender Offer Set For First Women's
LEAD: A group of investors who recently acquired a 42 percent interest in the First Women's Bank has started a tender offer for all remaining shares at $11 a share.
The group's original purchase was valued at almost $2.9 million.
The remaining stock is valued at $7.07 million.


SCIENTIST AND SOVIET EMIGRE
LEAD: Dr.
Benjamin G. Levich, an internationally prominent physical chemist who won a six-year effort to emigrate from the Soviet Union, died of cardiac arrest Monday at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital.
He was 69 years old and lived in Fort Lee, N.J.


EL NINO REUTRNS, BUT DISASTER IS NOT FORSEEN
LEAD: El Nino, the momentous shift in the winds and waters of the tropical Pacific, has returned, but it appears unlikely to bring the widespread climatic disaster it did four years ago, the National Weather Service said yesterday.


60-MINUTE GOURMET
LEAD: IT is a curious fact of life that some of the foods most coveted by gastronomes are looked upon with disdain by many home cooks.
These include most of the so-called variety meats, a euphemism if ever there was one for the innards of animals.
These include brains, sweetbreads, kidneys and, sometimes, liver.

All Welcome, For a Change
LEAD: A basketball game between rival high schools can stir the teen-age blood, so much so, in fact, that it has periodically led to brawls between opposing groups of fans at P.S.A.L. games in recent years.
Principals at a number of schools - roughly a dozen in Brooklyn alone - have been fighting back this season with a controversial tactic: barring game attendance by visiting teams' fans and cheerleaders.

He will be chairman of the company, based in Milpitas, Calif.

A CRIME RISE SPURS BRAZIL LYNCH MOBS
LEAD: During the wake for a taxi driver killed in late December in the western town of Amambai, word reached mourners that a murder suspect had been found.
A few hours later, his bullet-riddled and mutilated body was dumped beside an outlying road.
He was the victim of a lynch mob.


Blood Samples Tested For Form of Leukemia
LEAD: The American Red Cross said today that it had collected samples from thousands of blood donors around the country to test for a rare form of leukemia that could be spread through transfusions in the same way AIDS is sometimes transmitted.

He was 88 years old.

LEAD: Two of Texas's largest banks today reported losses in the fourth quarter, and a third reported a decline in profits.
All three are involved in pending mergers.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: Skiing Zurbriggen Takes Giant Slalom: Pirmin Zurbriggen rebounded from a disappointing weekend to win a World Cup giant slalom race yesterday in Adelboden, Switzerland, to widen his lead in the overall standing.
The 23-year-old Zurbriggen posted his 24th World Cup victory in seven seasons on the circuit with a two-run total of 2 minutes 33.82 seconds.

Competitiveness - Not Just a Buzzword
LEAD: Competitiveness is emerging as this year's fashionable political buzzword.
President Reagan is expected to make it a central theme of his State of the Union Message.
Given the Administration's difficulties, there will be a great temptation to advance a program that provides the ''answer'' to our trade problem, defuses protectionist pressures and distracts attention from other political issues.

10 Years of Capital Punishment
LEAD: In a widely publicized execution 10 years ago, a Utah firing squad ended Gary Gilmore's life and with it the national moratorium on capital punishment that was in force since 1967.
Death row inmates in more than 30 states around the country now die in relative anonymity in public acts sanctioned by the Supreme Court.

LEAD: Donald J. Trump, the New York developer, succeeded today in temporarily blocking the sale of the Golden Nugget Hotel/Casino to the Bally Manufacturing Company, a deal that Mr.
Trump's lawyer said was designed to prevent Mr.
Trump from taking over Bally.

LIFE IN THE 30's
LEAD: I WATCHED ''Gone With the Wind'' on television recently.
It's my favorite movie.
It's hokey, it's predictable, the color's lurid, I throw balled-up tissues at Olivia de Havilland when she's on screen.
I love it.
Each time I see it I notice something new.

LEAD: President Chun Doo Hwan, acting to defuse a political crisis, dismissed his Interior Minister and his National Police Chief today after the Government's admission that the police had tortured a student to death.


Utility Bonds Set For San Antonio
LEAD: San Antonio is tentatively offering $393 million refunding revenue bonds for the municipally owned gas and electric system through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
A maximum yield of 7.11 percent is offered for 7 percent bonds, due in 2012, at a price of 98 3/4.

The public may also be poorer in a way that is harder to measure but more lasting in its effect.

Banks Must Not Tempt Us to the Path to Debt
LEAD: To the Editor:


Night Trading Is Proposed
LEAD: Directors of the Chicago Board of Trade voted today to open the first evening trading session for a United States-based exchange.
The plan, approved by the 22-member board, would allow the Chicago Board of Trade to offer exchange-based Treasury bond futures and options between 5 P.M. and 9 P.M., central time.


Pass-Through Securities Make Debut in Sterling
LEAD: Efforts to export one of Wall Street's most successful concepts -mortgage pass-through securities -are moving forward with the first-ever Euromarket issue of sterling-denominated pass-through-type mortgage securities.


JUSTICES BAR A LAW LIMITING APPEALS MADE DOOR TO DOOR
LEAD: The Supreme Court today struck down an Illinois city's ordinance barring all door-to-door soliciting before 9 A.M., after 5 P.M. and on Sundays and holidays, ruling it was a violation of the right to free speech.

LEAD: A picture in Business Day on Jan. 9 with an article about the Honda Motor Company's expansion in Ohio was published in error.
It showed Shige Yoshida, executive vice president of Honda of America, not Shoichiro Irimajiri, the company's president.

LEAD: Despite growing signs of interest by the Soviet Union in getting its troops out of Afghanistan, American officials and foreign diplomats said today that an early withdrawal seems unlikely unless the Afghan insurgents moderate their opposition to forming a coalition government acceptable to Moscow.

LEAD: Two leading cable television home- marketing companies - the Home Shopping Network of Clearwater, Fla., and the COMB Company of Minneapolis - are considering a $650 million merger, the companies said late yesterday.

LEAD: More than 10 years after Don Bolles, a Phoenix newspaper reporter, was killed by a bomb, a new courtroom drama began in the long-running case today, reminding this city that Mr.
Bolles's murder is still unsolved.


AMTRAK CHAIRMAN ATTRIBUTES CRASH TO CONDUCT OF CONRAIL CREW
LEAD: The chief executive of Amtrak today attributed the fatal collision of a passenger train and three Conrail freight engines to ''the outrageous conduct of the Conrail crew'' and cited several violations of operating procedures.


Jersey Mayor Warns Of 200 City Layoffs
LEAD: Mayor Sharpe James warned yesterday that unless the state provided additional money for city operations he would be forced to layoff about 200 city employees, including police officers and firefighters, and raise property taxes almost 33 percent.


Economic Scene; Preventing A Money Crisis
LEAD: EXCITEMENT in the stock market and the foreign-exchange market is reaching a fever pitch.
Professional money managers are getting worried as the stock market seems to soar farther and farther away from the reality of a sluggish economy.
But the pressure for performance keeps institutional investors buying stocks, anyway.

G.M. Said to Study Plant Closings
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation is considering closing as many as 20 or more auto parts plants in an effort to become more competitive, The Detroit Free Press reported, quoting an anonymous source.
It said the plants would be phased out over two to three years.
A G.M. spokesman, John Mueller, told the newspaper he knew of no plans to close any of the automaker's parts plants.


G.O.P. PANEL PICKS NEW ORLEANS AS THE SITE FOR 1988 CONVENTION
LEAD: A Republican committee today recommended New Orleans, a city renowned for its jazz, Cajun cooking and wilting summer heat, as the site of the party's 1988 national convention.

LEAD: AFTER rising at 5 A.M. in the suburbs and driving more than two hours on icy streets and traffic-clogged roads, Bill Hogan alighted from his car in Manhattan yesterday and said, ''This was a breeze, an enjoyable trip.''


APPLE UP
LEAD: Wang Laboratories, citing inventory write-downs, problems in plant consolidations and sluggish sales, said yesterday that it had a loss of $78.6 million in the second fiscal quarter, ended Dec. 31.

LEAD: The Benedictine monks at the Newark Abbey, suffering from a shortage of vocations as are most religious communities, did something yesterday that the others rarely do.
They spent some big dollars for major ''help wanted'' ads in the secular press.

Thermal Underwear: A New Development
LEAD: The law of thermal underwear -weight equals warmth - no longer holds true at J. E. Morgan Knitting Mills Inc., a Hometown, Pa., concern that makes almost half of the nation's long johns.
Its Arctex fabric reportedly traps more body heat and weighs less than other popular thermal garments, according to tests done at the International Fabricare Institute in


New Xerox Copier
LEAD: The Xerox Corporation introduced a mid-volume copier that offers features normally available only on the company's largest copiers and can use them without sacrificing speed.
The machine, which makes 62 copies a minute, uses a microprocessor as powerful as five personal computers.
The 1065 sells for $23,095 and will be available by May.

Retirement Age
LEAD: Gov.
James R. Thompson signed legislation Monday under which the State of Illinois will build a new South Side home for the Chicago White Sox.
The new stadium, expected to be ready for the 1990 baseball season, will mean the razing of Comiskey Park, which holds the No. 1 spot on this list of the oldest major league sports arenas in the nation.

ART: UNEXPECTED JUXTAPOSITIONS IN THE MET'S NEW WING
LEAD: ONE of the better-kept secrets around New York this last nine years has been the content of the forthcoming 20th-century wing at the Metropolitan Museum.
To what extent would it rival, duplicate or usefully supplement the great quantities of 20th-century art already on view in New York's museums?
Was it primarily a vanity operation, or had it something all its own to offer?


CONCERT: 3 PREMIERES BY SPECULUM MUSICAE
LEAD: SPECULUM MUSICAE, the ensemble of 20th-century specialists that began its 16th season on Monday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, is one of the most active proponents of the idea that there is room in our culture for defiantly recondite musical craftsmanship.
Such groups - and there are quite a number of them - serve first to keep many composers of modest talent from sinking into total obscurity.

LEAD: An article yesterday about the reaction of Chinese students in the United States to political developments in their homeland misidentified a New York Chinese newspaper to which the students delivered a letter.
It was The Centre Daily News.

LEAD: The White House announced today that people who missed President Reagan's weekly Saturday radio speeches could call a recording of it later in the day, for a fee.

LEAD: China has stirred a debate in Indonesia, but not because of leadership changes in Beijing.
The problem is the Chinese exercises known as tai chi.

NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 21, 1987
LEAD: International


Finance Group Lobbies For More Deregulation
LEAD: A lobbying group made up of some of the nation's largest financial concerns said today that it would push for widespread deregulation of the financial industry.


An Abortion Anniversary
LEAD: Both sides of the abortion debate are preparing activities for tomorrow to mark the 14th anniversary of the Supreme Court's decision legalizing abortion.
The anti-abortion forces are planning a mass march on the Capitol, while supporters of legalized abortion, including the National Organization for

ELECTION EVE TALK WITH KOHL: SURE OF VICTORY AND ALL SMILES
LEAD: Snugly ensconced in one chair, Helmut Kohl reached out with a long arm and dragged an empty one to him in a kind of half-embrace. ''I have been underestimated for decades,'' the West German Chancellor said with a big smile. ''I've done very well that way.''


CLEMENTS RETURNS AS TEXAS GOVERNOR
LEAD: Bill Clements was once again sworn in today as Governor of Texas, facing what many believe will be the most painful era in the state's 150-year history.


U.S. MONITORS' POST IN SOVIET TEST AREA IS DESTROYED BY FIRE
LEAD: A seismic measuring station installed by American scientists as part of a project to monitor Soviet nuclear testing has been destroyed by fire, a member of the American team said today.


WINE TALK
LEAD: MANFRED ROMMEL, the Mayor of Stuttgart, tells the story of a wine-loving student named Hegel, who became a philosopher of some repute.
Hegel once turned up so drunk in the university town of Tubingen that his comrades hid him from his teachers.
A prefect supposedly warned him, ''Hegel, you'll drink away that little bit of sense you've got left.


BEN ALCOCK
LEAD: Ben Alcock, retired executive vice president and director of creative services of Grey Advertising Inc., died Jan. 14 at Waterbury (Conn.) Hospital.
He was 72 years old and lived in Heritage Village in Southbury, Conn.


THE SCREEN: 'THE HOUR OF THE STAR,' FROM BRAZIL
LEAD: THE heroine of ''The Hour of the Star'' is a doomed innocent, a young woman so naive and unworldly that she is first seen wiping her nose on the collar of her blouse.
She works as a typist in Rio de Janeiro, living in one cramped room with several roommates.
Yet she is so lonely that she likes riding the subway, just for the sake of companionship.


Dolphins Make Moves
LEAD: The Miami Dolphins, who were ranked next-to-last in the National Football League in team defense for most of the season, yesterday hired Tom Olivadotti, an assistant coach with the Browns, to be their new defensive coach.
Chuck Studley, who had been the defensive coordinator for the last three seasons, was reassigned to coach the linebackers, working primarily on the defense against the run.


KOOKABURRA III WILL DEFEND CUP
LEAD: Alan Bond spent nearly a decade and millions of his own dollars trying to win the America's Cup for Australia before finally succeeding in 1983.
Now he has lost his chance to defend it.


EX-OFFICER DESCRIBES KEY MOMENT AT SCENE OF THE BUMPURS SHOOTING
LEAD: A retired police officer testified yesterday that Eleanor Bumpurs made repeated stabbing motions at him after a fellow officer fired the first of two shotgun blasts during a 1984 police eviction attempt in her Bronx apartment.

LEAD: A dispatch on Jan. 7 from Tallahassee, Fla., about the induction of a new Governor misstated the party affiliation of the Florida Senate President.

Destination: West Virginia
LEAD: Representative Bob Wise, a Democrat from West Virginia, says he has spent a lot of time trying to preserve two programs that he considers crucial to his region: the Appalachian Regional Commission and the Economic Development Administration.
Both are chosen for elimination in the Reagan Administration's new proposed budget.


REVIEWING THE MET'S NEW WING
LEAD: Mezzanine sculpture gallery in Metropolitan Museum's new $26-million Lila Acheson Wallace Wing of 20th-century art, which opens to the public Feb. 3.
Works shown are by Al Held, Jose de Rivera, David Smith and Anthony Caro. (NYT/Angel Franco)

CONCERN WARNS IT WILL DISMISS ALL WHO SMOKE
LEAD: The USG Acoustical Products Company has told its employees at plants in eight states that they must stop smoking or lose their jobs.
The company said today that the smoking ban applied to both work and home and that it would conduct lung tests to make sure the employees had stopped.


BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 21, 1987
LEAD:  The Economy


5 DIE IN MIDWEST PLANE COLLISION
LEAD: Two planes, one a military aircraft carrying the deputy commandant general of Fort McClellan, Ala., collided over an Army ammunition plant today, killing all five people aboard the two aircraft, the authorities said.

FINANCE BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Browning-Ferris Industries is offering $100 million of A-2/A+-rated 8 1/2 percent sinking fund debentures, due in 2017, at a price of 97.677 to yield 8.72 percent, through Smith Barney, Harris Upham.
Nonrefundable for 10 years, the issue has a sinking fund beginning in 1998 that gives the debentures a minimum average life of 14.35 years and a maximum of 20.5 years.


Esposito Wants Jury Disbanded in Inquiry
LEAD: Meade H. Esposito, the retired Brooklyn Democratic leader, has asked that the grand jury investigating him be disbanded and a special prosecutor be appointed to investigate what his lawyer described as ''unlawful disclosures of grand jury materials'' by Federal law-enforcement officials.


Earnings Rise At Rockwell
LEAD: The Rockwell International Corporation reported yesterday that earnings in its fiscal first quarter, ended Dec. 31, rose 18.8 percent on a 3.6 increase in sales.
Rockwell, a major aerospace company based in Pittsburgh, attributed the profit rise mainly to its B-1B bomber program.


KOCH ADDRESS TELLS OF DAMAGE FROM SCANDAL BUT ALSO HEALING
LEAD: In language as ornate as his tone was restrained, Mayor Koch yesterday acknowledged the serious damage caused by the corruption scandal, but pronounced the city to be in sound and ever-improving shape.


MONEY-SAVING MENUS A LA BONNE FEMME
LEAD: THE French housewife, with her inborn sense of balance and proportion, her acquired instinct for the careful composition of robust stews and little sauces, her insistence on the finest quality at the cheapest price and her ability to make much of very little, is a paragon of culinary virtue.
As such she may already have become a creature of history, if indeed she ever existed at all.


Newsweek, McDonald's In Date at White House
LEAD: Gerard Smith, publisher of Newsweek, and Edward H. Rensi, president of McDonald's U.S.A., are scheduled to be at the White House today to present to the First Couple a copy of a special issue of the newsweekly entitled ''Newsweek on the Drug Crisis'' that is intended to educate the high school students of the nation.

Stuffing a Flank Steak
LEAD: FLANK STEAK, also known as London broil, comes from the tail end of the loin.
It is a relatively economical and lean cut of beef that lends itself exceptionally well to stuffing and braising.
To save time, ask the butcher to trim all the fat from the flank steak.
Follow the technique below for stuffing and trussing the steak and then brown it well on both sides in a high-sided pan.


ELECTION IS DUE
LEAD: The coalition that has governed Ireland for four years collapsed today, and Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald immediately announced that there would be a national election Feb. 17.


Topics: In the Wind; No-Show Ethics
LEAD: A Federal trial in Brooklyn casts an embarrassing spotlight on payroll padding, Albany style.
Richard Rubin, a longtime Queens Democratic Party official and formerly chief patronage dispenser for Donald Manes, is charged with using his political clout to have state legislators put his law office secretaries on their payroll.

CBS PLANS A SNAPPY PRELUDE
LEAD: CBS is not having a two-hour Super Bowl pre-game show on Sunday.
Instead, it will fill the two hours before the game with a show called ''The Super Bowl Today.''


SENATE PANEL HEARS RUSSIAN ABOUT CHERNOBYL
LEAD: A top Soviet scientist told a Senate committee today about the cleanup effort needed to recover from the Chernobyl nuclear accident last April and said that the Soviet Union nevertheless planned to quintuple nuclear power production by the year 2000.

CUOMO PROPOSES RAISING SPENDING BY 7% IN BUDGET
LEAD: Hailing a ''continued resurgence'' in New York's economy, Governor Cuomo today proposed a $40.9 billion budget that would increase state spending by 7 percent while putting into effect the final phase of a three-year tax cut.

Lenders Lose U.S. Tax Case
LEAD: The Supreme Court today bolstered the Government's power to hold banks and other lenders that directly or indirectly pay the wages of their customers' employees liable for failing to withhold Social Security and income taxes.


Henry J. Kaufman Gets Automobile Association
LEAD: The American Automobile Association in Washington has consolidated its advertising at Henry J. Kaufman &amp; Associates, also in Washington.


Caterpillar Layoffs
LEAD: Caterpillar Inc., which announced last week that it planned to close three of its plants, said it would indefinitely lay off about 350 workers at a fourth facility, its Joliet, Ill., plant.
The workers will be laid off as of Feb. 2 because of reduced production schedules and a consolidation program at the plant, the company said in a statement.


NEW ALLOYS TRIED AT LOW TEMPERATURE
LEAD: TWO recent discoveries in the esoteric field of superconductivity - a phenomenon in which materials lose their resistance to electricity at very low temperatures - could eventually save the electrical industry billions of dollars and result in a variety of new electronic intruments and computer elements, according to scientists and power industry experts.


ARCHITECTURE: BLAND WITHOUT, A MARVEL WITHIN
LEAD: THE galleries of the new Lila Acheson Wallace Wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art are the best museum spaces in New York for the display of 20th-century art.
This is not to say that they represent an architectural triumph: as a building, the Wallace wing is dull and not a little clunky.
But what is banal on the outside is both inventive and serene within, and it manages the difficult trick of accommodating the needs of art without capitulating into complete neutrality.


Pro Basketball Notebook; Trade for Dantley Paying Off
LEAD: Adrian Dantley's one-on-one confrontations with Coach Frank Layden of the Utah Jazz and Layden's attempts to trade Dantley to anyone who would take him have been well documented.

Goal Oriented
LEAD: Todd Linder made 7 of 11 field-goal attempts the other night as his University of Tampa basketball team beat Eckerd College, but he's bound to get his shooting eye back.


BARGAINS IN BULK SHOPPING
LEAD: THE New York area can be a bargain hunter's paradise for any cook.
Everything from pounds of fresh, plump shrimp and exotic mushrooms to plastic pouches of turmeric and liters of extra-virgin olive oil can be found at a fraction of the prices typically charged in most retail shops and supermarkets.


Teacher Cites Pressure
LEAD: A high school English teacher in Jackson, Tenn., said yesterday she quit her job after being pressured into changing a failing grade she had given a star member of the school's undefeated basketball team.
The teacher, Ann McGhee, said she changed an F to a D-minus at the direction of the Campbell County High School principal, Clifford C.


The U.N. Today: Jan. 21, 1987
LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee Drafting Convention Against Recruitment, Use, Financing and Training of Mercenaries - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.


Harris-Premark
LEAD: An investment group, led by the Chicago-based investment adviser Harris Associates L.P., has purchased a 5.7 percent stake, or 1.91 million shares, of Premark International Inc.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Harris group said that it had acquired the Premark shares for investment purposes only.


SHUTTLE ESCAPE SYSTEM IS DELAYED
LEAD: A rocket-powered system designed to eject astronauts from the space shuttle in an emergency will not be installed until further tests are conducted, an official at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.


TWO MORE QUIT IN GUINNESS SCANDAL
LEAD: The chief executive of Britain's top investment bank, Morgan Grenfell Group P.L.C., and the concern's head of corporate finance resigned today in the wake of the stock-trading scandal surrounding Guinness P.L.C.


GRAND JURY IS PRESENTED RACIAL ATTACK EVIDENCE
LEAD: A Queens grand jury began receiving evidence yesterday in the Howard Beach assault, sources familiar with the case said.


Howard Beach Gets A Visit From Mayor
LEAD: Mayor Koch met last night with 50 leaders of Howard Beach, Queens, to discuss their concerns about being labeled a racist community.

Parting Shot
LEAD: Howard Sharpe of Bicknell, Ind., who will retire at age 71 after the season with more victories than any other coach in the history of Indiana high school basketball: ''Of course, if I get incapacitated and can't see anymore, I can always be a referee.''

Owens to Sell Ladish Division
LEAD: The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation has agreed to sell its Ladish Company subsidiary, which produces high-technology forgings for aerospace and industrial applications, for $236 million to a new company formed by an investor group led by Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen, an investment banking firm specializing in leveraged buyouts.

LEAD: Four days after the President of Ecuador was briefly kidnapped by air force commandos, the National Congress went into special session today with opposition leaders seeking his resignation.


KIDNAPPING OF WEST GERMAN LINKED TO ARREST
LEAD: A West German business executive kidnapped in Beirut last weekend was evidently seized in an effort to prevent the extradition to the United States of a Lebanese suspected of being a pro-Iran terrorist.

Jeff Rutledge and Gary Kubiak were free to roam the practice field at Orange Coast College, enjoying the view, wondering what it would be like to be the focus of attention during the week of the Super Bowl.

LEAD: Six months after law-enforcement officials began seizing cars to stop out-of-towners from buying drugs, anti-drug strategists say they have inflicted a blow but not a defeat on the commuting crack trade in New York City.

LEAD: The Gipper may have played with a leather hat, but when the Giants butt heads with the Broncos Sunday in Super Bowl XXI their craniums will be protected with polycarbonate plastic shells lined with foam padding and honeycombed with hollow channels that can be inflated with air for a skull-hugging custom fit, or with antifreeze to absorb shocks and distribute the impact.

METROPOLITAN DIARY
LEAD: BARNEY GREENGRASS was known as the ''Sturgeon King'' when the store opened in 1908.
He was still the Sturgeon King when the store moved to its present site on Amsterdam Avenue, between 86th and 87th Streets.
His son, Moe, and his grandson Gary preside over the store nowadays and it is they who followed in Barney's footsteps and share the title of Sturgeon King.

LEAD: Mario Lemieux, the leading vote-getter in the National Hockey League All-Star balloting, will return to the Pittsburgh Penguins' lineup tonight after being sidelined for a month.
Lemieux twisted his right knee in a Dec. 20 game against the Philadelphia Flyers. ''He'll be a big lift,'' said Eddie Johnston, the Penguins' general manager.

Sacramento Teachers Strike
LEAD: Teachers went on strike today after a 20-hour bargaining session failed to produce a new contract.
Despite the strike by 2,300 teachers, the district hoped to keep schools open for the 44,000 students with the help of 700 substitute teachers who would be paid $140 a day.
Normal pay for substitutes is $52 to $89 a day.


SAYS PUBLICITY HINDERS HIS WORK
LEAD: A high-ranking commander in the New York City Police Department whose social contacts with a reputed organized-crime figure in 1983 have been under investigation applied for retirement yesterday, police officials said.


THE SUPER BOWL INITIATION
LEAD: In a sunny sky a softer blue than that of the Giants' jerseys, sea gulls floated in the wind that swayed the palm trees.
But with the temperatures plunging into the 60's, thin-blooded southern Californians considered this to be a ''cold'' morning.
They had to wear sweaters, some even windbreakers.


MARK B. MITIN
LEAD: Mark B. Mitin, a Marxist philosopher and member of the Academy of Sciences since 1939, has died, the Tass press agency announced today.
He was 85 years old.
He was a member of the Central Committee from 1939 to 1961, and a member of the Supreme Soviet, the nominal legislature, from 1950 to 1962.
He won a Stalin Prize in 1943.

LEAD: One day last fall, with liabilities of $2.1 million and assets of $1.7 million, Virginia and Doyle Lay filed for Chapter 11 protection in the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Dallas.

Technology Stocks: An Investment Strategy
LEAD: Historically, technology stocks have outperformed rising markets, notes Marc G. Schulman, an analyst with Salomon Brothers.
But unlike the big technology stock rally of 1983-84, which was dominated by small companies that had innovative new products, he says, this time the best performers will be larger-capitalization stocks, and among those, the winners will be the ones that offer ways to integrate existing hardware.

LEAD: Two military reconnaissance jets collided and crashed in flames in a remote area today, killing two crew members while two others parachuted to safety, the authorities said.

LEAD: The Royal Court Theater today canceled its production of a play in which a character asserts that Jewish leaders collaborated with Nazis in the murder of Jews during World War II.

Steel Output Off in 1986
LEAD: Crude steel production in the non-Communist world fell 4.3 percent last year, the International Iron and Steel Institute said today, to 416.9 million tons from 1985's 435.5 million.

LAST TENANT SPURNS OFFER OF 'BLANK CHECK' TO LEAVE
LEAD: Rafael Villa Vicencio was approached some time ago, he said, and offered ''a blank check'' to move out of his room at the St.
Clair Hotel at 69 West 38th Street. ''They told me to pick the amount,'' he said yesterday. ''I didn't accept it.
I asked them to fix the room I had.''

LEAD: Martina Navratilova, the defending champion, and Hana Mandlikova advanced today to the women's singles final in the Australian Open championships at Kooyong.


Arms Control Out of Control
LEAD: After six years and two summit meetings, the Reagan Administration's arms control policy remains in near-total disarray.
The State and Defense Departments remain consistently at war.
The weak National Security Council staff still fails to enforce order.
And now even the most elemental coordination between decisions on strategic weapons and negotiating positions approaches breakdown.

LEAD: Thousands of Muscovites, unaccustomed to being asked their opinion about a public works project, thronged the city's Central Exhibition Hall last week to quarrel over proposed designs for what is to be the Soviet Union's grandest war memorial, a 330-acre Moscow park celebrating the victory over fascism.

LEAD: Inflatable vests that repeatedly squeeze patients suffering cardiac arrest may save more lives with less injury than manual cardiopulmonary resuscitation, researchers say.

Xerox Retirements
LEAD: The Xerox Corporation said that about 1,000 of about 4,000 eligible salaried employees had elected to retire early, and most will leave the company by the end of the month.
The company said its savings would be substantial, but it declined to project its reduction in expenses this year.
Xerox said the retirees, who are at least 50 years old, with 10 years of service at the company, work at locations around the United States, but the largest group is at its Rochester office.


Waite Is Said to Meet With Captors in Beirut
LEAD: Terry Waite, the Anglican intermediary, conducted negotiations in a secret location today with kidnappers who hold two American hostages, according to a spokesman for a Druse militia.

NEW HAMPSHIRE G.O.P. TRIES TO UNDERSTAND KEMP
LEAD: Some conservatives criticize him as not being true enough to the cause.
Average Republicans complain that he speaks over their heads.
And so when Representative Jack F. Kemp finally got some kind words from the right place this week, it made all that sliding through the snows of New Hampshire worthwhile.


SETTLEMENT FADES IN L.I.R.R. DISPUTE
LEAD: Negotiators for the Long Island Rail Road reported progress last night with 3 of 11 striking unions -reaching a tentative agreement with one.
But a quick end still seemed unlikely for the walkout that has inconvenienced hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers all week.


COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: *
American Financial Corp., Cincinnati, a property and casualty insurance company, said that contrary to rumors it had no intention of selling any portion of its 31 percent stake in Circle K Corp.


LILLIANA W. TERUZZI
LEAD: Lilliana W. Teruzzi, a former opera singer and donor of the $2,500 Teruzzi Award for aspiring singers in the mid-1960's, died Thursday at her home in Manhattan.
She was 91 years old.


WIESEL WARNS OF PERILS IN DISUNITY AMONG JEWS
LEAD: Elie Wiesel, winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, warned yesterday that internal disunity was ''the most serious danger facing the Jewish people,'' more ominous than the threats from anti-Semitism or assimilation.


RECITAL: ERIC RUSKE, HORN
LEAD: ERIC RUSKE is a horn player of fluency and grace, and his Tuesday evening recital at the 92d Street Y was eminently satisfying.


Q &amp; A
LEAD: Q.About a year ago, motor oil spilled on the porch planking (pressure-treated 2-by-4's) and apparently soaked into the wood because the oil is seeping through the penetrating stain.
How can I remove the oil and restain the planking?
A.This will not be easy after such a length of time and it has been made worse by the stain that was applied.


Plant Catalogues' Sweet Seduction
LEAD: LIKE many other gardeners, I imagine, I feel sorry for the postman at this time of year.


Japanese Reaction: Uncertainty, Disappointment
LEAD: Government officials, economists and traders said today they were unsure of how to interpret a United States-Japan statement on exchange rates.


Short Interest on Big Board Falls 12.1% in Month
LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest fell 56.2 million shares, or 12.1 percent, in the month ended Jan. 15, to 409.3 million shares.
The short interest for the period a year earlier was 266.6 million shares.


Moscow Opening
LEAD: For the Soviet Union to invite a defector to return as an honored guest once was unthinkable.
A 1985 film, ''White Nights,'' was based on the opposite premise - that any defector unlucky enough to crash land in Soviet territory would be abducted by the K.G.B.
The star of that film was Mikhail Baryshnikov, the dancer who in real life defected in 1974.


George Goes to Miami
LEAD: Jeff George, former quarterback at Purdue, said yesterday that he will switch to Miami as a transfer student.
George said earlier this month that he had decided to leave Purdue, where he is completing his freshman year.
He will be eligible to play three years with the Hurricanes, starting with the 1988 season.


Johnson &amp; Johnson
LEAD: The health-care giant Johnson &amp; Johnson has formed a new subsidiary to market employee health promotion programs and services to employers, James E. Burke, the company's chairman, announced.
The unit's comprehensive product line is intended to help businesses cut health-care costs and related expenses resulting from such problems as high absenteeism while raising productivity and morale by motivating staff to make long-term improvements in their health, he said.

Whimsies Made of Found Lumber
LEAD: STEPHEN WHITTLESEY'S furniture is made from salvaged wood, which for this artist possesses a personality, smell or patina that new wood does not.
His pieces are whimsical and expensive. ''Mummy's Cupboard,'' $3,200, second from left, is of lumber from the floor of an 18th-century whaling supply building in Woods Hole, Mass., that still had a briny odor.

Most Violence Victims Said to Know Attackers
LEAD: In the last few years, fewer than half, or 46 percent, of reported violent crimes were committed by complete strangers, according to a report from a Justice Department agency.


Wood Loses Appeal
LEAD: A judge in United States Appellate Court has ruled against Leon Wood, the Nets' guard, in a case that tested the legality of the National Basketball Association's college draft and its salary cap provisions.
Judge Ralph Winter, on behalf of a unanimous three-judge panel, held that the draft and salary cap were governed by labor law rather than antitrust law, and since they were subject to collective bargaining with the union, the draft and the cap were not subject to challenge by an individual player.

Ford and Navistar In Engine Deal
LEAD: The Navistar International Corporation said that it would continue to supply diesel engines to the Ford Motor Company beyond its current contract, which is scheduled to expire later this month.
The current contract, in which Navistar produced 6.9-liter diesel engines for Ford pickup trucks and vans, was signed in 1981.


CONCERT: ORGANUM, POLISH CHOIR
LEAD: ORGANUM, a choir from Cracow, Poland, presented a concert late Sunday afternoon at the Church of St.
Jean Baptiste that was both rewarding and frustrating - rewarding because the ensemble is superbly trained and sings with euphony and fervor; frustrating because of a lack of documentation.


New Venture Offers Catalogues for Sale
LEAD: The Catalog Retail Corporation, New Canaan, Conn., of which Jay Walker, formerly of Folio, is chairman, will begin its new business of selling catalogues in retail outlets on Feb. 1.
Mr.
Walker says there is a demand.
Catalogues priced from $1 to $3 will be displayed in freestanding racks.
The first 1,000 racks will be in outlets of Waldenbooks and Eastern Newsstands, which operates in office buildings in three markets.


AMR Income Slides 73%
LEAD: The AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines Inc., reported a 73 percent drop in earnings for the fourth quarter.
With traffic up and revenues flat, the airline was apparently the victim of the fare wars that shook the industry.


A PERPLEXING RALLY HAS WALL ST. JITTERY
LEAD: Rarely has the stock market been the source of so much consternation - and befuddlement - as it is today.


DEFENSE IN 'BELL JAR' TRIAL MAKES OPENING POINTS
LEAD: In writing a novel or a screenplay, an author has great latitude in using and disguising autobiographical and biographical material, defense attorneys argued today in Federal District Court here in the libel trial that centers on a film of the late Sylvia Plath's novel, ''The Bell Jar.''

CANADIANS SCOLD BUSH OVER TRADE AND ACID RAIN
LEAD: Canadian officials, in an unusually fractious mood, met today with Vice President Bush today and demanded that the Reagan Administration make greater efforts to fulfill commitments on trade, acid rain and other issues.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A chart yesterday on the New York State tax reduction to take effect this year incorrectly described state income tax rates.
Currently, 9.5 percent is the maximum rate on earned income; 13.5 percent is the maximum rate on unearned income.
The maximum rates are to be reduced to 9 percent and 13 percent, respectively.


The Beira Corridor
LEAD: From this border city a road, rail and pipeline run to the Mozambican port of Beira, 190 miles away.
They are Zimbabwe's shortest connections to the outside world, and a way for other landlocked countries of the region to reduce South Africa's economic grip.
But they are fragile links now, threatened by war and decay in


NOTE AND BOND RATES UP A BIT
LEAD: Interest rates on Treasury notes and bonds rose slightly in quiet trading yesterday as market participants awaited the outcome of a meeting between Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d and Japan's Finance Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa.


DANCING: WHO WORE WHAT WHEN
LEAD: THIS has been quite a season for exhibitions tracing the history of social dancing.


Box-Bound Brian
LEAD: Brian Curran, the Islander defenseman, is collecting penalty minutes at a rate of 434 for the year, a total that would make him more heavily penalized in a single season than all but one other player in N.H.L. history.
Here are the 10 instances to date of greatest familiarity with the penalty box.


No Headline
LEAD: Karsten Mahlmann does not fit the stereotypical image of a commodities broker, in spite of his nickname, ''Cash.'' In fact, Mr.
Mahlmann, a soft-spoken and reserved German immigrant, more resembles a corporate chief executive than some of the more boisterous denizens of Chicago's exchanges.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The largest faction of the Nicaraguan rebels unveiled a strategy today for the coming year aimed at putting the Sandinista forces on the defensive with widespread hit-and-run raids in central Nicaragua.

LEAD: Of the 10 elementary schools that scored highest in the citywide reading test administered last spring, six are on Staten Island -including the top-ranking school, Public School 5 in Huguenot.

Khashoggi owes a British company.

Twenty-four hours went by and the Rangers did not make a transaction.

BIG CHARGE PUTS UNISYS IN THE RED
LEAD: The Unisys Corporation lost $188.5 million in the fourth quarter because of a huge one-time charge to cover the costs of its creation through the merger of the Burroughs Corporation and the Sperry Corporation, the computer maker said today.


Only Those Served by Public Housing Like It
LEAD: To the Editor:


People Express Head to Shift
LEAD: Donald C. Burr, a founder and president of People Express Inc., will become an executive vice president of the Texas Air Corporation on Feb. 1.
People Express has been acquired by Texas Air and will be merged into its Continental Airlines on that date.
Mr.
Burr will also be chairman of Continental's executive committee.


Firm Increases Van Heusen Stake
LEAD: An investment firm controlled by trusts of the wealthy Texan Caroline Hunt Schoellkopf has raised its stake in the Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation to 19 percent, or 1.1 million shares, from 13.79 percent.


SHULTZ DISCLOSES SECRET IRAN TALKS UNTIL LAST MONTH
LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said in a closed Congressional hearing today that as late as December, the United States was still using a secret channel involving C.I.A. officials to meet with Iranians despite the furor after the disclosure a month earlier of arms sales to Iran, committee members said.


WASHINGTON TALK: WORKING PROFILE: William L. Ball 3d; Taking Reagan Agenda To a New Capitol Hill
LEAD: In the late 1970's, William L. Ball 3d was working for Senator Herman Talmadge, a Georgia Democrat.
So when Ronald Reagan started a Republican landslide in 1980 that buried a dozen Democratic senators, including Mr.
Talmadge, the lawmaker's young aide was out of a job.

TIP LEADS TO THE ARREST OF RADICAL SOUGHT IN 1970 OREGON CASE
LEAD: A leader of the Weather Underground who had spent 17 years in hiding and was once listed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation as ''the most-wanted fugitive terrorist'' was arrested Monday in Eugene, Ore.


JAZZ: NEW YORK STRING TRIO
LEAD: THE String Trio of New York opened Sweet Basil's festival of new jazz, ''Music Is an Open Sky,'' with finely etched pieces that touched on classical and folk music.
Two-thirds of the trio - the bassist John Lindberg and the guitarist John Emery - have been together for 10 years; the violinist Charles Burnham recently replaced Billy Bang in the group.

Rescued Motorist Dies in Hospital
LEAD: A Long Island man who was saved from drowning Monday when his van slid off Interstate 95 and into a Connecticut river, died last night of heart failure at Yale-New Haven Hospital where he had been under intensive care since the accident, officials said.


Seals Trained as Rescue Aids
LEAD: One of the three harbor seals taught to retrieve guns, tools and other objects showing off its skills yesterday before police and public officials at the North Wind Undersea Institute on City Island in the Bronx.
Michael Sandlofer, captain of the institute, said with further training, the animals might also be used to help locate drowning victims, underwater wreckage of aircraft or vehicles and to deliver extra air tanks and tools from the surface to divers.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A picture caption yesterday with an article about President Reagan's involvement with the Iran arms affair incorrectly located the two men shown.
Senator Dave Durenberger was at the left and David M. Abshire at the right.


DE-ICING WITH SALT CAN HARM TREES
LEAD: AFTER a major snowstorm, many New Yorkers de-ice their walkways with rock salt.
But according to the New York City Street Tree Consortium, they may not be aware of the severe damage this can do to neighborhood street trees.


BONN HESITATES ON EXTRADITING TERROR SUSPECT
LEAD: There were signs today that the West German Government was hesitating to extradite an accused Lebanese terrorist being sought by the United States.


IN DALLAS, BUILDERS FIND LARGER IS BETTER
LEAD: A continuing trend toward larger and more expensive homes with custom kitchens, lavish bathrooms and fancy window installations was evident at this year's convention of the National Association of Home Builders.
The four-day event, which closed here Monday, attracted about 60,000 builders, architects, interior designers and contractors to the Dallas Convention


New Maryland Leader Sounds an Old Theme
LEAD: William D. Schaefer, the former Mayor of Baltimore, was sworn in today as Maryland's new Governor, sounding his familiar theme of putting people first and ''doing it now.''


CHARLES E. GOODELL, FORMER SENATOR, IS DEAD AT 60
LEAD: Charles E. Goodell, who shifted from establishment Republican to critic of the Vietnam War and the Nixon White House as he moved from the House of Representatives to representing New York in the United States Senate, died yesterday in Washington.
He was 60 years old and had been a Washington lawyer and lobbyist for the last 16 years.

LEAD: A father inclined to worry about his son finds reason to be grateful for the ultra-realistic Vietnam war movie ''Platoon.''

Chrysler Extension
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation said that it would extend indefinitely the cut-rate financing program that had been scheduled to end today.
The program offers financing as low as 3.9 percent for 24-month loans, or cash allowances of as much as $1,000.
The program applies to 1987 Dodge and Plymouth Colt E, DL and Premier models; Plymouth Reliants, and Dodge Aries, pickup trucks and Ramcharge sport utility vehicles.


Agency Reports Gust of Wind Caused Clipper Ship to Sink
LEAD: The 137-foot clipper ship Pride of Baltimore, which sank last spring leaving four crew members dead, was capsized by a powerful gust of wind, Federal safety investigators said today.


Puerto Rica Tourism Up
LEAD: Tourism in Puerto Rico appears to have been unaffected by the New Year's Eve fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel that killed 96 people, Mayor Baltasar Corrada del Rio of San Juan said today. ''This is very encouraging,'' he said, citing figures he said showed hotel occupancy rates increased about 12 percent in the first two weeks of January.


Closest Congressional Race Is Finally Settled in Indiana
LEAD: Representative John P. Hiler, Republican of Indiana, won a recount Tuesday in the nation's closest Congressional race by a margin of 47 votes, a state official said.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: N.B.A.
Jazz 112, Pistons 108: Karl Malone had 23 points and John Stockton sank two free throws with nine seconds left as Utah held back a late Detroit surge.
Detroit trailed, 109-99, with 2:50 left, but Isiah Thomas and Joe Dumars sparked a 9-1 Piston rally that closed the gap to 110-108 with 11 seconds left.


12 SOUTH AFRICAN BLACKS SLAIN IN HOME
LEAD: Assailants burst into a home in a black township near Durban today and opened fire with automatic weapons, killing 12 people, the police said.
Seven of the victims were children.


Perfect Blend
LEAD: One year after the State Department of Education lifted rules forbidding girls to play contact sports against boys, Lynn Auth, a senior at Edgemont High in Scarsdale, has nailed down a spot as a right wing on the school's hockey team.
And though her status as the only girl in the Westchester-Rockland Interscholastic Ice Hockey League may seem extraordinary to others, she's fully comfortable with it.


RACIAL VIOLENCE FOCUS OF BLACKS IN DAY OF PROTEST
LEAD: In moves protesting the racial attack in Howard Beach, Queens, last month, 3,000 marchers chanted noisily through Manhattan and small groups gathered to discuss racial violence.
But black shoppers, for the most part, ignored calls for a boycott of white-owned businesses.

Volvo's Profit Declines
LEAD: A.B.
Volvo, the Swedish car maker, today reported a small drop in 1986 sales and earnings, blaming the effects of a weakening dollar on the United States market.
Volvo's pretax earnings fell to $1.15 billion from 1985's $1.16 billion.

Zenith Expansion
LEAD: The Zenith Electronics Corporation said it would add 600 jobs at its plant in Melrose Park, Ill., a suburb, to build tubes used as computer monitors.
Production of the new tubes, which Zenith says are the first with a perfectly flat front, is scheduled to begin in the second quarter.
Zenith said $700,000 of job training aid from government agencies would help in the expansion.

In the drab space crowded with footlockers and bunk beds, half a dozen imprisoned Irish Republicans play Monopoly, swill homemade booze, bicker about politics and plot an underground escape.

STARTING OUT ON THE LONG ROAD BACK
LEAD: Questioners, dozens and dozens of questioners, milled about the football field at Orange Coast College as the Denver Broncos stood in the sunshine in their white uniforms.
The anxiety of a football game seemed a long way away.
Opinions were solicited on issues such as the size of a point spread and impressions of corporate America's sporting festival.


BANGKOK HOUSES PUT ON EUROPEAN AIRS
LEAD: A ROMAN extravanganza, a cosy corner of Bavaria, the whitewashed stucco of Iberia: they could all be part of a Floridian fantasy or the makings of a southern California developer's brochure.
But these aren't.
They are the most sought-after homes of Bangkok's newly rich.


Authors, Artists, Amateurs and Women
LEAD: Several years ago, members of the 139-year-old Century Association in New York City conducted a correspondence so felicitously phrased that it would have done credit to the young Henry James.
On one side were those who would admit women. ''It is our belief,'' they said, ''that the fundamental pleasures of the Century as a gathering place for cultivated people will not change if we acknowledge an important fact, that the worlds of 'authors, artists and amateurs' include women as well as men.

PASSIONATE COLLECTORS SET NEW AUCTION HIGHS
LEAD: IN 1986, period decorative arts commanded million-dollar prices at auction more often than they ever had before - not once or twice, but six times.
Remarkable seven-figure prices were paid for an American table and a wing chair, a German jeweled box, a British silver epergne, a French drop-front secretary and a Chinese porcelain dish.

Surgeons Strike in Italy
LEAD: Thousands of Italian surgeons refused today to operate except in urgent cases, in the latest of a series of nationwide medical strikes.

INSIDE
LEAD: C.I.A.
Chief's Illness  William J. Casey was treated for prostate cancer for nearly a year before his brain tumor operation, an Administration official said.
Page A20.
Inflation Slowed in 1986  Consumer prices rose 0.2 percent in December, leaving 1986 with the smallest annual rise in the inflation rate in a quarter century.


NETS' LOSING STREAK IS ENDED
LEAD: The losing finally ended tonight.
The Nets, whose season has been one losing streak after another, surged and held off the Phoenix Suns, 120-114, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

MUSIC: ROYAL PHILHARMONIC ORCHESTRA
LEAD: DVORAK'S concerto not excepted, there is no work in the cello literature that allows such latitude and variety in interpretation as ''Don Quixote,'' which Lynn Harrell performed last evening with the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra at Carnegie Hall.
Although Strauss cast this remarkable piece in the shape of an introduction, theme with 10 variations and finale, the most memorable readings of it treat it as a series of whimsical and pathos-laden adventures in which the formal workings-out are less prominent than a sense of tragicomic drama and shameless theatricality.

Three Quintuplets Are Dead
LEAD: Three quintuplets born 12 weeks prematurely died today while a team of doctors and nurses worked to keep a day-old brother and sister alive.

HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: SMALL hand-held electric grinders - rotary power tools that look something like a dentist's drill - have long been popular with hobbyists and craftsmen who carve or build models.
However, these versatile little tools are also handy for small maintenance and repair jobs around the house.
Sometimes they make it possible to complete a job that would otherwise be almost impossible.

LEAD: Arizona was notable by its absence from the ranks of states celebrating Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday this year.
The new Governor, Evan Mecham, in his first official act canceled the state holiday that former Gov.
Bruce Babbitt decreed last year.
Now, in a simple but eloquent protest, Democratic National Chairman Paul Kirk has moved a party council meeting that was scheduled for next month in


Educational Bonds For Penn Offered
LEAD: The Pennsylvania Higher Education Facilities Authority is offering $128.56 million of refunding bonds on behalf of the University of Pennsylvania through a group of underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.
A maximum yield of 6.741 percent is offered for 6 5/8 percent bonds due in 2017 at a price of 98 1/2.


Dooley to Wake Forest
LEAD: Bill Dooley, who left Virginia Tech on Jan. 1 after a contractual disagreement, was named head football coach at Wake Forest yesterday.
Dooley, 52 years old, replaced Al Groh, who resigned last week after Wake Forest refused to renew his contract.
For Dooley, it will be his second tenure in the Atlantic Coast Conference.

LEAD: The New York City Municipal Water Finance Authority is offering $387.3 million of revenue bonds with a maximum yield tentatively set at 7.017 percent for bonds due in 2015 through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

Baker Seeks Simpler W-4
LEAD: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d called the new four-page W-4 form for calculating wage withholding taxes ''too complicated'' and said he had ordered the Internal Revenue Service to see if it could be simplified.


ART: ROTHENBERG HORSES AT THE GAGOSIAN GALLERY
LEAD: IT is more than a decade now since Susan Rothenberg's horses began appearing in galleries and museums.
They were peculiar creatures.
They looked like horses, but they were invariably flat, featureless and tailless, and they stood and rocked in dense, nondescript spaces.
There was nothing romantic about them, but they were not anti-romantic either, and here and there they nodded in the direction of their illustrious ancestors.


Ah, New Mexico
LEAD: Ordinarily, pride in the home state flourishes almost uncontrolled in Congress.
Preposterous bets are made on the floor involving interstate sporting contests like the Superbowl.
Senators nearly come to blows over the relative virtues of their states' farm products or industrial prowesses.
Which is why the pending resolution on New Mexico's 75th anniversary as a state is so unusual.
