Gulf Canada Plan
LEAD: The Gulf Canada Corporation, a Canadian holding company, announced its restructuring into three companies in a move that is expected to strip debt from its oil and gas business and increase its shareholder value.
Gulf Canada proposed to spin off its oil and gas division into a publicly traded company that will resume oil exploration off Canada's Arctic coast.

LEAD: IN Christopher Blake's ''Taster's Choice,'' James Jenner plays a food critic who has completely lost his sense of taste and smell.

Players Gearing Up For Contract Talks
LEAD: Leaders of the National Football League players union said today that they would do everything possible to avoid another strike but that intransigence by the owners could force them into one.


A BIG-BAND WEEKEND IN TWO BOROUGHS
LEAD: BIG bands - a term for jazz-related orchestras of 10 to 25 musicians - were popular once, as popular as today's heavy-metal rock and heavily amplified folk-rock.
But the public grew tired of hearing shouting trumpets, thundering drummers and fast, flashy unison passages for saxophones.
Which is a shame, because many swing-band fans of the 30's and 40's rarely got to hear what a creative big band is really capable of.


A Job for Parents
LEAD: To the Editor:


BANKAMERICA REPORTS PROFIT, ON SPECIAL GAINS
LEAD: The BankAmerica Corporation, ending a nightmare of a year on a slightly bright note, returned to profitability in the fourth quarter of 1986, though only because of special gains.


Looking to Bonn for Bravery
LEAD: Terrorists are pressing West Germany not to extradite Mohammed Ali Hamadei, a Lebanese accused of participating in the 1985 T.W.A. hijacking and the killing of an American passenger.
Release him, the terrorists insist, backing up their demands by kidnapping two German businessmen.


NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JANUARY 23, 1987
LEAD: International


PREGNANCY CENTERS: ANTI-ABORTION ROLE CHALLENGED
LEAD: The advertisement in the Yellow Pages asked if she was ''thinking of an abortion,'' which the schoolteacher was.
So she visited the AAA Pregnancy Problem center in Brooklyn, where a counselor advocated child birth and chastity, with pamphlets and pictures to buttress the appeal.


Jakarta Gymnastics By Any Other Name
LEAD: President Suharto of Indonesia has put an end to the controversy over the use of Chinese fitness techniques by ordering that the exercises be given Indonesian names, The Jakarta Post reported today.


MANY PORTS IN THE STORM, BUT MOST OF THEM ARE ALREADY FILLED
LEAD: For those who never made it home last night, refuge from the storm could be found in a hotel, on a couch, or on an office desk.


Boxing Notebook; TORRES WANTS AN ARBITRATOR FOR CONFLICTS
LEAD: When Don King promoted the Tim Witherspoon-James (Bonecrusher) Smith heavyweight title fight last month in which his son, Carl, had managerial interests in both fighters, the words ''conflict of interest'' were beaten like a drum.


ART: JOSEPH CORNELL'S BOXED EPHEMERA COLLAGES
LEAD: LIKE a tropical fish exposed to the air, a Joseph Cornell exhibition reviewed loses its luster as well as its life.
Art - or the ritual of its appreciation - is not the element of these boxed ephemera, perhaps because they themselves don't behave like art.
Most come in clusters for, as John Bernard Myers has pointed out, ''continuity and repetition were necessary to the unfolding of the basic theme, to the vision,'' yet each remains a little magnetic field on its own.


Infinity in a Flake
LEAD: Walk out into the newly fallen snow and, without feeling a crunch under your foot, you will be crushing thousands on thousands of nature's most marvelously varied creations.
The snowflake is the product of nothing but water, dust and changing air.
Yet from this prosaic mix come structures of intricate design and patterned beauty.


ART: DAVID SALLE'S WORKS SHOWN AT THE WHITNEY
LEAD: THE exhibition of David Salle's work that has just opened at the Whitney Museum of American Art (945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street) and will be on view there through March 29, is a sobering, exhilarating event, full of handsome, intelligently made paintings that mirror contemporary life in ways we cannot help but find poignant, jarring and sometimes offensive.

Racing Notebook; Cordero Sticking to a Selective Schedule
LEAD: Angel Cordero rode a big gray horse into the paddock for a minor race here one day last week and, as always, his fans yelled out some encouragement. ''Hi-ho, Silver!'' one called out. ''Oh yeah, that's me,'' Cordero replied, half to himself. ''The Puerto Rican Lone Ranger - in living color.''

LEAD: As top Republican Party officials met here in an unusally low-key session that reflected the party's recent setbacks, President Reagan was preparing a State of the Union Message that one adviser said today could be a ''seminal event'' in Mr.
Reagan's struggle to regain his political footing.


PROBLEM ARISES IN DRUG TESTS IN TRAIN WRECK
LEAD: Federal investigators may be unable to determine precisely when a Conrail crew member involved in a fatal train collision this month last used the marijuana detected in his blood and urine, the chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

Last Friday, Mr.
Taylor said Washington had urged Paraguay to reinstate an independent radio station and a banned newspaper.

LEAD: His voice reduced by laryngitis to a rasping croak - ''a mixture of Willy Brandt and Louis Armstrong,'' he says - Johannes Rau goes bravely through the motions of pretending that he expects to be become Chancellor after the national election on Sunday.


A.T.&amp;T. Spending
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it planned to spend about $2.5 billion in 1987 to expand its digital long-distance telephone network.
Industry analysts said the announced expansion was a direct response to the aggressive marketing tactics of US Sprint.
A.T.&amp;T. has 11,000 miles of fiber optic lines in service and plans to build another 24,000 miles by 1989, when the company would offer digital service to 350 cities.


UConn Search Begins
LEAD: Under mounting criticism of its educational support program for athletes and widespread calls for departmental change, the University of Connecticut announced yesterday that it is launching a nationwide search to replace Athletic Director John L. Toner.
Toner, a past president of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, will relinquish his responsibilities as athletic director effective June 30 but continue to oversee the completion of a new campus sports complex.


4TH-QUARTER G.N.P. UP A SLUGGISH 1.7%
LEAD: The nation's economy grew at an anemic 1.7 percent rate in the final three months of 1986, the Commerce Department reported today, a weaker showing than the Reagan Administration and private economists had expected.


BROADWAY
LEAD: IT'S always great to hear something positive, especially in a season that hasn't been studded with hits.
The something positive in this case is a new theater, a dream come true for a 26-year-old theater buff who believes that Broadway became what it was because of young innovators and young blood.

BURT HAS HIS MEMORIES OF GOOD TIMES AND BAD
LEAD: The essence of Jim Burt has been captured in two distinct portraits during these playoffs.
He was the little boy in a football uniform skipping merrily across the field to the locker room after the Giants defeated the Redskins for the National Conference championship Jan. 11, having climbed into the stands earlier to share the victory with his wife and some fans.


POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
LEAD: New Orleans Funeral and Ragtime Orchestra, Vineyard Theater, 309 East 28th Street (683-0696).
On Sunday afternoon, the New Orleans Funeral and Ragtime Orchestra makes one of its rare excursions away from Michael's Pub, where it has been playing on Monday nights for 14 years.
This is the band with which Woody Allen plays clarinet at the Pub.


Soviet Says It Is Terminating Jamming of BBC Broadcasts
LEAD: Gennadi I. Gerasimov, the Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, announced today that Russian-language broadcasts of the British Broadcasting Corporation would no longer be jammed.


RALLY AGAINST ABORTION HEARS PLEDGE OF SUPPORT BY REAGAN
LEAD: President Reagan pledged his continued support to thousands of people rallying here today to protest abortion, saying he would work with them to overturn the Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion and to ''end this national tragedy.''


BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Chevron Corp., San Francisco, and Texaco Inc. said P.T.
Caltex Pacific Indonesia, a jointly owned affiliate, had discovered oil at two sites on the Indonesian island of Sumatra.
The output is expected to total 1,800 barrels a day.


SENATE PANEL ON IRAN NAMES NEW YORK LAWYER AS COUNSEL
LEAD: A New York City criminal lawyer who has represented many prominent public figures and directed several government inquiries was named today to be chief counsel of the special Senate committee investigating the Iran-contra affair.


RECITAL: CAROL WILSON
LEAD: CAROL WILSON, a soprano on the faculty of Vassar College, made her New York debut Tuesday in Weill Recital Hall.
She is, as her program of Nin, Mussorgsky, Poulenc, Schubert, Ives and Richard Wilson demonstrated, a thoughtful singer of discriminating curiosity, but she could develop further in the direction of effective vocal communication of the songs to which she is drawn.


Glemp Is Invited to Moscow; He Cites Too Busy a Calendar
LEAD: Jozef Cardinal Glemp, the Roman Catholic Primate, said today that he had been invited to attend a peace symposium in Moscow next month, but had declined because of a crowded calendar.


AUCTIONS
LEAD: ''WHY is this desk a Philadelphia piece and not a New York piece?''

RJR Nabisco Debentures
LEAD: RJR Nabisco Inc. is offering $500 million of 8 3/8 percent sinking-fund debentures due in 2017 at a price of 97 3/8 to yield 8.62 percent through underwriters led by Dillon, Read &amp; Company.


Environmental Groups Urge Ban on Pesticide
LEAD: A coalition of environmental groups released a study Wednesday demonstrating that a widely used pesticide caused cancer in animals and asked that the pesticide be removed from the market.


Essence Bans Ads Of Revlon
LEAD: ESSENCE COMMUNICATIONS, publishers of Essence, a magazine for black women, has announced that it will ban further advertising by Revlon from its pages because of a remark attributed to its president, Irving J. Bottner, last October.
A Revlon spokesman said that Mr.
Bottner had immediately apologized for the remark, saying that it was taken out of context.

YEAR-OLD SEX CASE IN BRITAIN STIRS CONCERN OVER U.S. TIES
LEAD: A sex-offense case involving a British child and the husband of an American diplomat formerly based in London came to light this week and immediately attracted national attention.


Some Feet
LEAD: When Darrick Heath thinks he has a kick coming, he takes it.
Heath, a 6-foot-5-inch forward for C. W. Post and a black belt in karate, was so incensed by a call in a recent game at Gannon University of Pennsylvania that, having carefully placed the ball on the court, he hurled himself into the air and unleashed a kick that missed the side of the backboard by less than an inch.

Diner's Journal
LEAD: IF the Japanese have an equivalent for the voguish American-style open grill restaurant, it is the yakitori bar, where meat and seafood are barbecued and served with various sauces.
One such grill opened two weeks ago, called Haru, at 165 West 72d Street.
This sleek new spot, with mirrored walls, black banquettes, track lighting and shocking pink tables, offers a full range of sushi, sashimi and other Japanese standards in addition to the grilled foods.


CITY EXAMINES DEATHS OF 2 INFANTS IN FOSTER HOMES
LEAD: The New York City Human Resources Administration said yesterday that it was investigating the deaths of two babies who died shortly after they were placed in separate foster homes by a Roman Catholic organization in Brooklyn.

BOOKS OF THE TIMES
LEAD: CHARADE. By John Mortimer. 188 pages.


MORRIS GETS AHEAD BY SLOWING DOWN
LEAD: At first glance, it would seem that Joe Morris of the Giants - whom general manager George Young calls ''our home-run runner'' - contradicts the accepted verity that patience is a virtue.


USX Raises Prices
LEAD: The USX Corporation's steel unit announced increases in the published prices of steel products effective May 5.
USX said the increases, which averaged 3 to 5 percent, would be $15 a ton on hot-rolled steel, $20 a ton on cold-rolled products and $30 a ton on coated steel products.
The company said it did not plan to discount its steel products to recapture the market share it lost during a six-month labor shutdown.


Illinois Pulls Funds From First Chicago
LEAD: The Treasurer of Illinois withdrew almost $220 million in state deposits from the First National Bank of Chicago to protest its 19.8 percent credit-card interest rate. ''Illinois taxpayers will not help fund their gouging of consumers any longer,'' Jerome Cosentino said, making good on a campaign promise 10 days after he took office.


IN STORM, WARMING TRENDS
LEAD: Some were smiling, some were grim, as they struggled through the snowstorm.
Hats were an asset, umbrellas a handicap, as the snow blew in at every angle.


Real Estate; Slim, High Building in Manhattan
LEAD: IT comes as no surprise to people familiar with the difficulty of assembling sites for development in Manhattan that many new buildings are slim and high.
The merger of zoning lots makes it possible to continue residential development in locations with high land values without demolishing all the buildings on the site, which would dispossess all tenants.

Chase to Close 21 Branches
LEAD: The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that it would close 21 of its 230 branches in the New York metropolitan area.

AMERICAN EXPRESS HAS GAIN
LEAD: Two of the nation's leading financial services concerns, the American Express Company and the Morgan Stanley Group, yesterday announced higher earnings for the fourth quarter of 1986.


O'Connor's Mideast Visit a Harbinger of Hope
LEAD: To the Editor:


California Federal Gets A President and Chief
LEAD: William L. Callender has been elected president and chief executive of California Federal Savings and Loan Association, the nation's fourth-largest thrift institution.


U S West's Net Is Flat for Year
LEAD: U S West Inc., which provides local telephone service to the Pacific Northwest, Rocky Mountain and Great Plains states, said yesterday that its earnings were flat in 1986 because of a $52 million restructuring charge it took in the fourth quarter.
The after-tax charge is the result of the company's decision to market its information and communications services solely within its servicing area.


BONN CUTS BASIC RATE HALF-POINT
LEAD: West Germany's Bundesbank approved today a package of monetary measures including a half-point cut in its basic interest rate, to 3 percent.


FILM: TECHINE'S 'SCENE OF THE CRIME'
LEAD: ''Scene of the Crime'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival.
Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times Sept. 27, 1986.
The film opens today at the Lincoln Plaza, Broadway at 63d Street.
ANDRE TECHINE'S elegant thriller ''Scene of the Crime'' is alive with danger and sexual possibility, in a manner reminiscent of Claude Chabrol.


THE SCREEN: BRUCE BERESFORD'S 'FRINGE DWELLERS'
LEAD: WITH ''The Fringe Dwellers,'' Bruce Beresford, whose American films have been a mixed bag ranging from ''Tender Mercies'' to ''King David,'' returns to his native Australia to make a small, graceful, low-keyed drama about the lives of contemporary aborigines.

Long-Term Treasuries Lower
LEAD: Renewed weakness in the dollar sent Treasury note and bond prices lower yesterday, even though data on fourth-quarter G.N.P. was weaker than forecast and heightened expectations of anemic growth in the first quarter.


RECORD FLIGHT IN CALIFORNIA:
LEAD: Glenn Tremml, a medical student, pedaling the lightweight airplane Eagle yesterday at Edwards Air Force Base.
The 92-pound plane was flown for 37.2 miles, unofficially breaking the world record for human-powered flight.


SOVIET CUTS OIL EXPORTS, SAYING IT BACKS OPEC
LEAD: The Soviet Union announced today that it had agreed to cut its oil exports to help OPEC increase world oil prices.


Czechs' Rights Movement: 10 Years of Struggle
LEAD: Charter 77 - the Czechoslovak human rights movement - is 10 years old this month.
It has endured longer than any other human rights movement in Eastern Europe.
This fact seems all the more remarkable, given the nature of the Czechoslovak regime.
Any hope for change in Czechoslovakia resides with the charter movement rather than in outside influences coming from either the East or the West.


A's Seek Gedman
LEAD: After meeting with Rich Gedman, the free-agent catcher, Sandy Alderson, the general manager of the Oakland A's, said the team's chances of signing him were 50-50.
Gedman, who batted .258 for the Boston Red Sox last season and .295 the previous season, was in Oakland on Tuesday and Wednesday with his agent, Jack Sands.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A front-page picture caption on Wednesday about the new Lila Acheson Wallace Wing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art omitted the identities of artists for two works shown.
The sculpture at right foreground was Eduardo Chillida's ''Silent Music II,'' and the work at left was Martin Puryear's ''Tango.


NAVRATILOVA GAINS FINAL IN AUSTRALIA
LEAD: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova breezed to victory and second-seeded Hana Mandlikova had a one-set lapse as they won semifinal matches today and advanced to the final in the Australian Open.


DONATIONS TO NEEDIEST CASES SURPASS RECORD SET IN 1986
LEAD: Contributions to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have exceeded the record of $2,702.695.23 received in the previous appeal.
That amount was reached in late February last year.
As of yesterday, gifts to the 75th appeal totaled $2,717,840.96.

Pictures Raise News Issue
LEAD: After the Pennsylvania Treasurer, R. Budd Dwyer, shot himself to death, cameras provided a graphic record for newspapers and television, confronting the news media with a decision of whether to use the images.


Surgery for Sutter
LEAD: Bruce Sutter, the Atlanta Braves relief pitcher, plans to undergo a third operation on his shoulder in an attempt to save his career.
The surgery will be performed, possibly within the next week, at the University of Colorado Health Center, according to Bobby Cox, the Braves' general manager.
Cox said that the right-hander would not pitch for the team in 1987, but might return the following season.

MCI Cuts Rates For Long Distance
LEAD: MCI Communications, the nation's second-largest provider of long-distance service, is cutting its rates by an average of 10 percent, following a similar reduction last month by the industry leader, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
MCI's cuts, totaling $250 million, will take effect over the next two months.


MAJOR POWER STRUGGLE IS REPORTED AMONG NICARAGUA REBEL LEADERS
LEAD: A power struggle is again splitting the Nicaraguan guerrilla movement, threatening its leadership at a time when it is trying to stage an offensive, according to American and rebel officials.


Market Place; Stock Analysts Raising Sights
LEAD: SOME technical analysts - those professionals who study investor sentiment and the internal workings of the stock market - believe that equity prices, despite yesterday's explosive action, are headed still higher.


RESIDENCY LAW ON TOP OFFICIALS SIGNED BY KEAN
LEAD: Governor Kean signed a bill today requiring members of his Cabinet and of the state Judiciary and Legislature to maintain their principal residence in New Jersey.

THE EVENING HOURS
LEAD: ''EVERYONE'S Rolodex is here.'' That's how an official of the Metropolitan Museum of Art described the crush of invited guests at the opening of the Lila Acheson Wallace Wing for 20th-century art.
Nearly 3,000 people, including artists, dealers, collectors, donors and business leaders, turned out for a look at the new galleries and cocktails and dcici a afterwa.


WEINBERGER WARNS OF GAINS IN SOVIET SPACE TECHNOLOGY
LEAD: Making his most specific and spirited arguments yet for an early deployment of a space-based defense against nuclear missiles, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that ''we must seize this opportunity'' because the chance to stay ahead of Soviet technology ''will not remain with us forever.


Largest of 'Sunflowers' By van Gogh to Be Sold
LEAD: Vincent van Gogh's ''Sunflowers'' - the largest of seven painted by the artist in 1888 and 1889 at Arles, France - will be auctioned by Christie's in London on March 30, Christopher Burge, the president of Christie's in New York, announced yesterday.


FLOOR PRICE PROPOSED
LEAD: A plan to provide greater energy security -first proposed by the Ford Administration in the mid-1970's - was revived before a Congressional committee today by James R. Schlesinger, who served as Energy Secretary in the Carter Administration.


NETWORK STAKE SOLD BY TURNER
LEAD: In a move that keeps Ted Turner in control of the Turner Broadcasting System, the company said yesterday that it had received $550 million in financing from cable operators and Kirk Kerkorian.

POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
LEAD: Les Skah Shah, Sounds of Brazil, 204 Varick Street (243-4940).
Haitian rock lilts unlike anything else in the Caribbean, cruising along at medium tempos with a rhythm that, sooner or later, insinuates itself into every listener's hips.
The Haitian compas direct beat is related to the Dominican Republic's merengue (from the other half of the island), but where the merengue has grown more and more uproarious, the compas direct has grown suaver.


H.R.A. CHIEF ORDERS REVIEW
LEAD: The city Human Resources Administrator, William J. Grinker, has ordered a major re-evaluation of how his agency delivers services to families and children.


Church's Son Pleads Guilty
LEAD: Chase Church, a son of Senator Frank Church of Idaho, now dead, has pleaded guilty to growing hallucinogenic ''magic mushrooms.'' Mr.
Church, 29 years old, of Bethesda, Md., was arrested at his family's home in June.
The police said the mushrooms contained the illegal substance psilocybin.
Mr.
Church pleaded guilty Tuesday in Chester County to one count of manufacturing a controlled substance.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''The Administration is taking and will take criticism of why its foreign policy went wrong.


Judge Rules For Panhandle
LEAD: An administrative law judge of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission yesterday absolved the Panhandle Eastern Corporation, the Houston-based pipeline company, of discriminatory procedures in transporting natural gas to industrial and utility customers in the Middle West.

AUTHORITIES INVESTIGATING REPORTS OF L.I. AND QUEENS RACIAL ATTACKS
LEAD: In unrelated incidents carrying overtones of last month's Howard Beach racial attack, the police reported yesterday an assault on blacks by white youths in Deer Park, L.I., and an attack on white teen-agers by young blacks in Jamaica, Queens.


A WORLD IN MANY MEDIA: IT'S 'THE BIG PICTURE'
LEAD: ''When I moved to New York in 1977, it was my first trip outside of Japan, and I didn't speak any English,'' the choreographer Yoshiko Chuma recalled the other day. ''It was a tremendous shock to come to here.
I felt I was in the middle of a nonstop performance.''


SCHEDULE OF 'FOCUS!' CONCERTS
LEAD: ''Focus!
Music in the Melting Pot: Immigration and Interaction,'' a series of concerts with dance and musical theater, opens tonight and closes next Friday at Alice Tully Hall.
Other performances will be at the Juilliard Theater.
All peformances are at 8 P.M.
For information on obtaining tickets, which are free: 874-7515 or 874-0465.


G.M. Announces Improved Warranty
LEAD: In an apparent effort to increase its sales and improve its image for workmanship, the General Motors Corporation said today that it would extend the warranty on major mechanical components from three years and 36,000 miles to six years and 60,000 miles on all of its 1987 cars built in North America.


Corrections
LEAD: A listing of reading scores for New York City's elementary and junior high schools in some copies yesterday omitted explanations for results marked with asterisks.
Students with a limited proficiency in English who have been in the school system less than a year were excused from the test, and their scores were automatically put below grade level.


AUDIT FINDS 7% DROP IN ANTI-SEMITIC VIOLENCE
LEAD: Acts of anti-Semitic vandalism against Jews and Jewish property in the United States declined 7 percent last year, the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith reported yesterday in its eighth annual audit of such incidents around the country.

Koch Praises Parking Violations Bureau
LEAD: Mayor Koch was joined by Ross Sandler, left, Commissioner of Transportation, and Joseph Bruno, head of the Parking Violations Bureau, in looking over the shoulder of Laren Patterson at his microfilm console.
Mr.
Koch toured the revamped agency and commended the director and workers for restoring public confidence since the corruption scandal last year.


GUINNESS GETS OFFER BY ARGYLL
LEAD: Guinness P.L.C., the British brewer, announced today that it had received a merger offer from the Argyll Group P.L.C. -the same company Guinness beat out last year in a takeover battle for the Distillers Company.
Guinness said it had turned down the offer.


What Not to Learn From Japanese Schools
LEAD: To the Editor:


BUREAUCRACY JUST ANOTHER MACHINE STALLED IN SNOW AT NATION'S CAPITAL
LEAD: A snowstorm today did what six years of the Reagan Administration's deregulation efforts had failed to accomplish.
It got the Government off the nation's back - at least the part that works in the capital.


334 Watch Devils Win
LEAD: Doug Sulliman scored three goals tonight to help the Devils post a 7-4 comeback victory in a game delayed almost two hours by the heavy snowstorm that hit the area.


All Eyes on Wright and His Brows
LEAD: In a top-secret meeting with Jim Wright the other day, several Democratic strategists gazed at the new Speaker of the House of Representatives and wondered how his bushy eyebrows would play on television.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article yesterday about a march in Manhattan to protest racial violence misidentified the police commander who estimated the crowd.
He is Assistant Chief Arthur J. McNevin, commander of the Manhattan South patrol borough.


SUPERVISORS UNION REACHES AGREEMENT WITH L.I.R.R.
LEAD: The Long Island Rail Road reached agreement yesterday with another union, the supervisors, as a swirling snowstorm made the fifth day of the strike the roughest yet for commuters.


WHITE HOUSE OFFICIALS SHOW IRRITATION WITH SHULTZ
LEAD: White House officials expressed irritation today with Secretary of State George P. Shultz, saying he was trying to shirk responsibility for the Iran arms deal.

GEORGIA COUNTY BRACING FOR TROUBLE
LEAD: Two members of the Southern White Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, wearing starched and pressed combat fatigues, sat in a restuarant Wednesday night in Cumming, Ga., and, as snow began to swirl outside, considered the likelihood of trouble when thousands of people gather this Saturday for a ''march against fear and intimidation'' in Forsyth


Alcoa, Inland Have Profits
LEAD: Two large and beleaguered companies in basic industries - Inland Steel and Alcoa - yesterday reported fourth-quarter profits after having had losses in the 1985 period.


Hokkaido Records a Tremor
LEAD: An earthquake registering 5.3 on the Richter scale shook Nemuro on the island of Hokkaido today, but there were no immediate reports of damage or injuries.
The Central Meteorological Agency said the center was in the sea about 35 miles off the Nemuro peninsula.


WEBSTER'S RELAPSE CAUSES CONCERN
LEAD: Coach Tom Webster of the Rangers, while on the team's commercial flight today to Edmonton from Vancouver, British Columbia, today, suffered a relapse of the inner-ear infection that has troubled him since soon after he was hired in November.
There is now the possibility that he will not be permitted to fly again this season and will therefore not be able to serve as coach.


FINANCE BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Credithrift Financial Corp. is offering $100 million of 7 3/4 percent non-callable notes due 1997 at 99.65 to yield 7.80 percent through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
The notes, rated A-1/A+, yield 78-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities of a similar maturity.

Happy Returns
LEAD: Three years ago, Ladell Anderson, basketball coach at Brigham Young University, watched helplessly as a debilitating total of seven of his best players left school on missions of the Mormon Church.
Anderson kept the program going for two years with junior-college transfers, and this season, patience is paying rewards.

Failing Promise of Junior College
LEAD: Community colleges were supposed to be the cutting edge of the democratizing reforms that swept higher education in the 1960's.
These two-year institutions were to be gateways to higher learning, affordable and accessible to all.
Over the years they often became academic dead ends, especially for the minority members who rely on them most heavily.


MAGUY MARIN'S DOLL'S-EYE VIEW OF 'CINDERELLA'
LEAD: IN the dance boom that has burst over France in the 1980's, there is one choreographer who stands apart.
Most would say that Maguy Marin does so because of her fiercely original talent, especially in the theatrical approach she takes toward modern dance.

Rockland Center Plans 40th-Year Programs
LEAD: The Rockland Center for the Arts is celebrating its 40th anniversary, and tomorrow at 8 P.M., the center will present the first of a number of special events that will be held throughout the year - a lecture by the writer Toni Morrison.
Miss Morrison is a prize-winning novelist, playwright and Albert Schweitzer Professor at the State University of New York at Albany.

OFFICIAL CALLS IN PRESS AND KILLS HIMSELF
LEAD: R. Budd Dwyer, the Pennsylvania State Treasurer, whose conviction for bribery last month jolted the state's Republican Party, shot and killed himself today at a news conference in his office in Harrisburg, the state capital.


STRIKE MESSAGE IS MIXED FOR REGION'S MARCHANTS
LEAD: While phones rang and reservations poured in at Direct Line Commuter ferry during yesterday's snowstorm, at Pennsylvania Station only four customers were in Pete Smith's Hall of Fame cocktail lounge across from Long Island Rail Road Tracks 13-17.


Septien Indicted
LEAD: The Dallas Cowboys' kicker, Rafael Septien, was indicted on charges of aggravated sexual assault, accused of molesting a 10-year-old girl, according to the Denton County (Tex.) District Attorney, Jerry Cobb.
If convicted, Septien could be sentenced to up to life imprisonment and fined $2,000, Cobb said.

LEAD: Under the palm trees of the peach-colored resort, Coach Dan Reeves and his laconic style are suited perfectly to the role of underdog.

NEXT: A SHOP-AT-HOME LOAN
LEAD: Picture this.
Right after viewers of the Home Shopping Network television show have snatched up an allotment of zirconium rings, and before a shipment of ceramic figurines from Capodimonte, Italy, is put up for sale, the announcer offers, of all things, a cheap car loan.


The Governor's Thermometer
LEAD: Governor Cuomo's 1987-88 New York budget proposal includes a plan that could interest governors all over the country.
He would install a large painted thermometer on the state Capitol lawn.
It would register the level of surplus funds to be returned to taxpayers when revenues exceed state spending.

President to Resign At American Can
LEAD: Frank J. Connor, president of the American Can Company, announced yesterday that he would leave March 1 to pursue other business interests.


U.S. Is Still Excluding People for Their Beliefs
LEAD: To the Editor:


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about earnings at big banking companies omitted a major qualification involving results for the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation.


Insurance Broker Case Is Settled
LEAD: Two former executives of the Marsh &amp; McLennan Companies, the insurance broker, settled Federal charges that they had falsified company records to hide millions of dollars in bond trading losses.
Marsh &amp; McLennan also signed a consent decree and agreed to establish new accounting and control procedures.


Hagler Gets a Scare
LEAD: Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the middleweight champion, left for his Palm Springs, Calif., training camp hours after surviving a scare on the Southeast Expressway near Boston.
Hagler's car skidded on an icy patch about 2 A.M.
Wednesday and banged into a concrete barrier, but the boxer was not hurt.
Hagler was heading toward his home in Hanover, Mass., after visiting friends in Boston when the accident occurred, The Boston Herald said.

Beyond Child Support
LEAD: To the Editor:


PURDUE SURVIVES IN OVERTIME
LEAD: Purdue's Kip Jones made the winning free throw with less than one second to play in overtime tonight and Doug Altenberger of Illinois missed a technical foul shot after that as Purdue won, 87-86, in a Big Ten game.


OUSTED JUDGE IS DENIED PAROLE
LEAD: Harry E. Claiborne, the Federal district judge impeached and removed from office last year, has lost his final bid for parole, the Justice Department announced Wednesday.


FOR ANTIQUES SHOW, IDEAS, IDEAS, IDEAS
LEAD: For the last three days the Seventh Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and 67th Street has been a sea of movers, painters and electricians.
Louis XV commodes and 19th-century armchairs, crates of porcelains and bundles of quilts have sailed from one end of the vast drill hall to another.
Indeed, the days before the opening of the Winter Antiques Show are spent magically transforming blank space into a labyrinth of creative showcases.

International Music
LEAD: The World Music Institute (206-1050) will present two concerts in its ''Music Around the Mediterranean'' series this weekend at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center, 179 Varick Street (691-9510).
Tomorrow at 8 P.M., there will be a concert of Lebanese music and dance featuring the oud (lute) players Mansour Ajami and Simon Shaheen and the nay (reed flute) player Jihad Racy.


WHITHER CHINA? WATCH TICKER TAPE
LEAD: This bustling British territory, which will become a part of China in just a decade, has been nervously eyeing the turmoil across its border in the last few weeks.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $168.9 million, to $234.43 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 91 institutional funds were down $25.0 million, to $64.99 billion.
Assets of the 195 general purpose funds were up $142.0 million, to $62.52 billion.


Let's Warm Up Relations With Eastern Europe
LEAD: A very strong case can now be made for reinvigorating United States relations with Eastern Europe.
The region is at a critical juncture, and the Administration has made a timely appointment in giving a high-level State Department official - Deputy Secretary of State John C. Whitehead - special responsibility for its policy there.


STORM'S SWIFTNESS A FACTOR
LEAD: The winter storm that pounded the Eastern Seaboard yesterday was the kind that can sometimes be more destructive than hurricanes, in terms of damage caused by high seas and coastal erosion.


Faculty Calls Foul on Knight
LEAD: Bob Knight has a temper, and as one who sets high standards for his Indiana University players (and even higher standards for referees), he has frequent occasions to lose it.
That, coupled with a coaching style that might best be described as leadership through intimidation, has helped him mold winning basketball teams.


MORALITY URGED IN SEX EDUCATION
LEAD: Secretary of Education William J. Bennett called on school boards today to insist that sex education courses teach children not to engage in sexual intercourse.


RESTAURANTS
LEAD: QUO VADIS, once the dolled-up doyenne of the East Side gentry, has tossed off her ankle-length gown and donned a bathing suit and white-rimmed sunglasses, California cool, in hopes of winning favor with the fickle new generation of diners.
The classic Italian cuisine that nurtured her habitues in the 1960's is a faint memory, replaced by such modern juxtapositions as ''sushi of wild rice and crisp vegetables'' and ''Dover sole spaghetti served with shrimp Bolognese.


FILM: 'SWEET COUNTRY'
LEAD: THE suffering of destitute, undernourished, ignorant and despairing peons amounts to nothing when compared to the ghastly emotional distress suffered by those liberal members of the haute bourgeoisie who care deeply about mankind.


TROOPS IN MANILA KILL 12 IN CROWD AT LEFTIST RALLY
LEAD: In the first such incident since President Corazon C. Aquino came to power 11 months ago, troops fired into a large crowd of demonstrators Thursday and hospitals reported 12 dead and at least 94 wounded.


U.S., Europe Seek Accord

HADASSAH CELEBRATES 75 YEARS OF HELPING
LEAD: Seventy-five years ago, Henrietta Szold, the first woman to enroll in the Jewish Theological Seminary, decided to transform her small New York study circle into a national organization dedicated to promoting Zionist ideals among American Jewish women and providing basic health care in Palestine.
She called her association Hadassah, the Hebrew for Esther, a queen in Persia who saved the


U.S. AND FRENCH EXPERTS DIFFER ON CAMEROON GAS ERUPTION
LEAD: Scientists who have investigated the death of 1,800 people in Cameroon in August generally agree that they were killed by carbon dioxide erupting from Lake Nios.
They differ, however, on the cause of the eruption.


STAGE IS SET FOR A GIANT GALA
LEAD: A light snow was already falling on Giants Stadium, but workers seemed intent on completing the 7-foot-high stage that was slowly rising at the east end.
It was the initial step of a grand plan to honor the Giants next Tuesday after they return home from Super Bowl XXI, and officials at the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority are bracing for an overflow turnout.

Du Pont Enters Venture in India
LEAD: E. I. du Pont de Nemours &amp; Company has agreed to a $100 million joint venture with the Thapar industrial conglomerate to manufacture and market industrial nylon yarn and fabric in India.
It is the largest American-Indian business deal in the private sector since Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi assumed power in 1984.


IOWA TOPS INDIANA FOR 18TH IN A ROW
LEAD: Top-ranked Iowa, facing third-ranked Indiana for the first time this year, put on an awesome display of rebounding and pressure defense this evening and routed the Hoosiers, 101-88, before 15,570 near delirious fans at Carver Hawkeye Arena.


ECUADOREAN BARS REQUEST TO RESIGN
LEAD: President Leon Fabres Cordero today rejected a formal request by Congress for his resignation.


The Journalists Debate
LEAD: The Washington journalism title for high-volume combativeness will be on the line next month when the 14th annual Conservative Political Action Conference presents a debate on ''The Media vs. the President'' between Sam Donaldson, White House correspondent of ABC News, and Robert Novak, co-author with Rowland Evans of the newspaper column Inside Report.


WEBSTER'S AILMENT CLOUDS HIS FUTURE
LEAD: A day after Tom Webster suffered a relapse of his inner-ear condition, he acknowleged that there was a possibility that his illness would prevent him from flying and, as a result, from coaching the Rangers for the remainder of the season.

LEAD: Golf  Twitty Shares Lead: Howard Twitty, a 38-year-old native of Phoenix, worked with Tom Weiskopf and Jay Morrish on the design and construction of the Tournament Players Club golf course of Scottsdale, Ariz.
This probably helped the 6-foot-5-inch Twitty shoot a six-under-par 65 yesterday on the new, 7,000-yard layout to share the second-round lead with Steve Jones in the 52d annual Phoenix Open.

Vuckovich Invited
LEAD: Among seven nonroster players who will report to the Milwaukee Brewers' spring-training camp in Chandler, Ariz., Feb. 23 will be Pete Vuckovich, a 34-year-old pitcher, and Jim Paciorek, a 26-year-old outfielder.
Vuckovich won the American League Cy Young Award in 1982 with an 18-6 record, but then developed arm problems that sidelined him for most of the next two seasons.


A MILLION SEEK 10,000 VISAS
LEAD: In a huge outpouring, more than one million foreigners have applied for the 10,000 immigration visas the United States is offering without the usual tough entry requirements, a State Department official said today.

LEAD: The Board of Estimate has ended a seven-month delay and voted to authorize the transfer of the two Manhattan cable television franchises to the American Television and Communications Corporation.

African Meeting on Oil
LEAD: Buoyed by higher prices, oil ministers from nine African countries will meet here Monday to formally begin a new forum aimed at improving cooperation and coordinating policy among African oil producers, the Nigerian oil minister's office said today.
The African Petroleum Producers Association, organized by Nigeria, OPEC's largest African producer, combines four OPEC members, Nigeria, Libya, Algeria and Gabon, with five non-members, Angola, Benin, Cameroon, Congo and Egypt.


SUPER BOWL XXI
LEAD: Bill Parcells yesterday with the Vince Lombardi Trophy. (NYT/Vic DeLucia)


Honda Is Japan's No. 3
LEAD: A sharp jump in output helped the Honda Motor Company leap past Mazda and Mitsubishi to become Japan's third-largest producer of vehicles last year, industry analysts said today.
Honda produced 1.24 million units in 1986, far below Toyota's 3.66 million and Nissan's 2.24 million, but above Mazda's 1.20 million and Mitsubishi's 1.18 million, according to the car industry's official data compiler, the Japan Automobile Industry Association.


MILTON ADLER
LEAD: Milton Adler, for many years a criminal trial lawyer on the staff of the Legal Aid Society in Manhattan, collapsed and died Monday on a subway platform in lower Manhattan.
He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: When they first met on a basketball court nearly three years ago, one was still a developing talent and the other was the most intimidating player in college basketball.
Clearly, a lot has changed for Akeem Olajuwon and Patrick Ewing.

He was 78 years old and lived in Floral Park, Queens.

Mets-Johnson Pact
LEAD: Howard Johnson, who may be the Mets' regular third baseman this year, reached agreement with the club yesterday on a one-year contract for $297,500.
Johnson was the second player to settle of the seven Mets who filed for salary arbitration.
Wally Backman, the platooned second baseman, agreed to a three-year, $1.95 million contract, with salaries of $550,000, $650,000 and $750,000.


STOCK DROP HURTS BOND PRICES, TOO
LEAD: Treasury bond prices slumped yesterday, with the longest maturities showing the largest losses, in trading that was heavily influenced by the turmoil in the stock market.

CONCERT: BATTLE SINGS WITH THE PHILHARMONIC
LEAD: Before Erich Leinsdorf began conducting the New York Philharmonic on Thursday evening he first turned to the audience, or what there was of it, and applauded.
Only enough people to half fill Avery Fisher Hall had defied the snowstorm but, as it turned out, they were rewarded with what surely will rank as one of this season's premier musical events.


Correction
LEAD: An article in Weekend yesterday about big bands gave an incorrect day and an incorrect ticket price for a concert with the Sauter-Finegan orchestra.
The concert, at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, is at 8 P.M. tomorrow, not today; tickets are $12 and $15.

M.T.A. Approves Toll Increase On Five East River Crossings
LEAD: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority board approved yesterday an increase of 25 cents on automobile tolls on several East River bridges and tunnels.
The increase, which raises the one-way toll to $2 from $1.75, will take effect Feb. 7.

THE FUN PART OF A SNOWSTORM
LEAD: Youngsters of various ages towing sleds up a hill in Central Park near Fifth Avenue and 72d Street yesterday.
With the sun out, mostly, and the ground covered, completely, it was a fine day for coasting.
For others, the fun was not as evident as they began to dig out stuck cars, step over and through mountains of snow and oceans of slush.

Tiger Gets New Chief
LEAD: Tiger International Inc. has named Stephen M. Wolf as its chairman, president and chief executive.
Mr.
Wolf will remain chief executive of Flying Tiger Lines, the air cargo carrier and Tiger's chief subsidiary.
Mr.
Wolf succeeds Robert P. Jensen, who retired and stepped down from the boards of Flying Tiger and Tiger International.

PROTESTERS CLASH WITH POLICE IN MADRID
LEAD: Spanish riot policemen driving back demonstrators yesterday.
At least 24 people, including 7 police officers, were injured in clashes between the police and right-wing protesters.
Clashes came at end of four-day boycott of classes and followed march by thousands of students calling for cuts in tuition, more spending on education and an end to stringent university entrance exams.

THE DANCE: A MODERN 'IN TRANSIT'
LEAD: The 16th-century poet George Peele once sighed, ''O time too swift, O swiftness never ceasing!'' That sigh sums up ''In Transit,'' the program Michele Elliman and Ryn Hodes presented Wednesday night at the Home for Contemporary Theater and Art (44 Walker Street).
Their works concerned the passing of time, and both choreographers combined movement with texts to explore themes of longing and retrospection.


EXPERTS QUESTION MARKET RATIONALITY
LEAD: Those who make it their business to analyze the inner workings of the nation's stock markets from a distance see an irrational tinge to the behavior of investors in the wild start for 1987.


INDIA PUTS MILITARY ON FULL ALERT, CITING A PAKISTANI TROOP BUILDUP
LEAD: India put its army and air force on maximum alert tonight, citing a threat from what it described as a huge Pakistani military buildup on the border.

FOR SOVIET CIVILIANS, A 'NERVOUS' LIFE
LEAD: In the last seven years, a small city of concrete apartment buildings and shops has risen on the outskirts of Kabul, not far from the airport.


CORRECTION
LEAD: A film review yesterday of ''Sweet Country,'' by Michael Cacoyannis, misidentified a film by Costa-Gavras on the 1973 military coup in Chile that overthrew President Salvador Allende Gossens.
The Costa-Gavras film was titled ''Missing.''


A BICOASTAL CASE OF GIANTS FEVER
LEAD: As with many former New Yorkers now living in Los Angeles, the Super Bowl game Sunday between the Giants and Broncos has given Nelle Nugent, the theatrical and movie producer, an extra shot of fizz.
In the game's honor, her 5-week-old daughter, Alexandra, cuddles up in a tiny, terry cloth Giants uniform.

LEAD: Dwight Gooden, after being put on three years' probation. Page 47. (AP)

SNOW AT KENNEDY CREATES HEAT IN FLIGHT OVER TEXAS
LEAD: The snowstorm over New York caused something of a tempest in a jumbo jet over Texas early this morning.


BEIRUT ABDUCTORS LINKED TO SUSPECT
LEAD: Senior officials in Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government said today that they believed the kidnappers of two West Germans in West Beirut were probably relatives of a Lebanese imprisoned in Frankfurt who is wanted by the United States for hijacking and murder.


Lear Siegler Offer Extended
LEAD: Forstmann Little &amp; Company and Lear Siegler Inc. said that the deadline for their joint tender offer for all of the common and preferred shares of Lear Siegler has been extended to 8 P.M., New York time, on Monday.
The offer originally was set to expire at midnight Thursday.

THE MORNING AFTER: BRIGHT SKIES, SMOOTHER TRAFFIC AND A TOUCH OF MAGIC
LEAD: Snowplows and traffic recaptured the roads, flights resumed at airports, schools and businesses reopened and a bright January sun reappeared yesterday as the New York metropolitan region dug out of its worst winter storm in nearly four years.

LEAD: Ilan K. Reich, a 32-year-old former partner with one of the nation's top law firms, was sentenced yesterday in an emotional court session to a year and a day in prison for his role in the Wall Street insider trading scandal.

COURT REBUFFS WHITNEY ON EVICTION OF TENANTS
LEAD: A State Supreme Court justice has thrown an obstacle before the Whitney Museum of American Art's expansion plans by ruling that the museum may not evict 10 tenants from rent-controlled apartments in buildings it owns.


Better Regulation of Expert Witnesses Needed
LEAD: To the Editor:


PROTEST IN MINNESOTA
LEAD: Demonstrators being sprayed with water as they attempted to scale fence Thursday night at Air National Guard facility at Minneapolis-St.
Paul International Airport.
They were pro-testing against National Guard missions to Central America.
No arrests were made, but an investigation has been ordered into the use of fire hoses against the protesters in sub-zero temperatures that prevailed.


S.E.C. Looking At Volatility
LEAD: After a Wall Street session in which stock prices fluctuated wildly, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the agency continued to be concerned about increasing volatility in the nation's securities markets, and was examining ways to dampen the volatility.

WASHINGTON'S PASS IS NO GEM FOR NETS
LEAD: Was it a smart play or a rookie mistake?
Pearl Washington wanted to believe he had done the right thing tonight, that his lob pass to Orlando Woolridge should have resulted in a basket at a critical stage for the Nets.
Instead, it resulted in a turnover and contributed to a 125-120 loss to the Seattle SuperSonics at Byrne Meadowlands


160 Homes for 160 Babies: Now
LEAD: Why can't homes be found for the ''boarder babies,'' the abandoned or abused infants who languish in city hospitals?
New York City is dragging its feet on accepting Albany's help, charges Cesar Perales, the state Commissioner of Social Services.
Albany promises much but is slow to deliver, responds Eric

High-Speed Trains Must Travel Alone
LEAD: To the Editor:


Samuel Sloan, 73, Executive Of Wingate School in Israel
LEAD: Samuel Sloan, executive secretary of the American Friends of Wingate, a physical-education school in Israel, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Brooklyn.
He was 73 years old.


REAGAN OFFICIALS DEBATE AIDS EDUCATION POLICY
LEAD: Education Secretary William J. Bennett and Dr.
C.
Everett Koop, the Surgeon General of the United States, expressed divergent opinions today on the role of schools in combating the spread of AIDS.


AMR ROUTE BID
LEAD: The AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines, said it was seeking regualtory authority to start daily nonstop sevice between Seattle and Tokyo.
AMR said it would seek approval for the route, currently held by UAL's United Airlines, once it completes its purchase of AirCal Inc., which has extensive service in and out of Seattle.

Toxic Threat Eased, Federal Agency Says
LEAD: The removal of toxic waste in a warehouse here will not force the removal of thousands of nearby residents, as had been feared, a Federal official said yesterday.

NEW GENERATION IS TRAINED FOR GEORGIA RIGHTS MARCH
LEAD: Thursday night, in the Ebenezer Baptist Church, where a generation of civil rights preachers were nurtured and where the funeral was held for its most famous one, the Rev.
Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr., a line of gray-haired men stood singing and chanting, teaching the tools and rhythm of the movement to the young.

CITY BALLET: A REVIVAL OF BALANCHINE'S 'PORTE'
LEAD: Picture the following.
A woman with a huge black cape that billows over an entire stage preens or advances toward a man, a desperate coiled shape at her feet.
The theater is filled with sounds of creaking and breathing for 20 minutes.
Suddenly the woman ''swallows'' up the man in her cape and disappears along with him.


REPORT ASSAILS SECURITY LAPSES AT ALIEN CENTER
LEAD: The detention center in lower Manhattan where aliens are held before being deported has serious security lapses and is not equipped to deal with the criminals who are often held there, according to a Federal report released today.

LEONARD NATMAN
LEAD: Leonard Natman, director of operations at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, died Tuesday at New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston from complications from acquired immune deficiency syndrome.
He was 34 years old.

A.T.&amp; T. Job Cuts
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it would lay off about 300 employees at its Oklahoma City works facility effective next Friday as a result of a soft market for the plant's products.
A.T.&amp; T. said it would lay off mostly entry-level workers producing microprocessor computers and telecommunications switching systems, leaving the plant with 6,000 employees.


CORRECTION
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the AMR Corporation omitted an explanation for its sharp drop in net income.
Profits in the fourth quarter fell mainly because of a one-time charge of $38.9 million, caused by provisions of the new tax law.
Operating income rose substantially, to $86.9 million, from $36.5 million in the 1985 quarter.


EXPANSION BY 1989 IS ROZELLE'S GOAL
LEAD: Describing himself as feeling ''more relaxed than I did a year ago'' in part because of recent favorable decisions in two major court cases, Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League said today that he hoped the league would add two teams by 1989, thereby creating six divisions of five teams each.


O'Neill Calls for Rise In Anti-Drug Budget
LEAD: Gov.
William A. O'Neill yesterday proposed a 50 percent increase in Connecticut's anti-drug effort, bringing the total to $28.3 million, and called for an emphasis on education ''so there is no longer a market for drugs in our state.''

LEAD: ''I've been in the business for 18 years and I have never seen anything like it before.
It's beserk.
It's total confusion.
No one knows what the heck is going on.'' - Donald Crooks, head of trading at Morgan Stanley &amp; Company.  [ 1:6. ]

LEAD: At 1:30 yesterday afternoon, Mark Loehr, a stock trader, was feeding orders into a record-trampling surge in the market.
Just 15 minutes later, he was scrambling to stay in control as prices suddenly were sucked into a free fall - and it dawned on him that he was in for a day unlike any other in his experience.

A Bad Hand May Provide Good Result for the Astute
LEAD: Four decades ago, a great English player-writer, ''Skid'' Simon, included in a list of common errors the habit of underbidding bad hands.
Experts are sometimes able to indicate that a bad hand is relatively good.


CONSUMER SPENDING SOARS 2%
LEAD: Americans buying big-ticket items to qualify for the sales-tax deduction pushed spending up 2 percent in December for the biggest rise in more than a decade.
Meanwhile, consumer incomes, inflated by farm subsidy payments, rose eight-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department reported today.


TOKYO MARKET IN RISE
LEAD: The Tokyo stock average rose to a record high close today in volatile trading after Wall Street's biggest single-session advance and in anticipation of a cut in Japan's discount rate, brokers said.

LEAD: Rafael Septien, the Dallas Cowboys' place-kicker, denied charges yesterday that he sexually assaulted a 10-year-old girl. ''The truth is, I am not guilty,'' Septien said. Get Smarter About Drunken Driving
LEAD: In New York and 41 other states, the 21-year-old drinking age law pays handsome dividends in accidents avoided and lives saved.
But new evidence suggests that another popular tactic in the war on drunken drivers is based on false and naive assumptions.
It's time to challenge these assumptions and change the programs.

LEAD: Washington is a town that thrives on news leaks.
Reporters love them, and in an environment in which information is power, those who have it usually want to use it.
Thus it was that Senator James A. McClure of Idaho, the ranking Republican on the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee, ruminated that he had attended a closed hearing at which senior intelligence officials briefed selected lawmakers.

Conagra-Miller
LEAD: Conagra Inc. said it had acquired E. J. Miller Enterprises Inc., a Hyrum, Utah, beef processor, for an undisclosed amount of stock.
E.
J.
Miller, whose plant processes and markets more than 450,000 beef cattle a year, has annual sales of almost $400 million.
Conagra's sales for the year that ended last May were $5.9 billion.

Pentagon Admits Fault On Iran Arms Pricing

CORRECTION
LEAD: A dispatch by The Associated Press on Jan. 8 from New Bedford, Mass., about a court ruling in the death of a student undergoing treatment at a school for autistic teen-agers, described the ruling incorrectly.
Matthew Israel, director of the Behavior Research Institute, was found negligent in having inadequately supervised the use of a helmet, not in the death itself.

LEAD: Ten years ago tomorrow, the pianist Bruce Hungerford died in an automobile accident in the Bronx at the age of 54.

Yet Hungerford has not been forgotten.

Permutations on a Coup
LEAD: Exactly half a millennium ago a man named John Morton became Archbishop of Canterbury.
Within a few years he was Lord Chancellor of England and a Cardinal.
For the supporters of Richard III, he is the villain who originated the Tudor and Shakespearean portraits of their hero.
As Lord Chancellor he was the inventor of Morton's Fork: A system in lieu of taxes in which a free-spending merchant has proved by his spending that he can afford a ''gift'' to the king.

From Swords to Knives in Kyoto
LEAD: Nishikikoji (familiarly referred to as just Nishiki), a narrow arcaded street in the heart of central Kyoto, is the market basket of Kyoto's food lovers.
Extending several blocks west of the Teramachi arcade, both sides of the street are bursting with the best Kyoto has to offer.
Fishmongers and butchers, greengrocers and noodle makers, the shops are stocked with the freshest of the season, and many offer regional specialties rarely seen in other parts of Japan.

Photography
LEAD: A half century ago, modern war photography cut its teeth on the Spanish Civil War.
Earlier photographers had captured the devastation and human toll of warfare, to be sure, but the combat between the Republicans and Franco's Nationalists was the first in which photographers joined the fray, showing the battlefields and combatants while bullets were flying.

What I Really Think About South Africa
LEAD: There is a place in South Africa, on the south coast, where the waves thrash and the whales come to mate, and from the shore you can see their humps and their tails slapping the waves.
The rocks merge into forest, which thickens and turns and climbs into sturdy green hills.
It is a beautiful place.

Why Sprinklers Stay on the Sidelines
LEAD: IN A 1983 survey of its 8,200 members, the American Hotel and Motel Association found that, while more than 70 percent of respondents had smoke, fire or heat detectors in guest rooms, less than 10 percent had installed automatic sprinklers.
The absence of sprinklers in guest rooms, fire protection experts said, is a glaring deficiency in hotel safety measures and could result in future fires and needless deaths.

A FAREWELL TO SOUTH AFRICA
LEAD: THE NEWSPAPER BILLBOARD I sighted on my last drive to Johannesburg's Jan Smuts Airport bore the message ''Evicted U.S.
Newsman Regarded as Hostile.'' I was, in fact, being expelled by a Government that no longer wished me to chronicle its country's internal struggle.
But hostile?
Had I been hostile to South Africa in my three years as chief of The Times's bureau in Johannesburg, then surely that last ride along the freeway would have been laden with relief.

Repertory May Be Solution for U.S. Opera Companies
LEAD: Is it permissible for one who is not a licensed seer to offer a few speculations about the future of opera in America?
For some years it has seemed to me that in New York we have a laboratory in which certain volatile developments in the art form may be observed at close range.
Under the microscope we see, side by side, a Metropolitan Opera committed to an international star system that no longer works with any consistency and a New York City Opera that, on a shoestring, has gone a long way toward building a repertory company of mostly American artists.

JAZZ: BASSDRUMBONE TRIO
LEAD: BASSDRUMBONE - the trio of Mark Helias on bass, Gerry Hemingway on drums and Ray Anderson on trombone - romps through its music, artfully pulling compositions in three directions at once.
Like the trio Air and a very few other jazz ensembles, BassDrumBone's collective improvisations can be bluesy or ethereal, pensive or raucous in the space of a few seconds.

Being Alert to Fire Safety
LEAD: Every so often a disaster serves to remind travelers that they cannot take their safety for granted.
Such was the case with the New Year's Eve fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel in San Juan, P.R., as a result of which 96 people died.
It reminded travelers everywhere of their vulnerability and of the need for precautions.

LEAD: Come next month, Dennis Conner could be the first American yachtsman to retrieve the 136-year-old America's Cup from foreign hands.


9 FROM NBC PROVIDE AID TO NEEDIEST
LEAD: Nine employees of NBC Enterprises at 30 Rockefeller Plaza gave $155 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. ''We are delighted to do what we can,'' said a note sent with their gift.

Is Just Another Test'' and the letters to the editor that it drew.


Koch Sees a City Getting Well Again
LEAD: Earlier this month, when he reported on the city's financial condition, Mayor Koch's rhetoric was fanned by a landward breeze. ''I can now say we sail in calmer waters,'' he said.
Last week, commenting in his State of the City Address on the corruption scandals that had ''wounded us all,'' the Mayor modeled his ship of state after the hospital vessel Hope: ''The knife of corruption endangered the life of New York City.

LEAD: On Friday, the United Nations Postal Administration will issue a set of three commemorative stamps to honor Trygve Lie.
Mr.
Lie served as the first Secretary-General of the United Nations from Feb. 1, 1946, to April 10, 1953.

LEAD: There is no denying that New Yorkers love their hometown sports teams.
I am writing this letter to point out the feelings of local pride and excitement we experienced as a result of the success of the Mets last fall, and now the Giants.

WHO WILL WIN THE SUPER BOWL, AND WHY?
LEAD: The Broncos and the Giants will both win the game.
How can any team that has played so valiantly, physically and psychologically, possibly be a loser?
Sure, one team will gain more points and drink more champagne, but no amount of numbers put down in black and white can tell the true story.
So everyone is a winner.


NOV. 23: GIANTS 19, BRONCOS 16
LEAD: Last Nov. 23 the Giants defeated Denver, 19-16, at Giants Stadium, with a 4 to 2 edge in turnovers and without the Giants' offense scoring a touchdown.

Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''Today we have embarked on a journey, a journey that will take a lifetime to fulfill, the journey of worldwide brotherhood and understanding.
Without this, Forsyth County, Georgia, and even our nation will fail.
Without brotherhood in a community, violence and intimidation will exist.''
- Dean Carter, an organizer of the march yesterday in Forsyth County.


NONFICTION: IN SHORT
LEAD: THE KREMLIN AND THE WEST: A Realistic Approach.
By Wolfgang Leonhard. (Norton, 7.95.) Wolfgang Leonhard would seem well qualified to deliver what he promises here - a ''new policy toward  [ the ]  USSR.'' Arriving in Moscow in l935 as a l4-year-old German, Mr.
Leonhard spent the war years in the Soviet Union and at war's end was whisked off to Berlin as one of the original members of the ''Ulbricht group,'' charged with setting up a Communist state in what became East Germany.


WORLD VIEW
LEAD: The lack of senior staff and operating managers with an international perspective is the major weakness of most companies doing business on the world market, contends Thomas Gross of Communications International, a management-consulting firm in White Plains that specializes in facilitating successful international business partnerships.

Jolie Lisa Busch Is Engaged
LEAD: Announcement has been made by Tobi Busch and Stuart Busch, both of New York, of the engagement of their daughter Jolie Lisa Busch to Darren Alexander Frank, a son of Rita Paleschuck of Roslyn, L.I., and the late Elliott S. Frank.
Ms.
Busch, a member of the class of '87 at the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law of Yeshiva University, graduated cum laude from Boston University.


When The Group Becomes The Star
LEAD: On the surface, Richard Harris's ''Stepping Out'' and Israel Horovitz's ''North Shore Fish'' are totally dissimilar.
The former, an English play with music, deals with Londoners from disparate backgrounds who are taking an evening class in tapdancing.
The latter, a drama set in Gloucester, Mass., is concerned with a group of workers who are employed in a frozen-fish processing plant.


HERETICS AND THE PRIESTHOOD
LEAD: NOBEL DREAMS Power, Deceit, and the Ultimate Experiment.
By Gary Taubes. 320 pp.
New York: Random House. $19.95.


Getting TV Stereo Plus High Fidelity
LEAD: With the spread of stereo television broadcasting, there has been growing interest in the sound quality of video presentations, and many videophiles cling to the notion that stereo means high-quality sound.
This is simply not so; and with so many stereo TV sets now being sold, the distinction between stereo and fidelity should be clarified.


TOY GUNS: A REAL AND GROWING PROBLEM FOR POLICE
LEAD: Just after midnight over the school holidays last month, three San Francisco police officers responded to a silent alarm indicating that someone had entered a local high school.
A few minutes later a 15-year-old high school student lay dying in a darkened hallway, shot by one of the officers, who had seen the youth pointing a gun at him.


A Pianist's Memorabilia
LEAD: Steinway and Sons, 109 West 57th Street, is currently exhibiting a display of memorabilia pertaining to the life and work of the American pianist William Kapell, who lived from 1922 to 1953.
Many of the same items are shown that were displayed at the International Piano Library in College Park, Md., last summer, including a wide variety of photographs (both personal and professional), letters from Virgil Thomson and Aaron Copland, press notices, recording documentation, diaries and other effects.

LEAD: THE hoopla that has come to characterize Super Bowl week has never been in keeping with Andy Robustelli's style.
And so today, when the New York Giants make their first appearance in the Super Bowl, Mr.
Robustelli, one of the greatest players in Giants history, will watch the game as most Americans will - on television.

FICTION: IN SHORT
LEAD: RECOLLECTIONS OF THINGS TO COME.
By Elena Garro.
Translated by Ruth L. C. Simms. (University of Texas, Paper, $10.95.) The narrator of Elena Garro's first novel, which originally appeared in 1963, establishes the tone of this dreamy, nonlinear story in the first paragraph.
The reader must guess at the identity of the speaker by solving sphinx-like riddles: ''I am and I was in many eyes.

WESTCHESTER GUIDE
LEAD: BLACK HISTORY EVENTS Black History Month is to be celebrated in various locations countywide, beginning with opening ceremonies at noon Saturday in the County Courthouse.
The courthouse lobby all month will house an exhibition focusing on ''Black American Scientists,'' sponsored by the Ciby-Geigy Corporation.


TALKS PROGRESS, BU NOBODY IS WORKING ON THE RAILROAD
LEAD: LONG Island Rail Road executives and the leaders of 15 unions have tried for more than two years to come to terms on new contracts for the line's 6,600 organized employees, with only partial success.
Last week, because railroad unions traditionally honor one another's picket lines, 110,000 daily riders paid the price.


HEARTY STEWS CAN TAKE THE CHILL OFF
LEAD: OLD-FASHIONED stews make perfect meals for cold winter evenings.
Hearty and comforting, they are also immensely practical, because they can be made in one pot and cooked a day or two in advance - and they improve in flavor when left overnight.


I LOVE THE GRAY, DEPRESSING (ACHOO) L.I. WINTERS
LEAD: I KNOW that winter is probably not your favorite season.
Once the holidays are past, all you have to look forward to is a succession of cold, gray days, slush-spattered windshields and heating bills that make your temperature rise, literally and figuratively.


FEELINGS OF AND AND IF, OF AND BUT
LEAD: IN the second chapter of Joyce's ''Ulysses'' Stephen Dedalus is admonished by his employer, Mr.
Deasy, ''We are a generous people, but we must also be just.'' ''I fear those big words,'' Stephen answers, ''which make us so unhappy.'' He does not specify the big ones: presumably they include ''generous,'' ''people,'' ''just'' and ''must,'' words that lodge an ethical or a nationalist claim.

LEAD: WHEN Ajai Singh Mehta leaves London in March to replace Robert A. Gottlieb at Alfred A. Knopf, he will be one of very few foreigners who have become editors in chief of an American book publisher.
But if foreigners are rare in editorial sanctums, they have become increasingly familiar in the publishers' management suites.

Switzerland
LEAD: To the Editor: In his Oct. 26 story on the Swiss hotel Haus Paradies, Israel Shenker says, ''Swiss Germans have quaint notions about spelling.'' There is nothing quaint about ''Paradies.'' It's the regular German spelling of ''paradise.''

FURNITURE FINISHES THAT AREN'T JUST PAINT
LEAD: DOROTHY DIAMOND'S studio in New Canaan has no easels, no brushes and no wet paint.
Yet The Studio, as her year-old shop is aptly called, is home to the ''painted finish'' look that is increasingly popular in decor.


2 Bombings in Italian Alps
LEAD: Two bombs exploded a minute apart today near the homes of local politicians in Bolzano, the capital of Alto Adige, an Alpine region racked by tensions between ethnic Germans and Italians.
The explosions blew out windows but caused no injuries.
No immediate claim of responsibility was reported.
The explosions occurred near the homes of a provincial assessor, Remo Ferretti, a Christian Democrat, and of Andrea and Piero Mitolo, who are local leaders of the Italian Social Movement, a neo-Fascist party.


Correction
LEAD: A report last Sunday on the engagement of Angela Simeone to Ben Yagoda described her postgraduate education incorrectly.
She received a Ph.D. degree in higher education from the University of Pennsylvania.


Your Cigarettes Or Your Job, Workers Are Told
LEAD: Voicing a concern for its employees' health that went mostly unappreciated, a Chicago company announced last week that it would ban smoking - on the job and at home, too - conduct lung tests to make sure workers comply and dismiss those who do not.

LEAD: A man who was penniless when he left Imperial Russia but died rich in the United States has left the bulk of his $8 million estate to the Federal Government, a bequest being contested by his stepchildren.

IN PRAGUE TODAY, TREASURES OF THE PAST
LEAD: Great capitals are usually hard to ignore: as cultural, economic and political centers, they attract crowds of travelers year after year, and are, if anything, overexposed.
Yet right in the center of Europe, one of the most attractive cities ever built, long the residence of the Holy Roman Emperors, is often overlooked - a fact all the more surprising because, unlike many of its neighbors, it largely escaped the ravages of the last world war.


Beaux-Arts Sketches: Grace Under Pressure
LEAD: Among the ordeals that faced the young French painter who wanted to climb the official ladder in the 19th century none was either more daunting or more decisive than the historical composition contest that was held every year between 1816 and 1863 at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in Paris.
Success in that contest was the indespensible preliminary to all the other competitive stages that led in time to the Rome Prize.

LEAD: BY the time the Giants and Denver Broncos finish butting heads in Super Bowl XXI today, about 130 million Americans, or more than one in two, will have watched at least part of the game on television.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036.
Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.


PERSONAL FINANCE
LEAD: SOON after passage of the tax act last year, many tax specialists and employee benefit consultants were predicting that deferred compensation arrangements for top executives would go the way of the dinosaur.
They reasoned that with a top tax bracket of 28 percent, executives would prefer to take their money now, rather than deferring payment and risking a tax rise later.

The State of the President
LEAD: What's new, coming up on the President's report to Congress, is not the State of the Union but the state of the President.
Starting suddenly, on successive days last November, the Reagan Administration changed.
Six years of genial invincibility have faded fast and that's why this address to Congress ranks in importance with his first one.

THE WOUNDED GIANT REGAINS HIS DIGNITY

In a statement issued later, the 41-year-old contractor said he regretted ''errors in judgment'' that resulted in his using funds from his company for his personal expenses.

A Lackluster G.N.P. Caps a Dismal Year
LEAD: The economy grew at a dull 1.7 percent rate in the fourth quarter, and just 2.5 percent for all of 1986, which had been heralded by many as a 4 or 5 percent growth year.
The fourth-quarter gain was below what most Government and private economists had expected.
Much of the blame goes to the trade deficit, which has remained stubbornly high despite the falling dollar, and lackluster performances in energy and business investment.

WHAT'S NEW IN HOTEL SAFETY
LEAD: THE scene following the New Year's eve fire that killed 96 people at the Dupont Plaza Hotel in San Juan, Puerto Rico, was a familiar one: officials parading before the television cameras, calling for tougher fire prevention laws.

New &amp; Noteworthy
LEAD: THE JOHNSTOWN FLOOD, by David McCullough. (Touchstone/Simon &amp; Schuster, $8.95.) On the afternoon of May 31, 1889, an earthen dam burst in the mountains above Johnstown, Pa., and in the resulting flood the booming coal-and-steel town was devastated and more than 2,000 people died.
David McCullough's re-creation of the catastrophe, its causes and its aftermath is ''a superb job, scholarly yet vivid, balanced yet incisive,'' Alden Whitman said in The Times in 1968.

Discovering China's Folk Art
LEAD: For centuries, the elite of China dismissed as trivial the crafts made by villagers for their own use - the leather shadow puppets, paper cutouts, embroideries, batiks and woodblock prints.
Today these handcut and stitched works are gaining recognition in China and in the West, a change that seems long overdue after viewing ''Chinese Folk Art: The Small Skills of Carving Insects,'' at the Yale University Art Gallery.

A CITY OF MUSICIANS AND AUDIENCES
LEAD: An art museum may sound like a strange place to begin a musical tour, but for the visitor to Prague who is interested in Czech music, the Gallery of 19th-Century Czech Art is a striking introduction.
The museum, part of the National Gallery, is imaginatively housed in the former Convent of the Blessed Agnes, a vast and magnificent 13th-century complex, the largest and oldest Gothic monument in the city, still being restored, rescued after centuries of neglect.

The Cat's Meow: Fake Furs
LEAD: THESE days fake-fur fanciers have little to growl about.
That's because of the preponderance of big-cat facsimiles, which are uncannily like the real thing.
The coats are made of lightweight but warm synthetics printed with mirror images of the cats' markings.
Among the most eye-catching are the Somali leopard fakes (top right), with small, ringlike spots, and the ocelot (bottom, second from right), with a distinctive dot-and-broken-line pattern.

Karl May's Indians
LEAD: To the Editor:


Degrading
LEAD: To the Editor:  Plastic is prominent in litter not only because it is non-biodegradable (''Plastic Falls to Pieces,'' Prospects Jan. 11) but because of its lightness.
The wind carries plastic everywhere while metal and glass, which are also non-biodegradable, stay put.
Similarly, metal and glass sink to the bottom of streams while plastic floats.

HARTMAN OFFERS PLAY BY MANET
LEAD: DAVID MAMET'S laconic style can lure one into thinking there must be something more to his plays than reaches the ear.
Just as the pauses of Harold Pinter are rife with suggestiveness and tension, the clipped cadences and sentence fragments, the repetitions, sometimes even the grunts, of Mr.
Mamet's characters have come to represent the poetic innuendos of the inarticulate.

The Surrogate's Baby Comes First
LEAD: A little boy's truck is a toy, not a harbinger of a career in the trucking industry.
A little girl's doll is not simply a doll but a symbol of the baby she's expected to have some day.
Small wonder, therefore, that women are so often devastated when they find themselves infertile.
Men may wish just as fervently to be fathers but women have been programmed for parenthood, socially as well as physiologically, almost since birth.

LEAD: More than a week after 154 contributors and staff members of The New Yorker wrote a letter to their newly appointed editor asking him to decline the job, their protest continues to preoccupy literary and journalistic circles.


Princeton to Increase Fees
LEAD: Students at Princeton University will pay 5.9 percent more in fees to attend the Ivy League school next year, according to the Board of Trustees.
Under the increase, announced after a board meeting Saturday, students will pay an average of $16,918 next year, a $938 increase, Princeton officials said.

How to Pick an Issue
LEAD: A Presidential election offers a golden opportunity for issue-oriented special interest groups.
Such a group can press candidates to take a position on its key issue in the nominating competition and in the general election.
If both finalists endorse the group's position - say, more national parks or no compulsory drug testing - favorable publicity results, and something might actually happen in the next Administration.

LEAD: The New York Pops - the assembly of freelance players that Skitch Henderson presents each year at Carnegie Hall - opened its season Friday evening with a first half devoted to music for the stage and a second half devoted to one of the stage's most successful composers, Marvin Hamlisch.
