Question Box
LEAD: QUESTION: Baseball's triple crown for hitters goes to the player who leads his league in batting average, home runs and runs batted in.
But there's also an unofficial triple crown for pitchers that goes to the one who leads his league in victories, strikeouts and earned run average.
Has any team ever had both triple crown winners in the same season?

PARENTHOOD THEN AND NOW
LEAD: With the average age of marriage increasing and growing numbers of women postponing childbearing to pursue careers, women age 35 and older gave birth to 224,000 babies in 1984, a 36 percent increase since 1980, according to the National Center for Health Statistics.
Yet, contrary to the widespread perception of late childbearing as a recent yuppie phenomenon, older parents were actually more common in earlier decades.

LEAD: WALL STREET savants are fond of saying that small investors usually come into a bull market too late, sell too late and generally exhibit poor timing.
If this is so, most small investors should have missed the extraordinary rise in the market this year and then been whipsawed by last Friday's roller-coaster market performance.

SILENT SUFFERERS, AND OTHERS
LEAD: At the first sign of a cold she takes to her bed and remains there till it subsides.
He, on the other hand, goes to the office no matter how hacking the cough, how throbbing the head.
She sprains her ankle but keeps her appointments; he throws his back out and cancels everything.
He wants chicken soup and conversation during recuperation; she yearns only for isolation and silence.

'ALAMO: 13 DAYS TO GLORY,' ON NBC
LEAD: SHOULD we fight the Battle of the Alamo again?
John Wayne did it last in 1960; there were films before that, too.
Davy Crockett, Jim Bowie and a handful of Texans met Santa Anna.
Comes now ''The Alamo: 13 Days to Glory,'' a three-hour movie on NBC.
Don't ignore it, however, just because you know how the battle turns out.

State Secret
LEAD: The Chinese may have taken long strides toward modernization in recent years, but when it comes to the Super Bowl they're four months behind the times.

Monday Night Football
LEAD: Maintaining Super Bowl suspense is also a matter for Japanese fans, several million of whom will stay home tonight to watch the game on delayed tape.
Because the broadcast begins 10 hours after the final gun, the trick is to get through the day without learning the result.
The Tokyo Broadcasting System could have gone live and, in fact, did provide a live closed-circuit hookup Monday morning, local time, at the Tokyo American Club and the Hilton Hotel, where a seat cost $50, breakfast included.

LEAD: A move to prohibit state officials who are lawyers from representing clients before state agencies will be debated at the 110th annual meeting of the New York State Bar Association, which opens tomorrow in Manhattan.


The Other Jersey Giants
LEAD: The folks at Logo 7, an Indianapolis shirt-screening concern, had a lot riding on the Super Bowl.
As the largest N.F.L. licensee, the company had its workers standing by last night ready to turn out T-shirts, jerseys and other garments proclaiming the winners as league champions just as soon as the outcome was clear.


LAVA LIES HEAVY ON HAWAIIAN LAND AND LIVES
LEAD: Although lava from the Kilauea volcano is now flowing away from inhabited areas, its output of recent weeks, when it flowed to the coast, lies heavy on the landscape and the lives of those whose homes were in its path.

PUBLIC SKEPTICAL ON STATE OF UNION
LEAD: President Reagan, fighting to revive his Presidency with his sixth State of the Union Message tonight, will address a nation that is deeply skeptical that he can achieve his goals and doubtful that he is telling the truth about Iran and the Nicaraguan rebels, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.


Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q.How do cats retract their claws?
A.Cats retract and extend their claws by using two tendons, one above and one below the claw's center of rotation.
The claw is retracted when tension is applied to the extensor tendon above the center of rotation.
This moves the claw upward and backward.
When tension is applied below the center of rotation through the flexor tendon, the claw is extended.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: N.H.L.
Flames 6, Maple Leafs 5: Calgary spotted Toronto a 5-0 lead in the first period last night, then score five goals in the third period at Maple Leaf Gardens.
The Flames won when Colin Patterson scored at 1 minute 30 seconds of overtime.


Parcells and Simms Bask in the Glow
LEAD: The triumphant few always seem to glow in the aftermath of winning a championship.
You could see it in Bill Parcells's tired face this morning at his final news conference of Super Bowl XXI.
You could see it in the little-boy face of Phil Simms, the most valuable quarterback who followed his coach to the podium.


Let Airwaves Auction Help Public Broadcasting
LEAD: To the Editor:


Japan's Target Is 3.5% Growth
LEAD: The Japanese Government adopted an economic growth target today of 3.5 percent for the fiscal year beginning April 1, up slightly from the 3 percent expected in the current year.
Approval of the target came at a special Cabinet meeting.


Loss Reported By Premark
LEAD: Premark International Inc. said today that it lost $95.5 million in the fourth quarter, partly reflecting a previously announced $98 million write-down of two raw material plastic plants.
A year ago, Premark said, it earned $24.4 million.


British Refuse Oil Cuts
LEAD: A British official told the Saudi Arabian oil minister, Hisham Nazer, today that the Government would not curb oil production in the North Sea to help the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to raise prices, an Energy Department spokesman said.
Mr.
Nazer met the junior energy minister, Alick Buchanan-Smith, after arriving in Britain on a private visit.


ESPOSITO RETURNS AND RANGERS WIN
LEAD: For people who follow the Rangers, there is one requirement.
They should never, not for a moment, turn away, for if they do, they are likely to miss something.


BUSINESS, AS USUAL
LEAD: At the end of the lobby of the hotel where the Giants have spent most of the week of their lives, the big man sat near the main entrance and very, very slowly signed his name across the pebbled surface of an official Super Bowl ball: George B. Young. ''B?'' someone asked. ''B for Bozo,'' Young said.


Inflation Up in Belgium
LEAD: Consumer prices have risen 0.55 percent in January, the Government said today.
Belgium's annual inflation rate grew to 0.88 percent this month from 0.59 percent in December.
Higher gas and medical costs were cited.

No Yellow Ribbons for Beirut
LEAD: Understandably, American responses to hostage-taking in Lebanon are hardening.
Civil authority in that shattered country has long since vanished.
Every Westerner still in Beirut surely knows the risks.
The State Department keeps urging Americans to clear out, as it did only days before the weekend abduction of four teachers at Beirut University College.

Biggest Winners
LEAD: The Giants, in rolling to a 39-20 triumph over the Broncos in Super Bowl XXI, amassed the largest cumulative scoring margin over three postseason opponents since the current playoff system was established for the 1969 season.
The Giants defeated the 49ers, 49-3, and the Redskins, 17-0, for a total playoff margin of 105-23, an 82-point differential.

LEAD: RUSSIAN STUDIES.
By Leonard Schapiro.
Edited by Ellen Dahrendorf, with an introduction by Harry Willetts. 400 pages.
Elisabeth Sifton/Viking. $24.95.
LEONARD SCHAPIRO, who died in 1983 at the age of 75, was a leading authority on 19th- and 20th-century Russian politics and ideas.
Born in Glasgow, he was taken back to Russia and spent his childhood in Riga and St.


Morales Pleads Guilty
LEAD: George Morales, three-time winner of the Offshore Power Boat world championship, pleaded guilty in Federal Court in West Palm Beach, Fla., yesterday to drug and tax evasion charges.


A Service for David Maysles
LEAD: A memorial service for David Maysles, the documentary film maker, is to be held Thursday at 6:30 P.M. at St.
Peter's Lutheran Church, 619 Lexington Avenue and 53d Street.
Mr.
Maysles, who was noted for the cinema verite films he made with his brother Albert, died Jan. 3 at the age of 54.
The service, which is open to the public, is to be followed by a reception.


Financial Fiddling With a Tinderbox
LEAD: Leaders in Western Europe and Japan have a good idea of what must be done to right the yawning imbalances in world trade and money flows.
Thanks to unsubtle signals from Treasury Secretary James Baker, they're also beginning to understand the dangerous consequences of continuing inaction.
But this doesn't mean that the Group of Five, meeting early next month, can achieve an agreement with teeth.


More Products in Stores
LEAD: The December tally of new product introductions in supermarkets and drug chains came to 203, an increaase of 28 from December 1985, according to the DFS-Dorland New Product News.
That brought the total for the year to 2,530, up from 2,206 in 1985.


Home Resales Set a Record
LEAD: A rush to take advantage of expiring tax incentives helped push sales of existing homes to a monthly high in December, closing out the best year for home resales since 1979, a real estate trade group said today.

NOTES ON FASHION
LEAD: DESPITE temperatures in the teens, New York's night set was out in force all last week.
The weather was unchanged at Nell's on West 14th Street: chilly outside and quite warm within.
Patrons included Marvin Hamlisch, the composer, who came to hear Edwige, a smoky-voiced chanteuse who was stoking the club's midnight fires.

RECORD NUMBER GIVEN HOUSING IN CITY SHELTERS
LEAD: As temperatures dropped into the teens Sunday night, a record number of people sought emergency housing, causing overcrowding at eight city shelters for homeless individuals.


ALLEN PORTER
LEAD: Allen Porter, for many years a member of the staff of the Museum of Modern Art, died last Wednesday at a nursing home in Rhinebeck, N.Y.
He was 84 years old and lived in Barrytown, N.Y.


STAGE: SONDHEIM SONGS IN 'MARRY ME A LITTLE'
LEAD: WHEN ''Marry Me a Little,'' the revue of Stephen Sondheim's trunk songs, was first produced in New York in October 1980, it triumphantly overcame the challenge of weaving such songs - some from unproduced shows, others cutouts from famous shows - into a dramatically coherent evening.


Viola Gets $837,000
LEAD: Frank Viola, a Hempstead, L.I., native, who last season won 16 games for Minnesota, reached agreement with the Twins yesterday on a one-year contract for $837,000, a healthy raise from the $674,000 salary he won in salary arbitration last year.


MUSIC: ORPHEUS ORCHESTRA PERFORMS AT CARNEGIE HALL
LEAD: ORPHEUS, the conductorless chamber orchestra, gave exquisite pleasure at the beginning of its Carnegie Hall concert Saturday night.
Everything that followed was substantial and pleasing, but it was this symphony by Haydn (in C minor, No. 52) that balanced so many and opposing tensions with such poise.


Coach Reprimanded
LEAD: The Mid-American Conference yesterday publicly reprimanded Vernon Payne, the men's head basketball coach at Western Michigan University, for public criticism of game officials after Western's 62-60 victory at Ball State Jan. 14.

Careers; Foreigners' Takeover Attempts
LEAD: SMALL, prosperous companies that expect to keep doing well may find themselves the object of foreign takeover attempts.
That is the gist of a recent survey by the Research Institute of America, a private organization.
Most of its members are closely held companies with sales of $50 million or less.

LEAD: A New York City police officer has been suspended without pay after he fired four shots at the back of a taxicab whose driver had refused to give a ride to the officer and a friend, the police said.

Fewer Oil Rigs Active
LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States has dropped to 837, down 49 from a week ago amid a traditional seasonal decline, the Hughes Tool Company said today.
One year ago its rig count was 1,671.


Racial Attack Suspect Freed
LEAD: A 19-year-old white man was released on $1,000 bail yesterday after he was arraigned on assault and other charges stemming from what the police said was a racial attack on two Hispanic youths in Ozone Park, Queens, last month.
The man, Arthur Biazzo Jr., is charged with having pointed a gun at the victims and with threatening them, not with participating in the beatings.

LEAD: THE REV.
THEODORE M. HESBURGH has called for the creation of a nonmilitary equivalent of the Reserve Officer Training Corps on the nation's college campuses.
The program would give outstanding high school graduates a choice of becoming leaders, not in the military, but in the cause of peace and international understanding.

ARC AMERICA TO BUY AGGREGATES CONCERN
LEAD: The American Aggregates Corporation, a mining and concrete products company based in Greenville, Ohio, said today that it had signed a definitive agreement to be acquired by the Arc America Corporation for $30.63 a share, or $242 million.


SUSPECT SEIZED IN OFFICER'S KILLING
LEAD: A 23-year-old Bronx man was arrested last night and charged with the murder on Friday of an off-duty police officer, Michael Reidy, in an apparent robbery attempt in the lobby of the officer's apartment building in the University Heights section of the Bronx.


Presidential Message To Be Aired Tonight
LEAD: President Reagan's State of the Union Message will be broadcast live at 9 o'clock tonight on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, on CNN, the Cable News Network, and on C-SPAN, the Cable-Satellite Public Affairs Network.
In addition, some local affiliates of PBS and SIN, the Spanish International Network, will carry the conference, either live or as a tape-delayed broadcast.


WOMAN DIES IN JUMP FROM ROOF
LEAD: A South Bronx woman apparently jumped yesterday with her 17-month-old granddaughter from the roof of her five-story apartment building in what the police said they believe was a suicide attempt.

LEAD: Reported deaths of abused and neglected children increased 29 percent last year in 24 states, according to a group that collects state statistics.

LEAD: Two co-founders of the defunct ESM Government Securities Inc. were sentenced today to prison terms for their role in the $315 million collapse of the securities dealer, which led to a thrift-unit crisis in Ohio.

OPERA: ARGENTO WORK, 'CHRISTOPHER SLY'
LEAD: THE idea on which Dominick Argento based ''Christopher Sly'' - his fourth opera, first heard in 1963 and revived Saturday by the Center for Contemporary Opera at the Henry Street Settlement - is not an unpromising one.
Sly is the tinker in the ''Induction'' to ''The Taming of the Shrew,'' who awakes from a drunken stupor to find himself dressed as a lord and surrounded by courtiers - the butt of a nobleman's joke.


Rates Up in Quiet Trading
LEAD: Interest rates on short- and long-term Treasury issues rose modestly in quiet trading yesterday, as government securities dealers began preparing for a heavy supply of new issues.


THEATER: 'MURDERER,' ONE-ACT BY KOKOSCHKA
LEAD: IN common with other artists, Oskar Kokoschka was drawn to the theater as a place in which to re-enact primal passions.
In 1909, the young Kokoschka staged his own one-act Expressionist play, ''Murderer, Hope of Women,'' in the Kunstschau garden theater in Vienna, and, according to the painter, it provoked a storm of protest.


Children's Mental Health
LEAD: One in eight children in the United States suffers from a mental health problem severe enough to require treatment, according to the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment.
Of these 7.5 million children, 70 to 80 percent are not getting appropriate mental health services, the office says.


RADAR IN GREENLAND BECOMES AN ISSUE IN DENMARK
LEAD: A dispute among American arms-control experts over a new early warning radar in Greenland, which is Danish territory, has spilled over into Denmark, creating foreign policy problems for the United States.


WINNIE MANDELA SAYS POLICE TOOK A SHACKLED MAN INTO HER HOME
LEAD: Winnie Mandela, the prominent opponent of apartheid, said today that the police brought an unidentified man in leg irons into her home while they searched the house before Mrs.
Mandela and her daughter, Zinzi, were detained Sunday.


HART CALLS FOR LONGER SCHOOL YEAR AND TESTS OF TEACHER COMPETENCY
LEAD: Former Senator Gary Hart, a Democratic Presidential hopeful, outlined a sweeping education program today that calls for competency tests for all teachers, a national volunteer effort to combat illiteracy and a longer school year.


Chess: Russian Grandmaster Wins Over 13 Players in Hungary
LEAD: The second Szirak International Tournament, probably the strongest competition held in Hungary in the last 30 years, was won by Lev Psakhis of the Soviet Union.
The 28-year-old Russian grandmaster scored 9-4 to top a field of 14 that included 12 grandmasters.

LEAD: Expressing frustration at his Administration's inability to prevent the seizure of Americans in Lebanon, President Reagan said today that the three men abducted Saturday had ignored official warnings and stayed in Beirut ''at their own risk and on their own responsibility.''

LEAD: A 65-year-old Roman Catholic nun was stabbed to death Sunday night in a Bronx shelter for homeless men where she worked and lived, the police said yesterday.

He was 96 years old.

AMID THREATS AND WAR, ISLAM'S CHIEFS SEEK UNITY
LEAD: The leaders of the Moslem world gathered here today for an Islamic organization ''unity'' meeting that was overshadowed by a war, virtually within earshot, between two of the organization's most powerful members.


FOR ONE FAMILY, CONTRIBUTING TO THE NEEDIEST IS A TRADITION
LEAD: Continuing her mother's tradition of giving to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, Myra Heller of Setauket, L.I., gave $25 to the 75th annual appeal.
Mrs.
Heller said as with her mother, Bertha Levine, who began contributing in 1925, she has given annually to the Neediest, first on behalf of her children and then her grandchildren.

LEAD: Citicorp has requested applications from Federal regulators to acquire troubled thrift institutions in Texas, Arizona and Pennsylvania, banking sources said yesterday.

Bridge: Ruffing With Smallest Card Is Common Beginners' Error
LEAD: An error made routinely by almost all beginners and intermediate players consists of ruffing in the closed hand with the smallest available spot card when it would have been safe and desirable to ruff with a slightly higher card.


The Giant Apple
LEAD: In 1956, when the Giants won their last National Football League championship, they did it at the same Yankee Stadium where three months earlier the New York Yankees beat the Brooklyn Dodgers in the World Series.
Those were heady days for New York sports fans, when all roads to sports championships seemed to run through the Big Apple.


Williams to Sell Agrico Chemical
LEAD: The board of the Williams Companies has approved a tentative agreement to sell the company's Agrico Chemical Company fertilizer subsidiary to Freeport-McMoran Resource Partners Ltd. in New Orleans.
Directors also said Williams's commercial real estate company, the Williams Realty Corporation, was for sale.

Merrill Net Up Sharply In Quarter
LEAD: In a sign of the enormously profitable environment that most of Wall Street has been enjoying, Merrill Lynch &amp; Company, the country's largest brokerage house, reported yesterday that its net earnings nearly tripled in the fourth quarter.


BellSouth Net Climbs 8.3%
LEAD: The BellSouth Corporation, the regional telephone holding company that serves nine states in the Southeast, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings increased 8.3 percent, to $361.1 million, or $1.14 a share, from $333.4 million, or $1.09 a share, a year ago.


Speakes Plans a Book
LEAD: When Larry Speakes departs Feb. 1 as the White House press spokesman to start his new job with Merrill Lynch &amp; Company, the Wall Street investment house, he hopes to supplement his $150,000 salary with a book contract.


Kidder to Advise U.S. on Loan Sale
LEAD: Kidder, Peabody &amp; Company has been named financial adviser for the Department of Agriculture's proposed sale of rural housing loans.


Democracy in the Military? Sort Of
LEAD: On June 21, Gen.
John A. Wickham Jr. must step down as Chief of Staff of the Army because the law allows him exactly four years in office, and not a day more.
On June 30, Gen.
P.
X.
Kelley will end his term as Commandant of the Marine Corps for the same reason.


Progressive Bar To Greenfield Plan
LEAD: The Progressive Savings and Loan Association said the Federal Home Loan Bank Board had given it permission to withdraw its conditional approval of Greenfield Partners' application to take over the association.
Progressive Savings, based in Alhambra, Calif., which has assets of $500 million and 10 branch offices in southern California, was put under the conservatorship of the bank board last summer.


Mesa Fulfills Plan
LEAD: The Mesa Petroleum Company said it had purchased 15.5 million Mesa Limited Partnership common units for $263.9 million, in accordance with its previously announced plan of liquidation.
The plan was approved by shareholders in December 1985.
The units will be distributed Feb. 2 to Mesa Petroleum shareholders of record Jan.

And after three decades, again.

LEAD: WITHOUT quite meaning to, Neil J. A. Sloane has become the world's clearinghouse for number sequences.

LEAD: UAL Inc., the parent company of United Airlines, reported a loss of $13.6 million in the fourth quarter, in contrast to income of $20.8 million, or 43 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1985.
Operating revenue rose 23.8 percent, to $2.34 billion, from $1.89 billion a year earlier.

First Black Is Inaugurated As the Mayor of Baltimore

REMEMBERING WHAT DAY IT IS
LEAD: WHEN AT-class computers were introduced in August 1984, each came equipped with a battery-powered clock and calendar.
Clock-calendars are a dandy thing for people who hate to type in the time and date each time they create or update a file.
Besides, some of us rarely know what time or day it is.
Even when the computer's power is switched off, the clock-calendar keeps track of the real time and date.


REPORT RAISES FEARS FOR WAITE
LEAD: Three men, including a Saudi national and two men believed to be foreigners, were abducted in West Beirut today, and there were reports that an anonymous telephone caller had threatened to kill one of two West German hostages ''at any hour.''

LEAD: Despite the Reagan Administration's attack on affirmative action remedies to eliminate employment discrimination, a Federal district court settlement this month proves that the concept is not only alive and well but can even create thousands of jobs for Americans, men as well as women.


SECOND BIG STORM IN 5 DAYS STRIKES EASTERN SEABOARD
LEAD: The second major storm in five days struck the East Coast and the New York metropolitan region yesterday.
High winds and heavy snows reglazed the city, buried some suburbs in mountainous drifts and brought a reprise of winter doldrums.

LEAD: A Federal drug agent, wounded last week in a shootout with a suspected cocaine dealer, died at an Atlanta hospital yesterday, the day after another Federal agent was wounded in a shootout in California.

It is a revolution people often forget until a prominent older individual's ailment makes the news or they face such procedures themselves.

LEAD: Johannes Rau, who was defeated Sunday as the Social Democrats' candidate for Chancellor, today renounced any claim to succeed Willy Brandt as party chairman next year.

It is a tiny shelter by New York City standards, with a capacity of just 15, but it is the biggest of five shelters in suburban Nassau County (population 1.5 million).
Last weekend, the coldest of winter, 17 men, women and children squeezed in.

WHERE MOVIE TICKET INCOME GOES
LEAD: What happens to the money when two friends decide to go to the movies?


GORBACHEV, CITING PARTY'S FAILURES, DEMANDS CHANGES
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, charging his Communist Party with stagnation and systematic failures, called today for secret balloting and a choice of candidates in the party's elections of its officials.


London Coffee Climbs
LEAD: Growing sales of coffee from Brazil have drawn processors back into the market, jolting prices out of a three-month slump, analysts said today.
The March futures contract here rose more than $152 a ton in the last nine days, to $2,462 on Monday.
The price dipped to $2,424 today, but dealers attributed this to market nervousness on the eve of a three-day meeting of coffee-producing countries here.


FOOD NOTES
LEAD: A Taste of Spring Is it too soon to think spring?
Not when shad and shad roe have arrived in town.
The shad fillets and pairs of shad roe are available at some of the fish markets that command higher prices. (At wholesale, the fish are selling for around $4 a pound, a price that may drop as the season progresses.) Citarella, 2135 Broadway (75th Street) has shad fillets for $6.95 a pound and the roes for $6.95 a pair.


PROFESSOR SEEN TO HEAD STATE ENVIROMENT UNIT
LEAD: Governor Cuomo has chosen Thomas C. Jorling, a professor at Williams College, to head the state's Department of Environmental Conservation, people familiar with the decision said today.


Chicago Magazine Names Publisher
LEAD: Roger Tremblay, 38, the former associate publisher, advertising director and a vice president of Texas Monthly, will be moving the old bones to Chicago to take the publisher's chair at Chicago magazine.

AMERICANS EATING THEIR VEGETABLES
LEAD: Americans are eating more vegetables than ever before, particularly the fresh kinds found in produce markets, according to a Department of Agriculture analyst.
But canned and frozen vegetables are popular, too, says Shannon Reid Hamm of the department's Economic Research Service.
Potatoes, excluded in the overall vegetable count, have recovered from earlier slippage.

American Can Chairman Set
LEAD: Gerald Tsai Jr. was named chairman of the American Can Company yesterday, succeeding William S. Woodside, who is retiring Jan. 31.
Mr.

He will also become president on March 1, succeeding Francis J. Connor.

LEAD: The upbeat mood of the spring and summer couture collections continued today as bright colors and fresh shapes gave a cheerful look to the showings of warm-weather clothes.
While all this gaiety is welcome, sometimes it seems to get out of hand.
Karl Lagerfeld tried so hard to express the new spirit at Chanel that he ended up making styles better suited to the theater than to real life.

Union Head to Lead St. Patrick's Parade
LEAD: The president of the Transport Workers Union of America, John Lawe, was chosen last night to be the grand marshal of the 1987 St.
Patrick's Day Parade, narrowly defeating a challenge by Dorothy Hayden Cudahy of Queens who campaigned to become the first woman to lead the 225-year-old parade.


Schools Boycotted in Spain
LEAD: Students in Spain's high schools boycotted classes today to protest police action during a student march last week in which 25 people were injured, officials said.
Several thousand teen-agers rallied in Puerta del Sol Square here and poured red dye in fountains.
The students demanded the resignation of Interior Minister Jose Barrionuevo.

MOBIL FALLS; LOSS FOR CHEVRON
LEAD: The Mobil Corporation, the country's second-largest oil concern after the Exxon Corporation, said that its earnings plunged 52.7 percent in the fourth quarter.


First Chicago in Acquisition
LEAD: The First Chicago Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire First United Financial Services Inc. for $20.83 a share, or $175.6 million.
The acquisition would establish First Chicago's presence in the western and northwestern Chicago suburbs.


Computer Crime Is 'Big Business'
LEAD: In computers, at least, crime appears to pay.
August Bequai, a Washington lawyer writing in ''Techno-Crimes'' (Lexington Books), estimates that the annual take of computer criminals could reach $5 billion a year.
The greatest potential for high-technology thievery with minimal risk is in electronic fund transfering, Mr.

LEAD: A bitter three-week-old takeover battle involving two leading Swiss food companies ended when Jacobs Suchard said it was abandoning its attempt to buy the preserved food manufacturer Hero.

Israel Extends Price Controls
LEAD: Israel's Government, trade unions and industrialists agreed today to extend price controls on goods and services until March 1988 in an effort to avert labor unrest and a return to hyperinflation.

Market Place; Boise Persists In Paper Chase
LEAD: ANYONE who has seen any of the Boise Cascade Corporation's financial papers lately surely must have seen the line: ''Boise Cascade is a different company than it was 10 years ago, five years ago or even last year at this time.''


Jane Morrison, Film Maker, Is Dead of Malaria in Africa
LEAD: Jane Morrison, an independent film maker, died of malaria Wednesday in Nairobi, Kenya, where she was attending a film festival.
She was 39 years old and lived in Manhattan.


DANCE: FROM PILOBOLUS, THE OLD AND THE NEW
LEAD: PILOBOLUS - that dance troupe specializing in mad scrambles of arms, legs and ideas - opened for a four-week season at the Joyce Theater Tuesday night with a gala benefit that spanned 12 of the 16 years the troupe has been in existence.
The early and more overtly athletic days were represented by two relatively simple pure-movement pieces.

CHRYSLER PULLS ADS FROM 'AMERIKA'
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation, the largest sponsor of the ABC mini-series ''Amerika,'' has pulled its commercials from the program, stating that the car maker's patriotic advertisements would be inappropriate in the 14 1/2-hour film about a Soviet takeover of the United States.


NYNEX AND PACTEL GAIN; SOUTHWESTERN BELL DOWN
LEAD: The Nynex Corporation and the Pacific Telesis Group yesterday reported higher fourth-quarter profits, while earnings fell at the Southwestern Bell Corporation.


MOTHER OF BABY M IS FACING LOSS OF HOME IN A SUIT OVER MORTGAGE
LEAD: The surrogate mother seeking custody of Baby M, Mary Beth Whitehead, faces the threat of losing her home because she and her husband owe $12,000 in back payments on a mortgage granted by her older sister.


Parallels: U-2, Bay of Pigs, Iran
LEAD: Michael R. Beschloss, adjunct historian of American politics and diplomacy at the Smithsonian's National Museum of American History, has worked as a consultant on a number of projects involving the Presidency, like the 1984 celebration of the Truman centennial.
He has also written two well-received books, ''Mayday: Eisenhower, Khrushchev and the U-2 Affair'' and ''Kennedy and Roosevelt: The Uneasy Alliance.

LEAD: A plan to expand Belvedere Lake and shrink the Great Lawn of Central Lawn was presented publicly last night and immediately ran into an unexpected obstacle: the 19 species of dragonfly and damselfly that are said to use the north shore of that small pond as their ''rendezvous.''


Lloyd Plans Cutback
LEAD: Chris Evert Lloyd says she expects this will be her final year of full participation on the women's tennis tour.
She will continue, however, to play selected tournaments, including Wimbledon and the French, United States and Australian opens. ''I would be very, very surprised if I play past this year,'' Lloyd said yesterday.

Radar Trap, and Opportunity
LEAD: The United States is building missile warning radars at Thule in Greenland, a Danish territory, and Fylingdales in Britain.
Soviet officials and some Americans assert these violate the Antiballistic Missile Treaty.
The issue is being debated this week in Denmark, too.
American critics suggest halting construction if the Russians will stop building an almost certainly illegal missile-sensing radar at Krasnoyarsk in Siberia.


AT THE FRONT IN THE GULF WAR: THE IRANIANS SEEM CONFIDENT
LEAD: About three miles behind the Iranian front lines, in what used to be an Iraqi stronghold, there was a traffic jam this morning.


Numbers Are Impressive
LEAD: Jim Catalano, the basketball coach at New Jersey Tech in Newark, an engineering college with high academic standards, was explaining on Monday afternoon the new point-producing power that has made his Highlanders the nation's top-scoring college team.


I.B.M. Upgrades Its PC Convertible
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation, in a move intended to bolster its sagging share of the lightweight portable-computer market, announced several improvements to its PC Convertible computer.
Although an I.B.M. executive said the company was ''very pleased'' with sales of the Convertible, which was introduced in April, machines from Toshiba, Zenith and others have dominated the market with technically superior features at comparable prices.


A FIRST NOVEL'S WINDFALL IN FILM AND CLUB RIGHTS
LEAD: Three months before its scheduled publication date, a first novel acquired for a modest $5,000 advance has already earned its author an additional $2.5 million in motion picture and book-club rights. LEAD: Coca-Cola Classic edged out Pepsi to become the nation's best-selling soft drink in 1986, the industry newsletter Beverage Digest said.

JAPAN KEEPS CAR-EXPORT CURB
LEAD: Bowing to political reality, Japan announced today that it would continue its curbs on automobile exports to the United States for a seventh year.
The decision is part of an effort to head off mounting American protectionist sentiment.

LEAD: One of the marvels of the computer age is the ''boss button.'' Instead of entering sales data, Mr.
Smith is playing a game on the company computer - say ''Leather Goddesses of Phobos.'' Without warning, the boss rounds the corner.

Smith hits the ''control'' and ''B'' (for Boss) keys, and an official-looking data base instantly fills the screen.

IN LEGISLATURE, WOMEN MAKE QUIET STRIDES
LEAD: If the designers of the State Capitol had intended there to be women in the Legislature, logic says, they would have built two bathrooms in the Assembly chamber.
But they did not.
So up until a few years ago, when the men's bathroom was divided in two, women who were legislators ran the risk of being locked out of the chamber during an important vote.


PLAINTIFF DENIES 'BELL JAR' FILM EVENTS
LEAD: A 1979 film of Sylvia Plath's novel ''The Bell Jar'' was shown on two television screens here today in Federal District Court, and a psychiatrist who contends she is the basis for one of its characters denied vehemently that certain scenes in the movie had ever taken place in real life.

LEAD: The Dow Jones industrial average rose sharply to a record level yesterday.
In the process, it nearly offset all of Friday's big loss as Wall Street appeared to regain its magic touch.

LEAD: Returning to the contentious issue of school prayer, the Supreme Court agreed today to consider the constitutionality of a 1982 New Jersey law requiring that public schools permit students to observe one minute of silence daily ''for quiet and private contemplation and introspection.''

Some Nerve in the Philippines
LEAD: How Corazon Aquino must enrage her foes: she refuses to fight like a man.
On the left, zealots thirst for martyrs and shootings, the stuff of revolution.
So what does the President of the Philippines do?
She opens her palace to fist-shaking demonstrators and orders her Cabinet ministers to greet them, for heaven's sake, in an arms-linked human chain of bureaucrats, businessmen, students and Roman Catholic nuns.

LEAD: Pope John Paul II has bestowed the title ''venerable'' on Mother Katharine Drexel, a step that could lead to the heiress nun's being declared a saint.
Mother Drexel, a member of a prominent Philadelphia banking family, founded the Sisters of the Blessed Sacrament in 1891 to work among blacks and American Indians.

Comings and Goings
LEAD: Bob Bailor, the utility infielder traded by the Mets to the Dodgers three years ago in the deal for Sid Fernandez, has been hired by Toronto to manage the Blue Jays' Class A farm team in Dunedin, Fla.
Bailor, 36 years old, was the first player selected by the Blue Jays in the 1976 expansion draft.

LEAD: Children learn of life's cruelties at an early age.
By kindergarten, most have seen the ice cream topple from the cone, the dime disappear through the grate, the balloon tangle itself in the treetop.
But few have been disillusioned as brutally as Shannon Burns, age 10, of San Jose, Calif.
The I.R.S.


WEST BANK STUDENTS MARCH IN SUPPORT OF FATAH FIGHTERS
LEAD: Hundreds of students at Al Najah University in Nablus, in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, defied warnings from Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin and demonstrated today in support of Al Fatah, Yasir Arafat's guerrilla organization.


PUBLIC BLAMES NASA OFFICIALS
LEAD: One year after the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, the American people blame officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration for the disaster, rather than the scientists and engineers who developed the craft's technology, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.


U.S. INVESTIGATES A HOLDOUT JUROR IN MISTRIAL
LEAD: Federal authorities said yesterday that they were investigating whether a juror had acted improperly in holding out for the acquittal of an accused organized-crime figure during a trial last November.
The judge in the case said the juror should be prosecuted if the inquiry indicated wrongdoing.


ON DRUG ALERT AT AN MX MISSILE BASE
LEAD: Three times a day, every day of the year, the Air Force security police on this nuclear missile base set up a roadblock at a different site and randomly stop five or six cars to search for illicit drugs.


WHEN SIMMS SAW RED
LEAD: Sometimes you can't even trust a good cliche.
There is the belief, for example, that bulls get mad when they see red.
There are those, however, who contend that this is false, that bulls don't get mad when they see red.
They say cows get mad when they see red, but bulls get mad when people mistake them for cows.


Stone to Purchase Southwest Forest
LEAD: The Stone Container Corporation, one of the nation's largest producers of corrugated container and paperboard products, said today that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire Southwest Forest Industries for $32.25 a share, or $441.8 million.

WASHINGTON STILL DIGGING OUT
LEAD: A worker using a snowblower to clear a path in front of the United States Supreme Court Building.
The Federal Government has offered to buy de-icing equipment for the city's transit authority after snowstorms paralyzed the subway system and left thousands of Federal workers stranded.
A total of 26 inches of snow covered the capital in storms on Thursday, Sunday and Monday.

Dow Chemical, Utility in Pact
LEAD: The Consumers Power Company and the Dow Chemical Company, as expected, announced a $600 million definitive agreement today to convert the idled Midland nuclear plant to burn natural gas.


60-MINUTE GOURMET
LEAD: BITOK, an easily put-together entree, is one of the most interesting distortions of an English word first ''borrowed'' by the French and further misappropriated by the Russians, who introduced the dish to France around 1920.


Nasdaq Short Interest Down by 12.4% in Month
LEAD: The National Association of Securities Dealers Inc. reported yesterday that short interest on Nasdaq stocks was down 25.7 million shares, or 12.4 percent, in the month ended Jan. 15, to 181.6 million shares.

LEAD: From the first flake of confetti to the final kazoo chorus of ''California, Here I Come'' it was a pep rally, it was a rock concert, it was a New Year's Eve blowout and it was a revival meeting.
But it was not Koch country.
The Giants celebrated their Super Bowl victory today in the Meadowlands stadium that, according to Coach Bill Parcells, the team calls ''our house.


WAGE INCREASES FELL TO 3.5% IN 1986, LABOR DEPT. REPORTS
LEAD: Wage and salary increases last year averaged 3.5 percent, down from 4.4 percent in 1985, as more employers issued year-end bonuses to their workers rather than larger raises, the Government reported today.

ANTONE ATALLAH
LEAD: Antone Atallah, a former Foreign Minister and a Member of Parliament, died today, his family said.
He was 89 years old.
Mr.
Atallah was a member of Jordan's lower house of Parliament for the Jerusalem district and later as a member of the Senate, the upper house.
Mr.
Atallah, born in Jerusalem of a Greek Orthodox family, was Jordan's Foreign Minister in 1964-65 and in 1970.

Emhart Divestiture
LEAD: The Emhart Corporation said that it would sell its assets in South Africa as part of its worldwide restructuring program.
Emhart's three operations in Port Elizabeth, South Africa, acquired in the company's 1976 purchase of the USM Corporation, have annual revenues of about $32 million and employ 900 people.


JUSTICES OVERTURN 3 DECISIONS BACKING DEFENDANTS
LEAD: The Supreme Court overturned three unrelated state court decisions favorable to criminal defendants today, taking a narrow view of its rules curbing police interrogations and upholding the procedures used in sentencing a California defendant to death.


EX-RESIDENT HELD IN NUN'S DEATH
LEAD: A former resident of a long-term shelter for the homeless was arrested yesterday and charged with the fatal stabbing of a 65-year-old Roman Catholic nun who lived and worked at the Bronx shelter.

LEAD: A prosecutor today asked a court today to acquit Otto Lambsdorff, a former Economics Minister and a senior figure in the Free Democratic Party, of charges he accepted $50,000 between 1977 and 1980 from the Flick concern in return for granting lucrative tax waivers.

WINE TALK
LEAD: IN a classic New Yorker drawing, a glowering husband sitting behind a newspaper says to his equally glowering wife: ''What did I have for lunch?

Fiat Profits Rise 12.5%
LEAD: Fiat, Italy's leading industrial group, said today that its estimated operating profits rose 12.5 percent last year.
Fiat's chairman, Giovanni Agnelli, commenting on Fiat's performance in his annual letter to shareholders, said the operating profit rose to 2.55 trillion lire, or $1.75 billion, in 1986.

Maryland County
LEAD: Ann Arundel County, Md., is offering about $61 million of refunding bonds with a maximum yield of 6 1/4 percent for issues due in 2012 through 2014, through underwriters led by the First National Bank of Chicago.
The financing also includes yields ranging from 3 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 4.60 percent in 1992, 5.40 percent in 1997, 5.95 percent in 2002 and 6.15 percent in 2007.

LEAD: The extraordinary bidding shown in the diagram is an accurate record of a deal in the 1986 world team championships in Miami Beach.

LEAD: The Procter &amp; Gamble Company, benefiting from improved gross margins, reported a 15.2 percent increase in earnings for its second quarter.

Complete Quarterbacks
LEAD: Phil Simms, in leading the Giants to victory in Super Bowl XXI, connected on 22 of 25 pass attempts for an 88-percent completion ratio, the best in Super Bowl history.
Simms, who set another Super Bowl record with 10 consecutive completions, easily surpassed Ken Anderson's previous percentage record, set five years ago.


Norfolk Considers Acquiring Piedmont
LEAD: In a disclosure that many analysts found puzzling, the Norfolk Southern Corporation said yesterday that it was considering the acquisition of Piedmont Airlines.
Such a merger, if it occurred, would be the first between a railroad and an airline in the United States.


Elizabeth G. Holt, 81, Peripatetic Art Expert
LEAD: Elizabeth Gilmore Holt, an art historian who wrote widely on the social context of art, died Monday at her home in Washington.
She was 81 years old.

LEAD: The House Veterans Affairs Committee will hold hearings on conduct by the Veterans Administration that has prompted a Federal district judge in San Francisco to impose more than $134,000 in penalties against the agency.


SCREENING URGED FOR ALL PREGNANT
LEAD: The American Liver Foundation and four medical experts yesterday called for routine screening of all pregnant women for the hepatitis B virus, a major cause of cirrhosis and liver cancer.

Esposito Decision Due Today
LEAD: Phil Esposito said yesterday that he was still agonizing over what to do about the Rangers' coaching situation.
He said that a meeting would be held today to ''clarify everything.'' He even went so far as to say that his decision would be harder to reach than ever.


ST. JOHN'S DEFEATS VILLANOVA, 61 TO 58
LEAD: St.
John's is rapidly becoming basketball's version of the hitless wonders.
The Redmen put together another tremendous defensive effort, with weak offensive support, and defeated Villanova, 61-58, at Alumni Hall last night.


Swiss Account Holders Challenge Iran Inquiry
LEAD: At least eight parties linked to Swiss bank accounts in the American investigation of the Iran affair have appealed a Swiss decision to give legal assistance to the United States, Swiss authorities said today.

HORNSBY'S 'WAY IT IS' CLIMBS THE ROCK CHARTS
LEAD: ''A SONG about racism with jazz piano soloing is certainly not your obvious hit,'' the pianist-songwriter-singer Bruce Hornsby said a few days ago. ''I don't think it's commercial at all.'' But that song, ''The Way It Is,'' moved steadily up the pop charts to No. 1 after its release last September, and it has made Bruce Hornsby and the Range one of the leading new bands to emerge in 1986, selling more than 1.7 million copies of their first album, also titled ''The Way It Is'' (RCA).


'BROKEN VOWS' ON CBS
LEAD: FATHER McMAHON is having a crisis of faith - sleepless nights spent staring at the ceiling.
Clearly, he is ripe for a trauma.
In ''Broken Vows,'' a two-hour movie on CBS at 9 tonight, he finds one: murder, nastiness and sex.
It's not an entirely persuasive television movie, but it is more interesting than most.


Technical Workers Snarled by Tax Law
LEAD: Scores of engineers, designers, computer programmers, systems analysts or other similarly skilled workers who make a living as independent consultants are planning to march on Washington tomorrow to protest a tax amendment that hurts them, confuses their employers and apparently puzzles the Government as well.

Victim of AIDS Is Rehired
LEAD: The Navy has rehired a commisary worker who was dismissed last year after contracting AIDS, his lawyer said Monday.
The lawyer, Katherine Franke, said the Navy rescinded its dismissal of 32-year-old Ed Horan, who took a medical leave from his job at the Navy Supply Center last August when he contracted pneumonia related to acquired immune deficiency syndrome.


Precious Metals Surge; Cotton Down Sharply
LEAD: Precious metals futures prices surged higher yesterday, tethered once again to the movements in the value of the dollar.


Steel Production Slows
LEAD: Steel production fell 1.3 percent last week, to 1.34 million tons, from the previous week's 1.36 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.
Production slowed to 58.9 percent of capacity from 59.5 percent.
Output for the year so far totaled 4.6 million tons, down 21.9 percent from 5.89 million tons in 1986.

Chrysler Lowers Rate
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation said it had lowered its loan rate on its buyer incentive programs to 3.7 percent, from 3.9 percent, and was expanding its selection of cars eligible for rebates, which range from $300 to $1,000.
It said annual percentage rates range from 3.7 percent for 24 months to 9.9 percent for 60 months on selected 1986 and 1987 model cars.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article on Friday about The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund misstated the total contributions to the 75th annual appeal.
The record amount received last year -$2,726,331.40 - was exceeded this Monday, not last Thursday.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A chart on the Washington Talk page on Jan. 5, comparing the First Congress and the 100th Congress described the racial makeup of the 100th incorrectly.
Two of the 100 Senators and 3 of the 435 Representatives are Asian-Americans.

LEAD: Is Patrick Ewing, who is averaging 19.8 points and 8.7 rebounds a game for the Knicks, the fourth best center in the Eastern Conference?


Paine Webber Profit Up 23.2%
LEAD: The Paine Webber Group Inc. said yesterday that its net earnings in the most recent quarter rose 23.2 percent, to $17.5 million, from $14.2 million in the corresponding period a year ago.

Baylor Honored Again
LEAD: For the second straight season, Don Baylor has been voted baseball's top designated hitter by public relations directors of American League teams, broadcasters and sportswriters.
Baylor earned the honor for 1985 as a member of the Yankees, who traded him to the Red Sox for Mike Easler before the 1986 season.

LEAD: After Mark Irgang paid $162,000 at a city auction for a burnt wreck of a building at 2712 White Plains Road in the Bronx, he renovated it into an indoor flea market.

LEAD: Nearly a decade after the National Rifle Association went through a sweeping leadership upheaval, a new power struggle is under way in the nation's foremost gun lobby.


Atonement for Racist Episodes Isn't Enough
LEAD: Howard Beach, N.Y.
Forsyth County, Ga.
The Citadel in South Carolina.
The University of Massachusetts at Amherst.
These are new place names on the map of racial violence.
As symbols, they remind us that the agenda of the Rev.
Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr. is still unfinished, that race-conscious behavior continues to endanger our society.


Advances in Tin Cans; Lasers Help In Welding Smooth Seam
LEAD: SOME manufacturers contend that the seams on tin cans are unsightly and make labeling and decoration more difficult.
They say technological advances in the welding process will make these seams less noticeable and, in turn, create more attractive cans.


73 Seconds of Silence Set by Space Workers
LEAD: Workers for the space agency will observe 73 seconds of silence, President Reagan will address them by a satellite television hookup later and a memorial service will be held near the Arlington National Cemetery as Americans recall the destruction of the space shuttle Challenger one year ago.

Champagne Customers
LEAD: Britain is the world's leading importer of champagne, the Champagne Bureau said today.
Shipments to Britain totaled 16.1 million bottles last year, up 5 percent from 1985.
The United States ranked second with imports of 14.85 million bottles, up 4.4 percent.


U.S. NAVY BOLSTERS MIDEAST PRESENCE
LEAD: The Administration has ordered five Navy combat ships to move deeper into the Persian Gulf and has instructed the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy to remain in the Mediterranean Sea indefinitely, Pentagon officials said today.


HOUSE AND SENATE VOTE COOLING-OFF IN L.I.R.R. WALKOUT
LEAD: Congress approved legislation today to end the 10-day Long Island Rail Road strike by imposing a 60-day cooling-off period.

LEAD: The warden of Westchester County's correctional institutions for 14 years, Norwood E. Jackson, was named yesterday by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke to be Commissioner of Corrections.
Mr.
Jackson, who is black, becomes the first member of a minority group to hold cabinet-level rank in the Westchester government.

Arrest the Customers as Well as the Drug Dealers in Our Parks
LEAD: To the Editor:


Head of G.M. Sees End To Perot Controversy
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation is recovering after a year of bad news, the company's chairman, Roger B. Smith, told a group of pension fund managers at an unusual meeting yesterday, the group's leaders said.


HEAT WHERE IT'S NEEDED
LEAD: WITH the advent of central heating in the mid-19th century, cast iron registers and grilles were used as a way to distribute heat in a home.
Installed in walls, ceilings and floors, the grilles enabled hot air, created by the basement furnace, to circulate from room to room.
Now these registers and grilles are being revived, largely by those using wood stoves.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo's closest advisers insist he is still making up his mind about running for President.

FINANCE BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Arizona Public Service Co. is offering $150 million of Baa-2/BBB+ rated 9 percent first-mortgage bonds due 2017, at 99, to yield 9.10 percent, through the First Boston Corporation.
Nonrefundable for five years, the bonds yield 1.46 percentage points more than the 9 1/4 percent Treasury bond due 2016.

LEAD: Forstmann Little &amp; Company, one of the most successful practitioners of the art of the leveraged buyout, has taken on a fifth general partner, the firm said yesterday.


GOTTI'S LAWYERS WARN OF EFFECT OF JUROR INQUIRY
LEAD: Defense lawyers at the trial of John Gotti and six co-defendants voiced concern yesterday that the investigation of a juror who held out for an acquital in another case would have a ''chilling'' and ''prejudicial'' effect on their case and on juries in all criminal cases.


Market Place; Global Funds For Bonds
LEAD: GLOBAL mutual funds that invest mainly in bonds of foreign governments are becoming popular.
These funds offer American investors a potential play on the declining value of the dollar against overseas currencies.


'CRIME' EXTENDED
LEAD: The Arene Stage has extended the run of its production of ''Crime and Punishment'' through March 8.
Performances of the play, based on the Dotoevsky novel and directed by the Soviet expatriate Yru Lyubimov, have been sold out since the opening on Jan. 8.

GUILTY PLEA BY BOESKY EMPLOYEE
LEAD: Michael Davidoff, formerly the head trader at a securities company controlled by Ivan F. Boesky, pleaded guilty yesterday to having engaged in bogus stock transactions with a British broker to evade Federal laws requiring brokers to maintain minimum amounts of capital.


STAGE: 'BLUE IS FOR BOYS,' HOMOSEXUAL HIGH JINKS
LEAD: ACIDIC badinage zips around the stage in Robert Patrick's farcical comedy ''Blue Is for Boys,'' a wildly fanciful imagining of the goings-on in an Upper West Side apartment converted into a college residence hall for male homosexual students.


MOSTLY MISERY FOR KNICKS
LEAD: There appears to be little to brag about for the Knicks at the halfway point of the season.
They have a record of 13-29 - two games worse than at this point last season - a four-game losing streak, and diminishing hopes of qualifying for the playoffs.


COMPUTER SHAKEOUT AWAITED
LEAD: For a little more than two years, computers for scientific and technical users have been the hottest sector in the industry, sending manufacturers scrambling to keep up with demand.
Though sales are still soaring, the manufacturers' ranks have so swelled that industry leaders and analysts alike say a shakeout is inevitable.

JAZZ: SAUTER-FINEGAN GROUP
LEAD: ''FROM the time the late Eddie Sauter and I started this band, everything went wrong but the music,'' Bill Finegan remarked at Town Hall on Sunday evening early in the concert by a reconstituted Sauter-Finegan Orchestra.
The music certainly was splendid.
And perhaps today's audiences, as well as the musicians involved, are ready for the uniquely evocative, gleefully eccentric sounds of an early 1950's dance band that thought nothing of accompanying a sentimental ballad in several different keys at once or voicing a swinging riff for orchestra bells, harp and tuba.


Koch Ends Visit to Poland
LEAD: Mayor Koch meeting yesterday in Warsaw with Jozef Cardinal Glemp, the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland.
As the Mayor ended his private visit, Deputy Secretary of State John Whitehead arrived on an official visit to determine whether the United States should continue sanctions.
Page A8. (AP)


The Editorial Notebook; Fraud and Garbage in Science
LEAD: An elaborate case of scientific fraud, first discovered at the Harvard Medical School in 1981, has turned out to have another, more surprising dimension.
Besides fraud, according to an analysis in Nature magazine, the papers of Dr.
John Darsee and his co-authors were studded with obvious errors and inconsistencies.


Elle Team Ventures Far Afield
LEAD: WITH the United States version of the French fashion magazine Elle booming, the partners in the publishing joint venture have decided to give it another go.
Their next effort will be a movie magazine, a category that has had its share of publishing failures.


Rodgers Guilty In Assault Case
LEAD: Johnny Rodgers, the 1972 Heisman Trophy winner as a Nebraska halfback, was convicted today of assault with a deadly weapon and being a former felon in possession of a firearm.


Britain Plans Merger Curbs
LEAD: The British Government, accused by the opposition Labor Party of having failed to take strong action against illegal financial activity, said today that it was going to tighten controls over corporate takeovers.


SPECULATION ON VISITS
LEAD: The Archbishop's statements came as some American officials suggested that Mr.
Waite's previous ability to act successfully as a hostage negotiator in Beirut may have actually been the result of the White House's secret deals.


Prime Computer's 5 3/4% Debentures
LEAD: Prime Computer Inc., a Natick, Mass., computer company, is offering $350 million of 5 3/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2012, at a price of 100, through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham &amp; Company.


SUFFOLK POLICE ARE DESCRIBED AS DEFICIENT
LEAD: The chairman of the State Commission of Investigation said today that the Suffolk County Police Department had displayed a ''startling lack of professionalism.'' A 14-month investigation, he said, has found evidence of perjury and fabrication of evidence by the police.


SHULTZ MEETS WITH LEADER OF REBELS IN SOUTH AFRICA
LEAD: Oliver Tambo, the head of the African National Congress, called on Secretary of State George P. Shultz today to use American influence to press other Western countries to impose economic sanctions on South Africa at least as strong as those enacted by Congress over President Reagan's veto.


GOING OUT GUIDE
LEAD: JOYCE IN PARIS The Gotham Book Mart and Gallery, 41 West 47th Street (719-4476), has had a relationship with James Joyce for more than a half-century, since ''Ulysses,'' which was classified as an immoral, unimportable work by the Federal Government, was sold under the counter at the store.
The society of James Joyce admirers still meets at the Gotham and his books are sold over the counter in this most venerable of quality New


ZAIRE IS SUPPORTING IMMUNIZATION TEST AGAINST AIDS VIRUS
LEAD: The Government of Zaire has given its support to an experimental immunization project against AIDS being conducted in that country by a team of French and Zairian scientists, according to a statement issued by the Executive Council of Zaire.


CAROLINA OVERTAKES CLEMSON
LEAD: Kenny Smith scored a career-high 41 points as North Carolina rallied from a 12-point halftime deficit to defeat Clemson, 108-99, in an Atlantic Coast Conference game last night.


Data Delay Weighed
LEAD: The Government may push back the release of key trade and economic reports by as much as two weeks because of concern about their accuracy, the Commerce Department said today.


KEY CONTRA LEADER IS SAID TO PLAN TO RESIGN
LEAD: A key civilian leader of the Nicaraguan rebel movement has told State Department officials and his political associates that he intends to resign, sources close to him said today.


Santa Fe Seeks I.C.C. Approval
LEAD: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation said it had reached an agreement with the Denver &amp; Rio Grande Western Railroad in hopes of securing Interstate Commerce Commission approval to merge two of its rail units.
The I.C.C. last July denied a petition by Santa Fe Southern Pacific to merge two of its units, the Santa Fe Railway and the Southern Pacific Transportation Company.


Not So Funny
LEAD: The Harlem Globetrotters have been doing their recent globetrotting without five of their key players.
As a result of a labor dispute, Lou Dunbar, a star of last year's squad, left the California-based team last fall along with four other 1986 players.

LEAD: To the Editor:


KEMP FAULTS THREE G.O.P. RIVALS AS HE PRAISES SOCIAL SECURITY PLAN
LEAD: In the first open skirmish over ideas in the 1988 Presidential campaign, Representative Jack F. Kemp today criticized three other Republican Presidential hopefuls for their positions on Social Security.
He vigorously defended the existing system, which he said must remain ''the bedrock of retirement security.


CAPITAL ADOPTS LAW ON INTERIOR DESIGN
LEAD: LEGISLATION prohibiting individuals from practicing interior design or calling themselves interior designers unless they are licensed was recently passed by the District of Columbia City Council.
Proponents of the measure are calling it a major victory in their three-year-old national campaign to require licensing of interior designers.

Star of Stars
LEAD: Julius Erving, playing in his final season, has been named a starter in the All-Star Game for the 15th consecutive season - 4 times in the American Basketball Association and 11 in the National Basketball Association.
He was not in the opening lineup in 1972, his first pro season, but still managed to score 20 points, which he has maintained as his average in All-Star competition.


Slim Loss for Woman In Grand Marshal Bid
LEAD: Dorothy Hayden Cudahy will have to wait at least one more year in her bid to become the first woman to serve as grand marshal in the 225-year-old St.
Patrick's Day Parade.


Third World Subsidy
LEAD: The European Community foreign ministers have agreed to give four underdeveloped countries a special subsidy already available to 66 states in Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific, community officials said today.
Ministers agreed Tuesday that the subsidy program, under which the community compensates certain countries for losses in export earnings, be extended to Bangladesh, Haiti, Laos and Nepal.


U.S. SEEKS DELAY ON NUCLEAR DUMP
LEAD: The Reagan Administration today proposed a five-year delay in opening the nation's first burial site for highly radioactive nuclear waste.
It said that a decision on where to place a second repository need not be made before the mid-1990's.


STUDENTS IN SPAIN WIN SOME DEMANDS
LEAD: The Government of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, confronted by student strikes and some of the worst youth violence in Spain in a decade, offered today to increase university scholarships and student participation in the schools.


ROBERT WARREN
LEAD: Robert Warren, a song writer and music arranger, died of pancreatic cancer Monday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 71 years old.

An Electoral Gap
LEAD: Analysis of exit poll data from last fall's Senate elections suggests that the political difference between how men and women vote is alive and well.
A breakdown compiled by CBS News indicates that women voted significantly more Democratic than men.
Of 23 races analyzed, in only one did the Republican candidate appeal more to women than to men.

Washburn in Clinic
LEAD: Chris Washburn, the Golden State Warriors' rookie center who was the third player picked in the college draft last spring, entered a drug-treatment clinic yesterday after voluntarily seeking help.
The team said that Washburn, who was placed on the injured list Tuesday for a kidney problem, was expected to remain at the Adult Substance Abuse Program Drug Rehabilitation Center in Van Nuys, Calif., for a minimum of four weeks.


HEAVY BURDEN OF COLLEGE DEBT RAISES ANXIETY FOR YOUNG FAMILIES' FUTURE
LEAD: In May, Mark Kaplan, a senior at the University of Michigan, will graduate with a bachelor's degree in English, $18,000 in student loans hanging over him and no idea how he will pay the money back.


Dow Rises by 12.94 To Another Record
LEAD: Profit takers robbed Wall Street of much of its energy yesterday, but in the end, the stock market was able to gather enough strength to move once again to record levels.


Chain-Collision in Fog Kills 4
LEAD: Four people died and five others were critically injured today as 33 vehicles collided in dense fog on Interstate 10, about 15 miles west of New Orleans, the state police said.
Officers said the collisions began about noon when three tractor-trailers collided.
Four people died when the small car in which they were riding was crushed beneath a tractor-trailer that burst into flames, the police said.

'BELL JAR' JURY IS TOLD OF SUFFERING
LEAD: After a day of emotional testimony by a psychiatrist who said that a 1979 film of Sylvia Plath's novel ''The Bell Jar'' had made her suffer ''extreme anxiety'' for which she was still in therapy, attorneys for both sides met with Judge Robert E. Keeton to discuss a settlement in the trial.

LEAD: PGA West, the controversial Pete Dye-designed course, continues to be the main subject around the practice greens as the golfers prepare for the A.T.&amp;T.
Pebble Beach National Pro-Am on three of their favorite courses - Pebble Beach, Cypress Point and Spyglass Hill.


Spinoff to Settle Avondale Dispute
LEAD: The battle for control of Avondale Industries has ended with the announcement that the company will sell six subsidiaries to a new concern being formed by William F. Connell.
Mr.
Connell, Avondale's chairman, is expected to leave the corporation when the sale is made final in late March.
Details of the agreement were not disclosed.

LEAD: Behind the theme of ''competitiveness'' that President Reagan struck in his State of the Union Message Tuesday lies new political attention to failings in the American economy that have troubled industrial analysts for years.

Bridge: A Delicate Bidding Decision Paid Off in a Florida Game
LEAD: Some very difficult bidding decisions arise when there is a weakness for no-trump purposes but no convenient trump fit.
An example is the diagramed deal, played recently in Hobe Sound, Fla.
There was no eight-card fit in a major suit, no nine-card fit in a minor suit and three no-trump was headed for heart trouble.

LEAD: Whitney Houston's two-year-old album has brought her five American Music Awards, while Lionel Richie, whose album was not even nominated, won four awards for songs and videos from his ''Dancing on the Ceiling'' album.


Truck in Newark Kills Stowaway Fleeing Ship
LEAD: Nine stowaways on a cargo vessel from Ecuador jumped ship yesterday in Port Newark, and one was killed and one was seriously injured minutes later when they were hit by a truck, a Port Authority spokesman said.

EATING FRESH FRUIT CAN REDUCE RISK OF STROKE, RESEARCHERS REPORT
LEAD: Eating an extra helping of fresh fruit or vegetables each day could cut the risk of stroke nearly in half by increasing the body's supply of potassium, researchers have concluded.

LEAD: A Federal district judge has ordered a woman who helped aliens flee political upheaval in Central America to report to prison to begin serving a six-month term.
The woman, Stacy Lynn Merkt, was sentenced in March 1985 after being convicted of conspiracy to transport illegal aliens.
The judge, Filemon Vela, denied her motion to reconsider the sentence on Jan.


JOINT PRESSURES BEHIND U.S. ACTION ON L.I.R.R.
LEAD: The vote by Congress to end the Long Island Rail Road strike resulted from the bipartisan efforts of a Governor and two Senators, pressure from 110,000 commuters, two snowstorms and the fear that a solution would not emerge from bargaining for days, or even weeks.

LEAD: The Union Carbide Corporation yesterday reported a substantial quarterly loss but a profit for 1986 as a whole.
Another chemical giant, E. I. du Pont de Nemours &amp; Company, was down 11.1 percent in the quarter but up 38 percent for the full year.

LEAD: American and European negotiators are close to an agreement that should keep a damaging trans-Atlantic trade war from breaking out this weekend, officials of both sides said today.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH much Indian dance is religious in nature, it is not necessarily also unremittingly solemn.

DESIGN NOTEBOOK
LEAD: WHEN the Museum of Modern Art opened its exhibition of Mario Botta's architecture last November, the Swiss architect's first work in the United States was being completed in Long Island City, Queens.
People who saw his monumental brick houses and schools displayed in the show could simply take the subway to the International Design Center, New York and see firsthand the surprising furniture showroom he designed for International Contract Furnishings.

LEAD: The Emergency Medical Services said yesterday that the 43 hospitals in New York City's emergency ambulance system would soon be required to have fully trained attending physicians and more nurses and lifesaving equipment in their emergency rooms 24 hours a day.

LEAD: Both Republicans and Democrats in Congress charged today that President Reagan's proposals for health insurance for catastrophic illness fell far short of what was needed.


HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: WHEN snow piles up on the roof in freezing weather, ice dams can form at the edges of the roof, particularly above the eaves.
Water may be trapped by these dams and eventually back up under the shingles, dripping into the attic and damaging insulation, plaster, gypsum board, paint or wallpaper.

LEAD: William G. Rabe, a former director of the Manufacturers Trust Company, died Jan. 17 at his home in Palm Beach, Fla., after a long illness.
He was 90 years old.

LEAD: Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole today proposed granting airlines an antitrust exemption to let them jointly discuss ways to reduce airline delays.

'Political Is Personal'
LEAD: Artworks by 90 women will be shown in ''The Political Is Personal,'' at the Ceres Gallery, 91 Franklin Street, from Feb. 3 through 21.
Sponsored in part by the New York State Council on the Arts, the show is the third annual exhibition for the New York Feminist Art Institute and Women's Center for Learning.


'Platoon' and 'Critical' Lead Box-Office Sales
LEAD: The Vietnam War film ''Platoon'' nearly equaled Richard Pryor's ''Critical Condition'' at the box office last weekend, even though it played in about one-sixth as many theaters.


KIDNAPPINGS PROTESTED IN BEIRUT
LEAD: Firyal Polhill, right foreground, wife of the kidnapped American professor Robert Polhill, and relatives of Leba-nese terror victims at rally yesterday.
The Beirut University College announced a strike following the abduction of Mr.
Polhill and three other professors last week. (Reuters)


NAVY MOVES SHIPS
LEAD: The State Department today barred travel to Lebanon on United States passports, and the Government reinforced its naval presence in the eastern Mediterranean and the Persian Gulf.

5 Directors Nominated As Best by Their Guild
LEAD: The Directors Guild of America today nominated five people as best film director.
They were Randa Haines for ''Children of a Lesser God,'' Woody Allen for ''Hannah and Her Sisters,'' Oliver Stone for ''Platoon,'' James Ivory for ''A Room with a View'' and Rob Reiner for ''Stand by Me.''


Armco to Sell Units
LEAD: Armco Inc. said it would sell several of its steel-tubing operations in Europe to the London-based TI Group for about $41 million.
The agreement includes Armco's small-diameter tubing business in Europe, consisting of a steel-strip coating operation in Liege, Belgium, and 10 facilities in Sweden, Denmark, Italy, Belgium and Spain.


SOME OF THE BEST STAYED ON SIDELINES
LEAD: A frequent caller to local newspapers and radio shows is someone who identifies himself as Steve, the Buck man.

PACT ENDS THE RUTGERS STRIKE
LEAD: Striking clerks and service employees returned to their jobs this morning at Rutgers University after tentative agreement was reached to end a nine-day strike at the three main campuses of the state university.

VALERIAN TRIFA, AN ARCHBISHOP WITH A FASCIST PAST, DIES AT 72
LEAD: Archbishop Valerian Trifa , who was deported from the United States in 1984 after being accused of being a Nazi supporter who incited attacks on Jews and other civilians in World War II, died yesterday in a hospital in Cascais, Portugal.
He was 72 years old and recently suffered a heart attack.

Fundamental Awards
LEAD: Fundamentalists Anonymous, an 18-month-old group based in New York, has chosen the Rev.
Pat Robertson, the television evangelist who is an unnanounced contender for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination, for a ''Hall of Infamy'' award.


LYNCH SISTERS SEEK SAME BLUE RIBBON
LEAD: One of the runners has set national records and the other, sprinting like a shadow on the heels of the first, would like to accomplish similar feats.
Theirs is the very essence of a rivalry: they are sisters, a couple of smooth-gaited, well-spoken city girls with two years and nothing much else to separate them.


Precious Metals Drop; Bond Contracts Gain
LEAD: Jitters over the value of the dollar sent reverberations yesterday through the markets for precious metals and interest rate futures.


U.S. Presses Airbus Fight
LEAD: The United States is ready to file charges of unfair-trade practices against Airbus Industrie, the European airplane-building consortium, if it builds A330 and A340 jetliners to compete against the McDonnell Douglas Corporation's new MD-11, officials here said today.


ISRAELIS REASSESS SUPPLYING ARMS TO SOUTH AFRICA
LEAD: Under pressure from both the United States Congress and American Jews, Israel is reassessing its arms and trade relationship with South Africa, Israeli officials and foreign policy experts say.


THE THEATER: 'WE SHALL,' RIGHTS ERA
LEAD: KARMYN LOTT'S ''We Shall'' is a celebration of the Rev.
Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr. and the civil-rights movement of the 1960's, and its funnier episodes and rousing musical numbers certainly leave one in a surprisingly festive spirit.
It is surprising because Miss Lott's story, about a Howard University student who returns to his hometown in Texas in 1968 to spark a civil-rights drive, has its serious purposes.

Fowler as Spoilsport
LEAD: After winning control of the Senate last November, Democrats on the Senate Commerce Committee began sharpening their knives in anticipation of President Reagan's renomination of Mark S. Fowler as a member of the Federal Communications Commission.
But now Mr.

Bethlehem Net Of $34.2 Million
LEAD: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's third-largest steelmaker, said yesterday that it had earned $34.2 million, or 55 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, in contrast to a loss of $77.5 million a year ago.


WHAT'S UNREAD, YELLOW AND STASHED ALL OVER?
LEAD: A nationwide search of newspaper offices, city halls, garages, attics and basements has uncovered newspapers carrying about 55,000 separate and sometimes long-forgotten names, including at least one from a town that no longer exists.


L.I.R.R. SERVICE IS DUE TO START THIS WEEKEND
LEAD: After an 11-day strike, service on the Long Island Rail Road should resume Saturday, the president of the line, Bruce C. McIver, announced last night.


Transactions
LEAD: BASEBALL YANKEES (AL) - Signed Bob Shirley, pitcher, to a one-year contract.
Announced that Ron Romanick and Eric Schmidt, pitchers; Bob Geren and Fred Gonzalez, catchers; Bobby Meacham, Bryan Little, Chris Alvarez, Shane Turner and Jeff Moronko, infielders, had been invited to spring training as nonroster players.

SETTING THE RIGHT TONE FOR 'NEW' CARNEGIE HALL
LEAD: ANYBODY who has spent time in Carnegie Hall since it reopened last month knows that - despite the painstaking care during its restoration and the oceans of public reassurance afterward - the acoustics of this magnificent space are not the same.
The changes, if not dramatic, are at least significant, and I think all the parties concerned - the people who run Carnegie Hall, the people who play there and the listeners who buy tickets - are going to have to come out from behind the wall of public relations and talk about it openly.

Genesco in Canada
LEAD: Genesco Inc. has signed an agreement to allow a group of investors to buy the company's operations in Canada, the company said.
The producer of footwear and men's apparel will sell three plants and 330 retail stores to a corporation controlled by Michael K. Graye and a group of Canadian investors, including the Royal Bank of Canada, a Genesco spokesman, John Pennington, said.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about the killing of a nun at a halfway house in the Bronx misidentified the men shown.
The police officer was Andrew Pecorino and the man leaving the house was Robert Martinez.


Let's Do Something About Parole Board Errors
LEAD: To the Editor:


Fannie Mae Issue For Home Savings
LEAD: Home Savings of America is offering $454 million of Federal National Mortgage Association securities backed by adjustable-rate mortgages, with the First Boston Corporation as underwriter.

WALL MASKS WITH DRAMA
LEAD: FOR the past five years, on her annual summer trips to Venice, the interior designer Altina Pierro Vergata, left, has collected modern papier mache and leather masks, and brass-topped wood walking sticks.
Most of the masks and sticks are handmade and depict classic characters from the 16th-century commedia dell'arte theater.

U.S. Woman Arrested On Thai-Burmese Line
LEAD: A New Jersey woman who has been campaigning on behalf of the rebellious Shan people in Burma was arrested today as she crossed the Thai border.
She was later reported to have been released, fined about $40 and ordered deported.


Contra Connection: Stalking Film Rights
LEAD: Given the mystery surrounding the Reagan Administration's secret effort to keep the Nicaraguan rebels supplied with arms, perhaps it was inevitable there would be talk about a movie.


BEST HOPE FOR NETS: '87 LOTTERY
LEAD: The season only seems to grow longer for the Nets.
At their present pace, they are likely to finish the season with their worst record in a decade and without a spot in the playoffs.
They have endured a succession of injuries, smallish crowds in their own arena and the indignity of losing at home with frightening regularity.


SCHOLARS BEGIN TO DELVE INTO CARTER'S DOCUMENTS
LEAD: Scholars and historians today began sifting through the first six million documents to be made public from the archives of the Carter Administration, but there was little expectation that the first papers would provide major disclosures.


RECTAL: STALLMAN, A FLUTIST
LEAD: ROBERT STALLMAN, a flutist who performs and teaches in both the New York and Boston areas, gave a musically rewarding if rather overbright and insistently performed recital Tuesday night in Weill Recital Hall.
These qualities may reflect Mr.
Stallman's association with Jean-Pierre Rampal, who has a similar approach, or the acoustics of Weill Hall.
