People
LEAD: *
Donald E. Fagan is joining Cahners Publishing as a vice president and publisher of Mini-Micro Systems magazine.


Glen Tetley Joining Canada's National Ballet
LEAD: Glen Tetley, the internationally known choreographer and former director of the Stuttgart Ballet, will join the National Ballet of Canada as artistic associate, the company has announced.


Rep. Burton Will Not Seek Re-election to House in '88
LEAD: Representative Sala Burton, who has been unable to attend a session of Congress this year because of treatment for cancer, said today she would not run for re-election in 1988.


Dr. King Would Laugh To See This Holiday
LEAD: To the Editor:


PRAISE FOR SAINT LAURENT'S TAILORED CLOTHES
LEAD: After several lackadaisical seasons, Yves Saint Laurent scored this morning with a spring and summer couture collection that was totally on target.
Simple and beautifully designed, it carried no excess baggage in the form of weird headgear or accessories.
It was his best collection since his ''rich peasant'' clothes 10 years ago, though the emphasis has shifted.


Talking Deals; Ted Turner Accepts a Veto
LEAD: MANY private financing deals are struck with investors who become minority shareholders.
Even though they do not get to call the shots, those investors often find ways to protect their interests.

LEAD: A tentative agreement between Deere &amp; Company and members of the United Automobile Workers was reached late Tuesday, ending a 168-day work stoppage at 14 plants in Iowa and Illinois, the longest in the company's history.

Septien Case
LEAD: A 10-year-old girl who accused Rafael Septien, the Dallas Cowboys' place-kicker, of sexually assaulting her would like to drop the charges, according to the girl's mother.
But Jerry Cobb, Denton County (Tex.) District Attorney, said that the case had already gone through the grand jury and that his office would continue to pursue the matter.


LOSING AREAS TRY TO BECOME WINNERS
LEAD: The letter to Pope John Paul II, dispatched from this upstate village, contains a two-part appeal: please bless our effort to become a New York State Economic Development Zone, and please send a copy to Albany.


Tentative Approval For USAir-P.S.A.
LEAD: The Transportation Department has tentatively approved USAir Group's proposed $400 million acquisition of Pacific Southwest Airlines.
The agency, which has final authority over airline mergers, said it had concluded that the transaction would not harm competition and would be consistent with the public interest.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A report in the Food Notes column of The Living Section yesterday incorrectly described the Petrina olive oil being sold locally.
It comes in 12.7-ounce bottles.

DEVELOPING TOMORROW'S ART PATRONS
LEAD: Paul Schnell said that two years ago he didn't know very much about the contemporary art scene but yearned to know more.
Though his mother was a painter and his grandfather an art dealer, Mr.
Schnell's everyday world revolves around corporate mergers and acquisitions -far from the heart of New York's art world.


Sunny Thoughts
LEAD: He was among those in Pasadena on Sunday, but the way things turned out, the young man figures he might as well have stayed at home. ''It's like we were never even there,'' said John Elway, who suggested that, for a while at least, the 39-20 Super Bowl loss has made him a quarterback without a team.

McDonald's Up 9.8%
LEAD: The McDonald's Corporation said today that it earned $113.6 million, or 89 cents a share, in the final quarter of 1986, up 9.8 percent from $103.5 million, or 80 cents a share, a year earlier.
Sales increased 10.5 percent, to $3.17 billion, from $2.87 billion.
For the year, McDonald's said it earned $479.7 million, or $3.73 a share, a 10.8 percent gain from the $433 million, or $3.32 a share, of 1985.

Books; U.S. and Arms
LEAD: TO ARM A NATION: Rebuilding America's Endangered Defenses.
By Richard Halloran.
Macmillan. 396 pages. $21.95.
AMONG the more unexpected developments of the last few years has been the growth of widespread public interest and debate about the state of the armed forces.
This debate goes well beyond the tired arguments about who should serve or whether more or less money is required for national defense.

STAGE: 'WHISPERS,' SOVIET OUTCASTS
LEAD: IN Crispin Larangeira's ''Whispers,'' Joan MacIntosh plays a Soviet poet who has survived years of Stalinist repression.
An exile within her own country, she has endured the death of her husband and child.
In isolation in Siberia, she continues to write verse - while working as a schoolteacher.
Privately, she transcribes her thoughts, putting the poems in jars, which she hides in various places in her cabin.

LEAD: The Speaker of the Iranian Parliament today defended the seizure of Western hostages in Beirut and other terrorist actions by Lebanese groups, saying the Lebanese had no other way to defend themselves.

The Stage of the Union
LEAD: Like an old trouper, President Reagan belted out all the old favorites.
Old oratory like ''You and I stand on the shoulders of giants'' . . .
Old proposals like ''a line-item veto so we can carve out the boondoggles and pork'' . . .
Even familiar jokes about his own age.
It was as though endless evocations of the old would serve as incantations to the political spirits; as though preserving the illusion of strength would preserve the real thing.

STRUGGLING TO KEEP SPANISH PURE
LEAD: To many Hispanic New Yorkers, ''vacunar la carpeta'' means to vacuum the carpet.
The phrase would baffle their Latin American counterparts, however, since by most dictionaries it translates into ''to vaccinate the portfolio.''


Chairman Out At Robinson
LEAD: Tom L. Roach, the chairman and chief executive of the J. W. Robinson Company department stores, has resigned amid a retructuring of the chain by May Department Stores of St.
Louis, its new owner.


Note and Bond Prices Gain
LEAD: Treasury note and bond prices improved yesterday after five consective days of declines, as traders were encouraged by Government estimates of reduced borrowing needs in coming months.


We Can Help
LEAD: As South Africa hardens in its determination to maintain white supremacy, what can the United States do?
Has it any useful role to play in this region?
The questions are urgent.
For it is ever clearer that apartheid threatens the peace of the whole area, with potentially dangerous consequences for the West as well.


Indiana Utility Improves
LEAD: The Public Service Company of Indiana said today that it will report a much smaller loss for 1986 than it had in 1985.
The company also said its board had approved the payment of preferred dividends for the first quarter, and for other quarters.
Such payouts were suspended last year.
The Indiana utility did not specify what its total loss will be.

HOW ONE AGENCY TACKLES ITS CHORES
LEAD: THE front parlor of Ilene Nordle's red clapboard home in Fairfield, Conn., has been cleared of its customary domestic furniture.
In its place are two large desks, a copying machine and chairs.


Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q.Behind the wood-burning stove in our home we have a wall of brown fieldstone.
We would like to put a clear coating over this stone to bring out the color.
Can you suggest anything that will not be affected by the heat from the stove?
A.It depends how far away the stove is from the wall.
Codes in many communities require that there be at least three feet between the stove and the nearest flammable materials.


ENGINEER DENIES USE OF DRUG IN COLLISION THAT TOOK 16 LIVES
LEAD: The Conrail engineer whose locomotive traveled into the path of an Amtrak train Jan. 4, resulting in a collision that claimed 16 lives, denies smoking marijuana in the cab the day of the crash and says he has been plagued with guilt for surviving.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on the Dance page of the Arts and Leisure section on Sunday gave an incorrect broadcast date for the ''Dancer'' series on the Arts and Entertainment Network.
The fourth and last segment will be carried by the Manhattan Cable service tonight at 9, with a rebroadcast at 1 A.M.

LEAD: In global currency trading roiled by rumors, the Japanese yen finally lost ground against the dollar yesterday.

Pension Gain Spurs Hughes
LEAD: The Hughes Tool Company said today that, because of a one-time gain from the use of excess pension funds, it earned $31.7 million, or 57 cents a share, up 56-fold from $560,000, or one cent a share, a year ago.
Revenue dropped 31.2 percent, to $215.7 million, from $313.6 million a year ago.

GATT MEMBERS AGREE ON NEW TRADE ROUND
LEAD: Representatives of nearly 100 industrial and developing nations finally agreed today to start important trade-freeing negotiations next month.
Their accord came after the United States and France reached an ambiguous compromise on what priority agriculture should have in the talks.

POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
LEAD: Don Cherry and Nana Vasconcelos, the Cathedral of St.
John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street (662-2133).
If anyone can use the vast, reverberant space within the cathedral to improve their music, it might be the improvising duo of Don Cherry and Nana Vasconcelos.
Mr.
Cherry made groundbreaking records in the 1960's as the puckish trumpeter in Ornette Coleman's jazz quartets.

Roger Mudd to Join 'MacNeil/Lehrer'
LEAD: Roger Mudd, the longtime television correspondent, said today that he would join the ''MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour'' on the Public Broadcasting Service after he leaves NBC.


Billy Harris Trio
LEAD: The pianist Barry Harris will lead a trio tonight and tomorrow at the Jazz Cultural Theater, 368 Eighth Avenue, above 28th Street (502-4300).
Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.
On Sunday, Mr.
Harris will lead a big band with the first set at 7 P.M.
Admission is $8, $5 for students and the elderly.


Diner's Journal
LEAD: THE early bird catches the worm - and a free bottle of champagne, too - at Prunelle, the graceful French restaurant at 18 East 54th Street.
Guests who dine between 5:30 and 7 P.M. can choose from a half-dozen champagnes in the $40 range, including Laurent-Perrier, Mumm Extra Dry and Piper-Heidsieck, or, if desired, a bottle of wine costing up to $30.


TRADE PACT IS SET WITH EUROPEANS
LEAD: The United States and the European Community reached an accord today resolving a major trade conflict over American grain exports to Spain.


Mets Invite 6 To Spring Camp
LEAD: The Mets issued the surest sign of seasonal cheer yesterday when they invited six of their farmhands to spring training, which opens when pitchers and catchers report to St.
Petersburg, Fla., Feb. 20.


MOSLEM PARLEY ENDS WITHOUT RESOLVING DISPUTES
LEAD: The leaders of the Moslem world wound up talks here today without resolving the issues dividing them, notably the Iran-Iraq war.

LEAD: The Gregg Smith Singers and the Ensemble Josquin Des Pres will present a program of French and American music for chorus and wind ensemble at St.
Peter's Church, 619 Lexington Avenue, at 54th Street, tomorrow night at 8:30.
The program includes ''An Acadian Mass'' by Charles Reynolds, and works by Dan Locklair, Ralph Swickard and Mr.


CONSUMER SPURT LIFTS DURABLE GOODS
LEAD: Civilian orders for durable goods rose 6.9 percent in December, although orders for all durable goods, including military projects, rose only nine-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department said yesterday.

AFTER YEARS OF COSTLY EFFORTS, THE RACE IS FINALLY ON
LEAD: The 1987 America's Cup series will finally begin here Saturday afternoon with the first race of the four-of-seven-race match between Dennis Conner's Stars &amp; Stripes and Iain Murray's Kookaburra III.


Money Fund Assets Fall
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 378 money market mutual funds decreased $554.6 million, to $233.88 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 91 institutional funds were up $294.7 million, to $65.28 billion.
Assets of the 195 general purpose funds were down $449.4 million, to $61.96 billion.


SENATORS CHARGE A WEB OF DECEIT IN IRANIAN AFFAIR
LEAD: A report on the Iran-contra affair made public today by the Senate Intelligence Committee portrays Reagan Administration officials as regularly deceiving one another, as well as Congress, about major elements of the operation.

FILM: WOODY ALLEN'S FOND REMEMBRANCES OF 'RADIO DAYS'
LEAD: RADIOS once came in two basic models of wooden cabinets.
The table-top, sheathed in oak or mahogany veneer, looked like a small, peak-roofed sentry box, with Romanesque or Gothic arches in front of the sometimes gold-flecked fabric masking the speaker.

LEAD: The White House confirmed today that President Reagan had sent a signed Bible to Iranian leaders.


TEXAN EXECUTED FOR 1980 SLAYING
LEAD: A former welder who had declined legal help was executed early this morning for the 1980 murder of a mechanic in a burglary at a service station.


A.T.&amp;T. REPORTS IT LOST $1.17 BILLION IN QUARTER
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it lost $1.17 billion in the fourth quarter because of a $3.2 billion charge taken to reduce its work force and consolidate operations.


4 SITES FOR SHELTERS REJECTED BY BOROUGH CHIEF IN BRONX
LEAD: Borough President Stanley Simon of the Bronx yesterday rejected four sites proposed by the Koch administration for new shelters for the homeless, and he offered a compromise involving two alternative sites and the rehabilitation of existing abandoned housing.


DR. OTTO NATHAN, AN ECONOMIST
LEAD: Dr.
Otto Nathan, an economist who served as executor and co-trustee of the estate of Albert Einstein, died of heart failure Tuesday at Van Etten Hospital in the Bronx.
He was 93 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: IT was Wednesday evening again, and Paul Feiner, a Westchester County legislator, was setting up his problem-solving booth - a card table and folding chair - right beside the express checkout lane at the A.&amp;P. here.

U.S. Says Kiev Is Safe For Visits by Tourists
LEAD: The United States said today that it was safe for Americans to visit Kiev, a city close to the site of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster last April.


AIRLINER SAFETY PRACTICE DEBATED
LEAD: The Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration today rejected a proposal that widespread resumption of in-flight holding patterns be resumed to ease airline departure delays.


FRANCIS BELLO
LEAD: Francis Bello, a retired associate editor of Scientific American magazine, died of leukemia Tuesday at the Stanford Medical Center in Stanford, Calif.
He was 69 years old and lived in Menlo Park, Calif.


BAKER POSTPONES AND PONDERS ON HIS CANDIDACY
LEAD: From his law office in the Willard, one of the city's most prestigious addresses, just two blocks from the White House, Howard H. Baker Jr. has a splendid view of Pennsylvania Avenue, the route of Presidential inaugural parades.
Mr.
Baker is still trying to decide whether he would rather be leading that parade in 1988 or watching it from his eighth-floor window.

Blustery Storm Moves Into the Plains
LEAD: Justin Doten, 8 years old, brushing snow from a car in Minneapolis.
A storm that rattled the Eastern Rockies with high winds brought snow and freezing rain to the Plains and Upper Mississippi Valley.
It left up to a foot of snow in Utah, and the gusting wind caused sporadic power failures in Utah and Colorado.


Horse Racing Notebook; ELECTRONIC TOUCH FOR BETTORS AT HIALEAH
LEAD: Horse-players who place their bets with Sam this winter are not patronizing a local bookie, but getting a glimpse at the future of parimutuel wagering.
Sam is the acronym for Screen Activated Machines, customer-operated electronic ticket dispensers, nine of which have been installed at Hialeah Park.


PLEA MADE TO KOCH BY JEWS IN HUNGARY FOR HELP FROM U.S.
LEAD: Hungarian Jewish leaders appealed through Mayor Koch today for financial help from American Jews to maintain Jewish life in this country.

FROM NUTS TO SOUP, FOR CHINESE NEW YEAR
LEAD: THE usual animated pace of Chinatown intensifies to a dizzying pace this weekend as the new year is welcomed with spirited toasts and staggering feasts.
Some Chinatown restaurants offer special prix-fixe banquets during the holidays; others feature traditional dishes ripe with symbolism: chicken brings good fortune, egg rolls portend the arrival of spring, egg dumplings signify golden ingots, round meatballs connote family togetherness.

Strawberry Faces Suit
LEAD: The wife of Darryl Strawberry filed a petition for a legal separation yesterday in Los Angeles Superior Court, accusing the Mets' outfielder of violent behavior last month and breaking her nose after a playoff game last October.
Lisa Strawberry also obtained a court order forbidding her husband from coming within 100 yards of her mother's home in Altadena, a suburb of Los Angeles, where she is staying.


A WORRY FOR LABOR

U.S. Warning On the Yen
LEAD: A senior United States trade official warned today that the yen would continue to rise unless Japan removed trade barriers.

'BELL JAR' CASE ENDS IN ACCORD
LEAD: The trial centering on ''The Bell Jar,'' a 1979 film of Sylvia Plath's novel, ended here today in Federal District Court when both sides agreed to a judgment that Dr.
Jane V. Anderson, a 55-year-old psychiatrist, was unintentionally defamed by the movie.

ITT Names a President For Its Automotive Unit
LEAD: The ITT Corporation announced yesterday that it had named Ralph E. Reins president and chief executive of ITT Automotive Inc., under which it is consolidating all of its automotive products units worldwide.


Concert: Kurt Masur With Gutierrez at Piano
LEAD: IT would be difficult to name two composers more dissimilar in temperament and taste than Hindemith and Chopin, who found themselves oddly coupled on last evening's New York Philharmonic program.
Kurt Masur, the guest conductor, began with Hindemith's Concert Music for Strings and Brass, one of those works that reflect with startling accuracy the German composer's personality.

Walt Disney to Sell Assets of Arvida
LEAD: The Walt Disney Company said today that it had agreed to sell the real estate assets of its Arvida community development subsidiary for $400 million in cash and notes.


BIRTHDAY CELEBRATIONS HONOR FRANZ SCHUBERT
LEAD: One hardly needs an excuse to celebrate Franz Schubert, but since the composer would have been 190 years old tomorrow, this seems as good a time as any for a party.
And that's just what's in store tomorrow at the Symphony Space, which will commemorate the birthday with a 12-hour free concert entitled ''Wall-to-Wall Schubert,'' scheduled to last from 11 in the morning until 11 at night.

Wesleyan Unit Urges Six Be Disciplined
LEAD: The Student Judical Board at Wesleyan University has recommended that three students be given written warnings and three others put on disciplinary probation for interrupting campus tours for prospective freshmen and their families.


Shamrock Ruling
LEAD: A Federal judge rejected a request by the Diamond Shamrock Corporation to block a $300 million stock tender offer by a group headed by T. Boone Pickens Jr., the Texas oilman.
Federal District Judge Jerry Buchmeyer said he would not grant a preliminary injunction because the Pickens group had not violated Federal securities laws.


NEWARK BISHOP SEEKING TO BLESS UNWED COUPLES
LEAD: The Episcopal Bishop of Newark, bolstered by a diocesan report, called on the church yesterday to ''open its eyes to reality'' by recognizing and blessing nonmarital relationships, including those between homosexuals.


DISCLOSURE CASE
LEAD: Congressional supporters of Michael E. Pillsbury, who was dismissed last year from his Defense Department job on the ground that he gave secret information to a newspaper, say they are heartened by developments in his case and hope to see him reinstated soon to his old post.

China Signs Pact To Loft Satellite
LEAD: China has signed its first contract to launch a foreign satellite.
The official New China News Agency said the contract had been signed by Wu Keli, vice president of the China Great Wall Industrial Corporation, and Henry A. Schwartz, chairman of the board of Terasat Inc. of Houston.
The communications satellite is expected to be launched in 1988.


Refunds for Tickets Are to Be Prorated
LEAD: Long Island Rail Road commuters holding weekly or monthly tickets will receive refunds or credit on a prorated basis for the days they could not travel during the strike, a railroad spokesman said yesterday.

West German Trade Surplus
LEAD: West Germany's trade surplus grew about 50 percent in 1986, to a record 112 billion marks, equivalent to $62.9 billion, the Federal Statistics Office said today.
The total included an unexpectedly large jump in December, to a record $6.46 billion, from November's $5.7 billion.

MAYOR OF NEW YORK IN 1950's
LEAD: Vincent R. Impellitteri, an immigrant cobbler's son who defied the Democratic machine of Tammany Hall and became Mayor of New York from 1950 to 1953, died of heart failure yesterday at Bridgeport (Conn.) Hospital.
He was 86 years old.

LEAD: Seven hundred miles of track and 375 miles of third rail must be cleared of snow and ice; 1,450 switches must be inspected.


FILM: EUSTACHE'S 'PETITES AMOUREUSES'
LEAD: IN many ways ''Mes Petites Amoureuses,'' Jean Eustache's 1974 French film opening today at the Public, looks as if it had been meant to answer anyone who'd been less than enchanted by the director's ''Mother and the Whore,'' one of the more antagonizing films presented at the 1973 New York Film Festival.

LEAD: Wade Boggs, Boston's three-time batting champion, and 11 other players, including Cecilio Guante and Charlie Hudson of the Yankees, settled their salary arbitration cases yesterday.

LEAD: The Triad America Corporation, the cornerstone of Adnan M. Khashoggi's business empire in this country, has filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.


BRIDGEPORT PLAN PROMISES JOBS TO GRADUATES
LEAD: Business leaders here today promised 75 jobs to students graduating from local public high schools this year.
Eventually, they intend to guarantee a job for virtually every graduate.


Dismember Items
LEAD: What does a cheese museum in upstate New York have in common with a harness racing hall of fame and a double-Dutch jumproping contest?
They are among the pet projects of Albany lawmakers that were funded last year out of a shameless legislative extravagance called the ''member items'' budget.
Member items are ways of using tax money to buy favors for incumbents.

IN 'FREO,' CAMELS BUT NO WORRIES
LEAD: G'day, mate.
Bet you haven't heard the camel story.
Not the kangaroo or the koala story, but the camel story.
About the four visitors to the America's Cup races who went camel-riding in the desert north of here.
If you stop to rest, they were told by the camels' owner, the camels will lay down, but just say ''Y'up'' and the camels will get up.

DANCE: PILOBOLUS OFFERS 'CARMINA BURANA, SIDE II'
LEAD: ANYONE who enjoyed Pilobolus - once known as Pilobolus Dance Theater - at its very beginnings will always have a soft spot for the company.
There are times, however, when the group might reciprocate the feeling and make things less uncomfortable for its audience.


Quake in San Francisco Area
LEAD: A mild earthquake struck the San Francisco Bay area today, but no injuries or damages were reported.
Preliminary reports measured the earthquake at 3.5 on the Richter scale of ground motion.
Don Finley, a spokesman for the United States Geological Survey in the District of Columbia, said the temblor was centered about 12 miles southeast of Oakland and occurred at 5:35 P.M.

The film opens today at the Cinema Studio 1, Broadway and 66th Street.

Timely Acts of Heroism
LEAD: Five New York City police officers after being named recipients yesterday of the ''Nick of Time'' award, for valorous acts in which time was of the essence.
From the left are Paul Yurkiw; Dennis Quinn; Edward del Pino, who is retired; Delia Lopez, and Thomas Gavin.
The awards are given by the Honor Legion, the Police Department's oldest fraternal organization, and Pulsar Time.

LEAD: Key members of the House of Representatives said today that the 100th Congress would probably establish a new Federal program to help elderly people pay for unusually long hospital stays but not for care in nursing homes.


Rates Close Little Changed
LEAD: Interest rates ended little changed yesterday in a quiet but nervous bond market that continued to take its cue from trends in the currency market and prospects for America's trade balance.

LEAD: Silas (Trim) Bissell, a captured fugitive who was once a member of the radical Weatherman organization and eluded Federal agents for 17 years, apparently by living as a ''model citizen,'' may be released on bond in the next few days, his lawyer said today.

ART: DUTCH SHOWS AT MORGAN AND MET
LEAD: THE Netherlands is now getting special attention by way of two related museum exhibitions.
The one at the Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, is a selection of 16th-century drawings, most of which are making their first appearance in the United States, and it comes with a plump catalogue.
A joint effort by the library and the National Gallery of Art in Washington, where it first materialized, the show musters about 120 works, including eight by Pieter Bruegel the Elder (about 1525 to 1569).


Special Summer Camps
LEAD: For parents who want to get a jump on summer-camp possibilities for youngsters with special needs, the third Special Camp Fair will be held on Sunday from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. at the Jewish Guild for the Blind, 15 West 65th Street.
Representatives from 100 summer camps will be on hand to provide information about sleep-away and day camps that specialize in programs for children with physical or learning disabilities.

HEAD OF BBC QUITS, ENDING STORMY TENURE
LEAD: The director general of the British Broadcasting Corporation resigned today, ending a tenure marked by Government allegations of biased or inaccurate television news coverage.


Too Much Pain Even for a Hero
LEAD: Billy Olson, the pole-vaulter whose last-minute withdrawal from tonight's Wanamaker Millrose Games had been blamed on ''despondency'' over his failure to clear the bar in his first two meets this year, was being portrayed yesterday not as an emotional weakling.
He was being portrayed as a hero who had been competing and setting world records while silently suffering from a chronic and debilitating sinus infection that has finally forced him to the sideline.


Canadian-British Talks
LEAD: Sir Geoffrey Howe, the British Foreign Secretary, met today with the Canadian External Affairs Minister, Joe Clark, for talks on trade and transatlantic air service, East-West relations, arms control, international cooperation against terrorism and developments in South Africa, a spokesman for the Foreign Office said.

Yanks' Scurry Arrested
LEAD: Rod Scurry, the Yankee relief pitcher who has undergone drug rehabilitation, was arrested Wednesday for drunken driving and reckless operation of a vehicle, according to police in Reno.
Officers said Scurry, 30 years old, was released on $770 bail six hours later.
Since Scurry refused to submit to a chemical test, his driver's license was revoked under Nevada law, the police said.


GIVENCHY IS OPULENT FOR BOTH DAY AND NIGHT
LEAD: After the histrionics of the last few days, the spring and summer couture collections ended on a calming note today.
Before an audience that included many American clients who find his traditional approach to fashion soothing, Hubert de Givenchy showed a reassuring collection with two flattering themes.


SAMUEL G. FUQUA
LEAD: Samuel G. Fuqua, who received in the Medal of Honor for heroism at Pearl Harbor and whose story of that day helped build the U.S.S.
Arizona Memorial there, died Tuesday.
He was 87 years old.
Mr.
Fuqua, who retired from the Navy in 1953, was a lieutenant commander aboard the battleship Arizona when Japan's planes attacked on Dec.


Woman Dies in Haitian Clash
LEAD: Government soldiers clashed with a crowd today in front of the National Palace, and witnesses said at least one person was killed and several were wounded.

LOW AIR FARES OFFERED, WITH A TWIST
LEAD: Continental and Eastern Airlines said yesterday that they would cut their lowest fares by as much as 40 percent on nearly all domestic flights beginning Sunday.
Passengers must buy the tickets when they reserve seats, and no refunds, exchanges or transfers to other people will be allowed.

LEAD: Pedro W. Wygodzinsky, curator of entomology at the American Museum of Natural History, died of Parkinson's disease Tuesday at a nursing home in Middletown, N.Y.
He was 70 years old.

MEN VS. WOMEN AT THE OFFICE
LEAD: An executive, a woman, entertains a male business client from out of town, taking him to dinner and a show.
Although it's a successful night out, his host is certainly not one of the boys, and he realizes that he feels awkward at times about how he should behave during the evening.

LEAD: A report commissioned by the City Human Resources Administration into the persistent problem of child abuse and neglect concludes that ''New York City's system of child protection appears not to be adequate to the task.''


ECONOMIC REPORT PRODS ALLIES
LEAD: Amid new signs of an impending five-nation meeting to try to stabilize the dollar, President Reagan urged other major countries today to help reduce the American trade deficit, a key reason for the dollar's decline.


MUSIC OF THE YORUBA IN 2 CONCERTS
LEAD: THE Yoruba orisha Oya can summon whirlwinds; Yemanja, another orisha, controls all the energy and riches of the ocean.
Like the other orishas - deities who symbolize forces of nature and human attributes in the Yoruba cosmogony - they also have their own rhythms, chants and dances.
Those rhythms, which were brought to the New World by slaves from West Africa, supply a heartbeat and a dance beat for all sorts of African-American and Latin


RESTAURANTS
LEAD: ERMINIA is an enchantingly romantic little spot, a snug Upper East Side hideaway of barn board and brick, dried flowers, rustic bric-a-brac, candlelight and soft music.
It attracts an urbane and self-possessed clientele, the type of diners who eschew the fervid fishbowl scene in favor of soft intimacy.

They are rated triple-A and are noncallable for life.

LEAD: Gov.
Madeleine M. Kunin of Vermont today asked three of the five justices on the state's highest court to step down until a complaint of judicial misconduct against them was settled.


Archives Sets a Date To Open Nixon Files
LEAD: The National Archives will give notice Friday that it intends to open for public viewing the most sensitive of all the papers seized from President Nixon when he resigned office.

Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''The Commissioner may, for the purpose of the safety of the public, the maintenance of public order or the termination of the state of emergency, and without prior notice to any person and without hearing any person, issue any order not inconsistent with a provision of these regulations prohibiting any publication, television recording, film recording or sound recording containing any news, comment or advertisement on or in connection with any matter specified in the order, to be published.


What's What in the America's Cup
LEAD: Those who follow the early-morning telecasts on ESPN of the America's Cup races will have to listen to a new vocabulary of sailing terms while fighting off sleepiness.
Here is a glossary of some of the terms likely to be used.
Aft: Toward the back of the boat.
Beat: To sail upwind.
Bow: The front of the boat.


Seat-Belt Defense Wins Case
LEAD: A motorist who argued he was not guilty of negligent homicide in the deaths of two crash victims because they were not wearing seat belts was acquitted Wednesday.
The two people who died in the collision had not been wearing seat belts, in violation of Michigan law, said Jim Fisher, lawyer for the motorist, Jeffrey Smith.

WEEKENDER GUIDE
LEAD: Friday A NEW OPERA Over the centuries, the twists and turns of love have been a favorite subject of opera singers.
This weekend will be no exception when ''All's Well That Ends Well'' is performed as a two-act opera at the Marymount Manhattan Theater under the auspices of Dell'Arte Inc., an arts organization.


Maine Utility
LEAD: The Central Maine Power Company said it would write off $17.2 million of its investment in the Millstone Three nuclear power plant in Connecticut.
The company said that after taxes the write-off would amount to $11 million, or 48 cents a share on 1986 earnings.
Last July, Central Maine and state regulators in Maine agreed to a rate order that did not permit recovery of 15 percent of the company's total Millstone Three investment of $114.9 million, the company said.


The Met's Extra Room
LEAD: Somewhere in New York City there lives someone who has never longed for an extra room.
This person has never wanted to house a guest; or store the butterfly chair and amoeba-shaped coffee table until they come back in style; or have a place for a sewing machine, or a miniature railroad.
This person, then, will not be able to see the Metropolitan Museum's new Lila Acheson Wallace Wing for what it really is: the quintessential extra room.

SENATORS SEEK TO MAKE ARMS TREATY BINDING

Perot Reportedly Invests in Next
LEAD: H. Ross Perot, founder of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, is investing $20 million for a 16 percent stake and a director's position in Next Inc., according to an article in the Feb. 9 issue of Business Week.
Steve Jobs, a co-founder of Apple Computer Inc., formed Next in 1985 to produce a powerful computer work station for educational use.

The Right Reagan Script
LEAD: The President had two scripts for his State of the Union Message Tuesday night - and delivered the wrong one.
The speech he delivered in person billowed with stale wind.
His written message crackles with energy, spelling out how to rebuild America's competitive pre-eminence.

LEAD: A rigging crew using a crane to remove one of the six 21-ton steel panels that constituted Richard Serra's ''St.
John's Rotary Arc'' around the traffic circle at the Manhattan side of the Holland Tunnel.


ESPOSITO ADDING STABILITY
LEAD: When he used to appear behind the bench, it was as Uncle Phil, laughing, grabbing his players by their necks, cheering them on.
He would win and then he would disappear for a while. ''When Phil Esposito is around,'' said Pierre Larouche recently, ''everything is light and happy.''

LEAD: The Intel Corporation, a leading manufacturer of computer chips, announced yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, Andrew S. Grove, will become chief executive at the next shareholders meeting in April.
Dr.

New Year's Crackle
LEAD: Exploding firecrackers showered a street in Chinatown during New Year's celebration.
With the Year of the Tiger over, yesterday began the Year of the Rabbit on the lunar calendar.


Dow Dips as Airline Stocks Decline
LEAD: Trading volume remained heavy on Wall Street yesterday, but stock prices dipped slightly, with airline issues suffering the biggest declines.


Time's Profits Are Off 76.9%
LEAD: Time Inc. said yesterday that a weak advertising environment for its magazines and a previously disclosed charge for staff reductions sent its fourth-quarter profit tumbling 76.9 percent from the corresponding period a year earlier.

INSIDE
LEAD: Impellitteri Dies at 86  Vincent R. Impellitteri, Mayor of New York from 1950 to 1953, died in a Bridgeport, Conn., hospital.
He was 86 years old.
Page B8.  2 Airlines Slash Fares  Continental and Eastern said they would cut discount domestic fares as much as 40 percent but would make the tickets nonrefundable.


A Bullish Start
LEAD: Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls, who is leading the National Basketball Association in scoring with 36.9 points a game so far this season, has tallied 4,233 points for an average of 30.0 during 141 games in his first two and a half seasons as a pro.
He was limited to 18 games last season because of a broken bone in his foot.

Masco Industries
LEAD: Masco Industries, a manufacturer of oilfield and industrial products, is offering $175 million of 6 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2011 at a price of 100.
The offering is being made through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham &amp; Company.
The debentures are convertible into the company's common stock at $36 a share; the stock closed yesterday at $28 in over-the-counter trading.


State Asks City Firms For Aid on Corruption
LEAD: The head of the State Commission on Government Integrity, Joseph A. Califano Jr., sent a letter yesterday asking 21 of the city's top law firms and the Big Eight accounting firms to allow at least one of their employees to aid his group in fighting corruption.


Pratt &amp; Whitney
LEAD: Pratt &amp; Whitney, a unit of the United Technologies Corporation, said that it had signed a contract with China to supply about $100 million worth of aircraft engines.
The order for 16 PW-4000 engines to be used in commercial Boeing 767's is part of a continuing program with China, which the company said was one of its biggest customers.

POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
LEAD: Morgana King, the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592).
Morgana King's humming coloratura and highly ornamental style of pop-jazz embellishment have changed little over three decades.
Her pitch, rhythmic precision and near-supersonic upper register remain as secure as ever, and her highly stylized delivery of pop standards suggests someone confiding an obsessive romantic daydream.

Contradictions Emerge
LEAD: To the Editor:


Rubin to Appeal Fraud Conviction
LEAD: An attorney for Richard L. Rubin, a former official of the Democratic Party in Queens, said yesterday he would appeal Mr.
Rubin's conviction for fraudulently arranging to have two former secretaries in his law firm paid with state funds.


VIBRANT NEWCOMERS AND VETERAN SOLOISTS IN CITY'S CONCERT HALLS
LEAD: ''VIRTUOSO should be a title of honor,'' the cellist Emanuel Feuermann once said, ''denoting the highest ability, respect for a piece of art and the ability to fit one's personality to the artwork.
I believe that among the greatest names on the stage, only a few deserve this title.''


Clarke Show Delayed
LEAD: Martha Clarke's ''Hunger Artist'' will begin previews next Thursday at St.
Clement's Church, 423 West 46th Street.
The production was originally scheduled to begin previews this Tuesday, but it needed more preparation time, according to Pete Sanders, press spokesman for the show.
Information: 265-4375.

SWEEPING CHANGES IN FINANCIAL SYSTEM URGED
LEAD: The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York proposed yesterday a revamping of the financial system that would eliminate many distinctions among banks, securities firms and insurance companies.


USX Price Rise
LEAD: The USX Corporation said that it would increase prices of certain carbon and high-strength, low-alloy plate steel.
USX said customers with special needs involving quantity or dimensions would face increases of $10 to $15 a ton, beginning April 5.
USX said its base price for such steel remains unchanged at $380 a ton.


THIRD SUSPECT IS ARRESTED IN FIRE THAT KILLED 96 IN SAN JUAN HOTEL
LEAD: A third worker at the Dupont Plaza Hotel was arrested today on charges of murder and arson in the New Year's Eve fire there in which 96 people died.


AMERICA'S CUP FINAL:
LEAD: Stars &amp; Stripes of the United States, above, faces Australia's Kookaburra III in contest beginning tomorrow.

AT THE MOVIES
LEAD: IN ''Scene of the Crime,'' Catherine Deneuve plays a small-town bourgeoise mother, separated from her husband and devoted to her son, whose external passivity masks a deep-seated thirst for action, passion and even violence.


Hannah's Distant Cousins
LEAD: The setting was in Maputo, Mozambique.
It is summer and the flame trees were in gaudy blossom along the broad, grass-verged avenues where well-to-do Portuguese lived when this was a colonial capital called Lourenco Marques.


FILM: MIDLER AND LONG IN 'OUTRAGEIOUS FORTUNE'
LEAD: IF Redford and Newman were chasing their man and had tracked him to a little shack somewhere, would they stop to check their makeup before breaking down the door?
Probably not - and certainly not with the delicious aplomb shown by Shelley Long and Bette Midler in ''Outrageous Fortune,'' which opens today at the Ziegfeld and other theaters.

Topics: Circumlocutions; Why Not Speak Up?
LEAD: The famous question during Watergate was, What did the President know and when did he know it?
That's also being asked in the Iran-contra arms affair, but there's now another necessary question: When will the President know and when will he tell the American people?


AMERICAN IN AFRICA ENSNARED IN A WEB OF CUSTOM
LEAD: The baby's name is Daliso, which means ''blessing,'' but his birth has snared an American expatriate in what he considers a web of troublesome African traditions.


INQUIRY INTO L.I. POLICE IS ASSAILED BY OFFICIALS
LEAD: The State Commission of Investigation, in the second day of a public inquiry into the Suffolk County Police Department, today questioned department procedures and drew angry reactions from police officials and a roomful of detectives.


Winans Case Plea Entered
LEAD: A former partner in a New York law firm, accused of embezzling $3.7 million from clients to bankroll his participation in the R. Foster Winans insider-trading scandal, pleaded not guilty yesterday in Federal court.


Wooing Parcells
LEAD: The Atlanta Falcons, still searching for a coach after the dismissal of Dan Henning and rejections from Dick Vermeil and Terry Donahue, have sought permission to talk with Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants, according to today's editions of The Atlanta Constitution and The Boston Globe.
The Giants denied Atlanta permission, though the Falcons have been in contact with Parcells's attorney, one report said.

VATICAN ENVOY DEFENDS HIS HANDLING OF CASE AGAINST ARCHBISHOP OF SEATTLE
LEAD: Archbishop Pio Laghi, the Vatican's Ambassador to the United States, has defended his handling of the disciplining of Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen of Seattle, saying that much of the criticism the episode unleashed stemmed from the Vatican's desire to handle the matter discreetly.


Financial's Net Falls by 76%
LEAD: The Financial Corporation of America said today that it had earned $23.1 million, or 56 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, down 76 percent from $97 million, or $2.58 a share, a year ago.
The quarter included an operating profit of $18.9 million, the first for the company in four quarters.

LEAD: The Indiana and Michigan Electric Company yesterday sold $150 million of bonds and notes through competitive bidding.
Underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company were awarded a $100 million issue of 8 3/4 percent first-mortgage bonds due in 2017, which were reoffered at a price of 99.75 to yield 8.774 percent, or 1.18 percentage points more than the 9 1/4 percent

Garland and Minnelli Share Screen at Filmfest
LEAD: Judy Garland and Liza Minnelli will share the silver screen during a five-week retrospective beginning Sunday at the Regency Theater, Broadway and 67th Street.
A double bill of ''The Wizard of Oz'' and ''Meet Me in St.
Louis'' will get the series under way Sunday, with screenings beginning at noon.


THE RESISTANCE TO GORBACHEV
LEAD: After 22 months in which his campaign for ''reconstruction'' appears to have gained considerable support, Mikhail S. Gorbachev this week started a fresh drive to overcome inertia in the Communist Party itself.
But in promising to shake up the party, the repository of real power, he moved into an area that has frustrated reform-minded leaders in the past.


Depleted Islanders
LEAD: The Islanders traveled to Washington for tonight's game against the Capitals with neither their best scorer, Mike Bossy, nor half of their goaltending team, Kelly Hrudey.
Bossy, who will miss his sixth and seventh consecutive games this weekend because of a strained back, may return next week when the team travels to western Canada for three games.


KOOKABURRA CREW TAKES THE EARLY LEAD IN GAMEMANSHIP
LEAD: Part of winning an America's Cup race is learning to beat your opponent both on the water and off.
Dennis Conner's Stars &amp; Stripes team and Iain Murray's Kookaburra III crew have shown they are experts in both places.


What Arms Control Is All About
LEAD: On Jan. 15, arms control negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union resumed in Geneva.
That event was greeted with satisfaction in most quarters around the world.
The outstanding exception is here in the United States, where a significant body of opinion on the right views arms control as a snare and a delusion.

Diplomat Dole, Candidate Dole
LEAD: Politicians are entitled to a certain quota of cynicism.
Senator Bob Dole exceeded his by denouncing Secretary of State George Shultz's meeting with Oliver Tambo, the head of the African National Congress.
Mr.
Dole, a probable candidate for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination, was perhaps less concerned with terrorism, as he claimed, than with currying favor with his party's right wing.


Costly Call at Aqueduct
LEAD: Because he had failed to provide workers' compensation insurance for his employees, Gaspar Moschera, a trainer with 41 thoroughbreds racing at Aqueduct, was suspended on Jan. 1 for 30 days by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board.
The recommendation for suspension had come from the stewards.

AIDS MAY DWARF THE PLAGUE
LEAD: A worldwide AIDS epidemic will become so serious that it will dwarf such earlier medical disasters as the Black Plague, smallpox and typhoid, the nation's top health official said today.

SENATE VOTES $50 MILLION IN AID FOR THE HOMELESS
LEAD: The Senate tonight approved $50 million in emergency aid to the homeless.
The vote was 77 to 6.


G.M. Layoffs
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it would lay off 3,000 hourly workers Monday, bringing to 30,000 the number of employees on indefinite leave from the car maker's American plants.
A spokesman said the layoffs reflect previously announced cuts at assembly and component factories.
G.M. employs 380,000 hourly workers in the United States.


ART: 50 YEARS OF TWORKOV ON PAPER
LEAD: THE current 50-year retrospective of works on paper by Jack Tworkov at the Nancy Hoffman Gallery, 429 West Broadway, at Prince Street, is an exhibition that reveals itself slowly and gently.
But it turns out in the end to have more strength, and more variety, than many a show that tries to knock us out before we even get inside the door.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: Dr.
Joseph R. Wilder, director of surgery at the Mount Sinai Medical Center, is among four former players who will be inducted into the Lacrosse Hall of Fame in Baltimore tonight.
Dr.
Wilder, a star at Dartmouth from 1940-42, will be enshrined with Major Peter B. Cramblet, a former star at West Point; Joseph Corcoran, formerly of Ithaca, and Tom Postel, formerly of C.


AQUINO ANNOUNCES THE MUTINEERS WILL BE 'HELD TO FULLEST ACCOUNT'
LEAD: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that the two-day occupation of a television station by dissident soldiers had been part of an attempt to overthrow the Government and that those involved would be ''held to the fullest account.''


JOHN HURT STARS IN 'THE STORYTELLER'
LEAD: WHAT makes ''Hans My Hedgehog'' such a treat is the writing.
Not that there's anything the matter with the pictures in this tale from ''The Storyteller,'' the NBC ''Family Special'' that graces Channel 4 at 8:30 tomorrow night - but we've come to expect visual virtuosity on television, and when a show arrives under the auspices of Jim Henson, we can be pretty sure we won't be disappointed.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: Golf Caldwell Takes One-Shot Lead: Rex Caldwell, who qualified on a sponsor's exemption, shot a 5-under-par 67 and took one-shot lead yesterday after the first round of the $600,000 A.T.&amp;T.
Pebble Beach National Pro-Am.
At 68, four under par, were a former British Open champion, Sandy Lyle of Scotland; Lanny Wadkins, Tom Byrum and John Adams.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article yesterday about tighter standards for hospital emergency rooms in New York City erroneously described staffing at some emergency rooms and the status of residency programs in emergency medicine.
The city's Health and Hospitals Corporation says that every municipal hospital, not just Bellevue, has an attending physician in the emergency room 24 hours a day.

STUDENTS STRIKE AT MEXICO SCHOOL
LEAD: Thousands of students at the National Autonomous University of Mexico went on strike here today, confronting the Government with a political problem and halting normal activity at the largest university in Latin America.


REINFORCING U.S.-MEXICAN RELATIONS:
LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Bernardo Sepulveda Amor, Mexico's Foreign Minister, in foreground with hands behind his back, at U.S.-Mexican Binational Commission ceremony in Washington.
The panel met yesterday to discuss ways to expand cooperation in combating drug trafficking and to improve the climate for trade and investment, among other issues.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A report in Sports Pages on Jan. 23 about a Devils game attended by only 334 spectators because of a snowstorm, omitted the name of the team that the Devils defeated, 7-4.
It was the Calgary Flames.

BUYS HYATT MAUI
LEAD: The Kokasai Motor Company, Japan's largest taxicab and livery service, has agreed to acquire the Hyatt Regency Maui hotel for $320 million, a record price for a hotel property, according to the Sonnenblick Goldman Corporation, the mortgage banker in the transaction.
Sanwa Bank Ltd. of Tokyo, Japan's fifth-largest bank, provided financing.

Kyung Wha Chung
LEAD: The violinist Kyung Wha Chung will play sonatas by Beethoven, Strauss and Bartok and pieces by Brahms and Elgar in her only New York recital of the season, at 3 P.M. tomorrow at Avery Fisher Hall.
Tickets are $16, $11 and $8; information: 874-2424.


Detroit Crime Rate Declines
LEAD: Detroit's overall crime rated declined 6.4 percent in 1986 from that of 1985, the second consecutive year the rate has declined, police officials said Thursday.
Detroit reported 9,540 fewer major crimes last year than in 1985, according to statistics released at a Board of Police Commissioners meeting.


BEAU GESTE II
LEAD: In another noble all-star gesture, Mario Lemieux of the Pittsburgh Penguins, still nursing a sprained right knee, said he would ask that Wayne Gretzky of the Edmonton Oilers replace him as the starting center for the National Hockey League team in the Rendez-Vous 87 series against a Soviet team Feb.


SUSPECTS IN HOTEL FIRE ARE MOVED TO FLORIDA
LEAD: Two of the three employees charged in the New Year's Eve fire in the Dupont Plaza Hotel that killed 96 people here have been transferred to a Florida jail and are under special security, officials said today.

Father Files Claim in Death Of Son Aboard Space Shuttle
LEAD: The father of Gregory Jarvis, a member of the Challenger crew, filed a $5 million claim today against the National Aeronautics and Space Administration for the death of his son.


U.S. TRADE DEFICIT, IN REVERSAL, FELL 44% IN DECEMBER
LEAD: In a reversal of startling magnitude, the nation's foreign-trade deficit plunged 44 percent in December, to $10.6 billion, the lowest level since March 1985.


2 ADMINISTRATION LEADERS AGREE ON AIDS EDUCATION
LEAD: Education Secretary William J. Bennett and Surgeon General C. Everett Koop, in a move to play down their differences on AIDS education, today released a joint statement asserting that young people should be taught that sexual ''abstinence is safest.''


SOUTH AFRICAN WHITES' VOTE SET FOR MAY
LEAD: President P. W. Botha of South Africa announced in Cape Town today that new elections to the white house of Parliament would be held in May.
He set the tone for his campaign with a call for unity ''against the spirit of revolution incited against us from abroad.''

END OF FEDERAL REVENUE SHARING CREATING FINANCIAL CRISES IN MANY CITIES
LEAD: The end of a Federal aid program that provided more than half the money for some municipal budgets has caused a severe financial crisis in small and medium-size cities around the country and is forcing larger cities to make hard choices between cutting services and raising taxes.


TEXAS SLAYER DIES IN FIRST EXECUTION OF YEAR
LEAD: A man convicted of killing an automobile mechanic in a burglary was executed today after lawyers ignored his objections and made last-minute efforts to save him.

CONCERT: NEW MUSIC BY JUILLIARD
LEAD: It's midwinter in Manhattan, but Thursday evening's ''Focus!'' new-music concert at the Juilliard Theater by the Juilliard School bore a curious resemblance to a midsummer Tanglewood Festival of Contemporary Music concert in the quasi-outdoor Theater-Concert Hall.
There was the same parade of modernist pieces (six, in this case) performed by talented student forces ranging from soloists to a conducted octet.


CONSTANCE WRIGHT
LEAD: Constance Choate Wright, a teacher and author, died last Saturday at the Brandywine Nursing Home, Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., after a long illness.
She was 88 years old and lived in Pleasantville, N.Y.

GOLDIN SOLICITED FRIENDS TO INVEST WITH BOESKY

HANDLE WITH CARE
LEAD: These are the salad days, and that means the horizontal lunch.
It generally comes in a white bag that has to be held carefully, in both hands, so that the salad prepared at one of the city's hundreds of new salad bars won't spill from its plastic container before it gets back to the office.
The vertical lunch, well, it's still around town but out of fashion, and it usually comes in a brown bag that can be held almost any which way except upside down.

2 Bidding Theories Govern The Use of the Jump Raise
LEAD: There are two schools of thought about the jump raise of partner's major opening.
Modern tournament players favor the limit treatment, showing the equivalent of about 11 high-card points and inviting game.
This leaves them with a problem with slightly stronger hands and it usually is solved by giving two no-trump or three no-trump a conventional meaning.

NEW SUMMARY: SATURDAY, JANUARY 31, 1987
LEAD: International 3-5


PROVIDENCE SURGES TOWARD ST. JOHN'S
LEAD: Who would have guessed last November that Providence would now be in the thick of the Big EastConference's championship race?


Shamrock Acts To Foil Pickens
LEAD: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation indicated today that its board would announce early next week the steps it will take in an attempt to thwart a $300 million partial tender offer from a group led by T. Boone Pickens.


A Mother Denies Guilt In Adopted Son's Death
LEAD: A woman pleaded not guilty today in connection with the 1965 death of her 3-year-old adopted son, a death that has remained unresolved for more than 21 years.
The boy's natural mother persuaded the authorities to reopen the case last year.


AIR FARE WAR HEIGHTENS AS TICKET CALLS POUR IN
LEAD: Customers seeking to take advantage of new low fares offered by Continental and Eastern Airlines swamped ticket sellers yesterday, and competitors continued to join the latest air fare war.


Moose in Experiment Dies of an Infection
LEAD: Moose No. 1, who wore a radio collar for a wildlife study, died on Wednesday of a bacterial infection, the state's Department of Environmental Conservation reported today.


Enough With, 'Hi! I'm Waldo!'
LEAD: For some, this is the Year of the Rabbit.
For Patrick O'Connell, it is the Year of the Waiter.

Precious Metals Plunge But Then Recover a Bit
LEAD: Precious metals futures plunged sharply yesterday, weakened by a drop in foreign currency values.

LEAD: Gary L. Bauer, the No. 2 official in the Education Department, was named by President Reagan today as his chief adviser on domestic policy development.
Mr.
Bauer, 40 years old, has been Under Secretary of Education since 1985, and before that he was Deputy Under Secretary for planning, budget and evaluation.

TWO AILING SOPRANOS ADD UP TO ONE IN PERFORMANCE OF 'LEMENZA DI TITO'
LEAD: Last night the Metropolitan Opera decided that misery loves company.
When both the lead soprano for ''La Clemenza di Tito'' and her standby cover singer said they could not perform, the Met thought it over, determined that their agonies were different but complementary, and put the two on stage together.


SIGNS OF A MILLER TURNAROUND
LEAD: After five disappointing years, the Miller Brewing Company is at last seeing signs of a broad turnaround, but the improvement, however welcome, is not shared by its Miller High Life label, which seems destined to continue its long decline.


David Buechner Recital
LEAD: The pianist David Buechner will play works by Beethoven, Schubert, Josef Suk and Stravinsky and the revised version of Richard Danielpour's ''Psalms for Piano'' in a recital at Alice Tully Hall at 8 P.M. tomorrow.
Tickets are $10; information: 362-1911.


HONDA PURCHASES A CRAY COMPUTER
LEAD: The Honda Motor Company has bought a supercomputer from Cray Research Inc. for $7 million, the seventh Japanese company to do so.
These high-speed computers, capable of extraordinarily complex calculations, have been the focus of trade talks this week between the United States and Japan.
Because they are so expensive, even a few sales may help trim Japan's trade surplus with the United States.


Rating The 1987 Autos
LEAD: One of the first acts of the new Reagan Administration in 1981 was to order the discontinuation of a free publication called ''The Car Book,'' which first appeared when Jimmy Carter was President.


Penn State Team To Meet Reagan
LEAD: Penn State's football team will celebrate its national title at the White House with President Reagan on Monday.


'THERE'S ALWAYS NEXT TIME'
LEAD: At rush hour Thursday night, in his neighborhood in the South Bronx, Felix Rodriguez boarded the No. 6 train on the Lexington Avenue line and rode to work.

Jewish Music
LEAD: The American Society for Jewish Music is to present the pianist David Holzman and the cantor David Lefkowitz in a free concert of Jewish music at 3 P.M. tomorrow at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue.
The program includes works by Mendelssohn, Bloch, Wolpe, Matthew Greenbaum, Lazar Weiner and others.


BROADCASTERS ATTACK LICENSE LAW
LEAD: The nation's broadcasters, seeking to secure their hold on their licenses, are lobbying Congress to eliminate a law that requires the F.C.C. to hold hearings when their license renewals are challenged.

Legal Foundation Troubles
LEAD: Dan Burt, president of the the Capital Legal Foundation, has turned in his resignation amid indications that support for such conservative legal foundations is flagging.


PRICES PAID TO FARMERS DOWN 1.7%
LEAD: Prices farmers get for raw products in January dropped an average of 1.7 percent, beginning the new year 4 percent below January 1986, the Agriculture Department said today.


RATINGS ON DEBT FOR ENRON CUT
LEAD: The rating on about $4 billion of outstanding debt issued by the Enron Corporation and its Houston Natural Gas subsidiary was lowered by Moody's Investors Service yesterday, to a high speculative grade level from a low investment grade.
The rating service cited expectations that neither the company's cash flow nor capital structure would soon improve substantially.

LEAD: West German officials were locked in a struggle today over what to do with about 3,000 tons of radioactive powdered milk, apparently a legacy of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster.

Mr.

Simms Scores a Triumph Of the Human Spirit
LEAD: To the Editor:


Doings About Ribbons
LEAD: Concerned over a cascade of unauthorized disclosures from closed hearings, the Senate Intelligence Committee recently adopted a rule that no Senator could take his notes from the hearing room.
That created the problem of how to make the notes secure between meetings, said David L. Boren of Oklahoma, the chairman.


O'CONNOR EULOGIZES NUN SLAIN AT SHELTER IN BRONX
LEAD: As snow fell yesterday outside St.
Pius V Roman Catholic Church in the South Bronx, the nave was lighted with candles and filled with voices in prayer at a funeral mass for a 65-year-old nun stabbed last Monday.


Gunman Held After Standoff
LEAD: State police officers forced their way into a house where a man armed with a shotgun barricaded himself for more than five hours, subduing the man without injury, the authorities said.
The standoff began at around 5 A.M. after the suspect, Andrew Marcaurel, 31 years old, of Plainfield, had a fight with a woman described as his girlfriend, the state police said.


IN NEW TROVE OF NOTES, THE HUMOR OF F.D.R.
LEAD: A series of jocular notes written by President Franklin D. Roosevelt during Cabinet meetings has just been presented to the Franklin D. Roosevelt Library here.


Senator Urges Regan to Quit
LEAD: Senator David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, called on the White House chief of staff, Donald T. Regan, to resign in the wake of the panel's report on the Iran-contra affair. ''He is the wrong chief of staff for this President at this time,'' Senator Boren said.

QUINN CAN'T COACH UNTIL '90-91 SEASON
LEAD: John Zeigler, the president of the National Hockey League, has banned Pat Quinn, the former Los Angeles Kings coach, from coaching in the N.H.L. until the 1990-91 season, the league said today.
Ziegler also fined the Vancouver Canucks and the Kings a total of $440,000, and barred Quinn from all league activities until after the annual N.H.L.


LTV POSTS BIG DEFICIT IN QUARTER
LEAD: The LTV Corporation, despite rising profits from its steel operations, said yesterday that it lost $453.4 million in the fourth quarter because of a newly reported $600 million charge related to anticipated creditor lawsuits.

PRIVATE AMBULANCES: WHEN TO USE THEM
LEAD: They come screeching through the streets, sirens wailing and lights flashing, grim symbols of life-or-death emergencies.
New York's best-known ambulances are those operated by the city's Emergency Medical Services, which respond to emergencies and can be summoned by telephoning 911.
The city's approximately 125 ambulances answer about 720,000 emergency calls a year.

SEAL SURGERY
LEAD: Doctors in Buffalo removing a cataract from the eye of Sandy, a performing harbor seal.
The rare operation was performed to try to save her career at the Niagara Falls Aquarium.
She had cataracts in both eyes, but only one was removed to avoid complications from anesthesia.
The outcome of the operation will not be known for a few days.


CORRECTION
LEAD: An article on Tuesday about AIDS testing misstated a policy of the New York State Health Department.
It is the New York City Health Department's testing program - not the state's - that offers confidential notification to the sexual partners of people who test positive for the AIDS virus.


Herbert Menzel Dies at 66; N.Y.U. Sociology Professor
LEAD: Herbert Menzel, a sociology professor at New York University, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 66 years old.

COGHLAN SETS MARK BY TAKING 7TH WANAMAKER MILE
LEAD: Forget the shinbones that kept getting fractured, and forget the dog that bit him five times and helped break his left hand, and forget the diet that almost ruined him.
Forget all the bad things that sidelined him so often.
Eamonn Coghlan is back.
Last night, the 34-year-old Irishman won the most glamorous race of indoor track, the Wanamaker Mile, in the most glamorous of indoor meets, the 80th annual Wanamaker Millrose Games in Madison Square Garden.

Phillip J. DiNatale, 67, Dies; Led Boston Strangler Inquiry
LEAD: Phillip J. DiNatale, the chief investigator in the Boston Strangler case, died Sunday at the home of a daughter here.
He was 67 years old.
Mr.
DiNatale was a Boston detective in 1963 when he was assigned to head the investigation of the killings of 13 women in the Boston area from 1962 to 1964.

GARTNER FRUSTRATES ISLANDERS AND SMITH
LEAD: Another tightly-wrought game, another tie, a trio of overtime sessions without a loss.
For the time being, continuity has become more important to the Islanders than any other asset, more important, even, than winning.


Fitting Setting for Fitting Choice
LEAD: The weather at Aqueduct yesterday was reportedly vintage Ozone Park in January: cold, rainy and dreary as the mist crept in from Jamaica Bay.
Amid the inclement surroundings, Lady's Secret was named the Horse of the Year for 1986.
The verdict was no surprise.
It had been widely expected and was ringingly confirmed as the gray daughter of Secretariat received 172 of the 228 votes from racing officials and journalists.

BOMB KILLS 2 ON BUS IN NORTHERN SPAIN
LEAD: A remote-controlled bomb blew up a military bus in the northern city of Zaragoza today, killing 2 people and wounding 41 others, the police said.


Man Slain in Dispute Over a Parking Space
LEAD: An altercation over a parking space in the Bronx last night left an accused assailant dead at the scene and an off-duty Transit Authority Police sergeant being treated in the hospital for head wounds, the police reported.


TAKEOVER BY SUCHARD
LEAD: The Swiss food company Jacobs Suchard has won a takeover battle with its Swiss rival, Nestle S.A., for control of Belgium's leading chocolate maker, Cote d'Or.
The Belgian company's board announced after a long meeting Thursday that it had accepted a takeover bid from Jacobs Suchard in preference to a later offer from Nestle.


McDonnell Net Declines 2.3%
LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that its fourth-quarter profit slipped 2.3 percent because of the higher costs of producing and developing two lines of airplanes and a higher effective tax rate.


ARTS CONCERN AIDS APPEAL FOR NEEDIEST
LEAD: Solstice Productions Inc., a not-for-profit organization in Manhattan producing dance, theater and music, sent $200 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
Guests at the organization's annual Winter Solstice Celebration each made a contribution to the fund.

Bronx Arts Ensemble
LEAD: The Bronx Arts Ensemble will offer a program of works by Mozart, Schubert and Wallingford Riegger tomorrow afternoon at 2 at the Riverdale Y.M.-Y.W.H.A., 5265 Arlington Avenue, the Bronx.
Mark Peskanov is to be the violin soloist in Mozart's Sonata in B flat (K. 378) for violin and piano.
Tickets are $8; $5 for students and the elderly.

LEAD: Publishers and scholars, traditionally opposed to legal restraints on publishing, have not rallied to the defense of Random House, which was prohibited by a Federal appellate court on Thursday from publishing an unauthorized biography of J. D. Salinger.

LUCE FUND OFFERING AID TO SCHOLARLY WOMEN
LEAD: Clare Boothe Luce, who never attended college but went on to become a playwright, Congresswoman and United States Ambassador to Italy, will have a new university professorship program named in her honor.


U.N. Won't Ask Court To Bar ABC's 'Amerika'
LEAD: The United Nations has decided not to take legal action to try to block the broadcast of the ABC mini-series ''Amerika,'' according to Theodore C. Sorensen.

OFFER SEEN FOR ICHAN'S USX STAKE
LEAD: Carl C. Icahn has turned down an offer from a foreign investor willing to pay a premium for the large Icahn holding in the USX Corporation, Wall Street sources said yesterday.


A'S ACQUIRE CEY
LEAD: The Oakland A's traded Luis Quinones, an infielder, to the Chicago Cubs for the right-handed-hitting Ron Cey, who they said would share the designated hitter's duties with Reggie Jackson, who bats left-handed.
Cey played third base the last four seasons for the Cubs after spending 10 years with the Los Angeles Dodgers.


NORTEK-REXHAM
LEAD: Nortek Inc. has purchased a 7.8 percent stake in the Rexham Corporation and said it might seek control of the Charlotte, N.C., packaging products concern.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Nortek said it had bought the Rexham shares ''with a view to acquiring a significant equity interest'' in the company, but added that any possible acquisition of the company was ''subject to future developments.

LEAD: Hidden in the service apartment of a friend's large mansion near here, awaiting his moment to burst back onto the political scene, the rebel air force general spoke bitterly of President Leon Febres Cordero as a ''tyrant'' and ''dictator'' who should resign to forestall ''a civil war'' here.

Guilt and Mr. Meese
LEAD: Last February the Justice Department's Office of Legal Policy sent a 128-page report to Attorney General Edwin Meese urging him to ask the Supreme Court to overturn its 1966 Miranda v.
Arizona decision.
That's the famous decision that made confessions inadmissible as evidence unless an accused person has been warned by police of the right to silence and to a lawyer, and waived it.

CITES BUDGET GAP
LEAD: President Reagan today vetoed a bill aimed at cleaning up the nation's water at a cost of up to $20 billion, but he acknowledged that Congress would override his veto and enact the measure into law next week.


HOTEL UNION LEADER ARRESTED AFTER GUN IS FOUND IN LUGGAGE
LEAD: Edward T. Hanley, the general president of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union, has been arrested for carrying a stolen gun in his carry-on luggage that was discovered when he tried to board an airplane, the police say.

CHRYSLER WILL PAY $295,000 FINE FOR VIOLATIONS ON INJURY RECORDS
LEAD: In the largest penalty ever imposed for violations of job safety rules, the Chrysler Corporation has agreed to pay a $295,000 fine for failing to keep accurate records about employee injuries, the Labor Department announced today.


Wardair-Airbus
LEAD: Wardair International, the Canadian airline, signed a contract worth more than $670 million for 12 European Airbus A310-300 aircraft and spare parts, Airbus Industrie announced.
It was the first Canadian order for new aircraft in the Airbus range.
Wardair currently operates three second-hand Airbus A300's.

DON KING'S ROLE CITED
LEAD: Trevor Berbick, the former World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, received at most $700,000 of his $2.1 million purse to fight Mike Tyson, with $1 million of the money going to the promoter Don King and his son, Carl, Nevada boxing regulators say.
Half of the $1 million went to pay advances improperly made to Berbick by King, and the other $500,000 went to Carl King as Berbick's manager, members of the Nevada State Athletic Commission said.


FISHER GUIDE
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said its Fisher Guide division plans a gradual phase-out of operations at the Detroit Fort Street plant to be completed by the end of the 1989 model year.
It said efforts would be made to cushion the impact of the closing on the plant's 2,057 employees.
The 1.5-million-square-foot plant builds a variety of car parts, such as foam arm rests, door trim panels and instrument panels.

WHITE HOUSE SAYS REPORT BACKS ITS ACCOUNT
LEAD: The White House conceded today that the President's Iranian initiative ''could be interpreted as a trade of arms for hostates,'' but it again insisted that that had not been the President's intention.


FRENCH SAY BARBIE'S AILMENT ISN'T EXPECTED TO DELAY TRIAL
LEAD: The hospitalization of Klaus Barbie, the former Gestapo chief in Lyons, is not expected to further delay his long-awaited trial, French judicial officials said today.


REAGAN NOMINATES A TOP ADVISER TO BE AMBASSADOR TO SOVIET UNION
LEAD: President Reagan today nominated Jack F. Matlock Jr., one of his top advisers on East-West affairs and a Russian-language scholar, to be Ambassador to the Soviet Union.


ARMY OPENING A NEW CENTER FOR DETECTION OF WAR POISON
LEAD: The Army today unveiled a new training center designed to teach all branches of the military how to detect chemical poisons in combat.

RIVER DISPUTE DIVIDES TICONDEROGA
LEAD: Like many one-company towns, Ticonderoga is not a place where corporate decisions are often debated.
When the major employer here, International Paper, sent clouds of acrid smoke drifting from its old mill, residents used to sniff the air unperturbed and proclaim it ''the sweet smell of prosperity.

The Stewart Case Again. And Again?
LEAD: An impressive report concludes that New York City's Transit Police acted excessively when they arrested Michael Stewart for graffiti-marking in 1983.
It finds that the arresting officer lied and that management failed to investigate appropriately.
Robert Kiley, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority chairman, calls these conclusions ''deeply disturbing.

GOING OUT GUIDE
LEAD: NEW NEIGHBORS IN THE BRONX The news from the Bronx is that there has not only been a modest influx of new residents, but also that they have moved into spanking new housing.
New developments have unfolded at the Bronx Zoo, Bronx River Parkway and Fordham Road, for this latest bloc of Bronxites: eight slender-tailed meerkats.

6 Banks Shut In 4 States
LEAD: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, whose chairman said last week that a ''sizable increase'' in bank failures was likely this year, said today that it had closed six banks in four states.

LICENSING PLANNED FOR NEW AIDS DRUG
LEAD: Federal officials say the Government intends to grant an exclusive manufacturing license for an experimental drug to treat AIDS victims to Hoffmann-La Roche Inc. of Nutley, N.J.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: Skiing  Hess Clinches Two Golds: In Crans-Montana, Switzerland, yesterday, Erika Hess of Switzerland clinched her third consecutive gold medal in the combined and record fifth gold over all with a controlled but swift downhill run at the world Alpine championships.
The 24-year-old Hess, competing in her fourth world championship, finished third in the downhill and, with her third place in Thursday's slalom portion, retained the title.

BRIEFS
LEAD: Alleghany Corp. has been given approval by the Federal Trade Commission to buy a Los Angeles-based title insurance company from Safeco Corp.

LEAD: The Economy


WINTER REFUGE
LEAD: A couple relaxed in a shelter at Prospect Park in Brooklyn as rain and snow drenched the region yesterday.
Today should be partly cloudy and windy, with the temperature reaching into the mid-30's. (NYT/Keith Meyers)

UNITED TO CUT A THIRD OF ITS CORPORATE STAFF
LEAD: United Airlines said today that it would lay off 1,016 employees, or nearly one-third of its corporate staff, beginning next week.


MEAD IS NAMED INTERIM LEADER OF UTILITY PANEL
LEAD: Two weeks after the retirement party for Anne F. Mead, a member of the state's Public Service Commission, Governor Cuomo today announced that he had appointed her the commission's interim chairman.


HOLIDAY CORP.
LEAD: The Holiday Corporation said it had received commitments from three banks for $1.23 billion in financing for its previously announced recapitaliztion plan.
The company also said it had set Feb. 27 as the date for the special meeting at which stockholders will vote on the plan.
Under the plan, Holiday shareholders will receive a $65-a-share dividend and retain ownership of about 90 percent of the company's stock to be outstanding.

LABOR DEPARTMENT TO CLOSE 16 OFFICES
LEAD: The State Labor Commissioner, Lillian Roberts, announced plans yesterday to close 16 local job service and unemployment offices across the state because of budget cuts, and she said more such closings could follow.
